Diamonds are forever -- but so is pigment etched into skin. Once the province of sailors and bikers, the tattoo has recently been elevated to the runway (Louis Vuitton and Yves Saint Laurent) and to the day's supermodels, like Catherine McNeil. Here, four artists suggest a few indelible additions to your jewelry box. JACOB BROWN AND DOMINIC SIDHU

DRECHSLER--Guenther Karl Passed away peacefully after a long illness in Berlin, Germany, on November 21, 2010. Known affectionately as "Boni", he was born in Schweidnitz, Germany, on January 23, 1930. He studied economics at Humboldt Universitaet, Berlin, and Technische Universitaet, Berlin. Mr. Drechsler joined Thyssen Stahlunion Corporation in New York in 1961 and soon thereafter was appointed its President. He also headed its sister company Marathon Specialty Steels. The company's name changed to Thyssen Steel Corporation and subsequently to Thyssen Inc., and Mr. Drechsler served as President and Chief Executive Officer. He led Thyssen's growth in America from a steel importer and mill representative to an international trader in steel, coal and scrap, and a US based distributor of steel. Mr. Drechsler retired from Thyssen in 1993. During his tenure at Thyssen, Mr. Drechsler was Chairman of the German American Chamber of Commerce from 1974 to 1981, and a leading representative of German industry in the US for many years. He also served on the board of The AXA Group. Guenther was an avid horseback rider and a member of the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Fairfield, CT. He loved social interaction and took great pleasure in bringing people together. Guenther launched and nurtured the careers of many associates. He will be dearly missed. Guenther is survived by his children, Ana Katharina and Christian, Christian's wife Karen, and his grandson Jack Guenther all of New York, NY, his beloved wife Gloria Drechsler, and his stepson Rolf Weischman both of Berlin, Germany.

SIMS--Franklin S.,on December 2, 2010. Beloved husband of June (nee Diedrich). Loving father of David (Lisa), Matthew and Lynne. Adored grandfather of Franklyn and Keira. Graduate of Fordham University, Class of 1961. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue, New York City, Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm. There will be a Funeral Service at the funeral home starting at 7:30pm.

An article on Nov. 28 aboutan online merchant who har-assed customers in the hope ofimproving his site's rank inGoogle search results referredincorrectly to a response fromGoogle. An e-mail from a com-pany spokesman was sent toThe New York Times but, be-cause of a technical problem atThe Times, was not delivered.It was not the case that Goo-gle's e-mail ''never arrived.''

Complete the following sentence by the photographer Walker Evans: ''All my life I've wanted nothing so much as. . . .'' Freedom to pursue my work? The respect of my peers? A retrospective at MoMA? It's actually none of the above (all of which he either already had or would eventually have). No, what Evans wanted was leisure. And he had it -- this was in 1947 -- in the form of an unbelievably cushy job at Fortune magazine. We often hear of artists going into decline, but by the 1960s, Evans seemed to have fallen into terminal recline.

GREENBAUM--Frieda. We mourn the loss of Frieda K. Greenbaum who died in her home on December 4th at the age of 101. Frieda was loved by virtually all who knew her. But especially by her sister Ceci Hockman, her daughters Ada Albert, Sylvia Greenbaum and Sandy Jacobson. Her sons-in-law, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and nieces and nephew. Frieda was uncommonly wise and insightful, always welcoming, gracious, and ready to offer a helping hand and an empathic ear. Her life had a powerful impact on those closest to her and each of us was enriched and inspired by her to be a better, kinder, more loving person. She is predeceased by two brothers, three sisters and her husband Paul. Service Monday at "The Riverside" 76th St. Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be sent to UNICEF.
Manhattan

Residents of Boulder, Colo., the often-kooky Rocky Mountain town of about 95,000, think nothing of day-tripping up the face of a nearby fourteener (climbers' parlance for a 14,000-foot-and-up peak). Perhaps that's why, once they've descended back to civilization, traveling a few miles uptown to sample the city's latest shops and restaurants doesn't seem like much of a hike. But it's a trip worth taking. As the downtown area and its Pearl Street Mall have grown crowded with national chains, upstart small businesses are flocking to North Boulder, or NoBo, giving rise to a neighborhood newly worthy of a stroll -- no trekking poles necessary. ROSE MAURA LORRE

When Reeve Carney was a child, his parents would suggest career options to him while he slept. ''I didn't know this till much later,'' says Carney, who claims to have decided to be an entertainer at 8, ''but they told me that they used to whisper 'doctor' and 'lawyer' in my ear because they were both musicians and wanted me to have an easier life than they had.'' They worried needlessly. A versatile performer whose great-uncle was Art Carney of ''The Honeymooners,'' Carney, 27, has made a respectable living, first as a child singer and actor, and more recently as the frontman for the Los Angeles-based rock band Carney. This month, he appears as prince Ferdinand in Julie Taymor's screen adaptation of ''The Tempest,'' opposite Helen Mirren. And next month he appears on Broadway as Peter Parker and his superhero alter ego in the musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' which is also being directed by Taymor and has been scored by Bono and the Edge of U2.

DORFMAN--Harold H.,87, Lt. Col. Retired U.S. Air Force, died December 3, 2010 at Montefiore Hospital in The Bronx, New York. He flew 28 missions over Germany during WWII and was awarded numerous medals including the Distinguished Flying Cross. He was a pioneer in the field of microfilm and worked for the City of New York and as a consultant in China, Egypt, Brazil and Poland. He is survived by Pearl, his wife of 63 years, his daughter Carol Pressman, and his granddaughter Sarah Warren. Services will be held 11am Monday December 6 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York (516) 487-9600 (Opposite LIRR).

Suddenly everyone is talking about Thomas Tait, 23, the London-based Central Saint Martins graduate who in October, with barely two collections to his name, won the first-ever Dorchester Collection Fashion Prize. The Montreal-born Tait has yet to sell a single dress outside of private orders (some accessories are available through a project with Asos.com), but he says the prize money will enable him to begin proper production and retail sales. However, it's his new friends, famous for their taste, who are likely to move his business along the most. Giles Deacon, Daphne Guinness, Stephen Jones and others selected him for the award; another judge, Manolo Blahnik, has been widely quoted gushing over Tait's ''incredible couture mind.''

LASKIN--Meyer. In grief and love, the Laskin family remembers Meyer Laskin, who died on November 30, 2010, at the age of 84. A child of immigrants, Meyer lived out an American success story, forging an impressive business career. Associates valued his intelligence and integrity. To friends, he embodied the ideal of an ethical, caring life. For his wife of 63 years, Leona, he was a lifetime companion in all the adventures of marriage. For his four sons Robert, Daniel, David, and Jonathan he was the Dad who read to them, coached their teams, skied and hiked with them, imparted a love of the Adirondack Mountains, gave them wise advise, and showed them, by example, that success in life is measured by morals, not money. His seven grandchildren discovered, with their Papa, the tang of a mountain morning, the glory of a summit view, and the meaning of the word mensch. The family asks that memorial contributions be made to the Adirondack Chapter of the Nature Conservancy, Adirondack Land Trust, PO Box 65, Keene Valley, NY 12943; or to Penn Hospice at Rittenhouse, 1800 Lombard Street, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19146.

It was more than 300 years after Spanish settlers brought cuttings from Chile's Central Valley, not ''just a few years later.''

The Peninsula hotels are known for their upscale perks, like the fleet of Rolls-Royces that its Hong Kong flagship uses to ferry its guests to meetings and to the airport. In New York and Chicago, however, the hotel has opted for an amenity that's more sporty than glam: chauffeur-driven Mini Coopers. The cars are available for up to three hours a day to guests who book a suite at either hotel. Passengers can follow city tours that are stored on iPhones or iPads in the cars, or they can simply tell drivers where they want to go.

Funchess, the Light Asylum frontwoman, drums and sings, pogoing around in a mix of black leather and new-wave neon, like a punker, harder-edged Grace Jones possessed by the sensibilities of Ian Curtis. Her voice has appeared on tracks by bands like Telepathe and TV on the Radio, but it's with this latest project (a duo, with Bruno Coviello on synth) that she has come into her own. IF you walk along East Seventh Street in the East Village, you're likely to hear Polish, Russian, Spanish, Ukrainian, German, maybe some Yiddish, and even English spoken in an array of regional accents. But the six-block stretch from Cooper Square to Avenue D is also like a college town, full of creatively dressed young people, many of them art students. Competing allegiances -- urban renewal versus civic pride, bohemian protest versus entrepreneurial spirit -- manage to live peacefully on a small campus. On a recent morning, the scene at Abraço espresso bar was a perfect illustration: A lanky Italian with one leg of his corduroys tucked into an argyle sock leaned against a tall, skinny wooden table on the sidewalk, sipping from a demitasse and reading The Financial Times. Inside, a rumpled young man lingered in the open window, wearing homesickness for Brazil on his comely face. At his elbow, a middle-aged woman in matte red lipstick and a hand-knit snood was eyeing the cured olive cookies and chatting about the charms of her East Village neighborhood.

Susan Philipsz, a 45-year-old Scottish artist, has won this year's Turner Prize, The Guardian reported. She is the first artist to win for a sound work: she recorded herself singing a 16th-century Scottish lament under three bridges in Glasgow. The prize, established in 1984 by the Tate in London, goes to a British artist under age 50 and comes with about $39,000. Ms. Philipsz beat out Dexter Dalwood, known for his contemporary take on traditional history paintings; Angela de la Cruz, a painter and sculptor nominated for her installation "After," at the Camden Arts Center in London; and the Otolith Group, consisting of the London artists Anjalika Sagar and Kodwo Eshun, who make documentary films for a series of exhibitions called "A Long Time Between Suns." (Finalists each receive about $7,800.) Ms. Philipsz is only the fourth woman to win the award, after Rachel Whiteread, Gillian Wearing and Tomma Abts. In a statement the judges said they "admired the way in which her work provokes both intellectual and instinctive responses and reflects a series of decisions about the relationship between sound and sight" and that she "draws on the immersive properties of sound and uses her own voice to create powerful sculptural experiences."

In "Desert Flower," the catwalk fixture and "Gifted" subject Liya Kebede stands in for the Somali-born model Waris Dirie. A victim of female genital mutilation, the 13-year-old Dirie escaped an arranged marriage in Somalia and made it to London in the 1980s, where she worked at McDonald's before being discovered by Terence Donovan. Kebede, 32, grew up in Ethiopia and was discovered by a filmmaker at the French lycée in Addis Ababa. In a recent interview, she was quick to draw a distinction between her own life story and Dirie's. "On the surface we have parallels," she said, before explaining how different life seemed in Djibouti, a neighboring country to Somalia, where parts of the film were shot. "This is where she came from. There's nothing there, there's no water, there's nothing. And being in that environment was a new thing for me, and then trying to understand how you go from that to become this incredible woman - [Dirie] was never really a victim of her circumstances."

When is a dress not just a dress? Certainly when it's part of "Aware: Art Fashion Identity," currently on view at London's Royal Academy. The third in a series of rapidly organized exhibitions on contemporary culture, "Aware" takes as its subject the mutable nature of sartorial identity. "It's really about how we use clothing to say who we are, what tribe we belong to and what we believe in," says Kathleen Soriano, the museum's director of exhibitions, who was considering the proposal for the show, put forward by the artist Lucy Orta and the independent curator Gabi Scardi, when news reached her of the death of Alexander McQueen. "When he died, it brought into focus the enormous contribution that he'd made, not just to fashion but also to art, and how close the two can be," Soriano explained.

"Toy Story 3," "How to Train Your Dragon," "Tangled," "The Illusionist," and "Despicable Me" received nods for best animated feature. The list of finalists, from the International Animated Film Society, is sure to have some overlap with the little gold man race, especially this year, when the Academy can nominate only three films (out of 15 submitted for eligibility). "Toy Story 3" is a lock, of course, but may also wind up in the best picture category, as "Up" did last year. "Tangled" performed well at the box office against stiff competition, which could help its chances. "How to Train Your Dragon" might be a good bet for the final spot, but don't double-down yet. Last year, Annie voters gave a nomination to the little-seen Irish film "The Secret of Kells," and it went on to secure an Oscar slot. Can the same happen for the "Despicable Me" or "The Illusionist" this year? The Bagger will pay close attention to the cartoon winnings to find out.

In a confluence of financial interests and theater availability on Broadway, two commercially popular rock 'n roll musicals - the metal/hair band love story "Rock of Ages" and the Beatles tribute show "Rain" - will change theaters in early 2011 to continue their runs, the producers of both shows said on Monday. The moves, which are relatively rare for Broadway, will allow "Rain" to stay open, while "Rock of Ages" will be able to lower its weekly running costs (and potentially increase its profit margin) by running in a smaller Broadway house.

Let's imagine an end-of-life scenario. Your ailing and elderly parent has been admitted to the hospital yet again with a condition she's not going to recover from. The medical team asks what they should do if her heart stops. She's always said she didn't want to die "hooked up to a bunch of machines," but you've never really explored the details. Besides, though she has a terminal illness, no one has yet mentioned the d-word.

For her latest book club selection Oprah Winfrey decided to go "old school," she said on Monday. Ms. Winfrey has selected two Charles Dickens novels, "A Tale of Two Cities" and "Great Expectations," both announced on her show on Monday, both books that she had never read before. They could be two of the last selected for the Oprah Book Club before her show goes off the air next year.

If you missed the season finale of "Boardwalk Empire'' on Sunday night, chances are you missed the whole season, in which case you are hereby advised to sequester yourself for part of the holiday season and catch up via HBO on Demand. The visual splendors of "Boardwalk Empire'' have been exhaustively noted -- the cinematography; the grand and meticulously constructed sets; the detailed Prohibition-era suits made by Martin Greenfield Clothiers, the renowned Brooklyn tailoring outfit; and so on -- but the series has also easily delivered the best television performances of the year. Steve Buscemi (as the Republican Party boss Nucky Thompson), Kelly Macdonald (as a young Irish widow, Margaret Schroeder, whose moral relativism is leaning in a Carmela Soprano direction) and Michael Pitt (as the Oedipally afflicted young gangster Jimmy Darmody) all merit recognition beyond what the devalued Emmys have to offer.

Heritage Auctions, better known for selling collectible coins and vintage comic books, is exploring new and perhaps more feminine ground. This month the company introduces its latest category: luxury accessories.

We filed out of the Spectrum in Philadelphia that warm December night, my high school buddies Jim, John, Glenn and I, exhausted and exhilarated, echoes of "Santa Claus is Coming to Town" ringing in our heads. Bruce Springsteen had rocked us righteously, and all was right with the world.
A group of college friends reunites for soul-searching and navel gazing in “The Extraordinary Ordinary.”

It's either a terrible day or a great day to be the creator of a cult cable-television series. FX announced on Monday that it would not be ordering a second season of "Terriers," its series about a former detective (played by Donal Logue) and an ex-burglar (Michael Raymond-James) trying to make it as private investigators in San Diego. The show, created by Ted Griffin, the "Ocean's Eleven" screenwriter, and whose producers included Shawn Ryan, the creator of "The Shield," was well reviewed at its debut in September. Ginia Bellafante in The New York Times called it "a welcome love child, one we are eager to embrace rather than put up for adoption." But it never seemed to reach a critical mass of viewers, and while we don't want to say its title was to blame, we will point out that Mr. Ryan recently renamed another new cop drama he is preparing, changing its title from "Ride-Along" to "The Chicago Code."

Anyone who's ever taken the elevator at the Standard Hotel in New York will be familiar with the work of the artist Marco Brambilla. His kaleidoscopic video piece "Civilization" - a film collage loosely depicting the journey from purgatory to celestial heights - has been wowing hotel guests since 2009. Following a recent collaboration with Kanye West for his video "Power," Brambilla has now taken his manic motion picture collageing to a new level and has produced arguably the first 3D video art piece ever. "Evolution (Megaplex)" is a three-minute-long three-dimensional firework of images, scenes, and clips culled from an archive of over a thousand movies, ranging from Hollywood blockbusters ("E.T.", "Mad Max", "Star Wars") to cult classics ("Idiocracy," "Zardoz," "Salo") - all set to a score of a bombastic rendition of Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet." During the poolside screening at the Standard Spa Hotel in Miami last Friday, guests including Jeffrey Deitch, Bob Colacello, Jefferson Hack, Michael Stipe and Cecilia Dean sported especially designed Armani Exchange 3-D glasses and turned the event into a quiz of sorts, trying to identify different bits and pieces. ("Was that Klaus Kinski in a loincloth, or a nubile Sting? And what movie was the woman riding a giant phallus taken from?")

As you may have noticed, we've been writing about Groupon a lot lately. MP Mueller did a post on the experiences of a high-end restaurant in Austin, Tex., and offered some tips. The sculptor Hany Armanious will represent Australia at next year's Venice Biennale. A native Egyptian who lives and works in Sydney, Armanious is known for his methodically messy installations that game the eye as well as the mind with circular materialities and metaphors. His work (shown above) at the Foxy Production booth was one of the standouts in the Art Positions section of the Art Basel Miami Beach fair, for which galleries present a statement exhibition made by one artist.
Normally, when one company offers to buy another, shares in the would-be acquirer fall while those in its target rise. That was not the case with the Borders Group and Barnes & Noble on Monday.

Viewers going through withdrawal as time runs out on Sunil, the patient on HBO's "In Treatment" played by the Indian actor Irrfan Khan, can breathe easier knowing there will eventually be an end to their pain. (Sunil's final session will be shown on Monday night at 9:30.) Mr. Khan, whose interpretation of a grieving Bengali widower won critical accolades, has just been cast in two high-profile film projects: Marc Webb's reboot of the "Spider-Man" franchise and Ang Lee's adaptation of "Life of Pi." Both films are to be released in 2012.

To the surprise of absolutely no one, "The King's Speech," an early Oscar favorite, swept the British Independent Film Awards last night, winning best film, best screenplay and a host of acting awards (honors went to Colin Firth, Helena Bonham Carter and Geoffrey Rush). A film about a monarch who has trouble communicating, "The King's Speech" may be the most British movie ever made. And Mr. Firth, who plays the titular character, a king overcoming a stutter, may be the most British performer.

ORLANDO, Fla. - Now that Brian Cashman has rappelled down a 21-floor building and lived to talk about it, a dangerous precedent has been set. Imagine him descending the exterior of the Walt Disney World Dolphin Hotel - a mere 17 stories - and swooping into the room of Darek Braunecker, the agent for Cliff Lee, to discuss a contract. Of course, such unconventional (and fanciful) tactics will not lure Lee to the Bronx - and away from the hovering Texas Rangers; money, and lots of it, will.

Though ArtsBeat has previously devoted bandwidth to the friendly-ish sibling rivalry between "The Simpsons" and Fox News, no story is truly complete until it's been commented on by Next Media, the Hong Kong- and Taiwan-based media company that brings to life American pop-culture and celebrity stories in comical (and occasionally baffling) computer-generated cartoons. In this latest effort, Next Media recaps the recent feud between the two warring arms of the News Corporation empire, using 3-D renderings of Bill O'Reilly, Rupert Murdoch and what it thinks the "Simpsons" writers look like. Wolfgang Munchau suggests that we need a German word -- ueberfordert -- to describe the condition of Europe right now. I think he's wrong about the lack of an English equivalent; "overmatched" seems fairly close. European leaders, and the European system, just seem not up to dealing with the crisis.

In an essay co-authored with Spencer Abraham, energy secretary under President George W. Bush, Fred Upton of Michigan, the leading Republican candidate for chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee in next year's Congress, calls for opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil drilling, a massive increase in domestic deepwater oil production and a rapid expansion of nuclear power. Yet "oil and nuclear are not the only energy sources we need more of," the two write. "The current situation demands an 'all of the above' strategy -- diversifying our energy portfolio and pushing development of our own natural resources. That means not just more oil and nuclear, but more coal, natural gas and renewables. Sooner rather than later." [Politico]

In just over a month, South Sudan is scheduled to vote on whether to become an independent nation. But it's no clearer now than it was three years ago that the North will actually allow the referendum to go ahead. There's still considerable anxiety that the North, determined not to lose the three-quarters of the country's oil that lies in the South, will find one means or another to block the vote or deny its legitimacy -- and that the result will be the world's worst war in 2011.

Some lingering awards news to start your week. Late on Friday the International Documentary Association gave "Waste Land" its top honors of the year. The film, Lucy Walker's documentary about how a group of trash pickers in Brazil are transformed by working with the Brazilian artist Vik Muniz, won the best feature award as well as the Pare Lorentz Award. The International Documentary Association, a Los Angeles-based group, last year picked "Anvil! The Story of Anvil," which was snubbed by the Academy, for its highest prize. "Waste Land" did make the Academy's short list of documentary contenders, where it will compete with frontrunners like "Waiting for Superman."

STAMFORD, Conn. - Most of the time, highly anticipated off-season signings are followed by stage-managed stadium news briefings or conference calls with reporters. But the day after reaching a contract agreement with Derek Jeter, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman took a different approach. Surrounded by reporters Sunday night, Cashman sat on a makeshift stage in this city's downtown while sporting red and green tights, a bejeweled Yankees jacket and an elf cap, still catching his breath from rappelling 21 stories down an office tower.

KUALA LUMPUR -- In many countries, university campuses, brimming with youthful enthusiasm and impatience for change, have long served as hotbeds of political activism and training grounds for future leaders. In Malaysia, however, it is illegal for students to join political parties or take part in political campaigns or protests. Students who do so risk expulsion from their university and other penalties, including fines.

Coming to a newsstand most likely not near you: Cosmo Mongolia. Cosmopolitan, which has been helping women all over the world unlock the secrets to better sex, tighter tushes and the enigmatic male psyche for four decades, will begin to sell a Mongolia edition this week.

''Long Story Short,'' the co-median Colin Quinn's satiricalhistory of the world, directed byJerry Seinfeld, has been extend-ed. The show began previews onOct. 22, opened on Nov. 9, and wasoriginally scheduled to close onJan. 8. It will now run at the HelenHayes Theater through Feb. 5.

The television may be on in someone's living room, but are people really watching the show? The Nielsen Company, which measures viewer engagement based on questions about plot and characters, has identified the top new series. People who are watching the shows more closely also watch the commercials more closely. Comedies, like ''Running Wilde,'' above, with Keri Russell and Will Arnett, dominate on the broadcast networks. Dramas are more prominent on cable, which begins its series at different times during the calendar year. SHELLY FREIERMAN

GOLDMAN--Richard. The Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel (SPNI) and the American SPNI mourn the passing of a true friend, Richard Goldman who along with his wife Rhoda, were loyal and generous supporters of environmental protection in Israel. Our sincere condolences to his family.

AHMED SALAMI, one of tens of thousands of fans who attended a pan-Arab soccer tournament in Yemen, which is trying to change its reputation for violence. [A7]

When a sports team loses long enough, fans get restless and soon enough, the coach ends up getting the gate. After all, you can't fire the whole team, right? Unless you work in television. Last week, every single member of the perennially last place ''Early Show'' on CBS was shown the door. Harry Smith and Maggie Rodriguez are out. Even the weatherman, Dave Price, was let go. (Why blame the weatherman for something besides the weather? Did he forget to convert from Celsius?)

GALLAGHER--William G.,of Riverside, CT, died peacefully at his home on December 4, 2010. A graduate of the College of the Holy Cross, Gallagher enjoyed a 45-year career in the municipal bond business. He was a marketing officer at Vance Sanders/Massachusetts Investors Trust, Chemical Bank and MBIA. Gallagher is survived by his wife of 42 years, Elizabeth (Scully); his daughter, Laura Gallagher McLean, of Manhattan; and his son, Gregory, of Brooklyn. Visiting hours will be on Wednesday, 2pm to 4pm, and 6pm to 8 pm, at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich. Funeral Mass on Thursday, 12pm, at St. Catherine of Siena in Riverside. Donations may be made to Iona Preparatory School in New Rochelle or St. Catherine of Siena.

The winter meetings officially begin Monday in Orlando, Fla. But for shock value, it will be hard to top the announcement made there Sunday. The Washington Nationals signed right fielder Jayson Werth to a seven-year, $126 million contract, a staggering deal for a one-time All-Star who turns 32 in May. The announcement came a few days after first baseman Adam Dunn left Washington to sign a four-year, $56 million contract with the Chicago White Sox.

''I would have won a Tony if there had been a category called Hating Other People's Careers While Combining Maker's Mark, Ambien and Pinkberry,'' Jackie Hoffman announced during ''Jackie Five-Oh!,'' her latest caustic cabaret show. She may be gainfully employed six days a week playing Grandma in ''The Addams Family,'' but as Ms. Hoffman's fans know, that doesn't stop her biting the Broadway hand that feeds her. And resentment mixes well with the cocktails in her savagely funny sixth original show at Joe's Pub.

Research In Motion, the company behind the BlackBerry, was once considered the leader in mobile phone technology, creating devices that changed the business world. Yet the company has never won much praise for the design and feel of its phones. It may be hoping that will change with its acquisition of the Astonishing Tribe, an interface and design company, which it announced on the R.I.M. blog last week. David Yach, chief technology officer at R.I.M., boasted of the Astonishing Tribe's design prowess in the blog post, saying the smaller company would help with the design and development of R.I.M.'s smartphones.

After a successful run with his Web sites that cover media, sports, gossip and technology, Dan Abrams, perhaps best known not as an Internet entrepreneur but as an MSNBC personality, is expanding. Mr. Abrams will start three online properties early next year: Mogulite, which will report on the comings and goings of famous business personalities; the Mary Sue, a technology news blog directed at women; and a job postings board intended to compete with Mediabistro.com, a widely read aggregator among media professionals.

HYMAN--Leah Goldstein, died in West Palm Beach, Florida on December 1, 2010, only 19 days before her 99th birthday. She lived a long wonderful life, married for 50 years to the late William Hyman; she was the mother of Judith Hyman Smith and Steven J. Hyman; mother-in-law of Miriam Hyman and Charles Smith; grandmother to Deborah Bergman, Susan Hackett, and Shari C. Hyman; and great-grandmother to Cheryl and Jennifer Hackett and Rebecca and Ari Horwitz. An art lover, docent, and avid bridge player until the end, she will be lovingly remembered by her family and friends. A private burial service will be held in New York.

Four nonprofit groups are trying to attract $25 gifts through text messages this holiday season, an experiment that may increase the popularity of giving via mobile phones among charities. This approach burst onto the scene this year when nonprofits raised tens of millions of dollars through text-to-give programs after the Haitian earthquake. One of its biggest limitations has been the small size of the donations charities could solicit, just $5 or $10.

KRISSEL--Robert A.,76, of Lakeville, CT., died on Saturday, December 4, 2010, at home surrounded by loving family and friends. He was born January 10, 1934. He was married to Janet Carter now deceased and Jenelle Soderquist who survives. Bob graduated from Dartmouth College and was a Captain in the US Air Force. He was CEO of Equitable Bag Co. and served on the Boards of Beth Israel, the National Museum of the American Indian, Sharon Hospital, the Santa Fe Opera (President), and the National Jewish Hospital in Denver. Bob was also a member of the Harmonie Club and the Young Presidents Organization. In addition to his wife Jenelle, he is survived by his children: Kim and her husband Matt Jones, Jim and his wife Jessica, Dina, eight grandchildren and his sister Toni Goodale. The funeral is private and a memorial service will take place at a later time. Donations should be sent to the Salisbury VNA, 30A Salmon Kill Road, Salisbury Ct. 06068.

But the connections finally clicked for a quick conversation with the film industry's man in Havana - one of them, anyway - Sidney Ganis.

A project that began with an iPod Nano and an experimental wristwatch design has quickly exploded online, receiving over $570,000 in financing through Kickstarter, a Web site that helps people find support for projects. The project was created by the Chicago-based design firm Minimal, which wants to take the iPod Nano, Apple's latest tiny iPod, and incorporate it into a wristwatch. Those who pledge $25 to the project will receive a Nano-holding watch kit when it is produced.

The sounds of the lame-duck session of Congress represent more than two parties clashing over power and philosophy. They are also clashing over how to manage the shift from one economic era to another. But unusual as it seems from recent political history, those conflicts may now be leading toward a year-end truce.
For the first time in his N.F.L. career, Peyton Manning has thrown 11 interceptions in a three-game span. He has thrown four interceptions in back-to-back games, another first.

ROSEN--Milton. With profound sorrow, the family of Milton (Mannie) Rosen announces his death on December 4, 2010 at the age of 91. Mannie is survived by his second wife Ruth, their combined family including seven children, their spouses, as well as nineteen grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. He loved his family deeply and will be greatly missed. A self-made man, Mannie was extraordinarily successful in his real estate business where he was known for his intelligence and strong sense of integrity. He was a leader in the Labor Zionist movement and was extremely generous in giving to charitable causes both here and in Israel. Memorial contributions in his honor may be made to the charity of one's choice.

Six months or so ago, Jeffrey Ruhalter was a butcher in a deep funk, grappling with a sinking family business that dated back to his German great-great-grandfather in 1870. Jeffrey's Meat Market is, he says, the last original tenant at the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, opened by his grandfather in 1940. The dynamics of change, along with the global economic downturn, had blindsided him. In the past year, nine restaurants he supplied with meat closed, one right after the other. ''How do you collect from restaurants that have closed?'' Mr. Ruhalter asked. He was in the process of laying off three of his seven butchers.

LOS ANGELES -- With the opening this Friday of ''The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader,'' comes a study in one of the most difficult challenges a studio can face: fixing a broken movie series. There are few matters studio executives sweat more than maintaining their franchises. In the high-risk film business, sequels and spinoffs are the equivalent of insurance policies, but keeping these properties afloat requires expert handling of casting, tone and narrative. Once core fans turn away from a series, it is next to impossible to win them back.

His vision and generosity and that of the Freeman Foundation transformed the lives of students and teachers across America and Asia, building enduring bridges of friendship and understanding.

SAEWITZ--Robert. Born Stamford, CT February 22, 1916. Died New York City December 4, 2010. An extraordinary human being in every way. Served in WWII, entrepreneur and business owner for seven decades, devoted family man. Beloved husband of Estelle, devoted father of Anita Saewitz, Bruce and Andrea Saewitz, Jerry and Ellie Altman, Mindy and Steve Golodny; loving grandfather of Mathew and Clara Altman, Julie and John Moran, Michael Saewitz, Lindsey Saewitz, Charles Schuster, Aaron Schuster, Andrew Golodny, Elizabeth and Christopher Lopez, Lee Golodny. Donations may be made to Hadassah or the Interfaith Nutritional Network.

FURMAN--Frank. Of White Plains, NY, formerly of Chappaqua, NY, born in Boston, died on December 4, 2010. Husband of Joan nee Baumgarten for 51 years. Father of David J. Furman (Gail), Joyce R. Minkoff (Neil), Nancy E. Furman Paul (Marc). Brother of the late Jack Furman (Sylvia). Treasured grandfather of six. BS and MS in Electrical Engineering with honors MBA. Elected to Eta Kappa Nu National Engineering Honor Society; Worcester Polytech, MIT, NYU. As a past vice president in the Global Division of Citibank he helped automate the world: from Brussels to Bangkok, South America to South Africa, to London, Milan, Athens, Tokyo, Taiwan and Seoul. Also pioneered the ATM. Past member Board of Trustees of Community Synagogue of Rye. Devoted student of Talmud. Ardent sports fan. His integrity and quiet strength sustained and inspired us. Services, Tuesday, December 7 at 11am, Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY.

(Ovation) BATTLE OF THE NUTCRACKERS: DANCE OFF Damian Woetzel, a former principal dancer with New York City Ballet, and Sarah Jessica Parker, above, offer sugarplum facts and sparkly banter as hosts of this annual competition, which pits five ''Nutcracker'' productions against one another and lets viewers vote online (ovationtv.com) for their favorite. LAMB--Julia Appleton Flitner, conservationist, died peacefully December 3, 2010 at RiverWoods, Exeter, New Hampshire in her 93rd year. Daughter of Gertrude (Wellington) and Stanwood Edwards Flitner formerly of Englewood, New Jersey and Cornwall, New York. Graduate of Dwight School and Vassar College. Fought for preservation of scenic Palisades, Hackensack River and the Hudson River Highlands watershed. Early advocate for open space, recycling and local foods. Founding advisory member Scenic Hudson Preservation Conference, Citizens Advisory Council to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, past president Greenbrook Sanctuary, Palisades Preservation Coalition, Englewood Shade Tree Commission, Women of St. Paul's Episcopal Church and League of Women Voters. Recipient of Ford's 1972 National Conservationist Award. Predeceased by her husband, Albert Richard Lamb, Jr, MD; survived by four sons Albert Richard Lamb III of Cambridge, Mass, George Stanwood Lamb of Vail, Colo, Thomas Appleton Lamb of Laguna Beach, Calif, Peter Flitner Henshaw Lamb of Kittery Point, Maine; five grandchildren, three daughters-in-law. Services private. Contributions may be made to "Julia's Fund," New Hampshire Charitable Foundation, 446 Market St, Portsmouth, NH 03801.

It turns out our government has been lying to us about whether we have troops in Pakistan engaging in combat operations. The Pentagon has said the mission of American soldiers is confined to "training Pakistani forces so that they can in turn train other Pakistani military," but in fact our forces have been embedded in Pakistani fighting units, giving them electronic data and other support as they kill the enemy.

.CANCÚN, Mexico -- As the main plenary session at climate talks here was getting under way on Tuesday, I received word that Lonnie Thompson, a longtime student of ice and climate at Ohio State University, has a paper coming out in a behavior journal, The Behavior Analyst, concluding with unusual bluntness that humanity is in deep trouble. Thompson is an extraordinary scientist focused for decades (along with his equally remarkable wife, Ellen Mosley-Thompson) on direct observations of climate as well as evidence derived from ice cores extracted from glaciers around the world. He appears to have spent more time on ice fields above 18,000 feet than any human being in history. (The connection between glaciology and behavior will become clear below.)

In case you hadn't heard, the hipster is dead. But who will replace their enigmatic omnipresence? Matt Fox, proprietor of the Web store Fine and Dandy Shop, just may hold the answer. As a response to the sartorial disarray that has become au courant of late, Fox started his e-commerce site two years ago to peddle comely accessories to dandies and Beau Brummels alike. He's shrewdly fixed his attentions on one-size-fits-all trimmings like bow ties, ascots and tie bars (a best seller) perfect for the rakish fop, and found an untapped market of eager fashionistos.

My column yesterday plucked out one thread from the National Marriage Project's depressing new report, "The Retreat from Marriage in Middle America," and looked at the ways in which its findings complicate some of our stereotypes about the American culture war - in particular, the widespread understanding (one that I've perpetuated in my own writings) that less-educated Americans tend to be more religious and socially conservative than well-educated Americans. The "Retreat from Marriage" report suggests that this frame held up more strongly in the 1970s than it does today. On some questions (the morality of premarital sex, whether a divorce should become harder to obtain) well-educated and less-educated Americans seem to have converged over the last few decades, or else the less-educated have become more permissive than college graduates. At the same time, rates of churchgoing have fallen much faster among less-educated Americans than they have among college graduates, to the point where there's now a strongly positive correlation between education and church attendance - one that didn't exist in the '70s. (The recent trend toward secularization, it turns out, may have been driven more by community college dropouts than by Richard Dawkins-reading Ph.Ds.)

Tear gas canisters and smoke bombs were lobbed outside the Teatro alla Scala in Milan on Tuesday as the police battled protesters who denounced cuts in funding to cultural institutions. Inside, the conductor Daniel Barenboim lobbed a brickbat of his own. Before conducting "Die Wälkure" in La Scala's season-opening gala performance, Mr. Barenboim spoke from the pit and urged Italy's president, Giorgio Napolitano, who was present, to protect the arts, The Associated Press reported. "We are deeply worried for the future of culture in the country and in Europe," the conductor was quoted as saying. The government is expected to soon announce decreases in spending on culture, including subsidies to La Scala and other opera houses in Italy.

Last year, city education officials issued the Choir Academy of Harlem a death sentence. Unable to find its footing after a 2001 scandal that led to the demise of its founding organization, the famed Harlem Boys Choir, the school, along with 18 others, "lacked the capacity to improve student performance," and would be closed, the city said.

Riverpark is a Tom Colicchio restaurant. What this means is that Tom Colicchio's name is on it and some people will call it Tom Colicchio's restaurant. They will believe that he created the menu and is in the kitchen cooking, at least when he's not off at photo shoots for TV Guide. But he didn't, and he's not.

Forget The Sartorialist. Jason Wu has been getting inspiration from the street fashion photos of the Séeberger Brothers, who captured Paris society of the 1930s. Back then, crazy hats, feathers and fur were the stuff of everyday wear. With the start of production drawing closer on his cinematic adaptations of "The Hobbit," Peter Jackson has begun reuniting his old gang from his Academy Award-winning "Lord of the Rings" movies. On Tuesday, Mr. Jackson announced that Cate Blanchett, who played the elf Galadriel in his film versions of J. R. R. Tolkien's "Fellowship of the Ring," "The Two Towers" and "The Return of the King," will reprise that role in his two-part "Hobbit" series. In a statement reported at comingsoon.net, Mr. Jackson said Ms. Blanchett was "one of my favorite actors to work with and I couldn't be more thrilled to have her reprise the role she so beautifully brought to life in the earlier films." Also joining the "Hobbit" movies are Sylvester McCoy, a star of the British fantasy series "Doctor Who," as the wizard Radagast the Brown, and Ken Stott ("Charlie Wilson's War") as Balin, a dwarf leader.

I got all twitchy (it's a good thing) when I saw the new "Really?" ad campaign for Windows Phone 7. It features people carrying on life's routines -- walking, running, playing with children, preparing for bed -- absorbed in their smartphones and missing life as it is happening around them. "It's time for our phone," a narrator intones, "to save us from our phones." The new Windows Phone 7, we are told, is "designed to get you in and out and back to life" -- something many small-business owners long for.

We know you've marked your calendar: there are now 83 days until the 83rd Academy Awards (Feb. 27, 2011). To celebrate this red-letter date, the Academy itself is starting a countdown, revisiting each and every Oscar event by year. The first one, held in 1929, gave the top prize to "Wings," the only silent film ever to win an Academy Award; it was also the only time individual prizes were given for dramatic and comedic direction. (They went to "7th Heaven" and the laff-riot "Two Arabian Knights," respectively.) There wasn't much room for industry speculation or public betting, though, because the ceremony, in the Blossom Room of the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, was held three months after the winners were announced. Two hundred and seventy people attended, and the Academy president, Douglas Fairbanks, was the host. Plus-ones were welcome, as long as they paid $5 for their seat. In this photo, the guests look mostly well-behaved, but the Bagger bets it won't be long until a close inspection reveals early celebrity misbehavior. Follow along!

Since captivating the downtown performance scene of the 1990s as Kiki, the singing, boozing, yarn-spinning half of the drag cabaret duo Kiki and Herb, the Maryland native Justin Bond has become a witty, kitten-heeled fixture of the New York avant-garde. Bond, who is in his 40s and identifies as transgender, was the mistress of ceremonies in John Cameron Mitchell's 2006 indie film "Shortbus," and in October he performed at the Kitchen with his House of Whimsy Players in "Re:Galli Blond (A Sissy Fix)," a self-penned musical spectacle of transgender oppression and uplift. From the phone in his East Village loft, he chatted about his latest project, "Justin Bond: Christmas Spells," opening Dec. 9 at Abrons Arts Center.

The San Francisco Opera on Tuesday disclosed details of a new opera by Christopher Theofanidis based on a book about Rick Rescorla, the head of security for Morgan Stanley who died shepherding people to safety during the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The opera, "Heart of a Soldier," will star the baritone Thomas Hampson, the tenor William Burden and the soprano Melody Moore. Francesca Zambello will direct and Patrick Summers will conduct. It will have its first performance on Sept. 10, the eve of the 10th anniversary of the attack.

I really had a great weekend of cooking; winter takes the pressure off of shopping for "the best possible ingredients" and just lets you hunker down and play with what's around. Think cartoons are all sweetness and fluff? That's not all, folks. In the wake of the Annie nominations on Monday, animators and Oscar watchers are talking about some studio drama behind the scenes. This past summer, the Walt Disney Company and Pixar Animation announced they were withdrawing from the Annies, the cartoon world's equivalent of the Oscars, presented by the Hollywood branch of the International Animated Film Society, because of a dispute with the way the group chooses its winners. "Among Disney's complaints: that the guild allows anyone to buy a membership (in contrast to most awards-bestowing organizations) and that rival DreamWorks Animation has too much power because it gives all of its employees complimentary membership to the guild," Brooks Barnes wrote in August.

As policy, the bargain Barack Obama just struck with Congressional Republicans is a classic "it makes sense, but only if ..." situation. Given the parlous state of the economy, it makes sense to maintain the low Bush-era tax rates, it makes sense to extend unemployment benefits, and it makes sense to temporarily drop the payroll tax rate ... if, that is, our leaders use the time between today and 2012, when this bargain comes up for renegotiation, to make real progress on a strategy for long-term deficit reduction, joined to a base-broadening, rate-lowering tax reform package that renders the debates over the Bush tax cuts obsolete.

The Philip Glass opera "Einstein on the Beach" will be revived in 2012  by the production company Pomegranate Arts,  the company said on Tuesday. The 1976 work will go on tour starting in Montpellier, France, in March of that year and travel to London, Toronto, Brooklyn and Berkeley, Calif., before closing in Amsterdam in January 2013. Mr. Glass and his collaborator, the director Robert Wilson, will be involved in the restaging, the producers said. Starting in January 2012, the company will rehearse and give previews at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.

Barnaby Roper, the innovative New York filmmaker and photographer, has created a short film exclusively for The Moment starring the model Dorothea Barth Jorgensen. In this captivating short, Roper combines powerful lighting and exquisitely timed edits - along with more than a little wax - to transform Dorothea into a three-dimensional otherworldly beauty. When not appearing in T films or posing for the pages of Italian Vogue or Love, the Swedish-born Jorgensen can often be found at Surf Café in Brooklyn, reading her beloved Anaïs Nin, or, you know, analyzing dreams. She also has a wicked blog called Displaced Bones, where you can see Jorgensen's beautiful friends captured through her own lens and read her poetry and various musings.

Susan Philipsz, a 45-year-old Scottish artist, has won this year's Turner Prize, The Guardian reported. She is the first artist to win for a sound work: she recorded herself singing a 16th-century Scottish lament under three bridges in Glasgow. The prize, established in 1984 by the Tate in London, goes to a British artist under age 50 and comes with about $39,000. Ms. Philipsz beat out Dexter Dalwood, known for his contemporary take on traditional history paintings; Angela de la Cruz, a painter and sculptor nominated for her installation ''After,'' at the Camden Arts Center in London; and the Otolith Group, consisting of the London artists Anjalika Sagar and Kodwo Eshun, who make documentary films for a series of exhibitions called ''A Long Time Between Suns.'' (Finalists each receive about $7,800.) Ms. Philipsz is only the fourth woman to win the award, after Rachel Whiteread, Gillian Wearing and Tomma Abts. In a statement the judges said they ''admired the way in which her work provokes both intellectual and instinctive responses and reflects a series of decisions about the relationship between sound and sight'' and that she ''draws on the immersive properties of sound and uses her own voice to create powerful sculptural experiences.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Ridley Scott's 1982 ''Blade Runner'' is a stylish action movie starring Harrison Ford as Deckard, a bounty hunter in pursuit of coolly attractive androids. Philip K. Dick's ''Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?,'' the 1968 book it's based on, is a very different novel of ideas, at its essence about an unhappily married man. In a twist that sounds straight out of the story itself, the movie has become so popular that many fans don't realize that the imitation is not the original. Edward Einhorn's new stage adaptation, which imagines a future populated by humans and androids difficult to distinguish from one another, aims to reclaim the spirit of the book. It's an act of fan love but also dramatically shrewd, since a downtown play is a better forum than a Hollywood blockbuster for a grim meditation on religion, consumerism and what it means to be human.

Passengers waiting on the downtown F train platform at the Broadway-Lafayette station on Sunday were stunned when the train approached. Instead of the silver bullet that they expected, an ancient-looking, olive-drab metal box lumbered into the station. When it ground to a halt and the doors opened, men dressed in orange reflective vests hopped out to announce that this was the F train, making all local stops. The cars on the train - model R1 through R9, for you rail fanatics out there - date back to the 1930s.

In the ever-expanding insider trading investigations, federal prosecutors last week subpoenaed the records of Broadband Research, whose head, John Kinnucan, refused to wear a wire for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. That they went after the firm and not the founder is an important legal distinction - one that means Mr. Kinnucan will have to comply, even if by doing so he incriminates himself. Broadband Research is registered as a corporation with the Oregon Secretary of State. Only two individuals are listed on its filing: Mr. Kinnucan, president, and his wife, corporate secretary and registered agent. Like many small businesses, Broadband appears to be a one-man shop, essentially an extension of Mr. Kinnucan.

SCHUSTEK--Nancy. Ethical Culture Fieldston School is deeply saddened by the death of our beloved EC prekindergarten teacher, Nancy Schustek. Since her first year teaching at the school in 1985, Nancy has touched the whole community with her warmth, generosity, and enthusiasm. A native New Yorker, she grew up in Yorkville, graduated from Hunter College, and received her master's from Bank Street College of Education. She is survived by her daughter, Natalie Joseph, and her brother, Russell Schustek. We will miss Nancy's dedication to children, her laughter, her kindness, and her occasionally wicked sense of humor. There will be two viewings this week at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th Street (between 1st and 2nd). The hours are Wednesday, December 8 and Thursday, December 9, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. The burial on Friday will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family encourages donations to the Nancy Schustek Memorial Fund, designated for support services for students on financial aid. Checks should be made out to ECF and sent c/o ECF Development Department, 33 Central Park West, New York, NY 10023. ECF will hold a memorial service to celebrate Nancy's life on Monday, December 13, at 4:30pm in the New York Society for Ethical Culture auditorium (64th St. and Central Park West).

To hear Eric H. Holder Jr. tell it, the Justice Department is aggressively cracking down on financial fraud. On Monday in Washington, Mr. Holder, the United States attorney general, announced with much fanfare the results of a new enforcement program: Operation Broken Trust. ''With this operation, the Financial Fraud Enforcement Task Force is sending a strong message,'' Mr. Holder declared, highlighting the Ponzi schemes, affinity frauds and investment scams his department had prosecuted.

For her latest book club selection Oprah Winfrey decided to go ''old school,'' she said on Monday. Ms. Winfrey has selected two Charles Dickens novels, ''A Tale of Two Cities'' and ''Great Expectations,'' both announced on her show on Monday, both books that she had never read before. They could be two of the last selected for the Oprah Book Club before her show goes off the air next year. Earlier this year Ms. Winfrey picked Jonathan Franzen's novel ''Freedom,'' and in 2009, her only choice was ''Say You're One of Them,'' a story collection by Uwem Akpan, a Nigerian Jesuit priest. According to the reading schedule on the Oprah Web site Ms. Winfrey's viewers have until the end of January to read both books before Ms. Winfrey will begin a discussion about them.

WASHINGTON -- The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal in the biggest employment discrimination case in the nation's history, one claiming that Wal-Mart Stores had discriminated against hundreds of thousands of women in pay and promotion. The lawsuit seeks back pay that could amount to billions of dollars. The question is not whether there was discrimination but rather whether the claims by the individual employees may be combined as a class action. The court's decision on that issue will almost certainly affect all sorts of class-action suits, including ones asserting antitrust, securities and product liability.

WASHINGTON -- Just a week after President Bashar al-Assad of Syria assured a top State Department official that his government was not sending sophisticated weapons to Hezbollah, the Obama administration lodged a confidential protest accusing Syria of doing precisely what it had denied doing. ''In our meetings last week it was stated that Syria is not transferring any 'new' missiles to Lebanese Hizballah,'' noted a cable sent by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton in February, using an alternative spelling for the militant group. ''We are aware, however, of current Syrian efforts to supply Hizballah with ballistic missiles. I must stress that this activity is of deep concern to my government, and we strongly caution you against such a serious escalation.''

FURMAN--Frank. Of White Plains, NY, formerly of Chappaqua, NY, born in Boston, died on December 4, 2010. Husband of Joan nee Baumgarten for 51 years. Father of David J. Furman (Gail), Joyce R. Minkoff (Neil), Nancy E. Furman Paul (Marc). Brother of the late Jack Furman (Sylvia). Treasured grandfather of six. BS and MS in Electrical Engineering with honors MBA. Elected to Eta Kappa Nu National Engineering Honor Society; Worcester Polytech, MIT, NYU. As a past vice president in the Global Division of Citibank he helped automate the world: from Brussels to Bangkok, South America to South Africa, to London, Milan, Athens, Tokyo, Taiwan and Seoul. Also pioneered the ATM. Past member Board of Trustees of Community Synagogue of Rye. Devoted student of Talmud. Ardent sports fan. His integrity and quiet strength sustained and inspired us. Services, Tuesday, December 7 at 11am, Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY.

ORLANDO, Fla. - Two years ago, when San Diego Padres General Manager Jed Hoyer was an assistant to Theo Epstein, the general manager of the Red Sox, he experienced visceral disappointment when Mark Teixeira, then a free agent, spurned Boston's offer at the last moment and instead signed with the Yankees, a defining moment in the recent histories of both teams. Hoyer described the event as a kick in the stomach, and explained how the Red Sox had been searching for a slugging first baseman with above-average defensive skills for years. When Teixeira was lost to Boston, the next player on the list became Adrian Gonzalez, whom the Sox pursued with even more resolve, until they finally acquired him from Hoyer and the Padres on Sunday in a trade for three of Boston's top minor league prospects.

He will be missed by many friends and colleagues. We extend our deep condolences to his entire family. Martin J. Blaser, M.D., Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

FEDER--Ralph, WWII Combat Veteran, Westfield, NJ - Ralph Feder, 88, of Hyde Park NY, New Castle NH, and Westfield NJ, passed away on Wednesday December 1st, after a long battle with lung cancer. Mr. Feder was born January 12, 1922 to Eva and Abraham Feder in Philadelphia, PA. He served in the 1st Infantry Division during World War II from 1942 to 1945, during which he fought in the Battle of the Bulge. He was a recipient of both the Bronze Star and Purple Heart. After completing graduate school, he worked at the Frankfort Arsenal in Philadelphia where he met his wife of 60 years, Josephine Feder, who survives. Mr. Feder spent a year in England and another in Argentina on a governmental research grant. He went on to work as a research physicist at the Thomas J. Watson Research Center of IBM for more than 20 years before retiring. He received numerous patents for his discoveries and inventions. Mr. Feder is survived by his daughters Elizabeth Feder of Ingleside, Illinois, Jennifer Kopser of Westfield, NJ, Kerry Feder of Verona, NJ, two sons-in-law, four grandsons, one granddaughter, a sister, a niece and several nephews. Doctor Wilker was Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. He was recognized as a "doctor's doctor," a skilled and compassionate physician and teacher held in the highest esteem by his patients, colleagues, students and friends. A proud and decorated WWII Army Air Force navigator who risked his life in the fight against oppression and genocide, he was the last of four children of Jewish European immigrant parents and a patriarch of the Wikler family. He will be remembered, admired and loved eternally by everyone whose life he touched. When we call something a puzzle, rather than just a problem or a question, we are often focusing on the recreational aspect of coming up with a solution. The enjoyment derived from solving a puzzle can help fix scientific lessons in memory. The following quiz is not itself a puzzle, but it is made up of puzzling questions that may surprise and stretch the mind in a satisfying way, and perhaps help reinforce or teach some scientific ideas. It is not meant to test your knowledge, but to drive home some principle of science or to illustrate some surprising phenomenon.

As Nouriel Roubini heads to Athens to meet with investors and policymakers potentially about the debt crisis in Europe, the economist says he's increasingly worried about a problem closer to home: America's real estate mess. The country's real estate problems are ''underappreciated,'' and banks could face another $1 trillion in housing-related losses, Mr. Roubini said in a phone interview with DealBook on Monday. At the same time, he played down the issues in Ireland, Greece, Portugal and Spain, calling the matter ''contained'' for now. The United States ''real estate market, for sure, is double dipping,'' Mr. Roubini said. ''The apparent increase in prices has been fully reversed, demand is falling, and supply is going to increase.''

William A. Ackman has never been shy about swooping into situations others would shy away from. But on Monday, his hedge fund proposed one of its boldest offers, homing in on the besieged bookselling industry. His firm, Pershing Square Capital Management, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Monday that it would be willing to finance a $960 million merger of Borders Group, the struggling bookseller in which it owns a 37 percent stake, and its larger rival, Barnes & Noble.

Watching the Atlantic Theater Company's exquisite productions of ''The Collection'' and ''A Kind of Alaska,'' two short plays by Harold Pinter, I almost forgot that the cast was speaking in a foreign language. Technically, of course, Pinter wrote in English. But as is true of most great dramatists, his syntax, locutions, rhythms and silences make up a sui generis grammar. To navigate the treacherous, autonomous nation that is Pinterland requires a thorough command of this exotic tongue. The facility demonstrated by the ensemble of ''The Collection'' and ''A Kind of Alaska'' -- directed by Karen Kohlhaas and featuring a knockout performance from Lisa Emery as a middle-aged woman waking up from a decades-long coma -- isn't always evident in productions of Pinter, particularly in this country. It's not just a matter of Americans having to assume British accents, though what those accents signify as to relative positions in class and power structures is especially important with Pinter.

An article on Thursday about a high school runner in California who collapsed and crawled across the finish line at a state cross-country meet in Fresno overstated the importance of her having completed the race. The team would have narrowly won the state champsionhip even if she had not finished; it was not the case that by crawling across the finish line she was able ''to clinch the championship for her team.'' (The runner, Holland Reynolds, and her team and coach were not aware at the time that the championship did not depend on her.)

The Senate is preparing to vote this week on whether to unseat a Louisiana federal judge impeached by the House on charges of corruption and bribery. A decision could come as early as Tuesday. The House impeached Judge G. Thomas Porteous Jr. in March on four articles of ''high crimes and misdemeanors.'' The charges stemmed from allegations that he ran up gambling debts, used a fake name to file for bankruptcy, accepted cash and gifts from lawyers involved in cases he handled, and lied to the Senate and to the Federal Bureau of Investigation while he was being vetted to fill the vacancy on the federal district court in New Orleans-- a pattern of conduct House lawmakers agreed made him unfit to hold office.

In a confluence of financial interests and theater availability on Broadway, two commercially popular rock 'n roll musicals - the metal/hair band love story ''Rock of Ages'' and the Beatles tribute show ''Rain'' - will change theaters in early 2011 to continue their runs, the producers of both shows said on Monday. The moves, which are relatively rare for Broadway, will allow ''Rain'' to stay open, while ''Rock of Ages'' will be able to lower its weekly running costs (and potentially increase its profit margin) by running in a smaller Broadway house. ''Rain'' began a 12-week run at the Neil Simon Theater in October, as a temporary tenant in between big-budget open-ended musicals. It will close on Jan. 15 and move five blocks south to the Brooks Atkinson Theater, resuming performances there on Feb. 8 for at least 16 more weeks.

It's either a terrible day or a great day to be the creator of a cult cable-television series. FX announced on Monday that it would not be ordering a second season of ''Terriers,'' its series about a former detective (played by Donal Logue) and an ex-burglar (Michael Raymond-James) trying to make it as private investigators in San Diego. The show, created by Ted Griffin, the ''Ocean's Eleven'' screenwriter, and whose producers included Shawn Ryan, the creator of ''The Shield,'' was well reviewed at its debut in September. Ginia Bellafante in The New York Times called it ''a welcome love child, one we are eager to embrace rather than put up for adoption.'' But it never seemed to reach a critical mass of viewers, and while we don't want to say its title was to blame, we will point out that Mr. Ryan recently renamed another new cop drama he is preparing, changing its title from ''Ride-Along'' to ''The Chicago Code.'' THURSDAY'S PUZZLE - As crosswords continue to evolve, certain themes that used to be common have gone out of fashion. We don't see so many quote (or step quote) puzzles anymore, word ladders are now rare, and the formerly popular "word that can precede the beginning of each theme answer" form is nearly extinct. It's not so much that it ran its course but the infinite variations lost their novelty long ago.

For his latest film, "The Fighter," a passion project brought to him by his frequent star Mark Wahlberg, Mr. Russell takes on the true story of Micky Ward and Dicky Eklund, brothers and struggling boxers from Lowell, Mass., near where Mr. Wahlberg grew up. The artist Dan Graham has not gone into retail design as far as we know, but you could easily mistake Pierre Hardy's first United States boutique, in the West Village, for one of Graham's installations. His glass and mirror pavilions, which are often plunked down into incongruous environments (say, a forest or the roof of the former DIA building in Chelsea), play tricks on the eye, integrating the spectator into the structure's reflected surfaces. "He's my dream artist," Hardy said earlier this week, acknowledging the homage. His shop, at 30 Jane Street, which was designed by David Mann of MR. Architecture + Decor is a little jewel box - all smokey brown glass and mirrors; its situation, ensconced within the rough and crudely patched walls of a historic carriage house, feels both serene and strangely precarious. "It's exactly the opposite of Paris," Hardy explained. "There you have historical places you can't touch and you have to work with it. Here we had to destroy and rebuild everything because what was here was unusable. We tried to do something more precious in the middle of something more raw." A particularly Grahamesque touch comes in the form of two large plates of interlocking glass that section off the 1,400-square-foot space into semi-private cubbies so you can catch furtive glimpses of the woman trying on Hardy's special New York "Skyline" shoes next to you (Um, excuse me, do those come in my size?), and still maintain the illusion that you have the place all to yourself.

West Coast fans of the jewelry designer Alexis Bittar now have three stores where they can view his creations. Last week, the Brooklyn-based jeweler opened a shop on Abbot Kinney in Venice, Calif., another on West Third Street in Los Angeles, and next week he'll open on Filmore Street in Pacific Heights in San Francisco. Expanding at a time when many other designers are just staying above water may be a bold move. But Bittar believes "it's a great time to come into new cities with a force." He chose Los Angeles, in particular, because he feels the city, along with New York, "shapes the country in terms of trends." San Francisco, on the other hand, is a revenue leader for the company; the new shop will cater to a woman Bittar describes as being more "artistic, with a personality more like New York City women." The boutiques' décor incorporates 1930s wallpaper that's been sprayed with graffiti, along with a smattering of the taxidermy groupings that have become a Bittar design statement. "We're creating animal hybrids with these, like putting swan wings on a gazelle," he says. "On a theatric level, having a store is great. And I think it makes shopping fun."

Seiji Ozawa's cancellation of performances at the Saito Kinen Festival Matsumoto, in Japan, in September because of back problems heightened concern at Carnegie Hall, since the programs in question were also scheduled for Carnegie next week. The programs are still coming, Carnegie announced on Tuesday, and so is Mr. Ozawa, though in a reduced capacity. In concerts with the Saito Kinen Orchestra next Tuesday and Wednesday, Mr. Ozawa will conduct only the second half of each program: Brahms's First Symphony the first night, Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' the second. Tatsuya Shimono, the young conductor who replaced Mr. Ozawa in Matsumoto, will conduct the first half: Atsuhiko Gondai's ''Decathexis'' and Beethoven's Third Piano Concerto (with Mitsuko Uchida as soloist) on Tuesday, and Toru Takemitsu's ''November Steps'' on Wednesday.

The San Francisco Opera on Tuesday disclosed details of a new opera by Christopher Theofanidis based on a book about Rick Rescorla, the head of security for Morgan Stanley who died shepherding people to safety during the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The opera, ''Heart of a Soldier,'' will star the baritone Thomas Hampson, the tenor William Burden and the soprano Melody Moore. Francesca Zambello will direct and Patrick Summers will conduct. It will have its first performance on Sept. 10, the eve of the 10th anniversary of the attack. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit organization behind the TKTS theater discount service, on Tuesday announced two new additions, one for iPhone users and one for theatergoers who prefer human interaction. The first new feature is an official TKTS iPhone app that will allow users to see in real time what tickets are being offered at the organization's three TKTS booths: in Times Square and at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, and at the MetroTech Center in Brooklyn. The app, which through March 1 will be available free at the Apple iTunes store and the theater fund's Web site, tdf.org, also offers a search feature for theater, dance and music productions in New York that includes descriptions and schedules, and access to the fund's online publication, TDF Stages. (At least one previous app, called At the Booth, has provided TKTS information but did not have fund's endorsement. T.D.F. said in a news release that a version of its app for the Android operating system was also in the works.)

She served as Council President from 1966 1971, and later as President Emerita, Vice Chairman, and Treasurer.We will all remember with deep fondness her keen intelligence, great wisdom, kindness, and her wonderful sense of humor. We send our profoundest sympathy to her three children David Straus, Robert Straus, and Sara Byruck; her six grandchildren Sara, Rebecca, Lisa, Drew, Mischa, and Chloe; and their families. Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President Joanne M. Stern, President Emerita Jeanne C. Thayer, President Emerita Joann K. ELIOT--Lucy Carter, of New York City and for many years of Cazenovia, NY, died on November 15th in her 98th year. She will be greatly missed by her nieces, Evelyn B. Patterson and Alice C. Van Tuyl, and nephew, Eliot D. Hawkins, their many descendants and her network of friends in both locations. All will remember her infectious good humor, her generosity with friends of all ages, her talents as a painter, including awards and exhibitions, her devotion to her art and her constant enthusiasm for its future. As she put it, "I hope to be able to continue working for some time to come, as I have the same feeling now that I have had over the years: that I am just beginning to paint." A Memorial Service will be held for her in the Chapel at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st Street, New York City on December 29, 2010 at 2:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in her name to the Art Students League of NY, 215 W. 57th Street, New York, NY 10019.

Last year, city education officials issued the Choir Academy of Harlem a death sentence. Unable to find its footing after a 2001 scandal that led to the demise of its founding organization, the famed Harlem Boys Choir, the school, along with 18 others, ''lacked the capacity to improve student performance,'' and would be closed, the city said. But then the unexpected happened. A judge reversed the closings on a relative technicality. Given an extra year, the Choir Academy raised its graduation rate to above the city's average, and in so doing, it saved itself. The city announced this week that it would allow Choir Academy to stay open.

10 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) HOOKERS: SAVED ON THE STRIP For more than a decade, Annie Lobért sold her body on the Las Vegas Strip. Now she tries to prevent others from walking in her footsteps through Hookers for Jesus, which works with the Church at South Las Vegas and its lead pastor, Benny Perez, to run Destiny House, a transitional home offering a haven from sex trafficking and the possibility of a fresh start. This three-part series focuses on three women trying to rebuild their lives, starting with Regina (above right with Ms. Lobért), who was forced into prostitution by her boyfriend while they served in the Navy. 8 P.M. (G4) AMERICAN NINJA WARRIOR In the second edition of this adaptation of a popular Japanese series, 300 American competitors are winnowed to 15, who then take on the Sasuke, a four-stage obstacle course in Yokohama considered the world's most formidable. Four consecutive half-hour episodes lead up to the Season 2 finale.

WITH millions of new tablets in Americans' hands, publishers spent the year scrambling to put cookbooks in digital form for the holidays. Last month, Amazon.com finally made it possible to send a gift of an electronic book to a loved one's Kindle or iPad. Random House has just released over a hundred cookbooks (from Rachael Ray, Bobby Flay and others) as e-books. Some collections, like the vast Cook's Illustrated/America's Test Kitchen library, are sold in multiple formats: as e-books, smartphone apps, tablet apps, Web caches, and books.

A headline on Nov. 30 with an article about SmithKline Beecham's role in the publication of a book about treating psychiatric disorders overstated SmithKline's actions. While documents show that SmithKline (now known as GlaxoSmithKline) hired a writing company for the book, they do not indicate that the company wrote the book for the authors, Dr. Charles B. Nemeroff and Dr. Alan F. Schatzberg. The article also described incorrectly, in some editions, events outlined in a letter from the writing company to Dr. Nemeroff. The correspondence proposed a timeline for the writing company to furnish the doctors and SmithKline with draft text and final page proofs for approval; the letter did not say that the company had already provided those materials for final approval. And the article misstated the context under which Dr. David A. Kessler, the former commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, commented about the book's production. The letter and other documents were described to him; he did not personally review the documents.

Private equity firms may finally have an exit strategy for deals made at the height of the buyout boom. While the market for initial public offerings remains somewhat unpredictable, the industry increasingly is finding a steady stream of buyers among rival firms and corporate suitors flush with cash. In the past two days, several potential deals involving private-equity owned companies have reportedly emerged. Among them: Chrysler Financial, owned by Cerberus Capital Management; nutrition retailer GNC, a joint holding of Ares Management and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan; and Goodman Global, the heating and air conditioning manufacturer owned by Hellman & Friedman.

Leonard Bernstein had finished conducting a concert at Philharmonic Hall (now Avery Fisher), and entered the elevator between stage and dressing room. Ken Heyman, who was spending a month with Bernstein for a lengthy photo essay, was there, too, but he had a way of making himself invisible. Later, at a workshop, Ken spoke about techniques used on such projects. One thing: The human cough is more tolerable than a camera click. When Bernstein, for the first time, let himself be photographed while composing, Ken shot sparingly, a cough covering each exposure. Recently, I rode the same elevator, holding Ken's photograph out, trying to match the angle. Someone said, ''Good evening, Maestro.'' Entering the elevator, was Alan Gilbert, music director of the New York Philharmonic. The maestro paid me no heed. Perhaps, with all my coughing, he thought I had a cold. Or more likely, the conductor had more important things on his mind. Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.
