STRAUS--Elizabeth Allen. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the passing of beloved Trustee and friend Beth Straus. Beth served on the Museum's Board of Trustees for over fifty five-years and brought her graceful leadership, keen intelligence, brilliant ideas, and amazing energy to the many committees on which she served and to all that she did for the Museum. Beth and her husband Donald were not only generous philanthropists, but active and passionate collectors of art. Over this extraordinary period Beth also helped build MoMA's renowned permanent collection by giving important works of art to the Museum and by helping with the acquisition of other pieces. We will miss Beth's strong and positive energy and extend our deepest sympathies to her family. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

Another Republican senator signaled Tuesday that he may vote for the new arms control treaty with Russia if it comes up for a vote before the Senate adjourns for the year later this month. Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, who did not run for re-election, said he hopes that the Senate will get a chance to vote on the treaty, known as New Start, right after a deal on tax cuts and a spending resolution to keep the government operating.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. -- The Knicks started their summer renovation with a flight to California, where the owner James L. Dolan and Coach Mike D'Antoni led a contingent that met with the free agents Joe Johnson and Mike Miller. The team president Donnie Walsh joined them in Ohio, where they made a pitch to LeBron James. Afterward, they recruited Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh in Illinois. They put miles on their plane and forfeited sleep, but gained no commitments. Tired from jet lag, the Knicks finally met with Amar'e Stoudemire in New York. He and D'Antoni met over what Stoudemire called a ''casual breakfast,'' where they discussed revisiting their days together in Phoenix and a patched-up roster.

The Federal Reserve has a story and is sticking to it: We didn't lose taxpayer money, and we won't. But several emergency programs and credit lines still exist, and the path to profitability on them remains uncertain.

AGL Resources agreed on Tuesday to buy a fellow power company, Nicor, for $2.4 billion in cash and stock, in a bid to create a big new natural gas distributor. The merger of AGL and Nicor will create a natural gas company with about 5.5 million customers across seven states in both its regulated and unregulated businesses, as well as $5.1 billion in annual revenue.

Fortune Brands, owner of Jim Beam whiskey and Titleist golf balls as well as other consumer brands, plans to split itself into three, a person with knowledge of the plans told DealBook on Tuesday. The breakup will leave Fortune as a liquor company, its most profitable business.

ROSS--Howard, Ph.D.,Professor of Economics and Finance at Baruch College, died on November 16 in New York City of complications from pneumonia. Professor Ross began his career in 1954 as a lecturer at Columbia University and then joined the faculty of Baruch College, City University of New York, where he taught for the past 46 years. His areas of expertise were micro and macro price behavior over business cycles; the relationship between the stock market and the real economy; and monetary, fiscal, and growth policies. He held many leadership positions including department chair, academic director of the Executive MBA Program and the Baruch chapter chair of the Professional Staff Congress. Among his professional honors were a CUNY Distinguished Faculty Award and fellowships at Yale University and Columbia University (the latter, his alma mater). He had also been a consultant to a variety of private, United States and foreign government institutions, notably the United Nations, the Government of Greece, the Ford Foundation, the Peoples Republic of China, and United States Treasury. Beloved, esteemed, and indefatigably kind to the department faculty and staff and his students, Howard was known as a Renaissance man, especially fond of opera, tennis and the New York Yankees. He was the son of Gertrude and Bernard Rosensaft and brother of Lenore Kantrowitz, uncle to Laura, Naomi and Paul, and grand-uncle to Brian and Alex Kennedy, and to Leba Gittel and Paul Kantrowitz's children in Jerusalem, Israel. He will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at Baruch College on Monday, December 20, 2010, from noon to 1pm, in Room 750, Information and Technology Building, 151 East 25th St., New York.

A federal advisory committee on Tuesday recommended approval of what could become the first new prescription diet pill in more than a decade. The advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration voted 13 to 7 that the benefits of the drug, Contrave, outweighed its risks. The drug was developed by Orexigen Therapeutics of San Diego.

In an apparent rebuke to the Smithsonian Institution, which last week removed an excerpt of the artist David Wojnarowicz's video ''A Fire in My Belly'' from an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery, the New Museum in New York is now showing the work in its lobby. The video, which Mr. Wojnarowicz made in 1986 and 1987, partly in response to the death of his close friend and fellow artist Peter Hujar from AIDS, contrasts black-and-white scenes from the streets of Mexico with color images, including one of ants crawling over a crucifix.

The battle between Carl C. Icahn and Lions Gate invites comparison with the studio's movies. Is it a slasher movie akin to ''Saw''? An action film along the lines of ''Kick-Ass''? Or perhaps it is something new, a cold and calculating thriller showing the perils of shareholder activism. Our story unfolds in March 2010 with an unexpected action scene. Mr. Icahn, through his affiliated funds, began a tender offer for Lions Gate at $6 a share. Lions Gate promptly rejected Mr. Icahn's offer as inadequately priced, but after raising his offer to $7 a share, Mr. Icahn was able to raise his stake to 38 percent.

The proceedings in the Senate on Tuesday were as remarkable as the charges that lawmakers there were asked to weigh. As tax policy debates swirled around the Capitol, the Senate on Tuesday began pondering the fate of Judge G. Thomas Porteous Jr. of Federal District Court in Louisiana, whom the House of Representatives impeached in March on four articles of ''high crimes and misdemeanors'' stemming from charges that he received cash and favors from those with business in his court. This is only the 12th impeachment trial of a judge in Senate history.

FOXBOROUGH, Mass. In the wake of their humiliating loss to New England on Monday night, Jets player after Jets player had variations of the same response -- that words could not convey the hurt and humiliation of losing this badly to a hated rival.

A theater review on Nov. 24 about ''In the Footprint: The Battle Over Atlantic Yards'' misstated the name of the rail yards that the Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn is to be built over, in part, and also referred incorrectly to them. They are the Vanderbilt Yards, not the Atlantic Yards, and they are still used by the Long Island Rail Road. They have not been abandoned. A listing of credits with the review misspelled the surname of an opponent of the project who is played by Colleen Werthmann. As the review noted, she is Patti Hagan, not Hagen.

ABOARD SEAHAWK 2007, Gulf of Mexico -- For the 31 workers on this jackup oil rig, the waiting is finally over. In recent weeks, they have been doing basic chores like painting handrails and scrubbing the deck while the federal government reviewed Castex Energy's application to drill a natural gas well in 150 feet of water in the Gulf of Mexico -- a normally quick process that turned glacial after the BP oil spill on April 20 prompted regulators to shut down almost all new drilling in the region.

WIKLER--Norman S.,M.D., died peacefully at his home on December 6th at the age of 86. He is survived by his adoring wife, Mary Katherine (Guerriero), sons Irwin (Ilene) and Alan (Beth) and grandchildren Gail, Ellen and David. Doctor Wilker was Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. He was recognized as a "doctor's doctor," a skilled and compassionate physician and teacher held in the highest esteem by his patients, colleagues, students and friends. A proud and decorated WWII Army Air Force navigator who risked his life in the fight against oppression and genocide, he was the last of four children of Jewish European immigrant parents and a patriarch of the Wikler family. He will be remembered, admired and loved eternally by everyone whose life he touched. Services Wednesday, December 8th at 11:15am, "The Riverside," Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St. Shiva at Dr. Wikler's home Wednesday 3-7pm, Thursday 4-7pm and Sunday 4-7pm.

SCHLESINGER--Anita, age 84, passed away December 7, 2010, lifelong resident of Brooklyn, New York, beloved mother of Gloria S. Hege, adored sister of Phyllis Wolfthal, larger-than-life grandmother of Damon Hege and Alexa Norstad. Married for 43 years to the late Frank Schlesinger. An elementary school teacher, avid lecture attendee and world traveler, she was enthralled by the peaceful, warm summer days in her cherished Easthampton hideaway. Her quick smile, firm love, twinkling eye, strong opinions, and occasional naked truths will be greatly missed by many relatives and friends. Services will be 3pm December 8 at Parkside Funeral Home, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Burial will be private. Family will sit shiva December 9-11. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

KALIK--Betty P. Died December 6, 2010. Beloved wife for 67 years of Larry Kalik. Loving and devoted mother of Millie Kalik and the late Allen Kalik; loving mother-in-law of Tom McGanney and Pat Kalik; devoted and loving grandmother of Lisa, Melanie, Daniel and Julie and of her niece Mimi Tibbs. Her warmth, her humor and her winning ways will be greatly missed by family and friends. Funeral service Wednesday December 8th at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to "60 Plus Program 92 Y" At 1395 Lexington Ave., New York, NY 10128.

An article on Tuesday about the filmmaker Claude Lanzmann and the re-release of his movie ''Shoah'' in the United States misstated, in some editions, part of the name of the Holocaust museum in Washington. It is the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, not the National Holocaust Memorial Museum. (The museum's director, Sara Bloomfield, praised the film.)

Does it make sense to combine two booksellers with eroding sales and growing competition from the likes of Amazon.com and now Google? Shareholders of Barnes & Noble apparently believe so. For a second day, shares of Barnes & Noble surged after the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman offered to finance a $960 million merger of Barnes & Noble with the Borders Group, its smaller rival.

Last year on The Fifth Down blog, I introduced a quarterback passer rating that put a heavier weight on passing yards per attempt (Y.P.A.). A regression model indicated that Y.P.A. was the biggest driver of points scored, the ultimate aim of any quarterback. The statistic also included touchdown passes per attempt and interceptions per attempt and, unlike the traditional passer rating, accounted for sacks.

Tear gas canisters and smoke bombs were lobbed outside the Teatro alla Scala in Milan on Tuesday as the police battled protesters denouncing cultural budget cuts. Inside, the conductor Daniel Barenboim lobbed a brickbat of his own. Before conducting ''Die Walkure'' in La Scala's season-opening gala performance, Mr. Barenboim spoke from the pit and urged Italy's president, Giorgio Napolitano, who was present, to protect the arts, The Associated Press reported. ''We are deeply worried for the future of culture in the country and in Europe,'' the conductor was quoted as saying. The government is expected to soon announce cuts in spending on culture, including subsidies to La Scala and other opera houses in Italy. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- When Bibi Aisha's nose and ears were cut off by her husband and her in-laws, no one ever expected much to be done about it, especially because it happened in a remote area under Taliban control. Thanks to support from aid groups and the American Embassy in Kabul, and the charity of a hospital in Southern California, Aisha was whisked off to the United States for treatment0., and everyone assumed that it was case closed on the perpetrators.

A report in the Food Stuff column last Thursday about a version of zubrowka, the Polish buffalo-grass vodka, that is approved for sale in the United States misidentified one of the ingredients. It is rye grain, not ryegrass.

GROSS--Malvern Joseph, 77, died peacefully at home in East Windsor, NJ, on December 5, 2010. Born in Chicago, he graduated from Lehigh University and rose to partner at Price Waterhouse. An avid pilot, he set two aviation world records, served as president of National Aeronautic Association and published a memoir, "Nine Lives: Adventures of a Lucky Pilot." He is survived by his beautiful wife of 52 years, Inge Stanneck Gross; devoted children, Randy Gross and Michele Siderius, and son-in-law, Johnny Siderius; beloved sister, Linda Sinrod and brother-in-law Keith Sinrod; and loving grandchildren Meagen, Johnny and Justin Siderius. Gifts to Meadow Lakes Scholarship Fund, Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ 08520.

An obituary on Nov. 16 about Fred Goldhaber, the first teacher at the Harvey Milk School for gay and lesbian students in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to his history there. He was the school's only teacher for a little more than a year, not four years.

STEIN--Alan J.,on December 6, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Rhoda, cherished and admired father of George and Juliana, Peter and Bonnie, Lonny and Patricia. Loving grandfather of Dana, Courtney, Brandon and Emily; and great-grandfather of Avery and Dylan. Born and raised in New York City. Graduate of NYU and Harvard Law School. Served his country in WWII, participated in the Normandy invasion and awarded the Bronze Star. Highly regarded entertainment attorney and senior partner in the law firms of Zissu, Stein, Couture & Mosher and Stein & Stein. Services: Friday, 1:15pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

The Philip Glass opera ''Einstein on the Beach'' will be revived in 2012 by the production company Pomegranate Arts, the company said on Tuesday. The 1976 work will go on tour starting in Montpellier, France, in March of that year and travel to London, Toronto, Brooklyn and Berkeley, Calif., before closing in Amsterdam in January 2013. Mr. Glass and his collaborator, the director Robert Wilson, will be involved in the restaging, the producers said. Starting in January 2012, the company will rehearse and give previews at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KRISSEL--Robert. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Santa Fe Opera note with sadness the death of Robert Krissel, member of the Board from 1994 until 2008, and President from 1996 to 1999. Mr. Krissel was an enthusiastic advocate for the Opera, and has many friends in Santa Fe who recall his devotion to it. The entire Company expresses its sympathy to his family. Susan F. Morris, Chairman Carey R. Ramos, President Charles MacKay, General Dir. The Santa Fe Opera

A music review on Thursday about ''Manning the Canon: Songs of Gay Life'' at Merkin Concert Hall, using information from the program, misidentified the performer who originally sang ''The Purest Kind of Guy'' -- a song performed at the concert -- in 1941 and referred incorrectly to the work in which it appeared. It was first sung by Curt Conway, not Paul Robeson, although Robeson did sing it later and it was associated with him. The song is from ''No for an Answer,'' which its composer, Marc Blitzstein, called an opera, not a musical.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - When I told today's constructor, Elizabeth C. Gorski, that I could tell this puzzle was by her as soon as I saw the grid, her winking response was, "I hope I'm not becoming a predictable Johnny One-Note constructor." Of course not, but few in the business have as distinctive a voice. Ms. Gorski is a musician and often includes unusual visual elements in her grids. She's also a veteran constructor who can handle the wide open designs like today's 63-worder. That single musical eighth note in a sea of white squares points directly at her.

While Wall Street's moguls and whiz kids might not want to admit it, the best way to figure out what's really happening in the economy is to read the daily newspapers. You'll learn all you need to know there. And the zeitgeist is fairly bubbling these days with an array of stories that seem to be pointing to serious economic trouble ahead. We can no longer ignore the message that is being broadcast loud and clear: We must get our fiscal house in order and take meaningful - exceedingly painful, yes - steps to close the $1.3 trillion federal budget deficit. You can be the most zealous Keynesian economist on the planet and still know that at some point we cannot continue to have both guns and butter without serious repercussions. And we have clearly reached that point.

I always love Chanel's Métiers d'Arts collection, created in 2002 to showcase the work of the small Paris ateliers, like Lesage, that the company bought. The clothes are quietly evocative of a place and usually a little more down-to-earth than couture. And, as we know, Karl Lagerfeld never minds extra work. I've seen two of the shows (in Paris and Tokyo); the latest one I had to catch online. It was held in the house, on the Rue Cambon. Called Paris-Byzance, the collection didn't quite soar off to Byzantium - too somber in color and shape, I suppose - but I liked the use of square shapes (jeweled buttons especially), the straight-line long dresses, many of the murky carpet-colored tweeds, the flat sandals and Freja's slouchy pants.

Maybe that Jeff Koons on display at the Gagosian booth at Art Basel Miami Beach last week was a little out of your price range. At Art Barter, opening tonight at NP Contemporary Art Center on Chrystie Street, your money is no good anyway. Instead you can offer up your personal goods or services in exchange for a work by, say, Tom Sachs or Terence Koh. The idea for Art Barter, which made its debut last year in London, came from Lauren Jones and Alix Janta, who were inspired by the free-thinking ways of Burning Man, the RCA Postcard Auction and Freecycle. If you're stuck for ideas, here are some things that have changed hands in the past: a Tracey Emin piece for 30 hours of French tutoring; a Jason Dodge work for a week in a Scottish castle. Other offers have included Web site design, three months of psychotherapy and a gallop on a white horse. But keep in mind the contract is legally binding so don't promise something you can't deliver.

A new creature has docked in Montreal's Old Port, nestling among the industrial silos and across the river from Moshe Safdie's Habitat 67 cuboid apartment block. Bota Bota, a massive 1950s steel liner redesigned by architects from Sid Lee - the Montreal-based creative agency - is the world's first spa-on-a-boat, a 25,000-square-foot urban fantasy of a Scandinavian-style bath with more than 20 treatment rooms. Aboard the vessel, guests can indulge in all sorts of treatments, like a Honey Ocean massage and a Cocoa Wave body wrap, or work the hot and cold water pool circuit on the ship's upper decks. After all the steaming and stretching, you can visit the cafe, which serves sophisticated takes on health cuisine, including scallop ceviche with strawberries, foie gras and chocolate-caramel cake - this is French Canada, after all.

The All-Star Game is, in many respects, quite odd. It's part coach-determined meritocracy and part popularity contest. It's a game that means absolutely nothing, and yet the players are supposed to treat it as genuine competition. The honor of being selected has meaning to younger players but is an inconvenience to many veterans. It's more celebration than exhibition, which makes it hard to draw a line between basketball and frivolity because there really isn't one.

After seeing "Celebrating 'Revelations' at 50," the film tribute by Judy Kinberg that precedes the piece this season at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Roslyn Sulcas wrote: "It's notable how rough hewn - and powerful - the dancing looks in the historical footage of Ailey and others performing in that work. Today the Ailey dancers are sleek, athletic masters of the universe, and the pieces routinely draw midmovement applause and cheers for moments of virtuosity." The film, which was created especially for the 50th anniversary of the work, features Alvin Ailey and Judith Jamison discussing the history of the seminal piece and its influence on American dance. It will be shown before all performances of the work at New York City Center through Jan. 2. Have you seen "Revelations"? Share your memories about the dance.

In a new exhibition at the Gallery at REDCAT in Los Angeles, the Decolonizing Architecture Art Residency (DAAR) looks at ways to use architecture to investigate and speculate about the future of sites that have been evacuated, or decolonized, by Israel in Palestine's West Bank. DAAR - a Bethlehem-based research studio and residency program led by Alessandro Petti, Sandi Hillal and Eyal Weizman - envisions a "detoured world," in which political, legal and architectural approaches can be employed to reuse both physical and organizational structures in new, and often unorthodox, ways.

One final point on the National Marriage Project report. I've been emphasizing the bad news, but I do think it's genuinely good news that well-educated opinion - as opposed to just well-educated behavior - has been moving in a more conservative direction on divorce. (48 percent of college-educated Americans now agree that "divorce should be more difficult to obtain," up from just 36 percent in the 1970s.) When social conservatives try to envision public policy responses to the crisis of the American family, they're almost inevitably stymied by the fact that our upper class (which is, by extension, our policymaking class), while increasingly conservative in the way its members arrange their own private lives, remains intensely allergic to the kind of legal and cultural paternalism that certain earlier elites practiced as a matter of course. I've suggested before that America would benefit if its upper class showed "a willingness to translate some of the more conservative habits they've embraced (or partially embraced) in their personal lives into law and public policy," but I've never seen much reason for optimism that our elite might actually move in this direction. So the fact that there's been an uptick in college-educated support for reforming divorce laws is better news than I expected - and a sign, perhaps, that the educated class's present mix of private conservatism and public permissiveness isn't set in stone.

A few days ago, I described how a stay-at-home mom named Amy Gottesman built a six-figure party-entertainment business largely via the effective use of Google AdWords and other pay-per-click advertising services. These services allow a company to bid on certain keywords and phrases, and if the bid is high enough a short ad from the company will appear alongside the search results of anyone typing those words into a search engine and on some other Web sites. The business then pays the bid price -- it can be anywhere from pennies to more than a thousand dollars depending on the competition for those words -- every time someone clicks on the ad.

5:51 p.m. | Updated Former President George H.W. Bush, who signed and won Senate approval of the original Start arms control treaty with the Soviet Union in 1991, endorsed the proposed follow-up treaty with Russia on Wednesday, lending another well-known Republican voice to the White House campaign for approval. ''I urge the United States Senate to ratify the Start treaty,'' Mr. Bush said in a one-line statement that offered no elaboration. His spokesman, Jim Appleby, said by telephone that the former president would let his position stand at that and would not discuss whether the White House solicited the endorsement.

Members of the House are likely to have some changes to their routine next year, based on a calendar released Wednesday by Representative Eric Cantor, the soon-to-be House majority leader. The new calendar would keep the House in session for 123 days next year, a number Mr. Cantor says is roughly in line with previous first sessions of a Congress. But, in a letter to colleagues, Mr. Cantor, of Virginia, added that the scheduled number of session weeks - 32 - is an 11 percent drop from past first sessions.

An article on Nov. 17 about the growth of alternative Catholic churches in Belgium, where parishioners worship and share communion without a priest, referred incompletely to the Vatican restriction on who is permitted to celebrate baptism and marriage. The restriction allows ordained church deacons -- not just ordained priests -- to perform such activities.

JERUSALEM -- Israel said on Wednesday that it would allow increased exports from Gaza, the Hamas-run Palestinian enclave, in order to improve the economy and ease hardship. Exports have been almost completely banned since Hamas, the Islamic militant group that won Palestinian elections in 2006, took full control of Gaza in June 2007. Israel eased the blockade on goods going into the area last summer under intense international pressure following its deadly interception of a Gaza-bound aid flotilla from Turkey. Now, Israel says, there has been a 92 percent increase in the number of trucks entering Gaza daily.

An unusual split in the labor movement has developed over President Obama's proposed free-trade pact with South Korea, with two powerful unions backing the deal -- a development that experts say will make Congressional ratification far more likely. The United Automobile Workers are pleased that the agreement will increase auto exports to Korea, and the United Food and Commercial Workers are encouraged that the pact will bolster meat exports to Korea. Both have embraced the deal, which is a modified version of an agreement that President George W. Bush first negotiated in 2007.

CANADA: A FINE FOR DENYING FLIGHT TRAINING The human rights commission in Quebec has fined an aerospace company for denying training to a Canadian of Pakistani origin who the United States had identified as ''threat to aviation or national security.'' In a statement announcing a fine of $315,000 against Bombardier, which is based in Montreal, the commission faulted the company for not consulting Canadian security and transportation agencies. The complainant, Javed Latif, is a professional pilot with 25 years of experience who wanted certification to fly a business jet made by Bombardier. IAN AUSTEN

The curators of a Smithsonian art exhibition that has sparked a firestorm in the last week - first because of the inclusion of a video that included an image of ants crawling on a crucifix, then because of the video's removal from the show - will talk about the show at the New York Public Library next Wednesday. The exhibition, at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington, is titled ''Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture'' and is devoted to representations of homosexual desire in American art. Early last week, after the head of the Catholic League and some House Republicans attacked the show, focusing on a video by the artist David Wojnarowicz that included the crucifix image, partly as a metaphor for the AIDS crisis, the Smithsonian decided to remove the video from the exhibition. That drew accusations of censorship from, among others, one of the show's two curators, Jonathan Katz, a professor at the State University of New York, Buffalo. Mr. Katz told The Buffalo News that he was outraged not to have been consulted, and called the Smithsonian's decision ''incredibly stupid.''

HORN--Herbert, 90, died December 7th, 2010. Beloved husband of Helen, father of Evelyn & Isaac, Larry and Judy, loving "opa" of Ari, Lois and Abby, sister of Rita Rosenthal, son of the late Julie and Ralph Horn. Born in Nuremburg, Germany, active in Jewish youth groups in Germany and Washington Heights. He immigrated to New York 1937, went from Washington Heights to Jackson Heights to Scarsdale. He spent many years at Phillipp Bros, lived for his family, was a professional volunteer supporter of his synagogues (Beth Hillel, Jackson Heights Jewish Center, Temple Israel White Plains), the Conservative movement and Israel. He has been an inspiration to us all and we will continue to uphold his values. We love you so much. Funeral at Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains 10am Thursday December 9th. Contributions can be sent to JNF Emergency Fund or Temple Israel Center, White Plains.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a plan to redevelop the hangar in Los Angeles where Howard Hughes built the Spruce Goose flying boat described the location of the Ballona Wetlands near the hangar incorrectly. The wetlands are west of Lincoln Boulevard, not east of it.

As you may have noticed, we've been writing about Groupon a lot lately. MP Mueller did a post on the experiences of a high-end restaurant in Austin, Tex., and offered some tips. I suggested how you might do the math to assess your Groupon deal (and a smart reader pointed out that I did not fully account for the loss of revenue if your regular customers buy Groupon coupons). In fact, we got lots of smart comments (especially here and here). We also ran several articles when it looked as if Google was going to buy Groupon and another reporting that the founders and owners of Groupon had decided to turn down Google's $6 billion offer. Groupon is a remarkable idea that has been executed remarkably well, but is turning down $6 billion smart 0r insane? In all of our reporting, posting and commenting, we really didn't hear much from one group: the businesses who've used Groupon and were satisfied enough to use it again. Groupon says that more than 95 percent of its merchants want to run another discount. But a study out of Rice University suggests that only 58 percent of Groupon's merchants would want to do it again.

MARX--Nolan J.,M.D. Dearly beloved husband of 60 years to his Jackie. His devotion, passion and interest for his family was never ending. He was loved like no one was ever loved before by his daughters Amy and Donna, and his grandchildren Becky, Haley, Ryan and Skylar. He was our moon, our sun and our earth. His compassion for his patients, friends and family healed us all.

The case study we published last week chronicled the efforts of OfficeDrop, a start-up that scans sensitive documents for its clients and therefore must ensure that employees are trustworthy. The article recounted how Prasad Thammineni, OfficeDrop's chief executive, struggled at first to find the right background-check company and then faced a daunting variety of checks to choose among -- including drug tests, credit checks and criminal checks. After Mr. Thammineni had done his homework and decided on a ''five-point'' bundle with Kroll Background Screening, which checks a variety of federal and local criminal records as well as Social Security numbers and driving history, he thought his job was done. Every new employee, Mr. Thammineni resolved, would be subject to a background check once he or she had accepted a conditional job offer.

FOR the opening of his first store in the United States, Pierre Hardy created a sculptural sandal designed to evoke the Manhattan skyline. It costs an eye-popping $1,540; then again, the platform heels are gold-mirrored. Mr. Hardy's price range starts at $395. (No wonder the designer's wallet-friendly collaboration with Gap, including wedges for $195, sells out in a nanosecond.) The 1,400-square-foot shop is in a former carriage house in the West Village at 30 Jane Street, (646) 449-0070; pierrehardy.com.

The 30-year-old chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, is the newest member of tech's most exclusive club: entrepreneurs who walked away from multibillion-dollar takeover offers. On Friday, Mr. Mason rejected Google's $6 billion bid, according to two people with direct knowledge of the situation. The move quashed the search giant's hope of buying the fast-growing social buying site and put Groupon on track for an eventual public offering. Whether his gamble is a brilliant play or a Friendster fumble - the once promising social network that tumbled after snubbing an offer from Google - remains to be seen. For now, Mr. Mason, who is currently juggling television appearances and managing a recent spike in traffic, seems content with Groupon's trajectory. Mr. Mason spoke with DealBook on Wednesday about his company's prospects, the opportunities in the local advertising market, and why he likes dollhouses. Q.How was Friday? A.What happened on Friday? Haha Friday was a good day.

Six years ago, after leaving a high-powered career in fashion sales to become a stay-at-home mother of very young children, Amy Gottesman found herself missing her income -- and looking for something to do when her kids were napping. So Ms. Gottesman, who lives on Long Island, put up a Web site under the name of Smash Party Entertainment, offering entertainment for parties, ranging from casinos to living Roman ''statues'' to murder mysteries. And then she waited for the business to come in -- which it didn't, even though she was advertising in local newspapers and mailing out coupons. After three months of staring at the phone, she decided to try $20 worth of pay-per-click advertising through Google's AdWords service, which placed her short ads alongside the search results for certain keywords, as well as on some Web pages with content related to those keywords. ''In a few days,'' she said, ''the phone started ringing.''

THE new Ted Baker store in the meatpacking district, the British retailer's second store in Manhattan, resembles something out of a P. G. Wodehouse novel, and the home of a man whose most-cherished goods -- cricket bats, fishing rods and gardening tools -- are in the process of being unpacked by his butler. A cheeky art installation, the décor also includes paneled walls with upholstered leather padding, designed to evoke the inside of a luxury trunk; wooden packing crates that do double duty as display tables; and piles of vintage suitcases (above) that provide a stage set for hats ($85) and scarves ($80 to $90); 34 Little West 12th Street, (212) 647-0991; tedbaker.com.

The headline on a capsule summary on Monday about an arrest in London involving accusations of espionage misidentified the person who was detained. As the summary and the article correctly noted, it was Katia Zatuliveter, a Russian aide to Mike Hancock, a member of the House of Commons; Mr. Hancock was not arrested.

SCHATZ--Belle, December 7, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Michael and his wife Mona and Leslie and her husband Billy. Cherished grandmother of Stacy, Jaime, Mark, Brooke, Noah and Morgan and great-grandmother of Max, Bruce, Jake and Jason. She was an exceptional caring woman who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral Service Thursday, December 9, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City.

The international flair of the Securities and Exchange Commission continued on Wednesday when it filed suit against unnamed investors who bought Wimm-Bill-Dann Foods, in the days before the PepsiCo agreed to buy the Russian beverage maker. As DealBook pointed out last week, the agency increasingly is going global with its insider trading cases.

Mandy Patinkin will return to the New York stage in a production of Rinne Groff's play ''Compulsion'' at the Public Theater in February, the theater announced Tuesday. The play, inspired by the life of the author Meyer Levin, is set in the early 1950s and tells the story of a man named Sid Silver and his quest to write a stage adaptation of ''The Diary of Anne Frank.'' The show, to be directed by Oskar Eustis, the Public's artistic director, is a co-production of the Public, Berkeley Repertory Theater in California, where Mr. Patinkin most recently performed the role, and Yale Repertory Theater, where it premiered earlier this year. The cast also includes Hannah Cabell and Matte Osian, and features puppets by Matt Acheson.

EISENSTEIN--Fannie P.,died on December 4, at the age of 94. Whether as a leader in street protests, gifted teacher, educational administrator, or through the beauty of her written language, Fannie was in the front ranks of those who struggle for a better world. Friends at the UCC, in East New York, Brooklyn, applaud her work in the 1960s and her inspiration and support in ensuing years. Friends of the United Community Centers, Inc.

Within hours of each other Wednesday, the White Sox and the Cubs came to terms with free-agent power-hitting first basemen. Paul Konerko batted .312 last season with 39 home runs and 111 runs batted in. That kept him on the South Side of Chicago with a new three-year, $37.5 million contract. He will play first base for White Sox even though they signed Adam Dunn last week.

The New Republic is getting a new editor in the new year. Richard Just, currently the executive editor, is taking over Jan. 1 from Franklin Foer, who is stepping down after a five-year stint. Mr. Foer, 36, who closed his last issue of the magazine on Tuesday, said, ''I steered the magazine through all sorts of transitions, and I was really aching to do my own writing.'' He signed a contract two weeks ago with HarperCollins to write a book about liberalism's roots in the Progressive era.
SCHATZ--Belle. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Belle who will be remembered with love forever. Charlotte, Iris and Howard, and Poppy and Ronny

STRAUS--Elizabeth Allen. The Board and Staff of The New York Botanical Garden are greatly saddened by the death of our beloved Board member and friend Beth Straus. Beth's involvement with the Garden extended over more than half a century. She championed horticultural excellence, and her vision was transformative. In the late 1980s, she was instrumental in creating the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden and in redesigning the Perennial Garden. She introduced to the Garden some of its most dedicated friends and supporters. Her energy and optimism were treasured and admired. We express our condolences to the Straus family. Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman of the Board Gregory Long, President and CEO Thomas J. Hubbard and Wilson Nolen, Chairmen Emeriti

The trustee seeking to recover money for Bernard L. Madoff's victims has turned his sights to Citigroup and six other banks that offered complicated investment products tied to funds that funneled money to the huge Ponzi scheme. The trustee, Irving H. Picard, filed lawsuits on Wednesday seeking more than $1 billion from the banks. The suits call for $425 million from Citigroup and $400 million from Natixis. He also filed complaints seeking lesser amounts from Merrill Lynch, Fortis, ABN Amro, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria and Nomura.

I got all twitchy (it's a good thing) when I saw the new ''Really?'' ad campaign for Windows Phone 7. It features people carrying on life's routines -- walking, running, playing with children, preparing for bed -- absorbed in their smartphones and missing life as it is happening around them. ''It's time for our phone,'' a narrator intones, ''to save us from our phones.'' The new Windows Phone 7, we are told, is ''designed to get you in and out and back to life'' -- something many small-business owners long for. I'm twitchy for two reasons. First, anytime a really big company makes such a statement, you know it spent a considerable amount of money on market research to understand what consumers want. I really like market research.

NAGOURNEY--Anne Hecht, of Manhattan, died December 4 at the age of 103. A lifelong resident of New York, she retired from a long career teaching high school French and devoted her retirement to world travel with her husband Rove, attending concerts and opera, and reading French, Italian, and Spanish classics. She is survived by daughter Carol Martucci (Nagourney), son Peter Nagourney and daughter-in-law Reena Liberman of Ann Arbor, and grandsons Tal Nagourney and Micah Nagourney.

BLACK--Abraham, 90, formerly of Teaneck, NJ and East Sandwich, MA, died peacefully shortly after his 90th birthday on December 7, 2010. Married 64 years to Eunice (nee Friedland). Proud father of Annette Raphel, Louis Black and Fran Black and cherished grandfather of Aaron, Jordan, Eli, Ian and Cora. Veteran of WW II, accomplished photographer and avid gourmand.

An article last Thursday about two upcoming books that recount Jacqueline Onassis' publishing career misstated the publishing date for one of the books, ''Jackie as Editor'' (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's). Its publication is planned for Jan. 4; it has not been moved up to this month in response to the other book, ''Reading Jackie'' (Nan. A. Talese/Doubleday). (The publication date for ''Reading Jackie'' was moved from early 2011; it was released this past Tuesday.)

The federal government is planning to sell a significant part of its shares in the American International Group - perhaps as much as one-fifth - in the first quarter of 2011 as it begins to unwind its ownership stake, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

SEGALL--Harold Abraham, 92, died on December 8 at home in Scarsdale with his beloved wife, Edith, and other family members at his side. He was partner in Gilbert, Segall and Young (later Holland & Knight) before retiring after 61 years as a lawyer. His many clients included A.C. Nielsen, the Manville Settlement Trust, the NY Governor's Club, the Puerto Rico Government Development Bank, Caribbean Refining and Children's Television Workshop. He mentored many lawyers, wrote legal books and articles, and published countless letters to editors of newspapers and magazines. With typical wit, he wrote, "The Tragedy of Kind Lear resulted from an excess of estate planning." He was a Phi Betta Kappa graduate of Cornell University, and a graduate of Yale Law School, where he was an editor of the Yale law Review. He also taught at Yale Law School, the Yale School of Organization and Management, and Fordham Law School. He was vice president of the Philip D. Reed Foundation, a trustee of SUNY Purchase, and a director of Oneida Knitting, Pierson Pharmaceutical and more. He served on the Board of Governors of Elmwood Country Club. Besides his wife of nearly 60 years, the former Edith Suzanne Besser, he is survived by devoted sons Mark (Karen), Grant (Victoria Belfiglio) and Bruce (Robin Rosenberg); grandchildren Michael, Steven, Rena, Felice, Ruth, David, Anthony and Mario; and a sister, Edna Goldfein. He will be sorely missed. His funeral will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York at Noon on Friday, December 10. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Alzheimer's Association.

MINTZ--Samuel I.,PhD. Professor Emeritus English, CCNY and CUNY Graduate Center, age 87, December 7, 2010. Fulbright Scholar, Guggenheim Fellow. Beloved husband for 63 years of Eleanor (Streichler). Adored father of Joel (Meri-Jane Rochelson) and Jonathan (Robin Kramarow), grandfather of Daniel (Sarah Allison), Serafima, Michael, Sarah and Benjamin. Devoted cousin and friend. Skillful raconteur, lover of classical music, avid sports fan. WWII veteran. Distinguished scholar, superb teacher, kind, warm and generous man. Services today at 12 Noon at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

GREGOR--Lawrence V.,77, of Hopewell Jct., NY died on December 6, 2010 in Poughkeepsie, NY. He was born August 10, 1933 in Spangler, Penn., to the late Andrew Gregor and Anna Palisin. He is survived by wife, Louise; son Andrew Gregor; daughters, Alison Gregor and Ashley Pietras. He is survived by grandchildren, Alex, Max and Grady Pietras and Lily Lam Gregor. Larry is survived by brothers Steve Lobick, Frank Gregor; sisters Mary Marchesano, Emma Silek. Larry received his Ph.D. in chemistry from the University of California, Berkeley in 1960, served as lieutenant in the U.S. Navy, and worked for IBM for three decades. He was awarded over 50 patents and wrote many scientific articles. After retiring in 1991, he taught astronomy and physics at SUNY-New Paltz, Dutchess Community College, and Marist College. Larry was completing an astronomy book dedicated to his grandsons when he passed. Services will be held in Downsville, NY, at the family's discretion.

From our colleague Jenna Wortham, who is attending the D: Dive Into Digital Conference in San Francisco. Google's Nexus One phone may have been a disappointment in the marketplace, but that hasn't stopped the company from taking a hands-on approach with another Android smartphone.

Farewell, Kanye West: Susan Boyle is back at the top of the Billboard album chart. Ms. Boyle's second album, ''The Gift'' (Syco/Columbia), has been out for a month but it's holding strong. Last week it sold 272,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a slight sales gain from the previous week that was enough to bump it up two spots to No. 1. Mr. West's album ''My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy'' (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam) fell six spots to No. 7 with 108,000 sales, a 78 percent drop from its first week.Taylor Swift's ''Speak Now'' (Big Machine) is No. 2 with 182,000, Jackie Evancho's ''O Holy Night'' (Columbia) is No. 3 with 145,000, and the expanding ''Glee'' franchise on Columbia holds down the next two slots: ''The Christmas Album'' is No. 4 with 129,000 sales in its third week out, and ''The Music: Volume 4'' opens at No. 5 with 128,000. ''Glee'' has seven albums in the Top 200, with combined sales of nearly 3.4 million.

THE Gucci children's collection will be introduced today with all its grown-up details intact. The GG pattern is on the boy's tie (far left, $85), the girl's pint-size ballerina flat patent-leather shoes (left, $220) and the boy's driving loafers ($220). The fashionistas-in-training complete their looks with Gucci staples, including a black poplin sleeveless shirt dress with the red-and-green web belt that goes from school to the playground ($195), a navy stretch gabardine double breasted jacket ($465) and red cotton poplin pants ($185). Available at select Gucci stores; (800) 456-7663; gucci.com.

STRAUS--Elizabeth Allen. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the passing of beloved Trustee and friend Beth Straus. Beth served on the Museum's Board of Trustees for over fifty five-years and brought her graceful leadership, keen intelligence, brilliant ideas, and amazing energy to the many committees on which she served and to all that she did for the Museum. Beth and her husband Donald were not only generous philanthropists, but active and passionate collectors of art. Over this extraordinary period Beth also helped build MoMA's renowned permanent collection by giving important works of art to the Museum and by helping with the acquisition of other pieces. We will miss Beth's strong and positive energy and extend our deepest sympathies to her family. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

Is anyone a performance artist anymore? Tim Miller might be one of the last working theater artists to embrace fully the term, already vague to the point of meaninglessness when Eric Bogosian made fun of it in his 1994 slacker drama, ''Suburbia.'' Whatever. Let Mr. Miller call himself whatever he wants. This influential artist, who helped found Performance Space 122 and relentlessly tours the country with his lean, personal and deceptively canny shows, has earned respect -- albeit not as much as is given to him by Tony Kushner, who (jokingly?) compares him to Proust in the introduction to Mr. Miller's book of plays, ''Body Blows.'' His latest solo work, ''Lay of the Land,'' reveals that whether or not he's a performance artist, he plays one charmingly.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about a devastating fire in northern Israel misstated the name of a 77-acre educational residence for young people that was heavily damaged. It is Yemin Orde Youth Village, not Yemin Ord.

An article on Dec. 1 about acute housing problems in India's cities misidentified the publisher of a recent research report that suggested government policies in place for decades had reinforced ''squalid, precarious living conditions in urban slums.'' The report was published by the Policy Research Working Paper Series of the World Bank -- not by the Center for Policy Research and the Centre des Sciences Humaines.
BOLLS--Imogene Ethyl Lamb, 72, a widely published, nationally recognized poet, formally of Springfield, OH, and Taos, NM, died December 4, 2010 in Manhattan, KS.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Marcie Madden Fund at the Fishers Island Library, P.O. Box 366, Fishers Island, NY 06390. For online guestbook gfdoherty.com.

Netflix made big news recently, when it announced that it would offer a streaming-only plan in the United States. As Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, said in a press release, ''We are now primarily a streaming video company delivering a wide selection of TV shows and films over the Internet.'' What he didn't mention is that consumers who prefer to stream their content will learn that just as with cellphones, they'll often have to sacrifice quality to get convenience.

With the start of production drawing closer on his cinematic adaptations of ''The Hobbit,''Peter Jackson has begun reuniting his old gang from his Academy Award-winning ''Lord of the Rings'' movies. On Tuesday, Mr. Jackson announced that Cate Blanchett, who played the elf Galadriel in his film versions of J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Fellowship of the Ring,'' ''The Two Towers'' and ''The Return of the King,'' will reprise that role in his two-part ''Hobbit'' series. In a statement reported at comingsoon.net, Mr. Jackson said Ms. Blanchett was ''one of my favorite actors to work with and I couldn't be more thrilled to have her reprise the role she so beautifully brought to life in the earlier films.'' Also joining the ''Hobbit'' movies are Sylvester McCoy, a star of the British fantasy series ''Doctor Who,'' as the wizard Radagast the Brown, and Ken Stott (''Charlie Wilson's War'') as Balin, a dwarf leader. Martin Freeman (of BBC's ''Sherlock'' and ''The Office'') was previously announced to star in the film as Bilbo Baggins, the title character. Still, no official casting for ''The Hobbit'' has been given on the role of Gandalf, who was portrayed in the ''Lord of the Rings'' movies by Ian McKellen. This shall not pass!
It would be much easier to take good pictures if only you had a tutor to advise you on each shot. To that end, Nikon has built a tutor of sorts into its new digital S.L.R., the D3100.

It's easier to check out some naughty little title online than in a brick-and-mortar store where your pastor could step up in line behind you. BARB PERFETTI, the chief financial officer of All Romance, an online retailer that sells only e-books. [A1]

HONIGFELD--Howard. December 6, 2010. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of our courageous husband, dad, grandfather, leader, mentor and kind friend. A University of Pennsylvania graduate, Howard was the Vice President of KRA Insurance and served on the board of many charities and organizations. Howard was a great "helper" and loved helping everyone he could. From the numerous causes he championed to the countless good deeds he did for individuals, his legacy will live on in the lives he touched. After he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 8++ years ago he became actively involved with the Fighting Children's Cancer Foundation. He simply wanted to give back to children in need. Last spring FCCF established the Howard Honigfeld Scholarship Fund to help cancer survivors attend college. He will greatly be missed by his wife, Lois, children, Marc and Rona Honigfeld, Stacey Honigfeld and Kim and Brian Ashton, stepchildren Billy and Andria Somers and Joseph and Kristin Desimone. Additionally, his grandchildren, Kylie, Mackenna, Emily, Jack, Joseph and Andrew John will forever miss their Papa Howie. We kindly ask that donations in his memory be made to the Fighting Children's Cancer Foundation, Howard Honigfeld Scholarship Fund, 67 Beaver Avenue, Suite 28, Annandale, NJ 08801 or on-line at: www.fccf.info/hhsfund.htm

The word in the philanthropic world is that Bill Gates and Warren E. Buffett are planning to announce 15 more signatories to the Giving Pledge they started last summer, bringing the total number of billionaires and multimillionaires committed to giving away at least half their wealth to 65. A spokesman for Mr. Gates declined to comment on his plans, answering a question about whether to expect an announcement on Thursday with this e-mail message: ''We are hoping to pull together an announcement of new pledge takers, and we'll make sure you get whatever goes out when we make the announcement.'' Speculating about whose names might be added to the list - and whose names were absent the first time around - has become a sort of party game in certain circles. Currently, three Steves - Steve Jobs, Steve Cohen and Steve Schwarzman - are among the most hotly anticipated additions, as are any of member of the Tisch and Walton families, Oprah Winfrey, Steve Ballmer and David Geffen. The pledge has not been without controversy. Some critics have branded it a publicity stunt, while others have noted that many of those signing have already given away a great deal of their wealth. Whatever its significance, though, it has sparked a worldwide discussion of philanthropy, which was in many ways its goal. ''The real value of this at this stage is in serving as a role model, inspiring, leading the way,'' said Salvatore LaSpada, chief executive of the Institute for Philanthropy, a philanthropic advisory firm. ''It is really important in validating philanthropy as a worthy pursuit.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BEIJING -- It was just before Christmas 2009, and Ding Xiaowen was not happy. The United States ambassador had just written China's foreign minister expressing concern for Liu Xiaobo, the Beijing intellectual imprisoned a year earlier for drafting a pro-democracy manifesto. Now Mr. Ding, a deputy in the ministry's American section, was reading the riot act to an American attaché.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about questions raised by the Philadelphia History Museum's sale of more than 2,000 items misstated the role of Janet C. Marstine at the Institute of Museum Ethics at Seton Hall University. Ms. Marstine, who commented on the need for some museums to pare their collections, was a founding director of the institute, not the founder and current director. (She is now a lecturer and program director at the University of Leicester.)

An article on Saturday about a new film version of ''True Grit'' misspelled the surname of a critic for The New Republic who wrote about the ''True Grit'' film released in 1969. He is Stanley Kauffmann, not Kaufman.

With Kelsey Grammer preparing to depart the Broadway production of ''La Cage aux Folles'' in February, is there another television star who can bring to the role of Georges an equal level of erudition and dignity that's begging to be chipped away? Hey now! It turns out there is. Jeffrey Tambor, who played the self-absorbed sidekick Hank Kingsley on ''The Larry Sanders Show'' and, after that, the fatuous Bluth family patriarch on ''Arrested Development,'' will take over the part of Georges beginning Feb. 15, press representatives for ''La Cage aux Folles'' said on Wednesday. Harvey Fierstein, the book writer of ''La Cage,'' was previously announced to take over the role of Albin from Douglas Hodge on that same date.

MASON, Ohio -- For more than a decade, some of the nation's shrewdest marketers have tried to muscle in on the neighborhood dry cleaner, only to give up after years of labor and millions of dollars in investments. Undeterred, Procter & Gamble is taking a shot at it, again. Having persuaded Americans to buy synthetic laundry detergent, fluorinated toothpaste and disposable diapers, P.& G. believes it has finally cracked the code on the dry cleaning business, too.

Even as Wall Street prepares to hand out rich year-end bonuses, one firm, Morgan Stanley, is mapping out a plan to reduce the pay of some of its senior executives, according to people with knowledge of the plan. The effort to rein in compensation in the management ranks - while still rewarding its top traders and bankers - is one way that Morgan Stanley is coming to grips with a quandary that has plagued it for a year.

At the end of this week's Fixes column on ESOP, an organization in Ohio that helps prevent foreclosures, I promised to share some stories of homeowners' experiences. I also asked readers to write in with their own mortgage tales. Many did. The stories illustrate why trusted, nonprofit, third-party intermediaries like ESOP, which know how to communicate productively with both homeowners and lenders - and are committed to finding solutions - are needed to ease the housing crisis. Even better, a few readers offered suggestions about how to avoid this problem in the future.

In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias they had warfare, terror, murder and bloodshed, but they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, and the Renaissance. In Switzerland they had brotherly love -- they had 500 years of democracy and peace, and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock.

The debate over United States immigration policy in recent years has been in equal parts tortuous and ineffectual. And one interested party had for the most part been relegated to the fringes: the hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who were born abroad but brought to America when they were children. Claimed by neither their parents' homelands nor the nation they grew up in, unable to work legally here, they exist in a curious limbo.

Peter C. Marzio, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, for the last 28 years, died this morning of cancer, the museum announced. He was 67. During his tenure, the museum's attendance increased from 380,000 people annually to over 2 million, and its endowment grew from $25 million to over $700 million. A full obituary will follow.

With the recent deal to extend the Bush tax cuts, cut payroll taxes and extend unemployment benefits, it may seem like Washington does not care quite as much about the deficit as some politicians have let on. The Minnesota Timberwolves are, by most measures, a perfectly abysmal basketball team. Only one N.B.A. squad currently boasts an inferior record to the lowly Wolves, and a deeper look into Minnesota's performance doesn't yield a rosier outlook. If teams exist in this league solely for the purpose of winning games, then the very existence of the Timberwolves franchise is an abject failure. It takes a unique brand of incompetence to build a roster this incapable, and in that regard, Minnesota is impressive in their impotence.

The ownership of Bob Dylan's handwritten lyrics to "The Times They Are a-Changin'" will soon be a-changin' hands: on Friday, a weathered sheet of ruled paper on which Mr. Dylan scrawled most of the verses to that classic protest song were sold at an auction for $422,500, a representative for Sotheby's said. The auction house said the winning bid, which includes the house's commission, was made by Adam Sender, whom it identified as an American collector; he is also a hedge fund trader whose office is home to works by Ed Ruscha, Kara Walker and John Currin, according to a recent report by Bloomberg News. Mr. Sender took part in the auction by phone and outbid three other contenders to claim his trophy, which Sotheby's expected to fetch $200,000 to $300,000. With this lot Mr. Sender does not receive the verse that begins, "Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen," which Mr. Dylan apparently added later, nor does he own the 1960s, which belong to everyone, man.

Dresses that fit like an embrace are nothing new. Dresses that show the imprint of every embrace, however, are far more unusual. We know of only one - this liquid blue "Science of Sequin" frock from the spring collection of Boudicca, the London-based label designed by Zowie Broach and Brian Kirkby. Run a hand over the sequins and they flip over, revealing a paler underside; if the path of the caress is retraced, they return to their original position. The idea of making a garment that recorded touch was, says Broach, "seductive as soon we came across the fabric. It immediately inspired your sense of imagination and play." Only six dresses were made, and they arrive in stores this week, just in time for the holiday cocktail circuit. "What would be amazing," Kirkby says, "would be to know where they finally end up. But something as unique as this is possibly best a secret that takes its own time to tell."

In "Rabbit Hole," Nicole Kidman and Aaron Eckhart play grieving parents dealing with the accidental death of their four-year-old son. The film, adapted by David Lindsey-Abaire from his Pulitzer Prize-winning play, was "a passion project for Nicole," Mr. Eckhart said last year, when they were filming in Douglaston, Queens. It was the first movie from her production company, Blossom Films, and, as a producer, Ms. Kidman made an unorthodox choice for director in John Cameron Mitchell ("Hedwig and the Angry Inch"), who had never before directed a movie he didn't write. "Rabbit Hole" was made for about $4 million, and eventually bought for distribution by Lionsgate. It opens Dec. 17 in limited release. In a wide-ranging interview in a SoHo hotel room recently, Ms. Kidman and Mr. Mitchell spoke about the constraints of indie filmmaking, their childhood and adult inspirations. This is an edited version of their conversation.

As everyone knows by now, Mick Jagger's foibles and flaws are on display in Keith Richards's autobiography, "Life." (Mick's harp playing receives the highest marks from Keith, but that's pretty much it as far as unqualified praise goes.) Jagger comes off considerably better in "The Sixties," the second volume of Christopher Isherwood's diaries. Isherwood describes meeting Jagger in the Australian outback, where he was filming "Ned Kelly": "Mick Jagger, very pale, quiet, good-tempered, full of fun, ugly-beautiful, a bit like Beatrix Lehmann; he has the air of a castaway, someone saved from a wreck, but not in the least dismayed by it."

In the early 16th century, as Italian Renaissance masters worked for their Papal patrons in Rome, Lucas Cranach the Elder was honing a bold and innovative style of his own in Wittenburg, Germany, birthplace of the Protestant Reformation. His close personal and professional relationship with Martin Luther placed him firmly at odds with the politics and theology of Italy, and his work was divorced from the classicism of the Italian Renaissance. Embracing a unique blend of Flemish and German iconography - though one not completely devoid of Italian influence - Lucas Cranach the Elder pioneered his own Renaissance aesthetic.

The opening ceremony for the World Festival of Black Arts and Cultures, which runs from Friday through Dec. 31 in Dakar, Senegal, will feature performances by Angelique Kidjo, Youssou N'Dour, Carlinhos Brown and the Mahotella Queens. ''The first festival in 1966 in Dakar, Senegal, was to make a statement about the newly independent African states,'' said Kwame Kwei-Armah, a British playwright and actor who is the festival's artistic director. ''This is the third one, and the theme of this festival is the African Renaissance. It's about the Africa we want to create for tomorrow. It's about artists across disciplines talking about the future of their art form.''

The reports appeared on Wednesday, not last Friday. (The Philippines has since reversed its decision.)

Leah Abraham opened her cafe on Lenox Avenue in 2001 with a track record in business and a determination to chalk up another success. It never occurred to her to court the local elected officials and business and church leaders -- the Harlem establishment -- and get their blessing before she opened her door. ''I never felt that I had to ask for permission or that I had to wait my turn,'' said Ms. Abraham, owner of Settepani, a cafe and restaurant on Lenox Avenue near West 120th Street. ''I have done whatever I wanted to do despite anyone's blessing.''

The life and work of Ernest Hemingway have been notoriously difficult to translate comfortably onto the screen. For one thing, his signature spare sentences, when spoken by actors, often sound as affected as the most rococo effusions of Oscar Wilde. Beyond that, Hemingway's chest-beating, rifle-bearing Papa Bear explorer persona seems overbearingly pompous if not creepily antediluvian in these postfeminist times. For all the cinematic crimes against him, there has been no book-to-screen translation of his work quite as atrocious as ''Hemingway's Garden of Eden,'' directed by John Irvin from a screenplay by James Scott Linville. An adaptation of Hemingway's problematic erotic novel, ''The Garden of Eden,'' posthumously published in 1986, it stars Mena Suvari as the meanest mean girl (pun intended) to spit venom in any film since I don't know when.

STRAUS--Elizabeth Allen. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the passing of beloved Trustee and friend Beth Straus. Beth served on the Museum's Board of Trustees for over fifty five-years and brought her graceful leadership, keen intelligence, brilliant ideas, and amazing energy to the many committees on which she served and to all that she did for the Museum. Beth and her husband Donald were not only generous philanthropists, but active and passionate collectors of art. Over this extraordinary period Beth also helped build MoMA's renowned permanent collection by giving important works of art to the Museum and by helping with the acquisition of other pieces. We will miss Beth's strong and positive energy and extend our deepest sympathies to her family. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

7:40 p.m. | Updated Dell may have lost the fight over 3Par, but it has found a consolation prize in another data storage company: Compellent Technologies. The two companies announced on Thursday that Dell was in talks to buy Compellent for $27.50 a share. The proposed deal is effectively a take-under, with a bid that is 18.3 percent below Compellent's closing price on Wednesday of $33.65.

For most of the past four years, Richard A. Falkenrath's job was helping to protect New York City against possible terror strikes. Now, he is defending his block in Riverdale in the Bronx against the Jewish academy next door, making his case at the local community board - and invoking his terror-fighting past in the process. Mr. Falkenrath, 41, says he is frustrated by the traffic congestion caused by the academy, the Salanter Akiba Riverdale Academy, and also by its plans to alter the property, which include building a trash storage shed.

PARIS -- For many Europeans, Washington's fierce reaction to the flood of secret diplomatic cables released by WikiLeaks displays imperial arrogance and hypocrisy, indicating a post-9/11 obsession with secrecy that contradicts American principles. While the Obama administration has done nothing in the courts to block the publication of any of the leaked documents, or even, as of yet, tried to indict the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, for any crime, American officials and politicians have been widely condemned in the European news media for calling the leaks everything from ''terrorism'' (Representative Peter T. King, Republican of New York) to ''an attack against the international community'' (Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton). Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates called the arrest of Mr. Assange on separate rape charges ''good news.'' Sarah Palin called for him to be hunted as an ''anti-American operative with blood on his hands,'' and Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor and Republican presidential candidate, said that whoever leaked the cables should be executed.

An obituary on Monday about the architect and artist John Diebboll described incorrectly the architect Michael Graves, for whom Mr. Diebboll worked as a principal designer for many years. He is considered a postmodernist; while he had once been ''known for his allegiance to a purist form of modernism,'' he no longer was by the time Mr. Diebboll joined his firm in 1984.

BERLIN -- Germany is determined to defend the euro as a political project that glues Europe together, its foreign minister said Thursday, dismissing euro bonds or other devices as a way to shore up the common currency. Europeans -- and not just Germans -- understand that only solid economies are able to support the currency, the foreign minister, Guido Westerwelle, said.

WILKER--Midge Kramer, of New York City and Great River, New York. She will be greatly missed by her husband, Jay Wilker, her siblings, Rita Titus, Jeanne Daly, Jack Kramer, Suzy Glynn and the late Billy Kramer and their respective spouses, Jay, Don, Eileen, Jamie and Mary Lynn; her sister and brother-in-law Mary and Chris Wilker and their respective spouses Tom and Debbie; her nieces and nephews Tom, Meg, Amy, John, Jim, Don, Mark, Caroline, Chris, Kelly, John, Janet, Maureen, Linda, Beth, Joanne, Lynore, Billy, Matt, Jimmy, Michael, Jack, Jeanne, Margy, Felicity, Sara, Annie and their spouses. She is survived by 66 great-nieces and nephews and two great-great-nephews. A memorial mass will be held at 11:00am on December 13, 2010, at St. Ignatius Loyola Church at 980 Park Avenue. Midge graduated from Newton College of Sacred Heart in Boston with a B.S. in Mathematics in 1966. During her professional career she worked for IBM, retiring as Senior Manager in 1992. She then joined Quantum Consulting Group, during which she managed numerous consulting engagements across the globe. Midge's intellect, friendship, guidance and fabulous humor will be missed by her family and countless friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Ignatius Loyola Church at 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10028 or VNSNY Care, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY 10001.

In fact, that 2000-1 season was the last time the Knicks were five games over .500 after their first 23 games. What has made the difference for New York this season?

A senior Chinese official met on Thursday with Kim Jong-il, the North Korean leader, and they came to some consensus about the crisis on the Korean Peninsula, according to Xinhua, China's official news agency. The agency gave few details about the meeting or the consensus but said that one of China's top diplomats, Dai Bingguo, had candid talks with Mr. Kim in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang. The visit came after the United States had asked China to exert pressure on North Korea after the North's artillery attack last month on a South Korean island.

MIAMI BEACH -- When Rony Seikaly was a young teenager in Athens, long before he grew into a 6-foot-11 all-American basketball player at Syracuse and a productive N.B.A. center, he built a small disco at home. ''I took a garage and turned it into my own little club,'' said Seikaly, now 45. ''I would save up money and I bought the record player, then a second record player, then a mixer. I built the whole disco myself, all the electricity, and I built all these kinds of colored lights and colored bulbs, and I'd make, like, a light show. I did that all myself.''

Wesley Snipes, a star of films including ''White Men Can't Jump'' and the ''Blade'' series, arrived on Thursday at a federal prison in Pennsylvania to begin serving a sentence for three misdemeanor tax convictions, the Department of Justice said. Mr. Snipes was given a three-year sentence in 2008 after a court in Ocala, Fla., found that he had willfully failed to file tax returns for 1999 to 2004, a period in which he earned more than $38 million. An appeal by the actor, in which he asked for a change of venue to New York from Florida and said he should have been considered for probation, was denied in July. Traci Billingsley, the chief public information officer for the Bureau of Prisons, said that Mr. Snipes surrendered before noon at Federal Correctional Institution-McKean, a medium-security site in northwest Pennsylvania with a satellite minimum-security prison.

Proving conclusively that a discussion of art with Steve Martin can be funny and entertaining, Stephen Colbert devoted a portion of his ''Colbert Report'' on Wednesday night to an erudite exercise with Mr. Martin, the art collector, ''Object of Beauty'' author and occasional adversary of the 92nd Street Y. After an interview with Mr. Colbert in which Mr. Martin was tested on his artistic acumen (among other tasks, he was asked to distinguish between an Ellsworth Kelly painting and a Sherwin-Williams swatch), he was called upon to determine the value of a portrait of Mr. Colbert. Mr. Martin initially placed its worth at about $19 (''if I wanted it,'' he said), at which point the artists Frank Stella, Shepard Fairey and Andres Serrano came out one by one to evaluate and/or modify the painting. Mr. Fairey added his telltale ''Obey'' logo and Mr. Serrano drew a Hitleresque mustache on Mr. Colbert's likeness. Mr. Stella contributed this philosophical remark: ''If you want to look at art, you can find it.''

The Commodities Futures Trading Commission wants to limit banks' campaign donations - but similar rules already exist. The regulator on Thursday introduced a plan to prohibit banks from making some campaign contributions in states and towns where they have derivatives business. The C.F.T.C is aiming to curb any undue influence Wall Street might exert on officials who can steer business to banks.

7 P.M. (USA) CHARACTERS UNITE SPECIAL: TOM BROKAW PRESENTS BRIDGING THE DIVIDE Nearly 50 years after the beginning of the civil rights movement in the United States, what is the status of racism, religious freedom, equality for women, gay rights, access for people with disabilities and bullying among children? Mr. Brokaw addresses that wide-ranging question as he investigates the impact of the economy, social media and the 24-hour news cycle on the nation's increasingly diverse population. He also speaks with ''champions of change,'' including Yvonne and Rich Dutra-St. John, who teach schoolchildren to see similarities rather than differences among people; Luma Mufleh, above with Mr. Brokaw, who unites children from war-torn countries through soccer; and Aimee Mullins, a double amputee and fashion model working to reshape notions of beauty and opportunity. 8 P.M. (FMC) FOX LEGACY WITH TOM ROTHMAN Mr. Rothman, a chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, analyzes the making of ''Cleopatra'' (1963), starring Elizabeth Taylor in the title role, Richard Burton as Mark Antony and Rex Harrison as Julius Caesar. MasterCard said on Thursday that it would buy the prepaid card operations of the British currency exchange company Travelex for 290 million ($458 million), pushing into foreign markets. An additional $55 million will be paid if the unit hits performance goals.

David Boies has had a big week in California. On Monday, he argued in support of same-sex marriage in the state's pitched legal battle over Proposition 8. On Tuesday, a judge awarded his client Jamie McCourt a victory in her divorce war with her former husband over the ownership of the Los Angeles Dodgers. But as those triumphant events unfolded out west, a sanctions motion was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan against his firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner, accusing it of ''egregious misconduct'' and ''gross negligence.''

SEGALL--Harold Abraham, 92, died on December 8 at home in Scarsdale with his beloved wife, Edith, and other family members at his side. He was partner in Gilbert, Segall and Young (later Holland & Knight) before retiring after 61 years as a lawyer. His many clients included A.C. Nielsen, the Manville Settlement Trust, the NY Governor's Club, the Puerto Rico Government Development Bank, Caribbean Refining and Children's Television Workshop. He mentored many lawyers, wrote legal books and articles, and published countless letters to editors of newspapers and magazines. With typical wit, he wrote, "The Tragedy of Kind Lear resulted from an excess of estate planning." He was a Phi Betta Kappa graduate of Cornell University, and a graduate of Yale Law School, where he was an editor of the Yale law Review. He also taught at Yale Law School, the Yale School of Organization and Management, and Fordham Law School. He was vice president of the Philip D. Reed Foundation, a trustee of SUNY Purchase, and a director of Oneida Knitting, Pierson Pharmaceutical and more. He served on the Board of Governors of Elmwood Country Club. Besides his wife of nearly 60 years, the former Edith Suzanne Besser, he is survived by devoted sons Mark (Karen), Grant (Victoria Belfiglio) and Bruce (Robin Rosenberg); grandchildren Michael, Steven, Rena, Felice, Ruth, David, Anthony and Mario; and a sister, Edna Goldfein. He will be sorely missed. His funeral will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York at Noon on Friday, December 10. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Alzheimer's Association.

COHEN--Martin H.,born in Brooklyn, New York on April 17, 1932, passed away on December 8, 2010. Martin attended Brooklyn Technical High School, Cooper Union and MIT's School of Architecture. He married Arline Sitner in 1956 and spent the first 25 years of his career with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in New York. He was a consultant for decades to owners, architects, and developers working on more than 160 health care facilities and senior living projects. Martin enjoyed classical music, opera, telling stories and spending time with his grandchildren. Martin is survived by his wife of 54 years Arline, his sons Bruce, Paul and Adam, his grandchildren Carolyn, Katelyn, Alyson, Lucas and Aiden, his sister Sara and many other loving family members, friends and colleagues. Funeral services are scheduled for Bet Torah, 60 Smith Avenue, Mount Kisco, NY on Sunday, December 12, 2010 at 10:30am with family and friends gathering at 9:30am.

PARIS - PPR, the French luxury giant, is close to a sale of its Conforama furniture unit to Steinhoff International Holdings, the companies said Thursday. Some market participants have linked the deal to a possible bid for the Burberry Group. The companies are holding exclusive talks for the sale of 100 percent of Conforama, which operates 241 stores in Europe. The price could be as high as 1.2 billion euros ($1.6 billion). Conforama had sales of 2.9 billion euros last year.
