An article on Thursday about Procter & Gamble's opening of a dry cleaning chain under the name of its Tide detergent brand described imprecisely the cleaning method it uses. While the ''Green Earth'' technology used at Tide Dry Cleaners is marketed as being environmentally better than perchloroethylene, a common dry cleaning solvent that is a likely carcinogen, it is not necessarily ''environmentally benign.'' (Some studies have found that silicone-based dry cleaning solvents like Green Earth persist in the environment in detectable amounts and have produced cancer in laboratory rats.)

STRAUS--Elizabeth Allen. It is with great sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of Mrs. Donald B. Straus. Beth was a beloved member of the International Council since 1958, and a MoMA Trustee since 1959. She served as Council President from 1966 1971, and later as President Emerita, Vice Chairman, and Treasurer.We will all remember with deep fondness her keen intelligence, great wisdom, kindness, and her wonderful sense of humor. We send our profoundest sympathy to her three children David Straus, Robert Straus, and Sara Byruck; her six grandchildren Sara, Rebecca, Lisa, Drew, Mischa, and Chloe; and their families. TWO years ago Ed Schmidt, a New York playwright, got word that his father was near death in upstate New York. He bundled his family into the car and drove north, explaining to his young children on the way the sad fact that Grandpa might not recognize them when they got there. As it happened, they arrived minutes too late; Willie Schmidt, a former history teacher and camp director, had died, probably as they were parking the car. That night, seeking solace, the younger Mr. Schmidt read the final act of his favorite American play, Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town.'' That's the one in which Emily Webb, a woman who has died far too young, revisits her family kitchen on the morning of her 12th birthday and discovers the agonizing truth about how little value people place on the quotidian moments of their lives.

The Broadway play ''Time Stands Still,'' starring Laura Linney, Brian d'Arcy James, Eric Bogosian and Christina Ricci, will close on Sunday, Jan. 30, at the Cort Theater. Donald Margulies's drama, about a photographer (Ms. Linney) who returns to her home in New York after being injured while covering the war in Iraq, originally opened in January at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater with Ms. Linney, Mr. d'Arcy James, Mr. Bogosian and Alicia Silverstone in the cast. After taking the summer off, it reopened at the Cort in October, with Christina Ricci replacing Ms. Silverstone.

A new poll from Marist University is suggestive of a potential worst-case scenario for President Obama. As he endures criticism from his left over his handling of the tax policy debate with Republicans, his approval rating has declined among liberals, according to the poll: 69 percent of them now approve of his job performance as compared with 78 percent in November. Likewise, his approval rating has declined among Democrats: to 74 percent from 83 percent. However, there has been no comparable improvement in Mr. Obama's standing among independents.

The ownership of Bob Dylan's handwritten lyrics to ''The Times They Are a-Changin''' will soon be a-changin' hands: on Friday, a weathered sheet of ruled paper on which Mr. Dylan scrawled most of the verses to that classic protest song were sold at an auction for $422,500, a representative for Sotheby's said. The auction house said the winning bid, which includes the house's commission, was made by Adam Sender, whom it identified as an American collector; he is also a hedge fund trader whose office is home to works by Ed Ruscha, Kara Walker and John Currin, according to a recent report by Bloomberg News. Mr. Sender took part in the auction by phone and outbid three other contenders to claim his trophy, which Sotheby's expected to fetch $200,000 to $300,000. With this lot Mr. Sender does not receive the verse that begins, ''Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen,'' which Mr. Dylan apparently added later, nor does he own the 1960s, which belong to everyone, man. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

7:52 p.m. | Updated Occidental Petroleum agreed on Friday to buy oil properties in South Texas and North Dakota for $3.2 billion, further fueling the acquisition frenzy in the energy sector. The deal came the same day the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, or Sinopec, agreed to buy Occidental's Argentine oil and gas business for about $2.5 billion. Occidental also bought an additional 13 percent stake in Plains All-American, one of the largest pipeline operators in the United States, bringing its holdings to 35 percent.

8:16 p.m. | Updated The case that put a spotlight on the world of ultra-fast, computer-driven trading of stocks has ended in a conviction. Sergey Aleynikov, a 40-year-old former Goldman Sachs programmer, was found guilty on Friday by a federal jury in Manhattan of stealing proprietary source code from the bank's high-frequency trading platform. He was convicted on two counts - theft of trade secrets and transportation of stolen property - and faces up to 10 years in prison.

The movement to equalize health benefits among gay employees with domestic partners continues to pick up speed. As it stands now, gay workers who are fortunate enough to work for employers that extend health insurance to domestic partners are still at a disadvantage because they are taxed on the value of that coverage -- a tax that is not paid by the heterosexual married person in the next cubicle.

An article on Thursday about the backing of the United Automobile Workers and the United Food and Commercial Workers for a free-trade pact with South Korea misstated the amount of American exports to South Korea in the first nine months of this year. It was $28.9 billion, not million.

The Social Security Administration published new rules this week that limit the ability of Social Security recipients to essentially receive interest-free loans from the agency. The rules took effect immediately. Under the old policy, people who decided to take their Social Security benefits early could change their mind at any time and withdraw their application for benefits, as long as they repaid the full amount of the benefits received, with no interest charged on the money. They could then also reapply for benefits later on and receive higher benefits.

Noon (BBC America) A ROYAL ENGAGEMENT The network celebrates the coming nuptials of Prince William and Kate Middleton, above in St. James Palace, with a day of royal programming, starting with ''Art of Diana,'' an exploration of the life and philanthropic work of William's mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, who died in 1997. It continues with ''All the Queen's Horses,'' at 1, which visits the annual Royal Windsor Horse Show alongside Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip. ''Memories of a Queen,'' at 2, chronicles the queen's life as princess, wife and monarch, including her Golden Jubilee and her 80th-birthday meeting with President Obama. ''William and Harry: The Brother Princes,'' at 3, follows the siblings to Africa, where they speak about their charity work and their familial bond. And in ''William & Kate: Modern Monarchy,'' at 3:30, Katty Kay chronicles the history of Prince William and Ms. Middleton's relationship and what the future holds for the couple. The British historian Simon Schama also weighs in. The tribute wraps up at 8 with ''The Queen'' (2006), the semiautobiographical drama directed by Stephen Frears, in which Queen Elizabeth II (Helen Mirren, in her Oscar-winning performance) and Tony Blair (Michael Sheen) struggle with the death of Diana. 10:30 A.M. (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND The First Amendment lawyers Floyd Abrams and Burt Neuborne debate, vigorously, the Supreme Court's controversial Citizens United decision, which lifted restrictions on corporate and union spending in elections.

It was 24 degrees at 10 p.m. on Thursday, but Semira Abdella seemed colder, her teeth clacking as she and a friend stood in their skates at the lip of the ice rink in Central Park. ''There's none of these ice things.''

It is the ruling party, not the opposition party.

The drug company Pfizer is withdrawing the blood pressure drug Thelin from Europe, Canada and Australia and halting clinical trials it was conducting in a years-long quest to gain approval in the United States, the company said on Friday. Thelin, a treatment for severe pulmonary arterial hypertension, can cause life-threatening liver problems, Pfizer said after two patients died in a clinical trial.

Cinthia Marcelle, a Brazilian artist who makes films, photographs and installations, is the winner of the first Future Generation Art Prize, it was announced in an award ceremony in Kiev, Ukraine, on Friday. The new biannual $100,000 award is given to an artist 35 or younger by the Victor Pinchuk Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded in 2006 by its namesake, the Ukrainian billionaire and art collector. Ms. Marcelle, who was 35 when she applied for the prize and has since turned 36, submitted three films that are on view, along with submissions of the 20 other finalists, at the Pinchuk Art Center in Kiev through Jan. 9. Her work uses repetition as an artistic tool, becoming like abstract manifestos ''as political as they are economic, reflecting subversively on social behavior and social structures,'' the catalog said.

SOLOMON--Sylvia. It is with deep sadness that we say goodbye to our Grandmother, Sylvia Solomon. But as we grieve, we also celebrate a life well lived. You will forever be in our hearts, and we will miss you. Rest well, Grandma. Love, Ken, Tammy, Crystal, Brittany, and Josh

SKLOOT--Martha, 96, died Thursday, December 9, 2010. Devoted wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Widow of George Skloot. Survived by loving children Phylis (Michael) Bamberger, Edward (Suzanne) Skloot, and Robert (JoAnn) Skloot; grandchildren Kenneth (Sara) Bamberger, Richard (Kristin) Bamberger, Joseph (Erin) Skloot, Sarah Skloot and Jules (Marielle) Skloot; great-grandchildren Max, Isaiah, Niva, Ezra, Madeleine, Ella, Quinn and Emma. Funeral services: Sunday, 11:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 91st St.

ONE by one, the venerable institutions of old Coney Island are vanishing. Ruby's, the last of the boardwalk-facing bars, has served its final drink; Shoot the Freak, one of the most popular game booths, won't reopen in the spring. And this week, demolition began on the Shore Hotel, pictured below. It's all part of a development plan to replace the area's old (and historic) buildings with retail stores and entertainment facilities. In addition to the Shore, destruction is imminent for a number of other structures, as local preservationists have run out of options in court. Below are some sights that will soon be just memories. THE SHORE HOTEL

KAPLAN--Emma Nogrady. Died in Northampton, MA, December 4, at 99. Wife of the late Sidney Kaplan, mother of Cora and Paul, grandmother of Jake Lushington and Danny Kaplan. She grew up in Astoria, Queens, and worked as a social worker, and then reference librarian at Smith College. A political activist in the causes of labor rights, peace, and civil rights, she was also a researcher, and co-author with her husband of The Black Presence in the Era of the American Revolution (1989). A Memorial event is planned for the spring.

An article on Friday about geocaching, an activity in which people use global positioning system devices to find hidden objects, misstated the term some enthusiasts use for nonplayers in the vicinity of their searches. It is ''muggles'' -- the word in the Harry Potter books for nonmagicians -- not ''muddles.''

LUCA--Sergiu. The musicians, staff and board of Chamber Music Northwest mourn the loss of Sergiu Luca, founder of our organization and its music director 1971-1980. His pioneering vision, creativity and sense of adventure launched a summer festival that has attracted leading performers, ensembles and composers ever since to Portland. We honor his legacy by sharing his passion for chamber music. Linda Magee, Executive Dir. David Shifrin, Artistic Director

A report in the Antiques column on Friday about Louisiana furniture omitted one of the main authors of the book ''Furnishing Louisiana: Creole and Acadian Furniture, 1735-1835.'' Besides Jack D. Holden and H. Parrott Bacot, Cybèle T. Gontar also helped write it.

Antoine Antoniol/Bloomberg NewsSamir Assaf HSBC said Friday that it had named Samir Assaf as head of its global banking and markets business, in a second round of senior management appointments ahead of Stuart Gulliver's taking on the role of chief executive next month.

Rachel Bonds seems to know something about loss. Her play ''Anniversary,'' about a woman trying to find herself again after the death of a loved one, was a standout of the Ensemble Studio Theater's one-act festival last June, and now ''Michael & Edie'' is proving that Ms. Bonds can sustain the sublime tone of the earlier play in a full-length piece. Michael (Matthew Micucci) is a new employee at a messy bookstore, and upon arriving for his first day of work he is immediately taken with Edie (Stephanie Wright Thompson), a co-worker with an unrelenting ache about her. The play, staged by the Greenpoint Division at Access Theater, follows Michael's overeager, starry-eyed attempts to initiate a relationship and Edie's anguish over her inability to warm to him.

An article on Friday about Andrew M. Cuomo's tax filings, using information from redacted tax returns he released on Thursday, misstated his official residence for tax purposes. While Mr. Cuomo does pay the income tax surcharge that all full-time New York City residents pay, aides said his full tax returns list his residence in Mount Kisco as his primary address -- not the rental apartment he occasionally occupies in Lower Manhattan. The article also described incorrectly, in some editions, Mr. Cuomo's investment income. He reported a capital gain of $28,211 on investments, not a capital loss of that amount.

The output of Taylor Swift has been known to elicit all sortsof reactions; in the case of the pop artist Peter Max it has inspired him to create this latest work (at right) in a series of paintings based on Ms. Swift's album covers. Mr. Max, whose psychedelic work has graced several presidential libraries as well as the 10-cent stamp for Expo '74, previously created four portraits based on Ms. Swift's 2008 album, ''Fearless,'' (including one that can be seen here) before setting his sights on her 2010 release, ''Speak Now.'' Representatives for Ms. Swift said in a statement that the singer ''was thrilled when she learned of Max's interest in doing the portrait, as she is a lifelong fan of his, having often seen his work on display in the Ocean Gallery in Stone Harbor, N.J.'' The statement added that Ms. Swift ''remembered walking past the gallery window many times as a child and young teen, and was often stopped in her tracks by the vibrancy of Max's works.''

KESTENBAUM--Judith. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Lisa Messinger, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus

What were the odds? The answer to a puzzle on Tuesday titled ''Frankie the Fixer'' misstated the number of rolls of a pair of dice Frankie should bet on it taking to throw double-sixes, if his skill adds 1 percent to each roll's chance. It is 18 rolls, not 16.

NEWMYER--James Morton. On Friday, December 10, 2010, peacefully at home in Washington, DC at the age of 91, after a brief illness. Adored husband of Virginia (Ginger), beloved father of Elsa Newmyer (Larry Forrester), Lory Newmyer (Stephen Cooper), and daughter-in-law Deborah Jelin Newmyer. He was predeceased by his wonderful son Robert in 2005. He is survived by nine loving grandchildren, Emma and Daniel Forrester, Julia, James, and Anna Cooper, and Sofi, Theodore, James, and Billi Newmyer. Also surviving are his nephews Charles G. Hutzler IV and AG Newmyer III. Alumnus of Sidwell Friends School class of 1937 and Yale University class of 1941. Avid lifelong tennis player. Lt. Commander in the US Navy during World War II, leading convoys across the Atlantic and Pacific. With his brother, owned and operated Newmyer Associates, a government consulting firm in Washington DC. The family will welcome friends at a Memorial Service at the Mary Ellin Caplin Theater, Sidwell Friends School, 3825 Wisconsin Avenue, NW, Washington, DC, at 10:00am on Sunday, December 12th, and at home immediately after the service. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be sent to the Sidwell Friends School or the Washington Tennis and Education Foundation at the Fitzgerald Tennis Center, 16th and Kennedy Streets, NW, Washington, DC.
SANDS--Donna Lynn. 4/9/1964-12/11/2008. Light of our lives, always in our thoughts, you are greatly missed. Mom, Michael, Svetlana & Isabelle Donna Sands and Richard Sands

LEVY--Bernard, died on December 10th after a courageous and valiant battle with congestive heart failure. He was a dedicated husband for 52 years to his dear wife Valerie. Father to Peter and Missy, Evan and Laura and Andrew and grandfather to Anasazi and Bridget. He spent his entire working life beside his older brother Victor. He is survived by his sister Shirley and brother-in-law Joel and his brother Victor and sister-in-law Ruth as well as sister-in-law Louise and brother-in-law Milton. He was a special "Uncle Bernie" to all his nieces and nephews including Patricia and Howard, Paul and Janice, Meryl and Howard, Dana, Lisa, Robin, Phillip, Janie and Richard, Robin, Barbara, Jay and Jayne and Lawrence and Cerise. He touched his entire family with his unending generosity and caring, especially to his many "great" nieces and nephews. He was a dedicated friend and surrogate father to many. He was an ardent advocate for children's health, and a founding member of Zero to Three. A sports fan till the end he watched and rooted for the New York Giants, Yankees and Knicks, watching with his family all around him. He loved to play golf and he was a coach, mentor and friend to many people, helping others accomplish their dreams. Funeral services Sunday 9am, at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

David Hasselhoff will have to come up with another way to mount a comeback. His reality show, ''The Hasselhoffs,'' has been effectively canceled by the channel that commissioned it, A&E, after only one night. The series was supposed to feature Mr. Hasselhoff, the former ''Baywatch'' star, managing the careers of his daughters but few people wanted to watch that. The first episode on Sunday night garnered 718,000 viewers, and the second episode, also that night, had only 505,000. To put that in perspective, another new A&E series, ''Storage Wars,'' opened on Dec. 1 with 2.1 million viewers.

A cover article this weekend about Joel and Ethan Coen's new movie, ''True Grit,'' refers imprecisely to the directing credits for their films. While the brothers have co-directed all of their movies since 1984, Ethan was not officially credited as a director until 2004, for ''The Ladykillers.''

MOHR--Mel, died on December 8 at home in Boca Raton, after a long illness. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and friend, he is survived by his wife, Irene Mohr, his daughters Jana Mohr Lone and Tracy Mohr, his son-in-law Ron Lone, his grandchildren, Laura and Rachel Wenig, and Will, David and Jackson Lone, and his sister Elayne Jablons. A memorial service will be held at Boca West Country Club in Boca Raton, Florida, on Monday, December 27, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mel's memory may be made to the American Heart Association. Mel's kindness, intelligence and sensational smile will be deeply missed by his family and friends.

LEVY--Bernard. Our nation's babies and toddlers lost a major champion yesterday. Bernard Levy, founding Board Member of ZERO TO THREE, a national non-profit devoted to promoting the health and development of infants and toddlers, was a successful businessman who was a passionate advocate for our youngest children. He dedicated his philanthropy to support a range of programs and services that helped all babies and toddlers have an equal chance to reach their full potential. He had a vision to expand pediatric care to provide comprehensive parenting and child development services to help parents promote their child's healthy overall development. He will be deeply missed by the ZERO TO THREE Board, staff and fellows.

Will Oldham, performing as Bonnie Prince Billy at Town Hall on Wednesday night, spent a lot of time standing on one foot: hopping, swinging his left leg, tucking it up under him like a stork. Perhaps, as he does in his songs, he was testing just how much instability he could get away with. He never toppled. On about two dozen albums since the early 1990s Mr. Oldham (who has also recorded under his own name, as Palace Brothers and as Palace Music, among others) has staked his own territory within Americana: a zone of countryish twang and diffident but tenacious vocals, of pain and longing, of madness and glimpses of redemption, of irregular structures that unravel and pull themselves together, again and again. The songs linger and then lurch, skip beats or add them; they move at their own wayward pace, sure of their intent.

A retro look is the prevailing wind on the slopes and in the lodge this season.

The new HECM Saver program reduces the upfront insurance premium due at closing.

Sun Valley celebrates its 75th winter season with a refurbished Sun Valley Lodge and Inn, more snowmaking and a new gondola, among other draws.

The Block by Block column last Sunday, about East Seventh Street in Manhattan, misstated the amount that Yonatan Israel paid for his red-brick town house in 2005. It was $2.5 million, not $4.2 million.

The Mortgages column on Nov. 21, about new Fannie Mae mortgage lending guidelines, misstated the number of years a typical borrower who has gone through foreclosure had to wait under the old guidelines before obtaining another Fannie-backed loan. The period was five years, not four. (It is now seven.) The column also misstated the year in which Fannie Mae tightened its debt-to-income ratios. It was in December 2009, not this month.

THE NEWS Hackers mounted coordinated attacks on the Web sites of Visa, MasterCard, PayPal, Amazon and others they see as enemies of Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, which publishes confidential government records online. BEHIND THE NEWS The attackers sought to overwhelm the targets' Web servers with torrents of data requests; in some cases they did disrupt Internet sites for a while, though little lasting harm was done. The hackers said officials were trying to starve WikiLeaks by cutting off routes for donating to it.
SLATKIN--Rose on November 25. Loving and beloved sister, aunt, godmother, friend. We will miss her always.

The Scene Makers at Play Short videos of the great performers of 2010 who have been invited to show -- in a few gestures and with a few props but without dialogue or story -- what acting is. Here they strike some of the classic attitudes of cinema, turning their bodies and faces into instruments of pure, deep and enigmatic emotion.

POPOFF--Edna Spieler, of Great Neck, NY passed away on November 14, 2010. She shared 65 years of a devoted and loving marriage with her beloved husband William. Edna was a loving mother to her son Joshua and daughter Leslie, and an adored grandmother to Ross. Predeceased by her parents Isador and Rose Spieler and sister Lillian Abramowitz, Edna will forever live in the hearts of those who knew her. A Hunter College graduate, she earned a Master's Degree in clinical psychology from Columbia University. Her dedicated career with the New York City Board of Education spanned 30 years as a teacher, guidance counselor, and a school psychologist. Her passion and expertise was recognized and valued by students, families, and colleagues alike. Edna's greatest achievement in life was the value placed on her family and lifelong friendships. She took advantage of every opportunity to share in life's joys with friends and loved ones, and was a constant source of support and advice. She will be lovingly remembered and deeply missed by all who knew her.

The cover story on Nov. 21 about Mendoza in Argentina, Latin America's largest winemaking region, explained the use of the ''aroma room'' at the Belasco de Baquedano winery incorrectly. The 46 winemaking fragrances displayed in the room are available so visitors can use them to explore the ''olfactory nuances'' of the wine. The winemakers do not infuse the wines with the scents.

An article last Sunday about the new movie ''Tron: Legacy'' and its director, Joseph Kosinski, described Oxford University's academic year incorrectly. Oxford bases its school year on a series of terms, not on two semesters.

A cover article this weekend about Joel and Ethan Coen's new movie, ''True Grit,'' refers imprecisely to the directing credits for their films. While the brothers have co-directed all of their movies since 1984, Ethan was not officially credited as a director until 2004, for ''The Ladykillers.''

To celebrate the reopening tomorrow of Christian Dior's sprawling 57th Street flagship, the house's creative director of accessories, Camille Miceli, designed a clutch of one-of-a-kind jewels, including this $3,500 metal and crackled ceramic necklace. The two-level boutique, which has been given a glamorous face-lift by Peter Marino, also features several chic art commissions, including mirrored glass installations by Rob Wynne, a Oyoram video piece and a stunning ceiling relief by David Wiseman. 21 East 57th Street; (212) 931-2950. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PORTE--Alvin Robert. Beloved by many, former Ted Bates Vice President Al Porte, died peacefully but too soon on December 3, 2010 at age 80 in Minneapolis, MN, his home since 1972. Of his many creative accomplishments, Al founded the Minnesota Neuropathy Association in 1996 and was its guiding light for ten years, along with his dear wife Bonnie. "May flights of angels sing thee to thy rest."
Classical Allan Kozinn

The Consumed column on Nov. 28, about the manufacture of private jets, misstated the degree of air pressure in the cabin of the G650, made by Gulfstream Aerospace. It is higher than that of one of the company's earlier models and also higher than a commercial airplane's, not lower. The column also misstated the effect of cabin pressure on the human body. Lower cabin pressure, not higher, makes it harder for the body to pump blood. e-mail letters to magazine@nytimes.com. All letters should include the writer's name, address and daytime telephone number. We are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters. Letters may be edited for length and clarity. The address of The New York Times Magazine is 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018.

A picture caption last Sunday with the cover article about the proliferation of small bookstores and literary readings in San Francisco misidentified the man shown seated by a desk at a Rumpus event at the Make-Out Room in the Mission. He is Walter Green, not Tom Walter.

Podcast Scheduled for this week: A conversation with authors from our 10 Best Books list; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Paper Cuts The Book Review's blog covers books and other forms of printed matter.

Every night in the N.B.A. is a fashion show for the sneaker fan, and few players have been turning heads like Gilbert Arenas this season. Arenas has been wearing a different pair of shoes every game, from Under Armours to throwback Jordans and a host of other Nikes, including a pair of low tops not meant for basketball that he fell out of during a game against the Hawks.
An article in some editions last Sunday about Tarry Market, a shop in Port Chester, N.Y., misstated the price of the fresh squid-ink tagliarini there. It is $5.49 a pound, not $29.99 a pound.

The Knicks' resurgence is causing problems for opposing teams and challenging Walt Frazier's vocabulary. ''I have to come up with some new rhymes now,'' Frazier said about the catchy phrases that he uses as the analyst for the team's games on MSG. ''They're no longer the stumbling, bumbling, fumbling Knicks.''

MOHR--Mel, died on December 8 at home in Boca Raton, after a long illness. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and friend, he is survived by his wife, Irene Mohr, his daughters Jana Mohr Lone and Tracy Mohr, his son-in-law Ron Lone, his grandchildren, Laura and Rachel Wenig, and Will, David and Jackson Lone, and his sister Elayne Jablons. A memorial service will be held at Boca West Country Club in Boca Raton, Florida, on Monday, December 27, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mel's memory may be made to the American Heart Association. Mel's kindness, intelligence and sensational smile will be deeply missed by his family and friends.

MARZIO--Peter C. The Association of Art Museum Directors mourns the loss of a great friend and colleague, Peter Marzio. Peter was a visionary leader who drew on a unique blend of charm, dedication, high scholarly standards, and populist values in his 28 year years as director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. A former president of AAMD, Peter was an incredible mentor to many in the field and was extraordinarily generous with his time. He had a passionate belief in the power of art to improve people's lives. We will miss his wise counsel, wit, and friendship. Kaywin Feldman, President, Association of Art Museum Directors

Magic Johnson, who has joined the effort to have the N.F.L. return to Los Angeles, was an honorary co-chairman of a recent fund-raiser in Harlem. It marked the collaboration of Mount Sinai School of Medicine's Center for Multicultural and Community Affairs with Jazzmobile, which provides free music education and performance programs to children throughout the neighborhood. The center and Jazzmobile aim to interest children and young adults in careers involving math, science, medicine and music. Johnson, 51, won five N.B.A. championships as a point guard with the Los Angeles Lakers. In 1991, he was found to have the virus that causes AIDS. Q. What does this cause mean to you?

Saab executives have been known to furtively share sketches of future models on the screens of their cellphones, but for now the company's freshest news is the 2011 9-5, developed while Saab was under General Motors ownership. The company is now joined with Spyker, a boutique Dutch supercar builder.The 9-5 sedan was shaped by Simon Padian, who runs the design studio in Sweden. Mr. Padian has said the design was inspired by the acclaimed 2006 Aero X concept. He also sought to evoke traditional Saab features: a wraparound windshield, a hockey-stick shape for the rear side glass, clean body sides and a concave C-pillar that goes back to the Saab 99.In fact, the 9-5 does not have a single one of these features, at least not as they existed on older Saabs, but several are cosmetically represented. The 9-5 offers a quick lesson in car design tricks and gimmicks. In recent years, market pressures have cornered Saab designers into using lipstick and eyebrow pencil to disguise other vehicles as Saabs: the Subaru Impreza wagon as the 9-2X, the Chevrolet TrailBlazer as the 9-7X, the Cadillac SRX as the 9-4X.On the 9-5, the body proportions and other features are dictated by the use of G.M.'s Epsilon II platform, making the 9-5

It sounds like a tough sell: a game that involves catapulting birds at elaborate fortresses constructed by evil pigs. But Angry Birds, a hit game by Rovio, a small Finnish company, is one of the unlikeliest pop-culture crazes of the year -- and perhaps the first to make the leap from cellphone screens to the mainstream.

The Practical Traveler column on Nov. 21, about holiday gifts for the globetrotter, erroneously included one electronic device among those that can be used with the JuiceBar Multi-Device Pocket Solar Charger. While it charges iPods and cellphones, it does not charge laptops.

Patriots (10-2) at Bears (9-3)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Patriots by 3 The thunderclap that shook the skies at about 9:30 p.m. last Monday was a message from the Patriots. They are back, and better than ever, thanks in part to one of the best draft classes in recent memory. The rookie cornerback Devin McCourty has six interceptions; linebacker Brandon Spikes has 61 tackles and assists. Tight ends Aaron Hernandez and Rob Gronkowski have combined for 65 catches and 10 touchdowns. Even punter Zoltan Mesko has been a factor -- if you do not think mistake-free punting by a rookie is important, Tom Coughlin wants a word with you. All of the new faces are keeping Tom Brady young, which explains (but does not justify) the Bieberization of his hair. The Patriots plan to hold onto their Team of the Decade title a little while longer, or maybe earn a second one.

To the Sports Editor: Now that Derek Jeter has accepted $51 million for hitting a baseball, all the people in this city who do not have jobs, or who do but live paycheck to paycheck, will have something to cheer about as they awake each day. Lawrence Fishberg

TOWBIN--Doris Fink, passed away on Thursday, December 9, 2010. Born on March 22, 1922, beloved wife of the late Jess Towbin. Dear mother to her son Barry and his wife Laura, and to her daughter Lisa Olim and her husband Leonard, and her grandsons, Michael and Zachary. She will be missed by her brother-in-law, Bob Towbin and his wife, Lisa and the whole Towbin Family. Daughter of the late Robert and Sara Fink, and sister to the late Richard Fink. She will be remembered fondly by all. Contributions to the Towbin Fund, c/o Muhlenberg Foundation, Park Avenue and Randolph Road, Plainfield, NJ 07601 would be greatly appreciated.

STRAUS--Elizabeth Allen. It is with great sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of Mrs. Donald B. Straus. Beth was a beloved member of the International Council since 1958, and a MoMA Trustee since 1959. She served as Council President from 1966 1971, and later as President Emerita, Vice Chairman, and Treasurer.We will all remember with deep fondness her keen intelligence, great wisdom, kindness, and her wonderful sense of humor. We send our profoundest sympathy to her three children David Straus, Robert Straus, and Sara Byruck; her six grandchildren Sara, Rebecca, Lisa, Drew, Mischa, and Chloe; and their families. Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President Joanne M. Stern, President Emerita Jeanne C. Thayer, President Emerita Joann K. Phillips, President Emerita Jo Carole Lauder, President Emerita Lewis B. Cullman, Vice Chairman Beatrix Medinger, Vice Chairman William L. Bernhard, Secretary International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

WASSERMAN--Sheila Ruth Wharton, was born in Boston, MA on April 22, 1931 to Patent Attorney Nathaniel P. Wharton and Deeda Levine Wharton. She died of cancer at her home in Bayside, WI on December 9, 2010. Beautiful, gifted, and adored wife for 54 years of Dr. Arthur Allen Wasserman of Bayside, WI (former senior executive with the Allis-Chalmers Corporation and retired Dean of the Cardinal Stritch University's College of Business and Management in Milwaukee, WI). Devoted mother of sons, Robert David Wasserman (married to JoAnne Marie Fait) and James Leonard Wasserman (married to Susan Ploszay) and doting grandmother of Haley Marie Wasserman, Aaron James Wasserman, and Jack James Wasserman. Also left behind, her younger siblings, Dr. Ralph N. Wharton of New York, Dr. Lennard Wharton of New Jersey, Attorney Paul Wharton of Utah, and Preschool Teacher Elsa Freedman of Connecticut, and their families and many loving cousins and friends. Sheila attended Runkle Grade School and Brookline High School, studied at Smith College for two years as a Sophia Smith Scholar and completed her BA in History and Government, Magna Cum Laude, and Phi Beta Kappa at Radcliffe College in Cambridge, MA. She obtained her MA in Teaching at Harvard University with a Ford Foundation Fellowship and taught Junior High classes in Massachusetts and in Idaho. In Idaho, she worked for several years as TV's Miss Romper Room. She raised two sons in Pittsburgh, PA, and later served as a News Reporter in Milwaukee, WI, where the family lived since 1968. In 1993, at age 62, she earned the Juris Doctor degree from Marquette University Law School in Milwaukee and served as law intern for Chief Judge of the Milwaukee County Court and won the American Jurisprudence Award in Dispute Resolution. From 1994-2010 she served at the Children's Court Center as a defense counsel for juveniles, taking assigned cases as a private attorney from the Wisconsin State Public Defender Office. She was a member of the American Association of University Women, the League of Women Voters, and the Association of Women in Law. She was listed in the Who's Who among Students in American Colleges and Universities. Memorial Services are being planned.

A review on Nov. 21 about ''Must You Go? My Life With Harold Pinter,'' by Antonia Fraser, misstated the city in which Pinter received the 2005 Nobel Prize in Literature, though he was too ill to attend the ceremonies in person. It was Stockholm, where most of the Nobel Prizes are awarded, not Oslo. (Only the Nobel Peace Prize is regularly awarded there.)
WASHINGTON RARE minerals. Food and water. Arable soil. Air-cleansing forests.

Though gentrification is slowly scouring much of the vibrant Aussersihl district in Zurich, a crimson glow still illuminates the questionable characters that populate the rough-and-tumble party strip along Langstrasse. But elsewhere in the neighborhood -- also known as Kreis, or District, 4 -- bohemian boutiques and avant-garde galleries have moved in over the past few years; more recently, restaurants, shops and cafes, along the edges of the district, have followed. And one of those spots, the restaurant Sankt Meinrad, earned its first Michelin star this year -- an official stamp of culinary approval for this still-evolving district. INGRID K. WILLIAMS

SKLOOT--Martha, 96, died Thursday, December 9, 2010. Devoted wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Widow of George Skloot. Survived by loving children Phylis (Michael) Bamberger, Edward (Suzanne) Skloot, and Robert (JoAnn) Skloot; grandchildren Kenneth (Sara) Bamberger, Richard (Kristin) Bamberger, Joseph (Erin) Skloot, Sarah Skloot and Jules (Marielle) Skloot; great-grandchildren Max, Isaiah, Niva, Ezra, Madeleine, Ella, Quinn and Emma. Funeral services: Sunday, 11:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 91st St.

Heritage Auctions, better known for selling collectible coins and vintage comic books, is exploring new and perhaps more feminine ground. This month the company introduces its latest category: luxury accessories. The items up for bid during Heritage's Fine Jewelry and Handbag auction, which goes live on Monday, Dec. 13, include two vintage Hermes crocodile Birkin bags, expected to sell for more than $40,000. (The opening price on the matte black bag is $38,000; the shiny fuchsia bag, above, will open at $35,000.)

MOODY--James. Purchase College faculty, staff and students mourn the passing of a dear friend whose legacy as a world famous saxophonist and flutist will live on through the many students he nurtured and through the James Moody Scholarship Endowment Fund which he established at Purchase College in 2005. Through his scholarship, he supported young musicians, many of whom performed with him at B.B. Kings Jazz Club, and at The Performing Arts Center. Future generations of jazz musicians will benefit from his generosity. He will be greatly missed. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife Linda and the Moody family. Thomas J. Schwarz President, Purchase College

SHANGHAI -- The booming Chinese economy is showing signs of overheating, according to a raft of new data, and that could spell trouble for this nation's growth early next year. On Saturday, the government said China's consumer price index -- its broadest gauge of inflation -- rose 5.1 percent in November, the biggest jump in 28 months. Food prices soared and retail sales and property construction both rose sharply, as well.
HYMAN--Ned. December 16, 1910 -- October 13, 1981. Happy 100th Birthday Daddy - the most loving husband, adored father and cherished grandfather. To know him was to love him. Annie-Pie Hartman

SOBOLEWSKA--Ingrid Robertson, passed away on December 1, 2010, after a joyful life. She was born on April 1, 1917, and graduated from the Curtis Institute of Music in 1942. She had a successful career as an opera singer mainly in Europe, performing for almost two decades at the Berlin Opera House. Ingrid passionately loved music and delighted in hundreds of friendships around the world. A Memorial Service will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship of the Poconos, in Stroudsburg, PA, on Saturday, April 2, 2011. A scholarship for an opera student at the Curtis Institute will be established.

FRIEDMAN--Eileen, passed away December 10, 2010. Born June 18, 1929 in the Bronx to Irving and Rose Toonkel. Survived by her cherished son Danny (Barbara), a daughter-in-law Geri Gigante, and many loving nieces, nephews, cousins, friends, and an uncle. Predeceased by her beloved husband Julie, son Jay, and a brother Herbert Toonkel. Funeral service Sunday December 12, 2010 at 11am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Eileen was much loved and is already much missed.

''Ho, ho, ho. You got a problem with that?'' Thus, we might imagine, speaks the New York Santa Claus. Certainly, the specimens seen in these photos, culled from the New York Times archive, have an edge. They may not be everyone's idea of that jolly old elf, but New Yorkers have a unique claim on the gentleman - St. Nicholas, after all, was the patron saint of Amsterdams old and new. We should be able to portray him any way we want.

I was rolling up the bike lane on Eighth Avenue on my way to work recently when a man on a Trek roared past with legs pumping like Greg LeMond. I didn't think much of it as I immediately caught up to him - with his casual office clothes and drop handlebars - at a red light on 23rd Street. I cruised past as the light changed, but by the next block he had come charging back, outside the lane and in traffic this time, and zipped ahead of me for good.

SHAPIRO--Eli, of Boston, MA, (94), MIT Alfred P. Sloan Professor of Management, Emeritus, died on December 4 after a short illness. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice (Ferbend) Shapiro. Loving father of the late F. Stewart Shapiro. Devoted father of Laura and her husband Neal Dowling of Sudbury, MA. Loving and cherished grandfather of Julia and Sarah Dowling of Sudbury, MA. A private burial has been arranged. A Memorial Service is planned for the Spring. Donations to the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney St., Boston, MA, 02115, are requested in lieu of flowers. Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA, (617) 277-8300.

This is a collectors' show. Nothing wrong with that. After all, collectors are people, too -- very important people. They are the ones who keep the lights on and the curators running. Without patrons like the Medici, Pope Pius IV and the kings of France, we would not have Michelangelo, Leonardo or Versailles. But in the same way museum exhibitions dedicated to one artist can distort the collective, network-based nature of art history, exhibitions based on a single patron's collection can misrepresent the career of the artists in them. Such is the case with ''The Independent Eye: Contemporary British Art From the Collection of Samuel and Gabrielle Lurie'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven.

JOSEPHSON--Donald H.,82, passed away December 8, 2010. In a career that spanned five decades, Mr. Josephson handled the advertising for over 500 Broadway and off-Broadway productions, including some of the most memorable shows in American theatre history. He is survived by longtime companion Beryl Seidenberg, sister Ann (Robert) Kranich, nieces Betsy Kranich (James) Lehrman and Nancy Kranich McElroy, nephew Laurence (Valerie) Kranich, and six great-nieces and nephews. Funeral services, Sunday, December 12 at 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

''It's sort of like 'American Idol' for science geeks,'' Melissa Milgrom said last night at the fifth annual Carnivorous Nights taxidermy contest at a jammed nightclub by the Gowanus Canal. ''Whereas the World Taxidermy Championship is based on anatomical accuracy,'' said Ms. Milgrom, author of ''Still Life: Adventures in Taxidermy,'' ''this is more of a celebration of nature and storytelling - in a twisted sort of way.'' Taxidermy, long the domain of backwoodsmen and museum employees, is enjoying a vogue lately among young urbanites, due in part to a back-to-the-land revival that also favors beards, flannel and butchery workshops. Carnivorous Nights is riding the wave.

IT'S Friday night, and the evening's still young. The stylist Keegan Singh and the model Harley Viera-Newton playfully sift through the dark, directional spring collection of Graeme Armour, the former Alexander McQueen intern and up-and-coming English designer. ''He has that oomph,'' Mr. Singh said. The first outfit Mr. Singh settles on (left) is his ''supermodel cocktail'': Armour petal shorts with Tom Binns jewelry and a T-shirt. The night (and Champagne) rolls on with the stylist working a late-night look (right): Hudson zipper jeans, Brooks Brothers oxford shirt, fire-red Versace heels and an Armour motorcycle jacket. ''Graeme offers that one special piece: the edge,'' Mr. Singh said, sighing.

ROSS--Howard, Ph.D.,Professor of Economics and Finance at Baruch College, died on November 16 in New York City of complications from pneumonia. Professor Ross began his career in 1954 as a lecturer at Columbia University and then joined the faculty of Baruch College, City University of New York, where he taught for the past 46 years. His areas of expertise were micro and macro price behavior over business cycles; the relationship between the stock market and the real economy; and monetary, fiscal, and growth policies. He held many leadership positions including department chair, academic director of the Executive MBA Program and the Baruch chapter chair of the Professional Staff Congress. Among his professional honors were a CUNY Distinguished Faculty Award and fellowships at Yale University and Columbia University (the latter, his alma mater). He had also been a consultant to a variety of private, United States and foreign government institutions, notably the United Nations, the Government of Greece, the Ford Foundation, the Peoples Republic of China, and United States Treasury. Beloved, esteemed, and indefatigably kind to the department faculty and staff and his students, Howard was known as a Renaissance man, especially fond of opera, tennis and the New York Yankees. He was the son of Gertrude and Bernard Rosensaft and brother of Lenore Kantrowitz, uncle to Laura, Naomi and Paul, and grand-uncle to Brian and Alex Kennedy, and to Leba Gittel and Paul Kantrowitz's children in Jerusalem, Israel. He will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at Baruch College on Monday, December 20, 2010, from noon to 1pm, in Room 750, Information and Technology Building, 151 East 25th St., New York.

I realize that dining out, other than at McDonald's, can be an expensive proposition. But as I look down at my Diet Coke and my house salad ordered from the ''Sides'' column of the menu, I wonder how you, Group Dinner Money Collector, can in good conscience request $30 from me with a straight face. Allow me to clarify that I am not cheap. If I am hungry enough to order a Porterhouse, I will (I have) - and I will pay for it (including tax and tip). Many a time, however, when I agree to go out to eat with a bunch of people, it is more about the company than the food - especially during this holiday season. So even if I'm not all that ravenous, or am watching my weight or had a big lunch, I order a little something just to have a plate in front of me while I socialize.
Manhattan

It goes without saying that acting is a matter of discipline and craft, and that what the best performers do is always subject to analysis, criticism and argument. They say their lines, hit their marks, suffer through retakes and rehearsals, and they trust that an artisanal collaboration with writers, technicians, directors and other actors will somehow yield a work of art. But acting is also an art by itself: alchemical, mysterious, at times almost magical. A person transforms into someone else -- a dancer, a Texas Ranger, a wife exiled from her native country, a young vampire, a former militant, a mogul in old age -- and in the process reveals something basic and essential that is his or hers alone. In the past, we have invited the year's great performers to be themselves for the camera and, on video, to talk about what they do. This year, we asked them to do it: to show us -- in a few gestures and with a few props but without dialogue or story -- what acting is. And here they are, striking some of the classic attitudes of cinema, turning their bodies and faces into instruments of pure, deep and enigmatic emotion. You will, of course, recognize them immediately and admire their grace, daring and skill. But you also may be startled to see how thoroughly themselves they are in the midst of pretending otherwise.

TOWNIES When Justin opened the door to his apartment, I was hit with a dank, overpowering smell. He said that a pipe had burst last January, gushing enough scalding water to turn the bathroom into a mold-filled, 24-hour steam room. Water damage had wrecked the floors. They were so rotted that you could dip your arm up to your elbow into the floorboard below the toilet. Meanwhile, huge chunks of the ceiling were missing, and you could see into the rafters above. I thought about Justin getting ready for school in the mornings. How did he take a shower? That bathroom was the worst I had ever seen in New York. It looked like a hurri- cane had hit it (I'm from Florida; I've seen a water-logged bathroom after a hurricane, and this was just as bad). And after I saw it, I was really shaken. My mind was racing: I started to fanta- size about taking Mayor Bloomberg to visit that bathroom, and forcing him to explain to me how this could have hap- pened. It felt unacceptable -- funda- mentally, jarringly so.-- ELIZABETH DWOSKIN, Excerpt from ''The Worst Bathroom in New York'' FIXES Empowering and Strengthening Ohio's People (ESOP), a not-for-profit organization with about 50 employees and 10 offices across Ohio, acts as a good-faith intermediary between par- ties to negotiate sustainable mortgage ''workouts.'' So why don't the banks refuse to sign the agreements or take the tours, and just foreclose? ESOP uses both a carrot and a stick. The car-rot is that ESOP genuinely helps its lenders do something they are not structured to do well: communicate ef- fectively with a large number of dis- tressed borrowers.But perhaps the biggest reason for ESOP's success is that, when push comes to shove, it knows how to fo-cus the attention of lenders. That's the stick -- and it har- kens back to ESOP's early days as a take-no-prisoners community organizer that fought to improve education and policing in Cleveland's poorest neighborhoods.-- DAVID BORNSTEIN, Excerpt from ''Foreclosure Is Not an Option''For more, nytimes.com/opinionator

A review on Nov. 28 about Edmund Morris's biography ''Colonel Roosevelt'' misidentified the British king whose funeral was attended by Theodore Roosevelt. It was Edward VII, not Edward VIII. (Edward VIII, who became the Duke of Windsor after his abdication, died in 1972, more than 50 years after Roosevelt.) The review also misstated the length of time the Democrats had been out of the White House before Woodrow Wilson became president in 1913. It was 16 years, not ''a quarter of a century.'' (The previous Democrat, Grover Cleveland, left office in March 1897.)

Here's a sampling of readers' responses to Chuck Klosterman's essay about the television show ''Walking Dead'' and the current popularity of zombie culture: ''With all of the bad economic news I keep reading about -- and seeing in my own life -- I'm starting to feel like a zombie myself. It's no wonder 'Walking Dead' is so popular. The show is a metaphor for what is happening to the American worker right now. Think of the undead as the unemployed, and you'll see what I mean.''

This winter, powder hounds who want to enhance their overall mountain experience should look to their smartphones. A number of resorts -- including Killington, Vt., Jackson Hole, Wyo., Aspen/Snowmass, Colo., and Smugglers' Notch, N.H. -- have introduced or are creating mobile phone applications that help you plan your runs by offering trail maps, live views and the latest grooming reports.

An article on Nov. 28 about the Tigre Delta region in Argentina, which is again drawing artists and tourists, erroneously attributed a distinction to the delta. In Africa, the vast Okavango Delta empties into the desert in Botswana, where most of the water evaporates, so Tigre is not the ''only major delta'' that does not empty into a sea or ocean. The article also misspelled the surname of the owner of Isla el Descanso, an island resort in the delta. He is Claudio Stamato, not Stomato.

THE Dior store on East 57th Street is reopening on Saturday after a retouch by Peter Marino, and if you need a new dress or just want to pretend you do, it's worth a visit. Mr. Marino, the architect of choice for many retailers (LVMH, Barneys, Armani), said he thought that the look of stores in general was becoming too international and what Dior's New York flagship needed was a frank hint of Paris elegance. To that end, Mr. Marino opened up the rooms, added moldings, used a gorgeous silvery-gray palette, commissioned furniture and sculpture by various French and American artists, and filled the marble stairwell with video screens that show a soft, blinking collection of penciled dress silhouettes. It was created by a video artist.

His vision created national initiatives to improve United States education about Asia; his ideals and energy inspired our work. The thousands of teachers, and their students, who have benefited from this and other Freeman Foundation programs are part of his continuing legacy to US-Asia understanding.
Television Mike Hale

KLEPAK--Ann B.,of Albany, New York passed peacefully at the age of 89 on December 8, 2010 in her home surrounded by love and beautiful flowers. Ann was born in Rochester, New York to Bernice and Julian Bakrow in 1921, the youngest of two children. Ann married Hillard Sutin in 1946 and they had two children. In 1981, Ann married Daniel Klepak, and they spent sixteen years of bliss together until Dan passed in 1997. In 2000, Ann met and later became engaged to the wonderful and generous Dr. Milton Sandler. Ann will always be loved and remembered by her family and her wonderful circle of friends with whom she shared her life of dinner parties, Broadway shows, and, of course, the many evenings of Bridge, Canasta and Gin Rummy. Ann was a grand woman with style and class who possessed an irrepressible joy of life. Ann was a stunning model for Eastman Kodak, and like Auntie Mame, she was the life of the party and she believed in Christmas in July. In the face any obstacle, there was only good luck, a positive omen and a brighter future. Ann was the eternal optimist who always gave us reason to have faith and believe in the miracle of tomorrow and a new day. Mom always said the life was for the living, and she truly appreciated and lived every second of it. Bless you our Auntie Mame and your incredible spirit, we will forever love you and miss you. Ann is survived by her loving children, Judith A. Sutin, MD of Buffalo, NY and Ken Sutin, MD of New York, NY, her step-daughter, Barbara (and Dr. Bruce) Shickmanter, and grandchildren, Lenore and Margo. Funeral services were held on Friday December 10, 2010.
Theater Jason Zinoman

Over the last couple of seasons, expert skiers at Western resorts known for deep snow have been using some unusual-looking gear: skis that are not only very wide -- now standard for powder -- but skis that have noticeably upturned, almost cartoonish-looking tips and tails. These skiers were early adopters of a ski design that is poised to dominate the retail racks. Known as rockered skis, the skis have varying degrees of reverse camber, or upward curvature, along the base (picture a rocking chair runner). As a result, they float infinitely better in powder, maneuver readily through turns and have more stability.

8 P.M. (HGTV) WHITE HOUSE CHRISTMAS 2010Michelle Obama and the designer Genevieve Gorder go behind the scenes at the ''People's House'' to document how dozens of volunteers and staff members interpreted this year's theme, ''Simple Gifts.'' Much of the décor is made of natural materials -- wood, paper, leaves, fruits and vegetables -- like the ornamental roses surrounding two doorways in the visitors' entrance area, which were made from dried oak leaves collected from the homes and neighborhood parks of volunteers. A military appreciation tree honors the contributions of America's armed forces. In the kitchen, Cristeta Comerford, the executive chef, shows off the holiday menu, while Bill Yosses, the executive pastry chef, displays a white chocolate replica of the White House and seasonal pastries. Mrs. Obama also discusses the importance of giving back to communities, especially during the holidays. Above, the Obamas at this year's national Christmas tree lighting. 8 P.M. FROM a Mongolian yurt surrounded by wild, snowy terrain to trails designed specially for kids, North America's mountain resorts offer just about everything a skier could want. In the United States alone, more than 470 ski areas -- from Rocky Mountain megaresorts to family-run slopes a short drive from Manhattan -- are courting winter enthusiasts of all kinds. Want your own private villa in a wildlife sanctuary? You got it. Is a helicopter your preferred transportation to the mountaintop? Done. Do you even want to ski? There are plenty of mountainside spots to drink, shop and gamble while others race down the slope.
Pop/Jazz Ben Ratliff

DAVID PABANA was standing on a sidewalk one day this fall when a baseball some children had been playing with rolled into the fence behind him. He threw the ball back to the children. It was at once the most routine act of neighborliness and one of the strangest journeys a baseball can make in New York City. When the ball left Mr. Pabana's hand, it was in Queens. When it landed, the ball was in Brooklyn. Mr. Pabana stood on one side of a narrow residential street called Eldert Lane. The children were assembled on the other. In between was an unheralded stretch of the invisible, zigzagging, occasionally awkward and often-disputed 21-mile border demarcating the only two of New York City's five boroughs that are connected to each other by land.

The black motorcycle sits in a show window on Park Avenue in Manhattan, sharing shopping attention with an auction of jewelry at Phillips de Pury. The 1925 prototype Brough Superior SS100 Alpine Grand Sport has a presale estimate of $600,000 to $700,000 and, at those prices, would set a record for a motorcycle sold at auction when it goes on the block on Dec. 15. The record for a motorcycle sale at auction, according to Phillips, is $551,000, for a 1915 Cyclone board track racer sold at the MidAmerica auction in Monterey, Calif., in 2008.

di VALMARANA--Mario.,of Charlottesville, Virginia, and Venice, Italy, a talented architect, outstanding educator, leader in historic preservation and devoted father and husband, died on October 13 at his home in Venice. He was 81. His distinguished 52-year career was remarkable for its breadth. It encompassed 14 years of professional practice with architectural firms in New York City and Washington, D.C. on a wide range of urban projects. He taught in the School of Architecture at the University of Virginia for 28 years, where he served as Director of the Historic Preservation Program and founded the School's first international study programs, in Vicenza and Venice, which remain an essential part of the curriculum. As author of a number of influential works on the theory and ethics of historic preservation he redefined and expanded the scope of the field and the values informing its practice. Mario di Valmarana was born on August 16, 1929, in Venice, Italy. After earning his architecture degree from the Istituto Universitario di Architettura in Venice in 1955, he moved the following year to New York City, where he practiced architecture and attended graduate courses in Columbia University's School of Architecture. In 1963 he married Betty Baker Supplee in Philadelphia. During the 1960s he practiced architecture as an associate in a variety of firms, including Alfred E. Poor, Architects, New York; Giuliani Associates Architects, Washington, D.C., and Corning, Moore, Elmore & Fischer, Washington, D.C. In 1972 he was recruited to teach in the University of Virginia's School of Architecture, which remained his academic home until his retirement in 2000. He was a legendary professor who combined a profound grasp of the history of architecture, studio instruction, and historic preservation with enthusiasm, eloquence, and a sense of humor. A strong advocate for historic preservation, both nationally and internationally, he chaired the Advisory Committee for the restoration of Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater and supervised the preservation of Andrea Palladio's Villa Almerico Capra "La Rotonda", which is owned by the Valmarana family. He also founded the Center for Palladian Studies in America and received numerous awards for his work in preservation, including an Honorary Citizenship from the city of New Orleans and a Knighthood from the Italian government. He is survived by his wife, Betty, and two sons, Francesco and Alessandro, two brothers, Lodovico and Alberto, and two sisters, Lodovica Grimani and Maria Catalano Gonzaga, as well as three grandchildren. He will be remembered for his love of family and friends, his generosity and boundless energy, and his grace, kindness, and eloquence. He loved life's beauty and bounty, whether in the form of good wine, delicious food, rare books, fine art, or outstanding architecture. He imparted that spirit to those who knew him, and they have never forgotten it. He was a deeply cultivated man. The family requests that, if desired, any contributions be made through the UVa School of Architecture Foundation to safeguard the funding for the Venetan Programs that Professor di Valmarana founded 35 years ago. Please direct your contribution to the Mario di Valmarana Memorial Fund payable to the UVa School of Architecture Foundation, P.O. Box 400122, Charlottesville, Virginia 22901.

When Amar'e Stoudemire, above, scored at least 30 points for the seventh consecutive game with a 36-point effort Friday night in a win over Washington, he not only matched a personal mark but also a Knicks' one. The Knicks' record was set by Willie Naulls in 1962. The streak has been impressive and has led to good things for the Knicks, who won all seven of the games. But Stoudemire still has a long way to go to reach the N.B.A. record of 65, set by Wilt Chamberlain for the Philadelphia Warriors in the same season Naulls set his mark.

HARWAY--Vivian I. (nee Thackaberry), died peacefully on December 7, 2010, at the age of 85. Resident of Milwaukee, WI; formerly of Wilmette, IL; Pittsburg, PA; Rochester, NY; and New York, NY. Beloved wife for 59 years of Norman Harway. Loving mother of Maura Harway (Richard Mark) and Judith Harway (Daniel Armstrong). Proud grandmother of Alice, Sylvie, Keith and Hannah. Vivian's parents, the late Ray and Florence Thackaberry, raised her family in Flushing, Queens. After graduating from Queens College, Vivian received her doctorate in Psychology from the University of Rochester in 1952. She had a long and distinguished career as a child psychologist, including nearly two decades at the Pittsburgh Child Guidance Center. Even in retirement, she brought joy to childrens' lives through library story hours and puppetry. She authored eleven volumes of stories and poems for her grandchildren, collected into a volume we will treasure forever. A private family memorial has been held. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Vivian's memory may be made to the Pittsburgh Association for Children with Learning Disabilities (ACLD, Inc. Development Office, 4900 Girard Road, Pittsburgh, PA 15227 or at www.acldonline.org).

GELMAN--Martin M. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the passing of their fellow member Mr. Martin M. Gelman and offer their deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Florence and the entire Gelman Family. Alpine Country Club Howard Bader, President

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the deficit commission reversed the retirement age for Americans entering the work force now and the retirement age proposed by the commission. The retirement age for these workers is 67 and would ultimately reach 69 if the commission's plan is adopted.

von der MOSEL--Valentina, MD, on 12th November 2010 joined her daughter Gretel, Mischi and others she had loved. She was born in Prague 21st April 1926 into the white Russian liberal intelligentsia. Three generations of the family fled west into Bavaria as the Bolsheviks approached with the end of WWII. Four generations emigrated to the US in 1949. After two years of fruitless efforts to continue her education here, she returned to Munich where she completed her Doctorate in Medicine at Ludwig Maximilian University. After finishing internship and residency at various New York City Hospitals she opened a practice in Weehawken, and subsequently North Bergen, NJ. Specializing in ob-gyn, she soon joined the Margaret Sanger Clinic in NYC, and went on into infertility and birth-control work, including research on IUD's. On staff at a number of tri-state area hospitals, she was known as a demanding perfectionist, as well as an extraordinarily talented and able surgeon. In 1982, shortly after the death of her beloved daughter Margarethe, she returned to a psychiatric residency at Roosevelt-St. Lukes with a subsequent fellowship at Columbia University's Psychiatric Institute. She continued to see patients until 2007 when she retired. Valentina von der Mosel was a truly rare person. She had an enormous intelligence which facilitated her in a broad spectrum of interests. A talented cook, with a reputation for brilliant entertaining, she was equally well versed in classical music, ballet, art, as well as botany and a love of gardening. She was an active alpinist (one peak in Swiss-French border area named after her after her first ascent thereof) as well as a die-hard skier until vision problems forced her to stop ten years ago. She always loved Europe and all things European, particularly Germany and France, though she traveled throughout Britain, N. Africa and the rest of the continent. In brief, she loved life, spiritual and physical, and feasted on the sweet and the bitter. A person with a forthright, straightforward nature, she had her quarrels. However, her friendships lasted scores of years, and her many true friends miss her sorely. She is survived in the US by her son Alexej Getmanov, and by several cousins in Europe.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the favorite recent local releases of three independent record store owners stated incorrectly the timing of Midlake's album ''The Courage of Others.'' It was recorded over a two-year span; it was not their third album in two years.

FREEMAN--Houghton. Wesleyan University mourns the passing of Buck Freeman, class of 1943. His belief in the importance of cross-cultural understanding found remarkable expression in the Freeman Asian Scholars program, which has brought hundreds of students from Asia to Wesleyan. His generosity and that of the Freeman Foundation has had a profound impact on the University. Wesleyan will cherish his memory.

BLAIR--Wesley K.,Jr. Born in Brooklyn, NY, July 22, 1924. Died Bronxville, NY, December 9, 2010. Son of the late Wesley K. Blair, Sr. and Amelia E. Blair (nee Schriver). He is survived by his loving wife and companion of 61 years, Doris Russ Blair, his four children and their spouses, 11 grandchildren, his sister, two nieces and a nephew. He worked for the F.W. Woolworth Company for 40 years, retiring in 1989.

Alpine goggles with GPS, jackets with digital avalanche rescue transmitters and high-definition helmet cameras -- today's ski shop looks increasingly like an electronics boutique. But one ski style micro-trend, the retro influence, stands up to all the gadgetry. Runway designers who dabble in the drift as well as the biggest names in outerwear have created modern ski gear that looks to bygone eras, with the 1970s as the big winner. STEPHEN HEYMAN

FUNK--Morton, died peacefully on December 11, 2010, at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. He was surrounded at his passing by his cherished wife, of 63 years, Esther, and his three children, Alan, Lani and Debra. Born in 1923 in New York City to Beatrice and Bernard Funk, Morton was a devoted and revered husband, father, son, brother to the late Irving Funk, adored grandfather of Daniel, Sofia, Blair and Benjamin, and esteemed father-in-law of Lisa Funk and Koki Doktori. Morton's long life embodied learning, valor, patriotism, business success and, significantly, charitable activities. He was graduated from Syracuse University and successfully operated a business for 50 years. He was a highly decorated, wounded WWII officer in the US Army in Germany. His bravery, complemented by his leadership in battle earned him numerous commendations, amongst which were the Purple Heart and Bronze Star. Morton transmitted to his family the importance of support for all charitable causes. His favorite cause for many years has been The Yeshiva Toras Emmes, in Brooklyn, where he has long been welcomed as a devoted friend. Morton's legacy of kindness, valor and unstinting family devotion, will endure and be eternally missed. Funeral services will be at The Riverside Memorial Chapel: 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, December 14, 2010 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Yeshiva Toras Emmes at 1904 Ave. N: Brooklyn, NY 11230.

An article last Sunday about Arizona's being considered a knife carrier's dream because of its loose restrictions on weapons referred incorrectly to ''West Side Story.'' It was the Broadway play, released in 1957 -- not the film, released in 1961 -- that influenced bans on switchblades in the 1950s.

For those on your list who like to linger in the 20th century, to wallow in the cultural riptides of a predigital age, the holiday catalog for Birch Books (212-787-2844) is manna from heaven. Choose from well-priced first editions of still glossy coffee-table books, with titles like ''Picasso's Picassos (1961)'' and Julian Schnabel's ''CVJ: Nicknames of Maitre d's and Other Excerpts From Life (1987).'' The pages from Robert Mapplethorpe's ''Certain People: A Book of Portraits (1985),'' above, demonstrate what the photographer meant when he said, ''I'm not interested in those plain people.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SCHIFFMAN--Donald I.,MD, 79, of Paramus, NJ on December 11. Beloved husband to Marcia. Devoted father of Susan Hecht and her husband Mark, Nancy Sklar and her husband Stuart and Wendy Wernick-Meth and her husband Rick. Loving brother of Stanley and wife, Jo. Cherished grandfather of Carrie, Gabe, Dylan, Zack, Kelsey, and Cody. He was a gentle, well respected pediatrician beloved by all. He graduated from NYU and Chicago Medical School and trained at Mount Sinai. He served as Chief of Pediatrics at Hackensack University Medical Center. Funeral Service will be held 1:30pm on Monday at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, Hackensack, NJ. Donations can be made to Adler Aphasia Center or Hackensack University Medical Center in his memory.

LEVY--Bernard. Our nation's babies and toddlers lost a major champion yesterday. Bernard Levy, founding Board Member of ZERO TO THREE, a national non-profit devoted to promoting the health and development of infants and toddlers, was a successful businessman who was a passionate advocate for our youngest children. He dedicated his philanthropy to support a range of programs and services that helped all babies and toddlers have an equal chance to reach their full potential. He had a vision to expand pediatric care to provide comprehensive parenting and child development services to help parents promote their child's healthy overall development. He will be deeply missed by the ZERO TO THREE Board, staff and fellows.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Russia and Qatar Expand Soccer's Global Footprint,'' Dec. 3: In selecting Russia and Qatar to host World Cups, FIFA stated soccer was going to ''new lands.'' Shouldn't FIFA have given more importance to the effect that the decision will have on our planet?

BARKER--Kathleen (Kit), 84, Director of Garden Club of America and President of Rye Garden Club, died on December 2 at her home in Rye, New York. Kit was a nationally renowned flower arranger, lecturer, judge, and mentor to generations of flower arrangers. She was a creative force who developed the connection between abstract art and contemporary flower arranging. Her lectures throughout the United States expanded the concept of flower arrangement as an art form and its evolution in the GCA. She was born April 8, 1926 in Plymouth, PA. She earned her nursing degree at University of Pennsylvania and was head surgical nurse there. She is survived by her husband Harold Barker; son Douglas Barker, daughter Janet Pinckney, and grandchildren Meredith Kent, Carolyn Fox, and Thomas Pinckney. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Kathleen Barker to Garden Club of America Endowment Fund at 14 East 60th St., New York, NY 10022.

Carving a path down a mountain on skis or a snowboard takes training. But several ski resorts are now offering downhill thrills that don't require any Alpine skills by installing mountain coasters. Built to race down elevated tubular rails, the sled-like Alpine coasters are the ski country equivalent of roller coasters, rocketing downhill at speeds of up to 25 miles per hour. Unlike roller coasters, alpine varieties use the natural contour of the mountains to dictate pitch, dips and curves, making each design different.

Devoted father of Steven Schonfeld and his wife Amy, Alan Schonfeld and his wife Debra, Shari Cherna and her husband David and Bennet and his wife Judy. Loving grandfather of Scott, Sara, Evan, Jeremy, Ali, Rebecca, Zachary, Sammy, Bryan, and Talia. Mr. Schonfeld was the former owner of the well known decorator and interior design stores, Schonfeld Decorator's of Brooklyn and Staten Island for over 50 years. He was also the proud creator and designer of the stained glass windows for the Chabad Center of Essex County.

Originally, I was going to write a quick post on how the Environmental Protection Agency has named the Bugatti Veyron the biggest gas guzzler on the market. The agency recently released its 2011 fuel economy list, and smack dab at the top of the list of least fuel-efficient cars is the super exclusive, super fast supercar. But that's not really a surprise for a 1,000-something horsepower car. What was surprising was how the E.P.A. classifies cars. For example -- and don't tell Jadakiss -- the E.P.A. considers a Bentley Continental GTC a subcompact car. In the words of Alec Baldwin's character from ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' have I got your attention now?

MILLBRAE, Calif. -- Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. has defended the use of sting operations orchestrated by government informers, telling advocates for the civil rights of American Muslims on Friday night that the tactic is an ''essential law enforcement tool in uncovering and preventing terror attacks.'' On Saturday, Muslim community groups said they appreciated Mr. Holder's effort at outreach, but emphasized their opposition to the tactic he defended. The method involves building cases against Muslims by using undercover agents who suggest violent and nonviolent ways to help the cause of Islam. In recent cases, the suspects are accused of choosing the violent.

BAXTER--William Joseph Jr.,86, formerly of Punta Gorda and Naples, Florida, passed away Saturday, December 4, 2010 at the Briarwood Healthcare and Rehabilitation Center in Needham, MA. Beloved husband of Betty Lou (Mohline) Baxter, who died in 2007, Bill was the second of three children born to the late William Joseph Baxter, and Ruth (Arundel) Baxter of Trenton, NJ. Born in Trenton, NJ, on August 20, 1924, Bill was a 1942 graduate of Trenton High School. He proudly served his country in World War II from 1942 through 1945 as a Navy Soundman 3rd Class, assigned to a destroyer that patrolled for submarines and convoy supply ships in the Caribbean, North and South Atlantic, and the Pacific theatres. Following service in the US Navy, he received his BS and Masters Degrees from Rutgers University and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa and the Crown and Scroll Society. Bill's career with Johnson & Johnson in Business Development and Sales spanned thirty-four years, during which he travelled to 57 countries. He and his family lived in Panama, Mexico, Brazil, and various states in the US. He headed up the Johnson & Johnson companies in Brazil and South America for 12 years, returning to the US in 1980 as President of Pitman-Moore, a J & J subsidiary. He retired in 1985 at the age of 60 and moved with Betty to Punta Gorda, Florida where he took up oil painting and enjoyed reading, golfing and swimming. Bill is survived by his four children, William Joseph Baxter III of Champaign, IL; Robert Scott Baxter of Chicago, IL; Steven Jeffrey Baxter of Cambridge, MA; and Carol (Baxter) Lynn of Sudbury, MA. He leaves behind five grandchildren, Chelsea Lynn, Geoffrey Lynn, Max Baxter, Amy Baxter, and Peter Baxter. Correspondence can be sent care of Steven J. Baxter at 217 Chestnut St., Cambridge, MA 02139. Those wishing to remember him may do so through memorial donations to the Briarwood Healthcare Resident Activity Fund, 150 Lincoln Street, Needham, MA 02492. To share a memory of Bill please visit www.eatonfuneralhomes.com
