JAEGER--Roberta K.,MD, age 69: Loved by her son Adam Behrens, daughter Caroline Jaeger-Smith, daughter-in-law Dawnelle Behrens, son-in-law Geoffrey Smith and two granddaughters she cherished, Stephanie and Charlotte Smith. Adored by her companion of seven years, Peter Hochstein. She attended on scholarship both Barnard College where she graduated Phi Beta Kappa, and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. She was a respected psychiatrist as well as a Training and Supervising Analyst at the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research. She was an esteemed teacher and a valued clinician, beloved by her colleagues and patients. She built her practice and raised her children as a single mother. She was known for her charm, wit, vivacity and ageless beauty. Memorial service Friday 11:30am, Frank Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons.

FIFE--John Dustin, 81, of Greenport, NY, formerly of Cutchogue, NY and Westfield, NJ, died on December 9th. Married 57 years to Alice Smith Fife. Survived by daughters Margaret Newcomer of Scotch Plains, NJ and Katherine Perretta of Manhattan, and five grandchildren. Predeceased by son, Randy, in 2001, and granddaughter Kate Newcomer in August. Memorial donations to East End Hospice, POB 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978. Further information contact Coster-Heppner Funeral Home 631-734-7720.

WATKINS--Helen Twombly of Saint Paul, Minnesota died December 6, 2010 after a brief struggle with an acute viral infection. She was 72. She was preceded in death by her parents, Dr. Gray and Mrs. Mary Twombly of New York City, and is survived by her brother Robert Twombly, sister Edith Eddy, and husband Eric, as well as by her children, Michael, Becky, and Tim, and five grandchildren. She grew up in New York City, attended Brearley School, Milton Academy, and graduated from Radcliffe College magna cum laude. She pursued doctoral work in English at Yale University, earning an MA and completing all requirements for a Ph.D. without dissertation. Later she received a JD from William Mitchell College of Law in St. Paul, MN. She moved with her husband to Minnesota in 1963, where she taught English at Augsburg College, worked for Campfire Girls of America, was a lobbyist for the Greater Minneapolis Daycare Association, and was Executive Director of the Women's Resource Center. An unabashed liberal, Helen was a staunch and fierce advocate for numerous causes. She had a sharp academic and legal mind, was a wonderful conversationalist, and held strong opinions. She was a breast cancer survivor. The loves of her life were her family, her dog Charlie, her close friends, and the family camp on Squam Lake, NH. A world traveler, Helen attended the UN Decade for Women in Nairobi in 1985, and climbed Mt. Kenya. A Memorial Service will be held January 29, 2011 at First Congregational Church, 500 8th Avenue, S.E., Minneapolis, MN at 3pm. A second Memorial Service is planned for extended family and close friends at the family camp at Squam Lake, NH sometime during the summer of 2011. Memorials are preferred to Doctors Without Borders, Southern Poverty Law Center, the Squam Lakes Conservation Society, or the donor's choice.

MUSHABAC--Estelle. August 3, 1913 - December 9, 2010. Enterprising, beloved Family CEO, wife of 67 years of Victor Rahamim Mushabac; mother of three; grandmother of seven. BACKHURST--Ruth Hargreaves, of Mount Dora, FL died December 5, 2010 from natural causes. She was born July 30, 1919 in Bloomfield Hills, MI to the late Robert and Jeannette Hargreaves. She attended St. Margaret's School in Waterbury, CT, and then studied primary education at Wheelock College in Brookline, MA. In 1942 she married the Rev. G Clare Backhurst. In 1950, her husband became the rector of Calvary Church in New York City. In the early 1950s Ruth also worked as an elementary grades substitute teacher at Grace Church School, and later served as president of their parents' association. In 1958 Clare became rector of St. John's Church, Buffalo, NY; Ruth served as director of volunteer services at Millard Fillmore Hospital. Clare died in 1981. In 2001 Ruth moved to Waterman Village in Mount Dora, FL. Ruth is survived by her three children, Deborah Johnston (husband Craig Johnston) of Buffalo, NY, David M Backhurst (wife Elaine Watson) of Grosse Pointe, MI, and Paul Backhurst of Oakland, CA; three grandchildren Ian Johnston (wife Silvia Muller), Jeff Backhurst and Berc Backhurst; and three great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at Waterman Village in Mt. Dora and a service and interment are to be held at a later date in St. Clair, MI. Memorial gifts may be directed to Cornerstone Hospice, 2445 Lane Park Rd., Tavares, FL 32778.

Sylvia always found reason to laugh and always enjoyed yet another "God-given day." For funeral details call; Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 800-522-0588.

The bloggerAndrew Sullivan has called America's policy toward Israel "assisted suicide." That may be an exaggeration, but on Friday it became less of one. The occasion was a speech by Hillary Clinton, much anticipated after the collapse of talks between Israelis and Palestinians.

I've never met an abler diplomat, or a smarter one, than Richard Holbrooke. He was inevitably the brightest guy in the room, and usually the most pragmatic and hardest-working - and he was also a friend whom I admired hugely. His death today is a tremendous loss for all of us who knew him, and for the country as well. Richard never achieved his dream of becoming secretary of state, but he leaves a legacy around the world - from Bosnia to East Timor, from AIDS clinics in South Africa to his legions of followers in the United States - that exceeds that of many Secretaries of State. He was simply a legendary public servant, and an inspiration.

Street art - graffiti, uncommissioned public art, call it what you will - has found greater acceptance in the gallery and museum world over the last several years but the fit hasn't always been comfortable. Anyone looking for evidence of the tensions now has a marquee example. The Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, run by the former New York gallery owner Jeffrey Deitch - a longtime champion of street art - late last week ordered a wall mural it had commissioned by Blu, an Italian graffiti artist, to be whitewashed because it found the artwork inappropriate. The mural, on a wall of the museum's Geffen Contemporary wing, was planned as a kind of advertisement for an ambitious exhibition focusing on street art that the museum will open in April. But as Blu neared completion of the mural - which conveyed a strident antiwar message, showing rows of caskets draped with one-dollar bills instead of flags - the museum changed its mind and began painting it over on Thursday.
What do losing Tea Party candidates do? They form political action committees, hoping to eventually snatch a bit of victory from defeat.

Spain's loss is New York's gain, and Wylie Dufresne had better watch his back. Jesús Núñez, who owned the restaurants Polenta and Flou in Madrid but closed them because of the economic crisis there, is poised to open a showcase for his very personal, sometimes deconstructed, foamed, pulverized or molecularized take on Spanish food here. (Did he also fall in love with a New Yorker who did not want to move to Spain? Yes.)

"The Social Network" has pulled off a cinematic hat trick - and a cross-country one, no less. The truthy drama also earned David Fincher another nod for best director.

The Andy Warhol Foundation is threatening to stop its financing of Smithsonian Institution exhibitions if the institution does not restore a work of art that was removed from an exhibition after it drew attacks by the head of the Catholic League and some Republican members of Congress. The Warhol Foundation gave $100,000 to the Smithsonian for the exhibition, "Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture," at the National Portrait Gallery, from which the work was removed.

A palette of washed-out camp colors brought it all down to earth.

A sea of trucks, weapons bristling. A cramped bunk room where beams of sunlight dissect the cool darkness. And mustard yellow tents, almost as far as the eye can see. These are 360-degree scenes from the places deployed soldiers with the First Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment in Kunduz, Afghanistan, call home. Each tells a small part of the story of their life at war.

For the first time in its 17 seasons of globe-trotting "The Amazing Race" has been won by an all-woman team. Viewers saw Nat Strand and Kat Chang reach the finish line first on CBS on Sunday night, beating another female duo, Claire Champlin and Brook Roberts. Several men-women pairs have won the competition's $1 million prize but television critics have wondered when two women would do so. Women have won other reality shows, like "Survivor" on CBS. The "Amazing Race" finale drew almost 12 million viewers on Sunday. When the series returns in February it will be broadcast for the first time in high definition.

Cameron (who appeared as her best-known character, Dynasty Handbag) performed elements of an unnamed work in progress, bringing the small audience to hysterics with her perfectly over-the-top physical comedy.

When charged with the task of writing the score for the acting vignettes in The New York Times Magazine's Great Performers feature, the musician Owen Pallett was presented with a couple of challenges. First, he had to compose the score while on his own solo tour. Secondly, he had to put the music together within the space of a week. He ended up assembling 14 pieces of music that bring to mind classic movie scores while also maintaining elements of Mr. Pallet's musical style. The compositions were recorded by a 32-piece orchestra in Prague. In a phone interview from his tour bus in Europe, Mr. Pallett answered a few questions about the project. Forget lacquerware bowls and silk kimonos: If you're on the hunt for a truly only-in-Japan souvenir, look no further than Marc Jacobs's new Tokyo flagship store. It's the only place in the world where you'll find the designer's "AOYAMARCJACOBS" T-shirt, emblazoned with a clever portmanteau that makes a reference to the store's neighborhood (the quiet, upscale Aoyama). There are other reasons to visit, especially since the award-winning space, by Stephan Jaklitsch Architects, is destined for a spot on the list of the city's design must-sees. Although the shirt is not Jacobs's only recent nod to Asia - his spring 2011 collection for Louis Vuitton featured a satin cheongsam - at approximately $75, it's likely his most affordable.

Speculators Eager to Bet on Madoff ClaimsThe lawsuits filed by the trustee seeking money for Bernard L. Madoff's fraud victims are catnip for an obscure breed of Wall Street traders speculating on the outcome of the enormous Madoff bankruptcy case. In recent months, hedge funds and other investment firms have been quietly contacting Madoff victims whose loss claims have been approved by the trustee, Irving H. Picard (pictured). These funds - specialists in beaten-down assets known as distressed securities - are offering to buy those claims immediately for cash, but at a sharp discount from their face value.-- Peter Lattman and Diana B. Henriques

Who needs capricious and sometimes financially imperiled movie studios to finance and release ambitious content when there's a whole world of video game companies waiting to do it? Certainly not Guillermo del Toro. Having withdrawn himself from "The Hobbit" movies when the future of that film franchise was less certain, Mr. del Toro, the "Pan's Labyrinth" and "Hellboy" director, has found a new dark fantasy series to keep him busy, but it won't be coming soon to a theater near you. On Monday, the video game publisher THQ Inc. said it had struck "a multiyear agreement" for Mr. del Toro to create a new game trilogy called inSANE.

The Knicks' eight straight wins have brought plenty of praise for all of the team's new toys, but behind them is a New York mainstay quietly enjoying the best season of his career. With the substantial shadows of Amar'e Stoudemire and Raymond Felton providing ample living space, Wilson Chandler has finally found a comfortably efficient place in the Knicks' offense.

At a time when contemporary architecture tends to get most of the attention, at least one award recognizes classicism. Robert A. M. Stern, the dean of the Yale School of Architecture, has been named the 2011 recipient of the Richard H. Driehaus Prize for Classical Architecture. Established in 2003 through the University of Notre Dame School of Architecture, the prize honors the practitioners of traditional, classical, sustainable architecture and urbanism.

A 31-year-old man stabbed both his parents Monday morning, killing his mother and critically injuring his father, before jumping in front of a subway train at the 15th Street station in Brooklyn, the police said. The stabbings occurred at the family's home on Howard Place in Windsor Terrace around 8:15 a.m. The man stabbed his mother, 57, in the eye and abdomen and his father in the throat, then apparently fled two blocks to the station, on the F and G lines, where he was seriously injured by the train, the police said. The son is at Lutheran Medical Center and the father is at New York Methodist Hospital. The names have not been released.

The headline on a new report [pdf] says it all: "Only One in Four Young Black Men in New York City Have a Job." While the statistic applies to black males age 16 to 24, many of them still in school, the report, prepared by the Community Service Society of New York, also shows that for blacks in that age group who are in the job market, the unemployment rate in the city is nearly double that for nonblacks. Read about the study on the Economix blog. »

The reaction to the season finale of "Dexter'' on Sunday night is surely divided into distinct camps: people who were annoyed and people who hated it. I fall into the first camp. Heat records fall in California, Oregon, Idaho, Nevada and Arizona, as a hot spell brings temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal. Los Angeles hit 83 degrees on Sunday, breaking a warmth record set in 1954. [AccuWeather]

It's that time of the year again, when there's a planet Hoth-like chill in the air, visions of midi-chlorians and power converters dance in our heads, and joy is spread by a familiar bearded figure -- namely, George Lucas -- when his "Star Wars" movies take their lumps from "Robot Chicken," the stop-motion animated comedy series created by Seth Green and Matthew Senreich. In "Robot Chicken: Star Wars Episode III," which makes its debut Friday on Cartoon Network's Adult Swim channel, an all-star cast lends its voice to a third installment of knowing, willfully nerdy send-ups of the "Star Wars" saga, including Zac Efron (playing Anakin Skywalker); the "Star Wars" veterans Anthony Daniels, Billy Dee Williams and Ahmed Best; Donald Glover of "Community"; Seth MacFarlane, Mr. Green's boss at "Family Guy"; and of course Mr. Green himself.

George A. Hirsch, announced he would step down from his position as chairman of the board and publishing director for La Cucina Italiana, the popular 80 year-old food magazine. How often do you hear the phrase "hood pass" uttered from a Lincoln Center stage? Not often enough, as far as the Bagger is concerned. A few weeks ago, during a Q. and A. after a screening of "The Fighter," Mark Wahlberg invoked his when an audience member asked about the depiction of residents in Lowell, Mass., where "The Fighter" was set and filmed. As a hardscrabble kid, Mr. Wahlberg suggested, he was off the hook for any negative response and left the question to his director, David O. Russell. Echoing what he told the Bagger in a later interview, Mr. Russell said that he took all of his cues from the residents themselves and that they were cool with their unvarnished depiction. "They're very alive and very unpretentious and very open," he told us.

Regularly visiting the Sartorialist, a picture blog created by Scott Schuman, is akin to a serendipiter's journey with a guide whose eye for detail, gift for framing and hopeful outlook help you see how many beautiful people there are. And not just among the Beautiful People. Mr. Schuman also finds considerable style in a house painter, all in white, or the keeper of a delicatessen in Rome, in his long smock. On the Sartorialist, a single image can prompt hundreds of comments. A spot on the blog is so coveted that there are guides online to getting noticed. In five years, Mr. Schuman's singular vision has transformed him from someone who documents style to someone who also influences it.

Now that the former Alaska governor Sarah Palin has wrapped up her 14-state book tour for ''America by Heart,'' her second book in two years, another potential Republican candidate for president has stepped up for his turn. Tim Pawlenty, the governor of Minnesota, announced on Friday that next month he would begin a multistate tour to promote his book, ''Courage to Stand,'' to be released by Tyndale House Publishers in January. Mr. Pawlenty has not yet said whether he will run for president in 2012, but he is widely believed to be a possible candidate. Alex Conant, a spokesman for Mr. Pawlenty, said the governor would decide early next year. (He will leave office in January, after eight years as governor.)

An article on Wednesday about the Irish Parliament's vote on an austere budget referred incorrectly to a lawmaker who blamed financial speculators, the International Monetary Fund and the European Central Bank for Ireland's financial problems. The lawmaker, Joe Higgins, is a member of the European Parliament, not the Irish Parliament.

Signaling changes to come in how it selects and produces new plays, Manhattan Theater Club will promote its associate artistic director, Mandy Greenfield, to the new position of artistic producer in January. The theater's artistic director, Lynne Meadow, said in a recent interview that Ms. Greenfield would take the lead in selecting, developing and mounting work for the club's Off Broadway stage at City Center. Manhattan Theater Club, one of New York's major nonprofit theaters, usually produces three plays at its Off Broadway home each year, and another three at its Broadway house, the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Ms. Meadow said the appointment reflected ''looking to the future and new thinking'' for Manhattan Theater Club, and that more news would be announced in 2011 about the organization's production plans.

WASHINGTON -- With the Senate poised to hold a key vote on Monday on the tax cut deal between President Obama and Republicans, the political jousting has focused on what the agreement does for the wealthy by extending all of the Bush-era tax rates, and for the unemployed, by continuing jobless aid. But a hefty portion of the $858 billion tax package will benefit middle- and upper-middle-income Americans -- precisely the demographic that felt neglected the last two years as the White House and Congress focused on the major health care law and on helping the unemployed and people facing foreclosure.

Joining the ranks of other popular cable series that have recently wrapped up or are planning to pack it in, TNT said on Friday that the coming season of ''The Closer,'' its long-running crime drama starring Kyra Sedgwick as a Southern detective relocated to Los Angeles, will be its last. TNT said the decision was Ms. Sedgwick's to conclude the show. ''The Closer,'' which made its debut on TNT in 2005, will be going out on a high note: the cable channel said the show is averaging about eight million viewers in its current sixth season, making it one of basic cable's most popular series.

Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo has a full plate awaiting him when he is inaugurated next month, including a gaping budget deficit. But Mr. Cuomo is already making clear to legislative leaders that one of his priorities is to cap local property taxes, which would have large consequences statewide for homeowners and school districts. Three New York governors have tried, and failed, to limit local taxes, which are among the highest in the nation and a primary reason suburbanites and upstate residents say the state has become unaffordable.

MINNEAPOLIS -- The roof of the Metrodome deflated early Sunday morning under the weight of the heaviest snowfall in almost two decades, forcing the N.F.L. to move the game scheduled to be played there between the Minnesota Vikings and the Giants to another domed stadium in Detroit on Monday night. The decision set off a multicity scramble. The Giants, who had been stranded in Kansas City, Mo., on Saturday night after their flight to Minneapolis was diverted because of the storm, hastily made plans to fly to Detroit. The Vikings did the same.

Tired of building vinegar-and-baking-soda volcanoes for your children's science projects? Recreate the collapse of the Metrodome roof instead. Glue some wooden dowels to green construction paper. Moisten a paper towel and fasten it to the top of the dowels. Then puncture it slightly and keep dumping artificial sweetener on or near the puncture spot until the roof gives way. Once the ''field'' is covered in white powder, wait for Brett Favre to explain how the Midwestern blizzard and the breathtaking footage of a major architectural landmark caving in is really just a backdrop for his personal saga. Conspiracy theorists will note that the extra day off gives Favre's shoulder more time to heal. That assumes that he has enough pull to call in a blizzard and have a building demolished and that he does not do his own shoveling. Favre announced Sunday evening that he still did not think he would play. He's really just angling for someone to give him a ride to Detroit.

A new study released Thursday by the Pew Research Center found that 8 percent of Americans who are active on the Internet are enthusiastic users of the social networking service Twitter. The study is part of a Pew Research Center's Internet & American Life Project that explores the changes taking place surrounding the spread of technology in the United States over a 10-year period. This portion of the survey, which was conducted in November of this year, is a subset of a question posed to Americans asking if they ''used Twitter or another service to share updates about yourself or to see updates about others?''

THE crisis in the Yellow Sea, which was set off by the North Korean shelling of South Korea's Yeonpyeong Island last month, is probably mystifying to many Americans. Why did the North fire a deadly artillery barrage at a sparsely inhabited, relatively insignificant island? Why has the United States dispatched an entire aircraft-carrier group to the scene? But things make more sense if you look at recent events as merely the latest in a decades-long series of naval clashes between the two Koreas resulting from a disputed sea boundary that was hastily imposed by the United Nations forces -- without North Korean agreement -- after the 1953 armistice that halted the Korean War. Several times the dispute has flared into bloody naval battles, most notably in 1999, when at least 17 North Korean sailors died, and in 2002, when four South Koreans and at least 30 North Koreans were killed.

von der MOSEL--Valentina, MD, on 12th November 2010 joined her daughter Gretel, Mischi and others she had loved. She was born in Prague 21st April 1926 into the white Russian liberal intelligentsia. Three generations of the family fled west into Bavaria as the Bolsheviks approached with the end of WWII. Four generations emigrated to the US in 1949. After two years of fruitless efforts to continue her education here, she returned to Munich where she completed her Doctorate in Medicine at Ludwig Maximilian University. After finishing internship and residency at various New York City Hospitals she opened a practice in Weehawken, and subsequently North Bergen, NJ. Specializing in ob-gyn, she soon joined the Margaret Sanger Clinic in NYC, and went on into infertility and birth-control work, including research on IUD's. On staff at a number of tri-state area hospitals, she was known as a demanding perfectionist, as well as an extraordinarily talented and able surgeon. In 1982, shortly after the death of her beloved daughter Margarethe, she returned to a psychiatric residency at Roosevelt-St. Lukes with a subsequent fellowship at Columbia University's Psychiatric Institute. She continued to see patients until 2007 when she retired. Valentina von der Mosel was a truly rare person. She had an enormous intelligence which facilitated her in a broad spectrum of interests. A talented cook, with a reputation for brilliant entertaining, she was equally well versed in classical music, ballet, art, as well as botany and a love of gardening. She was an active alpinist (one peak in Swiss-French border area named after her after her first ascent thereof) as well as a die-hard skier until vision problems forced her to stop ten years ago. She always loved Europe and all things European, particularly Germany and France, though she traveled throughout Britain, N. Africa and the rest of the continent. In brief, she loved life, spiritual and physical, and feasted on the sweet and the bitter. A person with a forthright, straightforward nature, she had her quarrels. However, her friendships lasted scores of years, and her many true friends miss her sorely. She is survived in the US by her son Alexej Getmanov, and by several cousins in Europe.

The Political Times column on Wednesday, about the possibility that President Obama could face a challenge in 2012 for the Democratic nomination, referred incorrectly to the most recent incumbent presidents who did not return to the White House after facing primary challenges. There were three, not four. They included Gerald R. Ford , Jimmy Carter and George H. W. Bush -- but not Lyndon B. Johnson. (Richard M. Nixon was briefly challenged in early primaries in 1972 and went on to win re-election.)

GIORDANO--Vincent, fifty-eight year old, photographer, documentary filmmaker, Fulbright scholar, and Research Fellow of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture, captured the world's beauty as well as its collective memories in his work. As elegant and timeless as the photographic median he worked in, Mr. Giordano created several photographic essays and portfolios, many that captured the essence of New York City. His work was also of historical importance, remembrance, a collection of 9/11 related portraits, is in the permanent collection of the New-York Historical Society, and Before the Flame Goes Out, a 10-year comprehensive photo and film documentary about the little known Romaniote Jews of Ioannina, Greece, has been exhibited as a work in progress most recently at the Museum of Biblical Art in New York City. Recipient of artist grants and seven Clio Awards as Director of Photography, as well as guest lecturer at universities, his will be proudly remembered and deeply missed by his loving wife Hilda and his step-children Elizabeth and Thomas, and grandchildren, Matthew, Analisa and Rachel. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 18th at 2pm at the Museum of Biblical Art (MOBiA), 1865 Broadway, at 61st Street, New York City.

The Shore Theater in Coney Island, a neo-Renaissance Revival contemporary of the Cyclone and the Wonder Wheel, is now a landmark. The Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the designation for the Shore and three other buildings on Tuesday afternoon. The Shore, originally known as the Coney Island Theater, was built between 1924 and 1925. Beginning in the mid-1960s, the theater began housing musical revues and burlesque. A few years later, following a brief experimentation with adult film, it catered to a (presumably) different demographic: bingo players. Today, at seven stories high, the vacant building is one of the tallest in the area.

The police are seeking two men who attacked and robbed a 90-year-old man in his Harlem building. The victim, Jessie Little, was returning home to 15 West 139th Street from grocery shopping on the afternoon of Dec. 4 when he was approached from behind by two men, the police said. "One of them put an arm around my neck and pulled me to the ground," Mr. Little told the Manhattan news site DNAInfo. "The other guy took the money from my pocket." They took $380, Mr. Little said. Anyone with information about the crime is urged to call or log on to Crimestoppers.

Richard Holbrooke was, like Daniel Patrick Moynihan, one of those rare public intellectuals who managed to combine a life in world affairs with the life of the mind. In his role as a diplomat, he seemed to maintain ironic distance on himself, watching as he conducted negotiations at the highest level and reflecting on his own activities and decisions. And when he died this week, he left a legacy in letters as well as in statecraft.

Kin Shop comes under the critical spotlight this week, a Thai-ish restaurant on Sixth Avenue opened in October by the chef Harold Dieterle and his business partner, Alicia Nosenzo. It's a warm place, neighborhoody, the sort of restaurant you might go to once a month if you lived within walking distance.

Howard Sherman, the executive director of the American Theater Wing, which co-presents the Tony Awards, announced on Tuesday that he would step down when his current contract ends on June 30, after eight years in the position. In a statement, Mr. Sherman said that he did not have a new job lined up but that he believed in making his intentions known rather than quietly seeking his next opportunity; the business side of New York theater is an insular world, and gossip tends to spread quickly when a top executive is coming or going. Theodore S. Chapin, chairman of the board of the Wing, credited Mr. Sherman with raising the profile of the organization through its "Working in the Theater" television program, video and Web-based programs, podcasts, and Twitter. Mr. Sherman developed new internship and education programs for aspiring artists, and he also conceived and supervised a 2009 collection of essays, "The Play That Changed My Life," contributed by leading playwrights and edited by Ben Hodges. He also serves as the point man on the Tonys for the Wing, which created the awards in 1947 and now co-presents them with the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

The designer, who went to Chapin, recalls having to wear a mint green shirt and a dark green skirt of indeterminate fabric content and flat shoes. This look has the colors and the components of a typical school uniform -- the gray skirt, the "knee socks," the crest -- but all grown up. "My fantasy school uniform," Wang says.

When you make a boxing movie, there can be few better fans than Robert De Niro. The Raging Bull himself hosted a party for "The Fighter" at his Tribeca Film Center on Monday night, the director David O. Russell told us. "He said the best thing," Mr. Russell said from his hotel in New York. "You know, my best compliment is that it was honest. That to me is a lot, coming from a man of few words."

The Honolulu Symphony has officially gone out of business. A United States Bankruptcy Court judge on Monday approved the orchestra's liquidation, The Associated Press reported. The orchestra was running out of money and mired in a labor dispute. It stopped performing in October 2009 and filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code but asked the court to convert the filing to Chapter 7, liquidation. The symphony said it was founded in 1900 and calls itself the oldest American orchestra west of the Rockies.

Ms. Holmes made her Broadway debut in 2008 in a revival of "All My Sons."

Tyler Cowen's essay in the latest American Interest is nominally about income inequality, but really it's about the pernicious role that big finance plays in modern political economy. Cowen isn't worried about inequality per se, but he is worried about the forces that give rise to it, and specifically the boom-bust cycle of Wall Street investment - and more specifically still, the way the "bust" part of the cycle tends to make taxpayers suffer more than the Wall Street investors themselves, thus incentivizing further recklessness and still worse crack-ups down the road:

Almost a year ago, we published a small-business case study that weighed the potential pros and cons of geographic expansion for Thinking Caps Tutoring, a company that offers study skills coaching, subject tutoring and test preparation to middle- and high-school students in the New York area. Alexandra Mayzler, who founded Thinking Caps and who described herself as a "control freak," feared the quality of her highly personalized services would suffer if she expanded hastily. But she also said she wanted to build an enduring "stand-alone brand, not an Alexandra brand."

Ukraine will open the sealed zone around the doomed Chernobyl nuclear reactor to visitors beginning next year, the country's Emergency Situations Ministry declared. The nuclear reactor exploded nearly 25 years ago, killing dozens and spreading radioactivity across Europe. A spokeswoman for the Ukrainian agency says the tour will be medically safe and will be "positive in conveying very important messages." [Associated Press]

The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Zac Posen has been looking at the work of the interior designer Madeleine Castaing who is the subject of a lush tome, The World of Madeleine Castaing, from Rizzoli. This was evident in upholstery-inspired fabrics, bits of fringe and Roman-shade like draping of the some of the more artfully engineered pieces that Posen turned out for Pre-Fall. (A laser cut leather dress with bouclé inserts cuts a bombshell figure.) But another muse made a cameo appearance in the collection: Tina Turner, the designer's 7 year-old poodle. That is her face, in silhouette, on the sweater that anchors one of our favorite looks.

Though he's better known for his portrayal of the comic-book hero Wolverine, Hugh Jackman might as well have been rehearsing for a role in the "Spider-Man" musical when a stunt he was taping for "The Oprah Winfrey Show" went wrong on Tuesday. Mr. Jackman, who is one of several Australian celebrities being filmed at the Sydney Opera House for a series of special episodes called "Oprah's Ultimate Australian Adventure," was zipping onto the set while suspended in a wire harness device called a flying fox, but at the end of his speedy trip collided with a lighting rig suspended above the stage. The Press Association said Mr. Jackman was bleeding from his right eye as he was removed from the rigging, and taping was halted for about 10 minutes while he received medical treatment (and a glass of red wine), but the actor returned to the set with a black eye and bandages to finish his interview. "That was so much fun until the end," Mr. Jackman said.

As the budget for the Broadway musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" has ballooned to a record-breaking $65 million, the conventional wisdom has been that the show would need to run for four years before it made back that initial investment. "The King's Speech," the film about a stuttering member of the British royal family and the speech therapist who helps him deliver a crucial oration, was the most nominated movie at Tuesday's announcement of the Golden Globe nominations, receiving seven nods including best dramatic motion picture, as well as nominations for actors Colin Firth, Geoffrey Rush and Helena Bonham Carter, and its director, Tom Hooper. Other films with multiple nominations included "The Social Network," "Black Swan," "The Fighter" and "Inception," which will all vie for best drama at the awards ceremony on Jan. 16.

10:11 a.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES— Voters for the 68th annual Golden Globes have circled around “The King’s Speech,” the period drama about George VI, the British king, and the overcoming of his stuttering problem, handing it seven nominations including best drama. Colin Firth (best actor in a drama), Geoffrey Rush (best supporting actor), Helena Bonham Carter (best supporting actress) and Tom Hooper (best director) were among the cited. Other front-runners announced Tuesday morning included “The Fighter” and “The Social Network,” both of which got six nominations, including best drama, best director and best actor. “Inception,” “The Black Swan” and “The Kids are All Right” each received four nominations.

To the Editor: Re ''Eye for Art and Artistry Amid Jigsaw's Jumble'' (Dec. 7): Every winter, my in-laws would set up the bridge table and do jigsaw puzzles until spring rolled around. In a secondhand shop one day more than 35 years ago, I found an old box with a label that simply read ''Victory Wood Jig Saw Puzzle: 'The Three Princesses' '' -- made in England, with no picture guide. I asked the proprietor if all the pieces were there; she had no idea, but I bought it anyway.

Recent columns on DealBook by Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jesse Eisinger asked why federal prosecutors have not brought any significant cases against senior corporate executives related to the financial meltdown. A partial answer to the question can be found in a decision issued on Friday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that reversed the conviction of a financial executive accused of accounting fraud for lack of evidence of any intent to defraud or mislead. It is easy to assert that there ought to be prosecutions of corporate chieftains -- ''show trials'' like the Soviet Union used to stage -- because of the enormous losses sustained from the meltdown. Actually proving criminal charges is much more difficult, however, if the government has only sketchy evidence of an executive's involvement in questionable decisions and the applicable legal standards are vague, at best.

Cherished grandmother of eight and great-grandmother of five, companion of Joseph Blackman.

Who needs capricious and sometimes financially imperiled movie studios to finance and release ambitious content when there's a whole world of video game companies waiting to do it? Certainly not Guillermo del Toro. Having withdrawn himself from ''The Hobbit'' movies when the future of that film franchise was less certain, Mr. del Toro, the ''Pan's Labyrinth'' and ''Hellboy'' director, has found a new dark fantasy series to keep him busy, but it won't be coming soon to a theater near you. On Monday, the video game publisher THQ Inc. said it had struck ''a multiyear agreement'' for Mr. del Toro to create a new game trilogy called inSANE. A news release from the publisher was not exactly brimming with details about the game series, which is planned for home computers and the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 consoles, but Mr. del Toro said in a statement that he wanted the games ''to take players to a place they have never seen before, where every single action makes them question their own senses of morality and reality.'' THQ said the inSANE games would be developed by Volition Inc., a studio that also produces the Saints Row and Red Faction series, and is planned for release in 2013.

An Op-Ed article on Monday, about the sea boundary between North and South Korea, listed as an author John H. Cushman, a retired Army lieutenant general who commanded the United States-South Korean First Corps Group from 1976 to 1978. During the editing process, General Cushman asked that his name be removed as a co-author, but because of technical problems his request was not received before publication.

The blogger Andrew Sullivan has called America's policy toward Israel ''assisted suicide.'' That may be an exaggeration, but on Friday it became less of one. The occasion was a speech by Hillary Clinton, much anticipated after the collapse of talks between Israelis and Palestinians. The good news is that Clinton sees the peril that Israel is moving toward. ''The ever-evolving technology of war'' means that, in the absence of a peace deal, ''it will be increasingly difficult to guarantee the security of Israeli families.'' Further, ''long-term population trends ... are endangering the Zionist vision of a Jewish and democratic state.''

Stop me if you've heard this one: a group of college friends in New York, now in their 30s but still best buddies and confidants. ... What's that you say? Stop? Yes, you've seen that plot device or something like it before, repeatedly, and you'll see it again if you have a ticket to ''The Extraordinary Ordinary,'' a new musical at the Clurman Theater. This is a competent enough ensemble show with solid performances, but it never quite overcomes your annoyance at having to choke down another variation of a well-worn construction: longtime pals with comfortable lives whose worldview seems limited to themselves. At least this show has no scene set in the Central Perk cafe.

Nick Sprayregen's six-year battle to stop the state from taking his buildings in West Harlem on behalf of Columbia University's expansion apparently came to an end on Monday, when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear his appeal. New York's highest court, the Court of Appeals, ruled earlier this year that the state could use eminent domain to take property for Columbia University's planned 17-acre adjunct campus, which would include 17 buildings for science, business and arts education and faculty housing north of 125th Street, near the Hudson River.

Sometime this week, the presidents of the universities that compete in the Patriot League will emerge from an undisclosed location and announce whether its football teams will be allowed to offer scholarships. At the heart of the discussion will be a couple of age-old collegiate athletic questions: How big-time do Lafayette and Lehigh and their fellow league members want to become? And how much are they willing to pay for it? The secrecy, as well as the silence emanating from athletic departments from Colgate to Holy Cross and beyond, demonstrates that the universities are taking their impending decision very seriously. Only Fordham's executive athletic director, Frank McLaughlin, spoke on the record about the decision. It was his university that decided to give football scholarships last year, and subsequently forced the hand of the other Patriot League members.

There is an idyllic little pond in the Bronx that might make any newcomer stop and stare and say, ''Say, just what is that pond doing in the Bronx?'' The answer is that this is Fieldston, the section of Riverdale that resembles an English garden district. Indian Pond has been a park for residents for nearly a century.

At a time when contemporary architecture tends to get most of the attention, at least one award recognizes classicism. Robert A. M. Stern, the dean of the Yale School of Architecture, has been named the 2011 recipient of the Richard H. Driehaus Prize for Classical Architecture. Established in 2003 through the University of Notre Dame School of Architecture, the prize honors the practitioners of traditional, classical, sustainable architecture and urbanism. Mr. Stern will receive $200,000 and a model of the Choregic Monument of Lysikrates at a March 26 ceremony in Chicago.

Bernard L. Madoff announced Monday, through his lawyer, that he would not seek to attend funeral services held for his son Mark, who committed suicide early Saturday morning, ''out of consideration for the family's privacy.'' According to his lawyer, Ira Lee Sorkin, Mr. Madoff said that he would be conducting a private service at the federal prison facility in North Carolina, where he is serving a 150-year sentence for running a Ponzi scheme that wiped out more than $64 billion in wealth from his clients' accounts.

An obituary on Dec. 3 about Frank W. Lewis, who for more than six decades wrote the cryptic crossword puzzle for The Nation, referred incompletely to the puzzle's recent history. The magazine did begin publishing it every two weeks rather than once a week in 2008, but because of reader complaints it later resumed the weekly schedule.

An entry on Friday in a listing of holiday concerts and other events, about a reading of ''A Visit From St. Nicholas'' at St. Peter's Church on West 20th Street in Manhattan, misstated the day. It is scheduled for 6 p.m. on Sunday, not on Dec. 23.

7:32 p.m. | Updated The number of takeover targets is rapidly dwindling in the fast-growing data storage sector. On Monday, Dell announced plans to buy Compellent Technologies, for $27.75 a share, in a deal that values the company at $960 million. The computer maker said Thursday that it was in talks to buy the data storage maker for $27.50 a share.

General Electric said on Monday that it had reached an agreement to buy the British oil services company Wellstream for $1.3 billion, two months after a lower offer from G.E. was rejected. The bid values Wellstream at 800 million, and will pay Wellstream shareholders 780 pence cash a share, as well as a 6-pence special dividend. The Wellstream board intends unanimously recommend the offer, with the deal set to close in the first quarter of next year.

A film review on Friday about ''Hemingway's Garden of Eden'' misidentified the character who makes a comment about absinthe and misstated part of what he says. The speaker is David, not Catherine. And he says: ''You know, you want to be careful about absinthe. It tastes exactly like remorse, and yet it takes it away.'' He does not say, ''You must be careful about absinthe.''

A picture on Saturday with an obituary about James T. Lynn, the budget director for President Gerald R. Ford, was published in error. The photograph was of Paul O'Neill, Mr. Lynn's deputy, in 1975 -- not of Mr. Lynn. And the obituary misstated the amount of time Mr. Lynn spent in the Nixon and Ford administrations. It was seven years, not 17. (The combined presidencies of Richard M. Nixon and Mr. Ford lasted only eight years.)

Is a dancer's body fair game for reviewers? The New York Times chief dance critic Alastair Macaulay argues that the answer is yes and wrote about the issue after singling out two dancers, Jenifer Ringer and Jared Angle, in his assessment of New York City Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker.'' Commenters here and here, for example, vehemently disagreed. On Monday morning, Ms. Ringer offered her own answer on the ''Today'' show. After discussing her reaction to the review -- she said she felt bad but ''where I am in my life right now I was able to kind of move forward from it'' -- and surprise at the outpouring of support from commenters online, she spoke about the pressure on dancers. ''It is a field where our bodies are important,'' she said. ''As dancers we're taught to try to be perfect in every way technically and in every way.''

The Mets announced their major league coaching staff Monday, adding Ken Oberkfell as bench coach and the former Oakland Athletics hitting coach Dave Hudgens as hitting coach. They also announced they were bringing back Mookie Wilson as first-base coach and replacing the bullpen coach Randy Niemann with Jon Debus, an old colleague of Manager Terry Collins's from their days with the Dodgers and in the Japanese league. Niemann, who has been in the Mets organization for 23 years, is expected to be reassigned to Class A Port St. Lucie to serve as the rehabilitation coordinator, a job he held previously with the Mets. He was the bullpen coach three separate times, twice under Bobby Valentine and most recently under Jerry Manuel.

Adler, Vice Chairman of the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers. May the entire Adler family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President

Two pairs of the short-tailed albatross, thought to remain only on two Japanese islands, have been found nesting on Kure Atoll and on Midway Atoll, American national wildlife refuges in the Hawaiian Islands. Until now, the last remaining breeding colonies of the birds were thought to have been on the Japanese islands. The total adult population of the species is only about 3,000.

Peter H. Nachtwey, whose departure as chief financial officer of the Carlyle Group was announced on Sunday, will join Legg Mason in the same role. The Baltimore-based wealth management firm announced his hiring on Monday. Street art - graffiti, uncommissioned public art, call it what you will - has found greater acceptance in the gallery and museum world over the last several years but the fit hasn't always been comfortable. Anyone looking for evidence of the tensions now has a marquee example. The Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, run by the former New York gallery owner Jeffrey Deitch - a longtime champion of street art - late last week ordered a wall mural it had commissioned by Blu, an Italian graffiti artist, to be whitewashed because it found the artwork inappropriate. The mural, on a wall of the museum's Geffen Contemporary wing, was planned as a kind of advertisement for an ambitious exhibition focusing on street art that the museum will open in April. But as Blu neared completion of the mural - which conveyed a strident antiwar message, showing rows of caskets draped with one-dollar bills instead of flags - the museum changed its mind and began painting it over on Thursday. The decision, reported by the Los Angeles Downtown News, was made because the mural wall faces an ambulatory care center for veterans and a monument honoring Japanese-American soldiers in World War II. ''The museum's director explained to Blu that in this context, where MOCA is a guest among this historic Japanese-American community, the work was inappropriate,'' the museum said in an e-mail, adding that Mr. Deitch had invited the artist to paint another mural.

Michael Fein/BloombergThermo Fisher Scientific agreed on Monday to buy the manufacturer of the chromatography systems Dionex for $2.1 billion in cash, in a deal applauded by investors at both companies. Dionex - whose equipment is used in medical research, environmental services and food testing - gives Thermo Fisher a stronghold in the applied sciences market and strengthens its position in Asia. Under the agreement, Thermo Fisher will pay $118.50 a share, roughly 21 percent above Dionex's closing price on Friday.

Loving mother of Stephen Weinstock (Susan), Joan Breiner (Bruce) and Teri Weinstock (Michael). Devoted grandmother of Robert, Eric, Jonathan, Douglas and Amanda. Great-grandmother of Alex, Jake and Ryan. Dear sister of Roslyn and Martin. A Funeral Service will be held at the Larchmont Temple on Today 11:00am. STONE--Edna. 92, died at the New York Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell Burn Unit on December 10th. Edna was a totally delightful, witty, spunky and vital person, who will be much missed by her friends and cousin Marion Bernstein. She was the beloved wife of the late Leon Stone and daughter of Devorah ( Doree) Zacharias. Edna had a successful career as Science teacher and Dean of the High School of Art and Design. After her retirement she constantly experimented with plants and developed a house full of flora. Funeral services are at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave on Wednesday, December 15th, 11:30am.

The lawsuits filed by the trustee seeking money for Bernard L. Madoff's fraud victims may be a blow for the defendants - but they are catnip for an obscure breed of Wall Street traders speculating on the outcome of the enormous Madoff bankruptcy case. In recent months, hedge funds and other investment firms have been quietly contacting Madoff victims whose loss claims have been approved by the trustee, Irving H. Picard. These funds - specialists in beaten-down assets known as distressed securities - are offering to buy those claims immediately for cash, but at a sharp discount from their face value.

For the first time in its 17 seasons of globe-trotting ''The Amazing Race'' has been won by an all-woman team. Viewers saw Nat Strand and Kat Chang reach the finish line first on CBS on Sunday night, beating another female duo, Claire Champlin and Brook Roberts. Several men-women pairs have won the competition's $1 million prize but television critics have wondered when two women would do so. Women have won other reality shows, like ''Survivor'' on CBS. The ''Amazing Race'' finale drew almost 12 million viewers on Sunday. When the series returns in February it will be broadcast for the first time in high definition. For the last three months they have been taking a star turn at their home, the Museum of Modern Art, in the sprawling "Abstract Expressionist New York" show. But in an unexpected move, a host of paintings by Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko, Robert Motherwell, Lee Krasner and other titans of the New York School will soon be heading north on tour. The museum announced Wednesday that the exhibition - or at least a large chunk of it - would travel to the Art Gallery of Ontario, where it will be on display from May 28 through Sept. 4. The show will feature about 100 well-known works from the Modern's collection. And as of now, the Art Gallery of Ontario - once run by Glenn D. Lowry, the Modern's director - will be the only other site to host the exhibition.

When cooking Italianate dishes with winter squash or pumpkin, I almost always cook the squash until it is very soft. For ravioli fillings I generally roast it, yielding a puree that is relatively low in moisture and that benefits from caramelization in the oven; for risottos I typically cook the squash with onions or shallots before the rice even goes in, then add more once I begin moistening the rice with liquid - or use roasted squash. And very good it all is, in that dense, pumpkin-pie way we're used to with these fruits.

For its next original series AMC is going back to the '60s -- the 1860s, that is. On Wednesday AMC, the cable-television home of the period drama "Mad Men" (as well as "Breaking Bad" and "The Walking Dead"), said it had committed to a full season of "Hell on Wheels," a series set in post-Civil War America. In a news release AMC said "Hell on Wheels," which is created and written by the sibling screenwriters Joe and Tony Gayton ("Faster"), would star Anson Mount as Cullen Bohannan, a former soldier in the Confederate Army who, in searching for the Union soldiers who killed his wife, finds his way to a lawless town called Hell on Wheels, and to the construction of the first transcontinental railroad. The release said the series would explore "the railroad's institutionalized greed and corruption, the immigrant experience and the plight of the newly emancipated African-Americans during Reconstruction." Additional cast members include the rapper Common (whose acting credits include "Just Wright" and "Date Night") and Colm Meaney (of the "Star Trek" spinoffs "The Next Generation" and "Deep Space Nine"); no premiere date has been announced.

Purchasing estate jewelry can be a daunting (and expensive) experience. The twins Coco and Tay Blaisdell took a fresh approach when they set up their brand Cocotay, curating antique gems and chains and restoring them. The best part? The pieces don't cost a fortune. A clear rhinestone and emerald drop necklace ($225) has the same effect as the crown jewels, sans the pretension. Extracting the best elements of vintage pieces, the sisters rework them into fresh designs that blend the past with the present. This holiday season looks especially frosted.

Continuing his streak of hosting remarkably erudite guests for the channel that gave us "Crank Yankers" and "The Jeff Dunham Show," Stephen Colbert stayed serious long enough on Tuesday night to introduce his "Colbert Report" guest, Stephen Sondheim, as "the greatest voice of the American theater of the last 50 years." From there on out a lot of gentle ribbing ensued: there was no reinstatement of the long-ago "Daily Show" segment "Even Stevphen" (even if the circumstances could not be more appropriate), but Mr. Colbert asked Mr. Sondheim if a lyricist was merely "a poet who has a possibility of making cash," and wondered if, as the libretto of "West Side Story" declares, there really was a place for Tony and Maria. (There was, Mr. Sondheim replied: New Jersey.)

Sepp Blatter has never been shy. But Blatter, the FIFA president, has been garrulous since the executive committee of soccer's world governing body awarded the 2018 World Cup to Russia and the 2022 edition of the championship to Qatar. First, he called the English bad losers. Then he proclaimed a manifest destiny of sorts for FIFA in the Middle East. Now, he is offering advice on how soccer fans should conduct their sex lives, and angering many in the process.

HOLBROOKE--Richard C. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend Richard C. Holbrooke. Renowned as a statesman, diplomat and peacemaker, Richard was also a tireless advocate for the world's refugees and internally displaced people. Because of his efforts, millions of people the world over enjoy better lives and have brighter futures. We were honored to have him as a member of our board from 1985 to 1993 and from 1997 to 1999. We extend heartfelt sympathies to his wife and our fellow IRC Overseer, Kati Marton, his sons David and Anthony, his step-children Elizabeth and Christopher Jennings, and his daughter-in-law Sarah. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board Glenda Burkhart and Scott Pelley, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers George Rupp, President

Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 24 about a ruling that five police officers could not be held negligent in the wounding of two bystanders in Harlem in 2005 described their involvement imprecisely. While all five officers fired their weapons, they did not all wound the bystanders, who were hit by one bullet each.

BARKER--Kathleen (Kit), 84, Director of Garden Club of America and President of Rye Garden Club, died on December 2 at her home in Rye, New York. Kit was a nationally renowned flower arranger, lecturer, judge, and mentor to generations of flower arrangers. She was a creative force who developed the connection between abstract art and contemporary flower arranging. Her lectures throughout the United States expanded the concept of flower arrangement as an art form and its evolution in the GCA. She was born April 8, 1926 in Plymouth, PA. She earned her nursing degree at University of Pennsylvania and was head surgical nurse there. She is survived by her husband Harold Barker; son Douglas Barker, daughter Janet Pinckney, and grandchildren Meredith Kent, Carolyn Fox, and Thomas Pinckney. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Kathleen Barker to Garden Club of America Endowment Fund at 14 East 60th St., New York, NY 10022.

INTERNATIONAL An article last Wednesday about the arrest by local Afghan police officers of a suspect in the disfigurement of an 18-year-old Afghan bride who had fled her arranged marriage misstated the month that the arrest took place. It was in mid-November, not the first week of December. (The arrest was reported by the police in the first week of December.) And a picture caption with the article also misstated, in some copies, the treatment the victim received for her severed nose. As the article correctly noted, she has been fitted with a prosthetic nose; she has not yet undergone reconstructive surgery.

FRANK--Reinhard. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Reinhard Frank of Cambridge, MA, whose more than 25 years of dedicated support of the Technion have been a source of inspiration. He was an active member of the Technion International Board of Governors and the ATS New England Chapter. A Holocaust survivor whose own education was interrupted, Mr. Frank made access to education his highest priority. His support of the Technion reflected this, and included the Reinhard Frank Technology Education Laboratory and the Gateways-Youth Wing Extension of the New England Region Center for Pre-University Education. Mr. Frank was a Technion Guardian, achieving the highest level of commitment, and he was recognized with a Technion honorary fellowship in 2004, and honorary doctorate in 2009. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

8:29 p.m. | Updated The Carlyle Group solidified its standing as one of the year's busiest deal makers this week with an agreement late Monday to sell the real estate of its big nursing home operator, HCR ManorCare, to the real estate investment firm HCP for about $6.1 billion. The deal is the largest involving a real estate investment trust like HCR in the last three years, and will bolster HCP's presence in high-end nursing. HCR, based in Toledo, Ohio, is among the nation's biggest nursing operators and has benefited from rising demand for care that costs less than what hospitals can provide.

NEW YORK An article on Monday about Wal-Mart's latest efforts to open a store in New York City described incorrectly a deal being discussed between Wal-Mart and the Building and Construction Trades Council. Under the deal, union workers would be used for construction and renovation of all Wal-Mart stores in New York City, not just some of them. The article also described the City Council's zoning powers imprecisely. While it must approve retail stores over 10,000 square feet, that is the case only in some manufacturing districts, not anywhere in the city.

Rarely do one-of-a-kind brands like Yoplait come up for sale. So when the French private equity firm PAI Partners said a few months ago that its 50 percent stake in Yoplait was in play, it came as no surprise that a parade of possible buyers -- including well-known companies like Nestle and PepsiCo -- lined up. With its 7 percent worldwide share of the yogurt and dairy dessert market, Yoplait appealed to the growing number of food companies seeking to expand in the health and wellness area.

A video parody of ''Yogi Bear'' that's much darker than your average episode of that vintage Hanna-Barbera cartoon - not to mention the coming Warner Brothers film adaptation - isn't a viral marketing campaign gone awry. But the studio said on Monday that it wouldn't try to take down the Web satire, either. The video, which was posted Monday morning on YouTube, appears to be rendered in the same 3-D style as ''Yogi Bear,'' an animated feature starring Dan Aykroyd (as the voice of Yogi) and Justin Timberlake (as his sidekick, Boo Boo) that Warner Brothers will release on Friday. The key difference is that the parody, which takes its cues from the 2007 Western ''The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford,'' ends with Boo Boo blasting Yogi with a rifle (the violence is implied but not depicted on screen) and turning him into a bearskin rug.

COWAN--Marvin S. September 5, 1923 - December 12, 2010. For 61 years, beloved husband of Lois Goldman Cowan. Adored father of Hillery and George Ballantyne, Beryl Ann Cowan, and Candiss Cowan and Robert Neufeld. Cherished grandfather of Dustin Newman, Gabriel Frumkin, Sidni Newman and Amara Frumkin. Treasured brother and brother-in-law of Lewis and Ruth Cowan, Sonya and Bernard Friedman and Sue Goldman. Devoted son, nephew, uncle and cousin, lifelong friend and mentor to many others. Veteran of World War II. A graduate of New York University and Harvard Law School, Marvin was a founding partner of Cowan, Liebowitz and Latman, PC. He was committed to the highest standards in the practice of law and served as trusted counsel to many during a legal career that spanned over fifty years. Marvin valued friendships above all else, and his loyalty to others was returned in kind by people of all ages. At the center of his life was his extended family. Calling hours will be 4-7pm on Wednesday, December 15, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Funeral and burial will be private. Friends and family are invited to attend a memorial celebration of his life at The Harvard Club of New York City, 27 West 44th Street, on December 17, 2010 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cowan Family Scholarship at Westchester Community College, 75 Grasslands Road, Valhalla, NY, 10595 or to Children's Services, Mental Health Association of Westchester, 2269 Saw Mill River Rd., Elmsford, NY 10523 would be appreciated.

They were not supposed to come within three miles of each other, these two airplanes that represented the end of one era of air travel and the onrush of a jet-powered age. The Trans World Airlines plane that had taken off from Columbus, Ohio, bound for La Guardia Airport was an aging beauty, a Lockheed Super Constellation, affectionately known as a Connie. It flaunted a distinctive triple tail, with red stripes across the fins. Bolted to each of its wings were two of the same propeller-driven engines that had powered B-29 bombers in the Korean War.

HOLBROOKE--Richard C.,New York, NY. Asia Society Trustees, Staff and family mourn the passing of our former Chairman and one of America's most distinguished diplomats Richard C. Holbrooke. The world is a poorer place for the loss of his towering intellect and lifelong commitment to public service and diplomacy. He was a passionate advocate for diverse voices from Asia, and for the work of journalists, civil society leaders and artists. During his tenure as our Chairman from 2002-2009, he led Asia Society with boundless energy and enthusiasm, fostering a dramatic increase in our profile and activities. We express our deepest condolences to his family, to his wife Kati and their children.

Jay Feely's 5-yard touchdown run against the Broncos on Sunday -- the first touchdown by an N.F.L. kicker since 2001 -- was the spark that helped the Cardinals end a seven-game losing streak. But the play also let him reveal a secret he has been keeping. Feely wears gloves when he kicks, a reasonable decision during his years with the Jets but an odd one since his move to Arizona, which plays in a domed stadium in a warm-weather state. (The gloves have their own Facebook page, the tone of which may now change from ridicule to admiration.)

An article last Wednesday about the potential effects of a free-trade agreement between the United States and South Korea gave an incorrect estimate for the growth in American merchandise exports as a result of the agreement. The increase in exports is expected to range from $9.7 billion to $10.9 billion a year -- not from $10.1 billion to $11.9 billion. (The United States currently exports about $29 billion in goods to Korea.)

Chuck Jordan, a General Motors designer who dreamed up automotive confections dripping with tailfins, chrome and postwar exuberance, then helped reshape the look of G.M. cars as the company grappled with foreign competition and steeper fuel costs, died Thursday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 83. The cause was lymphoma, his wife, Sally, said.

Ernie Sisto was as good a storyteller as he was a photographer. A tale would typically begin, ''I was doing a handstand on the table when the cops broke the door down.'' After nearly 50 years with The New York Times, Ernie retired in 1972, having won a bevy of awards and mentored dozens of photographers. He took many great pictures. But his most challenging moment was on July 28, 1945, when a B-25 bomber lost in a dense fog crashed into the Empire State Building, tearing a hole between the 78th and 80th floors and killing 14 people. The photograph above was taken when Ernie persuaded two other photographers to hold his legs while he hung over a parapet overlooking the gash. The others, not interested in repeating Ernie's derring-do, passed Ernie their film holders, and he shot an image for each of them. Later, he said, half-joking, ''Those guys won a lot of prizes with my picture.'' Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

If you were an arbitrager in Airgas hoping against the odds that the Delaware Chancery Court would provide a Christmas present, you would likely be disappointed. A teleconference hearing was held on Monday in the lawsuit brought by Air Product and Chemicals seeking to have the Delaware court redeem Airgas' poison pill. At that hearing, Chancellor William B. Chandler III informed the parties that he would be on vacation through the New Year and that he was not ''going to give any decision until the first of the year, the New Year.'' Chancellor Chandler also noted he would be working on the decision during that time. The delay, if it really is one, is not surprising. The judge was unlikely to rule until Airgas had responded to Air Products' latest offer. It has yet to do so, and while the federal securities laws require a prompt response, Airgas clearly has some internal matters it needs to sort through before the board can decide. In the wake of this teleconference, Chancellor Chandler circulated a letter on Tuesday to the parties (see below). From the letter, it appears that Chancellor Chandler is skeptical of Airgas' argument that the whole case is moot because the trial concerned an offer of $65.50 per share and Air Products is now offering $70 per share. He invites Air Products to submit a full response to this argument and quotes Air Products' lawyer to ask whether this was all one ''big 'moot court exercise.''' The judge also poses new questions to Airgas. His questions are: Depending on the responses that I receive, I also may decide to grant plaintiffs and defendants an abbreviated discovery window as well as provide counsel with an opportunity for oral argument with respect to whether or not the $70 offer is a threat.
Harry Campbell The poison pill is in flux.

NOLAN--Margaret Dabney, 61, wife, mother and beloved sister died on December 13, 2010, unexpectedly. She is survived by her ex-husband, David Nolan, and 3 children, Justin, Adrienne and Spencer Nolan, of New York City, New York. Born in Bethesda, MD on May 16, 1949 to Captain Thomas B Dabney, USN Retired, and Mrs. Lillian E Dabney, Margaret graduated from the Johns Hopkins University with an undergraduate degree in Economics in 1973. She commenced her career as an accountant in Washington DC and later moved to New York City. She acquired a Masters Degree in Business Administration from the Columbia Graduate School of Business in May 1978, and soon thereafter met David Nolan. They were married in 1980 and remained in New York, where they raised their 3 children. Margaret worked for Price Waterhouse and Coopers and Lybrand before dedicating herself to raising her family. Margaret was a great lover of the city and was thrilled to be able to raise her children in New York. Her greatest love was spending her summers with her family on the Connecticut coast of Long Island Sound. Always known for her strong presence, Margaret was a particularly warm and sentimental person. She cared sincerely for those around her and engaged them eagerly and earnestly. She was a generous person, wanting to share herself and her things with others. Her greatest joy was being with others and making them happy. Since his contract as a senior news analyst at NPR was terminated in October, Juan Williams has found no shortage of platforms from which he can express himself. In addition to the new contract he signed with the Fox News Channel, amid a dispute over remarks he made on ''The O'Reilly Factor,'' he has now entered into a two-book deal with the Crown Publishers imprint of the Crown Publishing Group at Random House, the imprint said on Tuesday. Crown said in a statement that the first book from Mr. Williams, planned for a summer publication and not yet titled, will ''focus on free speech and the growing difficulty in America of speaking out on sensitive topics.'' In the book Mr. Williams ''will argue that the American public benefits from a vigorous and full-throated debate on hot button issues of political and cultural import'' and ''chronicle his own first-hand experience of the consequences of crossing the line in public expression,'' the statement said.

The producers of the Off Broadway revival of ''Dracula'' fired their star actress Thora Birch on Friday, four days before the play's first performance, the production's director and Ms. Birch said in interviews on Monday. Ms. Birch, a 28-year-old actress, is best known for the films ''American Beauty'' and ''Ghost World,'' and was preparing to make her New York stage debut. She said that she was ''in a state of shock'' over her dismissal and the subsequent order from the producers to leave the theater immediately. The two sides offered sharply different interpretations of the events that led up to Ms. Birch's firing from ''Dracula,'' which is still scheduled to begin preview performances on Tuesday night at the Little Shubert Theater.

HOLBROOKE--Richard C. The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) mourns the passing of Richard C. Holbrooke. A creative, forceful, and effective diplomat, Ambassador Holbrooke spent a career working on some of the most difficult areas of United .States foreign policy, from Vietnam to the Balkans to Pakistan and Afghanistan. He will be additionally remembered for his work drawing international attention to global health issues, particularly HIV/AIDS. A CFR member since 1970, he served three times on the Board of Directors and had also chaired the advisory board of Foreign Affairs magazine. He was a statesman, a colleague, and a friend, and will be greatly missed. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Kati, and his family. Carla A. Hills, Co-Chair Robert E. Rubin, Co-Chair Richard N. Haass, President

BUSINESS DAY The Media Equation column on Monday, about the strategy of WikiLeaks, described incorrectly, in some copies, comments by Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, in which he called for the execution of those responsible for the WikiLeaks disclosures. Mr. Huckabee was referring to Bradley Manning, the person suspected of originally supplying the cables -- not to Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, who disseminated them. The article also misstated, in some editions, the circumstances of Mr. Assange's arrest in Britain. He was in jail in connection with a Swedish extradition request, not on sex charges brought in Britain. And the article misstated the month that WikiLeaks released a trove of United States diplomatic cables. It was in November, not October.

The Herald Angels Sing,'' and Mr. McCullough, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, reflects on the topic of American Christmas memories. The hourlong program also features the 360-voice choir, which was first organized in 1847, not long after Mormon pioneers arrived in Utah, singing ''For Unto Us a Child Is Born'' from Handel's Messiah, ''Christmas Carols in the Air'' and ''Angels, From the Realms of Glory,'' accompanied by a children's choir and ballet dancers. 6 P.M. HONG KONG -- The United States is too reliant on China for minerals crucial to new clean energy technologies, making the American economy vulnerable to shortages of materials needed for a range of green products -- from compact fluorescent light bulbs to electric cars to giant wind turbines. So warns a detailed report to be released on Wednesday morning by the United States Energy Department. The report, which predicts that it could take 15 years to break American dependence on Chinese supplies, calls for the nation to increase research and expand diplomatic contacts to find alternative sources, and to develop ways to recycle the minerals or replace them with other materials.

LAST December, The New York Times asked online readers to send photos and recipes of their holiday cookies. About 100 people answered the call, filling the inbox with creations that were classic (sugar cookies), endearingly oddball (chocolate-pepper cookies in the shape of frogs) or both (meringue mushrooms that looked as if they'd fallen off a bûche de Noël). When it comes to holiday cooking, the bottom line seems to be that, if it's festive, it flies. Sesame cookies made with tahini join eggnog or glazed ham at the table. And treats based on supermarket staples -- hello, saltine brickle --compete for affection with more elegant specimens, like a very dignified Scottish shortbread.

As the end of the year approaches, it seems appropriate to look at the economy from a macro-perspective - that is, at the level of gross domestic product or G.D.P. - to determine if the economy is growing, and if so, what G.D.P. components are contributing to growth. While this is not a definitive analysis of the economy, it does show if things are moving in the right direction. All of the statistical information that follows is from the Bureau of Economic Analysis, or B.E.A., and is inflation-adjusted.According to the National Bureau of Economic Research, the recession ended in June 2009, or the end of the second quarter of 2009. Since then, the U.S. economy has grown for 5 consecutive quarters at the following quarter to quarter rates: 1.6 percent, 5.0 percent, 3.7 percent, 1.7 percent and 2.5 percent. This is a median growth rate of 2.5 percent. The median growth rate for the first five quarters of the early 1990s and early 2000s expansions were 2.7 percent and 2 percent respectively, placing the growth rate of the current recovery right in the middle of the pack. This also indicates that slower growth at the beginning of a recovery is not atypical.

For breakfast, lunch or dinner, this cozy boîte hosts regulars like Hedi Slimane, Terry Richardson and Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte. By night, Kliegman and Quirarte operate the Jane Ballroom and are about to open their first nightclub, an ironic hipster strip joint on Clarkson Street and the West Side Highway, aptly named the Westway.

When you examine the balance sheet of Donald J. Trump, is there really anything that funny about him, other than his relentless self-promotional streak, the seesawing fortunes of his "Apprentice" reality-television franchise, his string of marriages and his enigmatic hairline? That's for the comedians to figure out: Mr. Trump, the real-estate mogul and media personality, will be the next victim guest of honor at a Comedy Central roast, the cable channel said on Thursday. "The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump" will be taped on March 9 - the first such roast to be filmed in New York since 2005, back when Comedy Central felt the comedian Jeff Foxworthy deserved the distinction - and broadcast in the spring. No slander-slinging panelists were immediately announced for the event, but if tradition holds, Mr. Trump can look forward to a speedy elimination from a future season of "Dancing With the Stars."

If we consider basketball to be a constant series of possessional puzzles, there is a seemingly endless number of ways for players to navigate to their desired ends. Knowing which players are talented enough to solve the puzzle and generate points for their respective teams is essential, but it's just as crucial to understand the stylistic differences that influence the ways players score, pass, defend, and even rebound.
