As the former photography director for Dazed & Confused, AnOther and Tar Magazines, Emma Reeves has worked with some of the sharpest shooters in the game. She's also made stops at V and The Journal, and worked as a curator. (She pulled together David Armstrong's "Mad About the Boy" at Half Gallery last month.) So when Christian Parkes, the head of marketing for Levi's, reached out to her to create the programming for the brand's Photography Workshop at 18 Wooster Street in SoHo, she says, "it was a natural fit." The revolving door of installations, spread over 10 weeks and including "Tiny Vices," curated by Tim Barber, an exhibition of Taschen's mega-book "Portrait of a City," speaking engagements by the likes of Bruce Davidson, and a workshop with state-of-the-art Leicas, was by all counts a smashing success. We caught up with the busy multi-hyphenate as she readied for Saturday's triumphant closing party, to talk about Levi's, lessons and the potential of participatory retail.

With the current emphasis on reining in costs, increasing productivity and improving safety, it's hard not to view the personal amenities offered by certain hospitals with some level of suspicion. While the well-appointed lobbies, personalized meal services and private rooms with a view -- all designed to make hospitals feel un-hospital-like -- can be meaningful to patients, families and even clinicians and staff, few of us have ever acknowledged their role in patient care. Instead, we tend to deride these nonclinical services as fluffy perks at best and frivolous manifestations of profit-driven medicine at worst.
Hospital amenities like a pleasant lobby, private rooms and good food are important to both patients and doctors.

The lead producers of the new Broadway musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" have decided again to delay its opening night, now scheduled for Jan. 11, until sometime in February, two people involved with the musical said on Thursday. With preview performances now under way the delay is intended to provide more time for the creators to stage a new final number, make further rewrites to the dialogue and consider adding and cutting scenes and perhaps inserting new music from the composers, U2's Bono and the Edge, who will resume working full-time on the show in late December.

There's plenty to ponder in the newly released summary of the Annual Energy Outlook 2011 by the Department of Energy. While all such forecasts are implicitly uncertain, this one helps clarify where to focus efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions; reinforces the importance of resolving questions about how to safely expand, while not stopping, extraction of vast domestic reserves of natural gas; and powerfully challenges proponents of accelerated deployment of today's menu of renewable energy technologies or nuclear power plants to lay out a credible strategy for supplanting coal.

William Allen Baltz was 4 years old when his brother, Stephen, died following the Park Slope plane crash, having struggled for a day to survive at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.

America met Stephen L. Baltz on Dec. 16, 1960, held him in a collective embrace for a day and then, grieving, let him go. It was as if some celestial central casting agency had carefully assigned the role of courageous survivor to an 11-year-old boy whose life - had it been spared - would have lent to the senseless wreckage one single note of grace.

Attention, bird-watchers: the National Audubon Society's Christmas Bird Count is under way. The annual census, which began on Tuesday and runs through Jan. 5, relies on volunteers throughout the Western Hemisphere who head out with binoculars, spotting scopes, bird guides, cellphones, mobile apps and notepads. They scan trees and fields, reporting on every bird they see over a 24-hour period.

More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, the New York Times "Really?" columnist, Anahad O'Connor, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

At the party following the New York premiere of "True Grit" on Tuesday night, the 14-year-old star, Hailee Steinfeld, held court with her 15-year-old best friend, Katee Cassidy, prancing around the Pool Room at the Four Seasons restaurant holding hands. The prancing was greatly helped by the fact that Ms. Steinfeld had changed out of the purple stilettos she wore on the red carpet and into silver glitter hi-tops. Toward the end of the night, another of the movie's stars, Jeff Bridges, dressed down too, getting all Dude-like in his wrinkled white shirt and posing for photos with a glass -- of what appeared to be water -- in his hand. As usual, Joel and Ethan Coen, who wrote and directed the film, declined to talk. But the Bagger was glad to find Carter Burwell, the film's composer. Mr. Burwell has always written music for the Coens, as well as for Spike Jonze's films, like "Where the Wild Things Are." This awards season he is also represented by "The Kids Are All Right." He lives and records in New York; the score for "True Grit" was composed at the Manhattan Center with a 70-piece orchestra. And it was being fine-tuned until the very last moment - the last recording session was held Nov. 8. Mr. Burwell is a member of the Academy, but, he revealed to us, that didn't make him an expert on who would win the Oscar for best score. (Readers, you're on your own.) But Mr. Burwell did clue us into the process of composing that memorably grand music. An edited version of the conversation follows.

Manhattanites no longer have to trek to Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, and wait on line at Noah Bernamoff's Mile End Deli for Montreal-style meats. At Vic's Bagel Bar, 544 Third Avenue (36th Street), the owner, Vic Glazer, gets regular deliveries of smoked meat, smoked turkey and smoked beef salami. The meats are layered into sandwiches, including the Ellen Barkin, using the smoked meat ($7.95). Mr. Bernamoff's wife, Rachel Cohen, is an old friend of Ms. Glazer's, which is how the connection was made. "I've known Rachel since we were at Yeshiva together," Ms. Glazer said. Ms. Glazer also sells the smoked meat by the pound, $30; the salami is $28 a pound. If you insist on a Montreal-style bagel, then it's Mile End, 97A Hoyt Street (Atlantic Avenue), for you after all. Meanwhile, check out what Robert Sietsema has to say about the Montreal-New York culinary connection.

Madrileños celebrate Christmas with the same gusto that they celebrate life, enjoying the holiday in all its manifestations: from attending Christmas-themed concerts to skating on the ice rinks specially set up in plazas. For sustenance, they snack on churros and hot chocolate.

Back in European history class in junior high, many teenagers were taught that World War I was brought about, in part, because of ''entangling alliances.'' And this, of course, is not unlike earbuds. Like European nation-states, otherwise well-intentioned headphones can be dragged into chaos over relatively trivial matters. In this case, audio quality is undermined considerably if you cannot get the blasted earbuds untangled so that you can listen to them.

HOROWITZ--David H.,82, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, December 14, 2010. Terminally ill with cancer, he showed great courage facing his disease, comforted at the end by the presence of family and friends. Born September 11, 1928 to Abraham and Florence Bob Horowitz in New York City, David was educated in the city's public schools before entering Columbia University at the age of 16. While in college he earned admission in Phi Beta Kappa. After enrolling in Columbia Law School in 1948 he became editor of the Columbia Law Review. Following graduation he clerked for Judge Stanley Fuld, and then joined the Schwartz & Frohlich law firm that specialized in entertainment law. In 1963 he moved to Screen Gems, Inc., and then to its parent company, Columbia Pictures, Inc. in 1968 where he served as vice-president and general counsel. In 1973 he joined Warner Communications, where among other positions he served as co-chief operating officer with particular responsibility for the company's music and cable operations. In 1980 David helped to establish a joint venture between Warner Communications and American Express that developed programming specifically for cable television; under his direction its first creation was a channel devoted to music videos, well-known now as MTV. When MTV became an independent public company in 1984, David was its first president and chief executive officer. He left MTV after it was acquired by VIACOM, but continued to be active in the entertainment and technology areas. For many years he was active in SPIN magazine, including serving as its publisher, as well as serving as a consultant for ASCAP. He taught entertainment and copyright law at New York University and Columbia Law School, and served on the board of directors of a wide range of new internet companies. David bought a home in Santa Fe in the mid-1990s, and settled permanently here in 1999. He quickly became active in many local cultural institutions, including the Lensic Performing Arts Center and the Santa Fe Opera. He also was a trustee of the College of Santa Fe and an executive board member of the Governor's Council on Film and Media Industries. Courtly, generous, and widely-read, he is remembered for his intellect, generosity, and endless curiosity about all aspects of our world's culture. He is survived by his wife Susan, children Marilyn, Roger, Diana, and Adam, stepson Justin Weyerhaeuser, and grandchildren Jason and Lucy. A memorial service to remember his life will take place at the Lensic Performing Arts Center, 211 West San Francisco Street in Santa Fe, NM on Thursday, December 16, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Lensic or the Santa Fe Community Foundation.

49ers (5-8) at Chargers (7-6)Thursday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Chargers by 9 One of these teams is not like the other. One of these teams just doesn't belong. Both the Chargers and 49ers are still in the playoff picture, and the two teams won their games by a combined score of 71-21 last week. But the Chargers are legitimate contenders; they lead the A.F.C. in yards per game (399.6), lead the N.F.L. in fewest yards allowed per game (265.5), and lead the planet in inventive self-sabotage, which explains their 7-6 record. The 49ers are just another bunch of toddlers splashing around the N.F.C.West kiddie pool, their 40-21 drubbing of Seattle this week the football equivalent of a good soaking in a water pistol fight. Alex Smith has replaced Troy Smith as the 49ers quarterback once and for all, meaning that his job is safe until at least halftime.

THE Wired Store is a temporary hands-on gallery curated by the editors of Wired magazine to showcase new electronics and gaming and home goods. The space is divided into categories like the Adventure Capitalist, Culturazzi, Digital Gentleman, Gadget Girl and Gastronaut. Shoppers can buy some products online at wired.com/wiredstore; a few are available at the store, including Urbanears for Wired headphones, left, the Tanto ($47). The Wired Store, 692 Broadway (at Fourth Street), is open from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Wednesdays through Sundays until Dec. 26.

FINGER--Gregory. The Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) deeply mourns the untimely loss of our beloved Board Chair and former Executive Director Gregory H. Finger. Greg, a longtime social justice organizer and activist, passed away at his home on the morning of December 13, 2010. To the end he believed that the struggle against racism is indispensable to the achievement of justice. CCR was graced with Greg for 39 years and he was the bedrock upon which CCR was built. Greg dedicated his life to justice and service to humanity. From his work as a young man in the racial justice movements of the 1950's to his years as an organizer for the Congress on Racial Equality (CORE) in the mid-1960's, to his anti-war activism during the Vietnam era, to his more than three decades as director of the co-ed, multiracial Camp Thoreau, Greg was a living, breathing example to all of us of how to speak truth to power and live life to the fullest. Greg's commitment to service was further evident in his many years volunteering as a firefighter, emergency response technician, and community leader. Greg is greatly missed by his friends and colleagues. Our loss of Greg has opened a gap in our lives that he would have wanted filled with our efforts to make a better world. Our deep and sincere condolences go to his wife, Joan Hollister, his brother Karl, and the host of family members so beloved by Greg. Our hearts are with you all.

He will forever be remembered for his extraordinary commitment to the highest standards of patient care and medical education. He was predeceased by his son Edward in 2004. To his beloved wife Gloria, his daughter Lynne, the entire Roberts family and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Harris M. Nagler, MD President Louise M. Klebanoff, MD President, Medical Board Arnold J. Friedman, MD Chairman Dept. of OB/GYN

Last month, the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn complained that the price in Dynegy's deal to sell itself to the Blackstone Group, about $604.5 million, was far too low. In urging shareholders to reject the bid, he argued that others would be willing to pay more than Blackstone's final offer of $5 a share. Mr. Icahn succeeded in killing the Blackstone deal, and on Wednesday, he proved that the company could strike a higher-priced deal - by making his own bid.

An article last Thursday about hiring bartenders for private parties misstated the name of an agency that sends out Columbia University undergraduates and graduate students as bartenders. It is the Columbia Bartending Agency, not Columbia Bartenders.

An article on Tuesday about a Congressional report critical of the Treasury Department's loan modification program gave an outdated title for Ted Kaufman, chairman of the panel that issued the report. Mr. Kaufman is a former senator from Delaware, not a current one. (He was appointed to the Senate to fill the unexpired term of Joseph R. Biden Jr., who was elected vice president. Mr. Kaufman's successor, Chris Coons, was elected in the midterm election Nov. 2 and sworn in later that month.)

The Fred Ebb Foundation has given Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS a gift of $1 million, the largest donation in the organization's history. The contribution is to be announced on Tuesday. The foundation, established after the death of the Tony Award-winning lyricist in 2004, has given money annually to Broadway Cares, a New York-based nonprofit HIV/AIDS grant-making organization that is perhaps best known for producing benefits by and for the Broadway community, including the striptease-centered Broadway Bares.

On the brink of extinction last spring, the nonprofit organization charged with restoring Ellis Island will benefit from a $100,000 gift from American Express, the credit card company is to announce on Thursday. ''It's an enormous boost,'' said Judith R. McAlpin, the president of the organization, Save Ellis Island. ''American Express has long been associated with the very best in historic preservation. It's like the Good Housekeeping seal of approval.''

9 P.M. (Fuse) FUSE PRESENTS: Z100'S JINGLE BALL LIVE FROM MADISON SQUARE GARDEN If you couldn't witness this annual holiday blowout (target audience: tween girls) at the Garden on Friday, this is the next best thing. Katy Perry (above), Justin Bieber, Enrique Iglesias, Paramore, B.o.B., Bruno Mars, Taio Cruz, Selena Gomez, Hayley Williams, Michael Bublé and Travie McCoy perform for screaming fans and guests like Kim Kardashian, Jay Sean and Flo Rida. Mr. Bieber ''and his retinue, including the actor Jaden Smith, danced the most by far,'' Ben Ratliff wrote in The New York Times. ''But for production and costumes and performance and general three-dimensionality, Ms. Perry won,'' seeming, he added, ''imperious and absurd, completely in control.'' Yet it was the 35-year-old Mr. Iglesias who kissed a girl -- Rachel, 16, plucked from the crowd -- and liked it. ''It was a shrewd, queasy-making set piece that he's done before and could do forever,'' Mr. Ratliff wrote. ''It's as easy as mowing the lawn.'' A pre-show begins at 8. 6 A.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: MICKEY ROONEYTurner Classic Movies continues its Thursdays-in-December tribute to Mr. Rooney, a larger-than-life 5-foot-2-inch package who married eight times, made and lost millions of dollars, and has enjoyed a career spanning more than 80 years. This 14-film Andy Hardy marathon begins with ''Andy Hardy Comes Home'' (1958), in which a grown Andy (Mr. Rooney) returns to his hometown to negotiate a land deal and becomes mired in local politics. The salute ends at 4:15 a.m. on Friday with ''Judge Hardy's Children'' (1938), in which Andy lands in hot water with the French ambassador's daughter (Jacqueline Laurent) during a trip to Washington.

Fifty years later, on a gray December day, there is little to indicate that the corner of Seventh Avenue and Sterling Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, bore violent witness to the worst air disaster at the time, that the disembodied leviathan tail of a ruined jet came to rest here amid flaming carnage and falling brick. There is no marker, no memorial to the 90 people whose bodies littered the sidewalk the slushy morning of Dec. 16, 1960, when a United Airlines DC-8 plunged down after colliding with a Lockheed Constellation over Staten Island. The Pillar of Fire Church, destroyed when the jet slammed into it and exploded, and the corner building with the grocery store and the Chinese laundry, consumed by flame, have been replaced by condominiums that more or less fit in with the brownstone row houses.

About a year and a half ago, I gave an unreserved rave to the Skyfire browser. I did the same about a year ago when the browser was made available for Android, with speedy downloads and the ability to show Adobe Flash animation on phones that didn't support it. So I was doubly psyched when Skyfire came to the iPhone. The iPhone's greatest flaw is its continued inability to see Flash, meaning I can't view something like 70 percent of all videos on the Web, not to mention various games and retail sites.

The Honolulu Symphony has officially gone out of business. A United States Bankruptcy Court judge on Monday approved the orchestra's liquidation, The Associated Press reported. The orchestra was running out of money and mired in a labor dispute. It stopped performing in October 2009 and filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code but asked the court to convert the filing to Chapter 7, liquidation. The symphony said it was founded in 1900 and calls itself the oldest American orchestra west of the Rockies. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A picaresque life in which you've won a Tony Award and an Emmy Award, starred in ''The Beastmaster'' and ''The Larry Sanders Show'' alike and been preserved on film wrestling Norman Mailer to the ground may earn you a special place in the hearts of the people, but it doesn't exempt you from obeying the law. Rip Torn has pleaded guilty to charges stemming from a January incident in which he was arrested after taking a loaded revolver into a bank in Litchfield, Conn., The Associated Press reported. David Shepack, a Connecticut prosecutor, told The A.P. that Mr. Torn pleaded guilty Tuesday to reckless endangerment, criminal trespass, criminal mischief and illegally carrying of a firearm and received a two-and-a-half-year suspended sentence and three years' probation; he will have to submit to random drug and alcohol tests as part of the probation. A lawyer for Mr. Torn said the actor was thankful that no one had been injured and that he had not been sent to jail. But he did provide us with an excuse to post ''Torn and Frayed'' by the Rolling Stones below:

7:17 p.m. | Updated Initial casting has been announced for the New York production of Tony Kushner's new play, ''The Intelligent Homosexual's Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures,'' which will run at the Public Theater from March 22 through June 12, 2011, with opening night set for May 5. Michael Cristofer, Linda Emond, Michael Esper and Stephen Spinella will reprise their roles from the production at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, where the play premiered in 2009. Joining them will be the actors Bill Camp (''Notes From Underground'') and Steven Pasquale (''reasons to be pretty''), who are replacing Mark Benninghofen and Ron Menzel, respectively. Additional casting is still to be announced.

7:52 p.m. | Updated The board of Capital Shopping Centers of Britain rebuffed a $4.8 billion overture on Wednesday from the American developer Simon Property, the latest development in the highly contentious mating dance between the two mall owners. Simon Property stepped forward with an informal offer of 425 pence a share for Capital Shopping. Hours later, Capital Shopping's directors unanimously rejected the plan, saying it ''very substantially'' undervalued the company and its prospects.

III (Kay) of Burbank, CA and Nancy MacMillen Brown (John) of Pomona, NY. Barbara is also survived by seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. A lifelong amateur athlete, she was an avid skier and won numerous golf, squash and tennis tournaments at the Rockaway Hunting Club and the Saratoga Golf Club, where she met Bill. Barbara was a world traveler, a gracious hostess, a gourmet cook and an active volunteer in her community. Her generosity, engaging manner and tremendous spirit will be remembered and missed by her family and her many friends. A memorial tribute and luncheon will be held at the Rockaway Hunting Club, Lawrence, NY, on Saturday, January 8, 2011 at 11am.

The over-the-knee boot, worn perhaps most memorably by Julia Roberts, may not be ideal for navigating city sidewalks, but the stacked heel on the Ralph Lauren Collection Vallerie boot in tumbled vachetta leather makes strutting easier. At Ralph Lauren, select stores, $1,350. BIKER CHICK CHIC Church's Carly ($515) has treads for traction; buckles and laces add flare. An up-to-minute take from the British company founded in 1873. Of all the news releases inundating my in-box in the weeks before the annual Consumer Electronics Show - new cameras, new computer chips, a ton of gadgets for the iPhone and iPad - the one least likely to catch the attention of any au courant reviewer was about a new phonograph preamplifier. Of course, it caught mine.

ERLANGER--Jack, known for his valor in war, his abiding love of family, and an outstretched hand to all in need, left this world peacefully on December 13 at his home in New York. He was 86. In 1940, at age 16, Jack joined the Royal Canadian Air Force to fight in World War II. He served with the US Air Force in the Pacific and was decorated with bronze and silver medals. In 1948, he fought with the Israel Air Force in the War of Independence. Jack was a textile manufacturer and later became a financial adviser and broker. He was a devoted husband to Meryl and an adoring father to son John Lipman, daughter Jennifer Gebhardt, son-in-law Morgan Gebhardt and grandson Jason Gebhardt. He believed in God, country, and family. Jack, your memory will live on in the lives of those who loved you. Erlanger Family

SMOLLENS--Harry, on December 14, 2010, age 95. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of Susan and Steven (Sherrill), dear brother of Rita, adoring grandfather of Lily Anne and Amelia Rose. Service, Friday 9:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BELL--Karen Z. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend, Karen Z. Bell, wife of our partner and dear friend, Sanford A. Bell, and we offer our sympathy and condolences to Sandy, Katherine and Jonathan at this sad and difficult time. Teitler & Teitler

AFTER 10 years with Lutz & Patmos, Marcia Patmos has introduced her own collection, M.Patmos, featuring her trademark luxury knits and extending her repertory to trousers, vests, outerwear and hand-beaded silk dresses. Lutz & Patmos guest designers included Julianne Moore, Jane Birkin and Richard Meier. This season, Ms. Patmos was inspired by the art of a friend, Rebecca Chamberlain, whose ink drawings of sleek modern interiors have a hand-worked quality; the collection is elegant minimalism with vintage-inspired tailoring, like hand-picked stitching on pleated trouser belt loops, and dressmaking details, like silk piping on a jacket's inside edge. Ms. Patmos, above, models the drape front cardigan ($985). M.Patmos is at Barneys New York, Kirna Zabête and Edit (from $295 to $3,100).
SOBEL--Terry. All of us at Land'n Sea mourn the loss of its great matriarch Terry Sobel. May we continue to live up to her level of class and dignity.

An article on Friday about geocaching, an activity in which people use global positioning system devices to find hidden objects, misstated the action affecting those devices that President Bill Clinton took in 2000. He ordered that the intentional degrading of signals received by civilians end, making their devices more accurate. He did not announce that GPS technology would be available to the public; it had been for several years.

GREENFIELD--Bruce F. On December 12, Bruce F. Greenfield the longtime Executive Director of the United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism's New York Metropolitan Region died suddenly at his home in North Bellmore, Long Island. Beloved husband of Annette. Loving father of Michael and Adena, Ari and Stacey, Danit and Eric Taub. Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Atara Rafi, Ava and Ian.
HOLBROOKE--Richard. Kati, Our love and thoughts are with you and your family. Ricki Roer and Paul McIsaac

An article on Saturday about allegations in a State Department cable released by WikiLeaks over Pfizer's tactics in fighting lawsuits stemming from drug trials on Nigerian children overstated what is known about how Pfizer ultimately handled the dispute. While Pfizer did reach a financial settlement with Nigeria, the amount was not disclosed. It is not the case that the company paid $75 million. (An earlier settlement with the Nigerian state of Kano, where the trials occurred, was $75 million.)
SOBEL--Terry. Beloved friend, will be missed forever. Heart felt sympathy to Seymour, Leslie, Robby (Meryl) and grandchildren. Selma Rosen

COWAN--Marvin S. September 5, 1923 - December 12, 2010. For 61 years, beloved husband of Lois Goldman Cowan. Adored father of Hillery and George Ballantyne, Beryl Ann Cowan, and Candiss Cowan and Robert Neufeld. Cherished grandfather of Dustin Newman, Gabriel Frumkin, Sidni Newman and Amara Frumkin. Treasured brother and brother-in-law of Lewis and Ruth Cowan, Sonya and Bernard Friedman and Sue Goldman. Devoted son, nephew, uncle and cousin, lifelong friend and mentor to many others. Veteran of World War II. A graduate of New York University and Harvard Law School, Marvin was a founding partner of Cowan, Liebowitz and Latman, PC. He was committed to the highest standards in the practice of law and served as trusted counsel to many during a legal career that spanned over fifty years. Marvin valued friendships above all else, and his loyalty to others was returned in kind by people of all ages. At the center of his life was his extended family. Calling hours will be 4-7pm on Wednesday, December 15, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Funeral and burial will be private. Friends and family are invited to attend a memorial celebration of his life at The Harvard Club of New York City, 27 West 44th Street, on December 17, 2010 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cowan Family Scholarship at Westchester Community College, 75 Grasslands Road, Valhalla, NY, 10595 or to Children's Services, Mental Health Association of Westchester, 2269 Saw Mill River Rd., Elmsford, NY 10523 would be appreciated.

SOBEL--Terry (Helene). The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member, Terry Sobel. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her entire family. Michael Barasch, President William Schultz, Secretary

T. I. may be impeded from many things while he serves a prison sentence after a recent parole violation, but not from cracking the Top 10 on the album sales chart. This rapper's latest release, ''No Mercy,'' sold 159,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen Soundscan figures reported by Billboard.com, good enough to make it No. 4 for the week but a far cry from the 568,000 copies his previous album, ''Paper Trail,'' sold in its first week in 2008 when it made its debut at No. 1. This week's top seller was once again ''The Gift,'' by Susan Boyle, which moved 243,000 copies and has racked up 1.43 million sales in five weeks. The No. 2 slot went to Taylor Swift's ''Speak Now,'' with 201,000 sales, followed by the ''Glee'' Christmas album, with 193,000. The week's second-biggest debut was the release of Daft Punk's score to the coming Disney film ''Tron: Legacy,'' which sold 71,000 copies, good enough to chart at No. 10. That's the strongest showing Daft Punk has enjoyed on the album chart, and the highest position and best sales a score album has seen since the 2005 release of ''Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith.''

POP-UP The Hester Street Fair, on sabbatical from its outside locale until April, is setting up shop on Friday at 11 a.m. as THE BIG SOCIAL HOLIDAY MARKET at the Open House Gallery space at 201 Mulberry Street (917-267-9496; Hesterstreetfair.com). The market will celebrate its opening, appropriately enough given its name, with a party hosted by Santos Party House on Friday from 7 to 11 p.m. The market will have a mini food court and vendors selling handmade goods, jewelry and vintage gift items, and will last through Dec. 23. Hours: 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily.

BELL--Karen Zelfman, 63, of Larchmont, NY passed away on December 15, 2010, beloved wife of Sanford for 37 years; adoring and adored mother of Catherine Bell and Maddie Ribble and Jonathan and Julie Bell; devoted daughter of the late Esther Zelfman; loving sister of Barbara and Norman Gross and Linda Buxbaum and sister-in-law of Linda Bell. Dear friend and esteemed colleague. Attorney. Former President, Westchester Women's Bar Assoc.; Member, Board of Directors of Women's Bar Assoc. of the State of NY; Director of Westchester Women's Bar Assoc. Foundation. Service 10:00am, Friday, December 17 at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY. Contributions may be made to the Westchester Women's Bar Assoc. Foundation c/o Robin Carton, 5 Waller Ave., White Plains, NY 10601 or to Sloan Kettering c/o Patient Free Care Fund at MSK Cancer Center, P.O. Box 5028, Hagerstown, MD 21741. For details call Fox Funeral Home, 914-834-0144.
A report last Thursday in the Scouting Report column about a jewelry designer's sample sale misspelled his given name. He is Isaac Manevitz, not Issac.

8:29 p.m. | Updated The Carlyle Group solidified its standing as one of the year's busiest deal makers this week with an agreement late Monday to sell the real estate of its big nursing home operator, HCR ManorCare, to the real estate investment firm HCP for about $6.1 billion. The deal is the largest involving a real estate investment trust like HCR in the last three years, and will bolster HCP's presence in high-end nursing. HCR, based in Toledo, Ohio, is among the nation's biggest nursing operators and has benefited from rising demand for care that costs less than what hospitals can provide.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- Giants receiver Steve Smith, who went to the Pro Bowl last season after setting a franchise record with 107 catches, was put on injured reserve Wednesday after sustaining a cartilage injury to his left knee during a 21-3 win over the Vikings on Monday. The loss of Smith is a significant setback. With Mario Manningham gimpy with a hip-flexor injury (he insists he is fine) and Hakeem Nicks (lower leg injury) still not 100 percent, Eli Manning will rely on some combination of Derek Hagan, Michael Clayton and Devin Thomas, all of whom signed midseason as free agents.

In a bid to turn down the temperature in what promises to be an extended legal battle, Bank of America has opened a dialogue with investors who want the bank to buy back tens of billions in soured mortgages. But bank officials insisted on Wednesday the talks did not represent a shift in strategy by the company's chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, who has promised ''hand to hand combat,'' fighting the so-called put-back claims on a loan-by-loan basis.

THE Kyoto-based watchmaker dedegumo has opened its first store in the United States, and customers can watch craftsmen in its open workshop. Adhering to the techniques of dedegumo's founder, Izumo Senco, a single artisan builds each of the one-of-a-kind watches, which feature brass, copper and colorful leather straps as well as unique faces and hands (pictured, $425). Each watch comes in a masu, a wooden box, and is wrapped in a furoshiki, traditional Japanese wrapping cloth, with the name of the watchmaker included. The Brooklyn-based architectural firm JPDA incorporated Japanese design elements, using reclaimed wood, into the compact space on the Lower East Side; dedegumo, 188 Orchard Street; (212) 677-1977; dedegumo.com.

Neil Diamond, Alice Cooper, Tom Waits, Dr. John and Darlene Love are the latest inductees to the pantheon of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the organization will announce on Wednesday morning. Ms. Love, the go-to backup singer in the 1960s who sang on many of Phil Spector's biggest hits -- sometimes as the lead, but not always with credit -- had been nominated twice before, but all of the other performers had been nominated for the first time. In addition, Leon Russell is being honored with the award for musical excellence (formerly known as the sidemen award), and nonperformer honors will go to Jac Holzman, who founded Elektra Records, and Art Rupe, who created the Specialty label.

It's hard to describe ''Momentum,'' the newest offering from the Israeli performance troupe Mayumana. But it's easy to like what you see. Even when your inner cynic tries to label the show a ''Stomp'' clone or ''De La Guarda'' light, the 90 minutes of dancing, songs and percussion will have your inner child smiling too much to care.

HOLBROOKE--Richard C. The Trustees and community of the American Museum of Natural History are deeply saddened by the sudden and untimely death of our former Trustee Richard Holbrooke. Others have duly lauded him as one of the most brilliant statesmen and diplomats of our time; we remember him as well as a greatly valued colleague and dear friend. Richard shared the Museum's commitment to fostering cross-cultural relationships and collaborations, and was especially engaged by the Museums partnership with the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology, the first collaboration between cultural institutions from the two countries since the Vietnam War. His impact on our world is undeniably monumental, and we shall not see his like again. Still, it is his friendship and wise counsel that we hold dear. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Kati and the entire Holbrooke family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

It was big: 1,900 pages. It was expensive: $1.2 trillion. And it was loaded with Washington's favorite white meat: more than 6,000 earmarks. But on Thursday night, it went the way of the rest of the dinosaurs: "The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Thursday night that he was abandoning efforts to pass a $1.2 trillion spending measure to finance the government through Sept. 30 because Republicans would not support it," reported The Times's David M. Herszenhorn. "Mr. Reid said he would work with the Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, on a stop-gap spending bill instead. Senate Republicans also said they would not support a House-passed temporary spending measure running through the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. Instead, they want to develop a separate measure running only through the early part of next year."
More Photographs

Few who fly - or fly coach, anyway - would disagree that the entire experience of air travel from check-in to landing carries with it an overwhelming sense that everyone involved has simply given up. Watch people as they enter airports: shoulders rise, expressions grow steely, civility erodes. Things that shouldn't be a big deal - learning that you'll have an on-time departure or receiving a free bag of potato chips - feel like winning lottery tickets, so low have our expectations become.

Schumer, Democrat of New York, has been working feverishly to convince Republican colleagues to support legislation that would provide compensation and medical assistance to some rescue workers and others injured in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

The comments on this week's column on kangaroo care were extraordinary.  Reader after reader told personal, emotional stories of how they did kangaroo care - wearing a baby for many hours a day on a parent's chest -- with their premature babies.  I particularly liked the story sent in by Anita Bruce of Modesto, Calif.: her five- and seven-year-old boys also took turns kangarooing their preemie sister.  Many other readers discussed the wonders of holding their newborns of normal weight, and even older children.  Clearly, kangaroo care was already familiar to many people, and its benefits instinctively appreciated.

The National Gallery of Canada has thrown its support behind a Canadian artist, AA Bronson, who is seeking to have one of his works withdrawn in protest from a National Portrait Gallery show, "Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture." In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan looks at the impact of the new tax law on the estates of the wealthy. He concludes that only the richest of the rich will end up paying an estate tax over the next two years and that even those few people will be able to reduce their tax bill by taking advantage of the exemption for gift taxes.

FORT LEWIS, Wa. -- Mark Zuckerberg is a name I grew quite familiar with even through my year in Kandahar. Facebook was the novelty through which I interacted with most of the world back home. Though it was accessible only on our trips to the forward operating base -- no connectivity on our stranded outpost in the Zhari District. Despite all that Facebook meant to me while at war, I was less than thrilled to find that Mr. Zuckerberg had been named Time Magazine's Person of the Year.

According to N.H.L. deputy commissioner Bill Daly, the league's system of sharing revenue with lower-profile teams in large markets will likely change in the next collective bargaining agreement. In the C.B.A. that was negotiated in 2005, it was decided that teams in markets with television households of 2.5 million or more would not qualify for revenue sharing. Beyond Palencia, however, Domínguez is struggling to generate sympathy amid allegations that she was involved in a network that trafficked in performance-enhancing substances.

MOSCOW -- Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday said that an outburst of nationalist violence in Moscow proved that Russia could not allow its law enforcement bodies to weaken, despite the arguments of ''our liberal intelligentsia.'' In a marathon question-and-answer session that went on for four hours and 29 minutes, Mr. Putin offered a bravura defense of the central control that is a hallmark of his leadership.

An article on Monday about inmates in Georgia prisons who used contraband cellphones to coordinate a protest misidentified the location of Smith Prison. It is in Glennville, not Downing. While Ms. Brown considers him her son and says she has ''spiritually'' adopted him, he is not her biological son.

Devin Harris knew that facing the Washington Wizards, a team without a road victory this season, was the best opportunity for the Nets to snap their eight-game losing streak -- and he had to be the one to do something about it. ''This was one we had to have,'' said Harris, who called a team meeting before the game, then went out and had 29 points and 9 assists in the Nets' 97-89 victory Thursday night. ''If I'm going to be the guy here, then it's all about being aggressive and making things happen.''

An article on Tuesday about new guidelines for giving tenure to New York City teachers referred incorrectly to their job security. Teachers can indeed be dismissed, though it is considered a difficult process. They are not guaranteed lifetime employment.

MEYER--Mary Donovan, of Rye, NY, a teacher, attorney and world traveler, passed away on December 15, 2010. She was born on December 4, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY. Mrs. Meyer graduated from Barnard College, Class of 1935, with a bachelor of science in chemistry. She went on to earn her master's degree in education from Columbia University, and taught high school chemistry for several years before her marriage to Charles H. Meyer, with whom she traveled the world during their 15 years of marriage. Mrs. Meyer went on to earn a law degree from Syracuse University in 1970, where she graduated second in her class. She then joined the Manhattan law firm Shea & Gould, where she was its first female lawyer. She will be remembered for her tremendous story-telling ability, unmatched knowledge of culture and history, and her kindness and devotion to her family. She is survived by her two sisters: Ruth Donovan Ruth of Rye and Marion Donovan of Norfolk, CT; a brother, John Donovan of Emerson, NJ; and a stepson, Charles Harrison Meyer of Washington, D.C. She is also survived by a nephew, Timothy Ruth of Alpharetta, GA; and six nieces: Mary E. Ruth of New York, NY, Anne Ruth of Bronxville, NY, Julie Ruth of Old Greenwich, CT, Claudia Metter of Alexandria, VA, Marcia DeSalvo of Emerson, NJ and Claire Long of San Diego, CA; several grandnieces and a grandnephew. She was predeceased by her husband in 1962. Services will be private.

Confirming recent speculation, the Broadway production of ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' starring Vanessa Redgrave, left, James Earl Jones and Boyd Gaines, will extend through April 9, 2011, the producers of the show announced Wednesday. All three actors will remain with the production, which was scheduled to run through Jan. 29, 2011. The revival of Alfred Uhry's 1987 play, directed by David Esbjornson, opened at the Golden Theater on Oct. 25 to mixed reviews. During a season in which many shows have struggled at the box office, the play has been a commercial success, earning $732,896 in eight performances last week. (The only play to do better was ''The Merchant of Venice,'' with Al Pacino.)

LONDON - For Leonhard H. Fischer, chief executive of the European investment firm RHJ International, the future of banking lies in its past. When Kleinwort Benson, the eminent British private banking brand with a 200-year history, came up for sale last year, RHJI, a spinoff of the American private equity house Ripplewood, swooped in. The acquisition of the business was completed in July for 230 million, or $363 million.

For its next original series AMC is going back to the '60s -- the 1860s, that is. On Wednesday AMC, the cable-television home of the period drama ''Mad Men'' (as well as ''Breaking Bad'' and ''The Walking Dead''), said it had committed to a full season of ''Hell on Wheels,'' a series set in post-Civil War America. In a news release AMC said ''Hell on Wheels,'' which is created and written by the sibling screenwriters Joe and Tony Gayton (''Faster''), would star Anson Mount as Cullen Bohannan, a former soldier in the Confederate Army who, in searching for the Union soldiers who killed his wife, finds his way to a lawless town called Hell on Wheels, and to the construction of the first transcontinental railroad. The release said the series would explore ''the railroad's institutionalized greed and corruption, the immigrant experience and the plight of the newly emancipated African-Americans during Reconstruction.'' Additional cast members include the rapper Common (whose acting credits include ''Just Wright'' and ''Date Night'') and Colm Meaney (of the ''Star Trek'' spinoffs ''The Next Generation'' and ''Deep Space Nine''); no premiere date has been announced. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Erik D. Prince, founder of the private security firm formerly known as Blackwater Worldwide, has reached a deal to sell his embattled firm to a small group of investors based in Los Angeles who have close ties to Mr. Prince, according to people briefed on the deal. Blackwater, now called Xe Services, was once the United States' go-to contractor in Iraq and Afghanistan. It has been under intense pressure since 2007, when Blackwater guards were accused of killing 17 civilians in Nisour Square in Baghdad. The company, its executives and personnel have faced civil lawsuits, criminal charges and congressional investigations surrounding accusations of murder and bribery. In April, federal prosecutors announced weapons charges against five former senior Blackwater executives, including its former president.

'A Visit from St. Nicholas' (Sunday) The holiday would not be complete without a reading of Clement Clarke Moore's poem ''A Visit From St. Nicholas,'' and on Sunday there will be two. At 4 p.m., the 100th annual reading of the poem at the Church of the Intercession, Broadway at West 155th Street, Washington Heights, will feature the actor Malik Yoba; there will also be music and caroling and a procession to Moore's grave in the nearby cemetery (participants at a past event, above); (212) 283-6200. HOLBROOKE--Richard C. The Staff and Trustees of the American Academy in Berlin mourn the loss of Richard C. Holbrooke, the Academy's founder, longtime Chairman, and passionate advocate. During the mid 1990s, as United States troops left the city they had protected during the Cold War, Ambassador Holbrooke conceived the idea of replacing the US military presence with a lasting American intellectual and cultural presence. Through his unique vision, passion, and extraordinary powers of persuasion, the American Academy in Berlin was born. And he accomplished all of this while actively involved in major foreign policy initiatives on behalf of his country. Richard Holbrooke's friendship, intellect, and personality were indispensable to the institution's continuing success. The Academy opened its doors as a center for visiting American scholars, writers, artists, and public policy experts in 1998. Over the past 15 years, thanks to Ambassador Holbrooke, the American Academy has evolved into a major voice in the US-German dialogue, reinforcing the bonds between the people of Germany and the people of the United States. His mentorship, creativity, and ever inspiring presence will be greatly missed by all of us. Henry A. Kissinger and Karl von der Heyden, Co-Chair Gahl Hodges Burt, Vice-Chair Norman Pearlstine, President & CEO Gary Smith, Executive Dir.

FALZON--Norbert, 87, Economist, Linguist and U.N. Aide. Norbert Falzon, a natural resources economist, linguist and retired senior United Nations official, died on December 6, 2010 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 87. He was one of the first to draw attention to the potential of new and renewable sources of energy, such as geothermal, solar energy/wind power, for the economic development of developing countries. As early as 1960, he was instrumental in the preparation and publication of a series of studies and books aimed at assisting emerging countries in the growth of their natural resources. The first one was entitled "New Sources of Energy and Economic Development" (1960) and was followed by six other studies encompassing all aspects of economic progress. Dr. Falzon was also fluent in four of the official languages of the United Nations. He was, for a time, Dean of the United Nations French Language Program. A French citizen, Dr. Falzon studied at the University of Paris and at the London School of Economics. He held doctorates in Economics, Physics and International law. Dr. Falzon served with distinction in the First French Army during World War II. He joined the United Nations Secretariat in 1951 and retired as Deputy Director of the Technical Cooperation Department in 1983. Dr. Falzon is survived by his wife, daughter, son-in-law and grandchildren.

Where does one go after ''Shakespeare in Love,'' which ends with its title character immersing himself in the writing of ''Twelfth Night'' while his sweetheart, Viola, is bound for the New World? What comes next? ''Shakespeare in Tears''? ''Shakespeare in Bed, Eating Bon-Bons''? ''Shakespeare in a Disappointing Marriage With Anne Hathaway, Running Out the Clock While Thinking of Gwyneth Paltrow''? We may find out sooner than anyone expected: a follow-up to ''Shakespeare in Love'' is one of several sequels being planned under an agreement announced Thursday by Miramax and the Weinstein Company. The two studios said they would work together on new films, television shows and other entertainment properties.

NEWMAN--Arthur B.,a loving family man, died peacefully on December 16, 2010, surrounded by his family at his home in New York City. He was 67. The cause was cancer. Mr. Newman was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Eileen; his children, Sondra, Allison, and David; his son-in-law, Cengiz, his daughter-in-law, Stephanie; and his six grandchildren, Leah, Sarah, Alex, Oliver, Isabella, and Zeki. Mr. Newman enjoyed many lifelong friendships. He especially loved playing cards, solving puzzles, and spending time with family and friends. In a career spanning more that 40 years, Mr. Newman served as an advisor to debtors and creditors to some of the nation's largest and most complex business restructurings, including America West Airlines, American Pad & Paper Co., AMF Bowling, Arch Wireless, The Charter Co., Chiquita Banana, Dow Corning, Eastern Airlines, Enron, Exide Technologies, Eurotunnel, General Electric Credit, Global Crossing, Goodyear Tire & Rubber, Iridium, LTV, Levitz Furniture, Macy's, Manville, Mobile Media, Montgomery Ward, Sunbeam, and Texaco. Mr. Newman began his career in 1966 at S.D. Leidesdorf & Co., a predecessor through merger of Ernst & Young. At Ernst & Young he founded the corporate finance department and restructuring practice, which he led until 1989. After 18 months with Chemical Bank, Mr. Newman joined the Blackstone Group in 1991, launching the firm's restructuring and reorganization practice, which he led until his retirement in June of 2010. Mr. Newman received his BS and MBA from Rutgers University. Mr. Newman served on the corporate boards of Associated Camps, CIT, the Fund for Modern Courts, Lone Star Industries, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Premium Standard Farms, and Toys 'R Us. Mr. Newman's dedication to hard work, fair dealings and equal justice has been honored with various awards, including: the AJC's 2009 Herbert H. Lehman Human Relations Award, the 2007 Justice inMotion Award, and the 1990 award by the Bankruptcy & Reorganization Group of the Lawyers Division of UJA-Federation. Arthur Barry Newman was born in Newark, New Jersey on October 12, 1943. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, 333 E. 30th St., New York, NY, 10016, or the New York Presbyterian Hospital Fund, 425 E. 61st St., Suite 211, New York, NY 10065. Funeral Service, Sunday 11:30am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave., at 81st St.

A map last Friday with an article about the tensions arising nationwide because of illegal immigrants who drive without licenses erroneously labeled West Virginia as Maryland and omitted the percentage of Hispanic drivers killed in crashes in West Virginia from 2000-2009 who did not have licenses. It was 21 percent. (Though the map did not label Maryland, it correctly noted that the figure there was 23 percent .)

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the discovery of four bodies on Long Island misspelled the given name of a woman who was the subject of a search by the police when the bodies were discovered. She is Shannan Gilbert, not Shannon. The error was repeated in an article on Wednesday about the possibility that the killings might be the work of a serial killer.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the dismissal of Iran's foreign minister by the president misstated the given name of the speaker of Iran's parliament, who heads a faction of moderate politicians engaged in a power struggle with the president. He is Ali Larijani, not Ari.

The lead producers of the new Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' have decided again to delay its opening night, now scheduled for Jan. 11, until sometime in February, two people involved with the musical said on Thursday. With preview performances now under way the delay is intended to provide more time for the creators to stage a new final number, make further rewrites to the dialogue and consider adding and cutting scenes and perhaps inserting new music from the composers, U2's Bono and the Edge, who will resume working full-time on the show in late December. The producers and creators are still weighing the extent of the changes that they believe the musical needs before theater critics see it during the week before opening night, according to the two people involved with the show, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the producers and their spokesman are supposed to make the only public comments. The spokesman, Rick Miramontez, declined to comment on Thursday.

A caption for a satellite image on Tuesday with an article about disagreement among physicists over concentric ring patterns in the cosmic microwave background may have left the impression that the rings shown were clearly visible in satellite data. In fact, the image was modified by researchers to highlight what they see as evidence of black hole collisions in earlier versions of the universe.

HOLBROOKE--Richard C. The many participants in Dayton-A Peace Process and Dayton Literary Peace Prize events, Sister City exchanges, and Friendship Force missions to Bosnia-Herzegovina mourn Ambassador Richard Holbrooke's passing. (CMT) EMANCIPATED Lorin, above, a privileged 16-year-old from New Orleans who believes she doesn't need parental supervision, receives a reality check when she is given only 10 minutes to pack her bags and bid her family farewell before embarking on a three-week trial separation. That means trading her Range Rover, credit cards and luxurious surroundings for an unfurnished rental house without electricity and only a small amount of money for her basic needs. (HGTV) HOLIDAY BATTLE ON THE BLOCK Lights by the tens of thousands. Soldiers. Dancing snowflakes and a sugarplum fairy. In the third of four episodes, three neighboring families in Youngstown, N.Y., pull out the stops and then some to create the best holiday displays. FREBERGE--Albert, on December 15, 2010, devoted husband of Phyllis, beloved father to Eve, Julie, step-children Karen, David and Barbara, cherished grandfather to Elizabeth, Madeleine, and Aron, father-in-law to Frank, Phil, Paul and Anne, cousin to Evelyne, Frankie, Ludovic, and Anthony, dear friend to Charles and many others. Albert, a hidden teenager during the Holocaust, joined the French Resistance as a courier and saboteur of German munitions. He was awarded the Croix de Guerre for heroism in Vietnam. He was an entertainer a la Maurice Chevalier and a volunteer at the Queens Museum of Art. He will be missed greatly for his joie de vivre and warmth. He loved wholeheartedly and was loved in return. Services on Friday at Parkside in Queens at 1:15pm. Donations to US Holocaust Museum.

America met Stephen L. Baltz on Dec. 16, 1960, held him in a collective embrace for a day and then, grieving, let him go. It was as if some celestial central casting agency had carefully assigned the role of courageous survivor to an 11-year-old boy whose life - had it been spared - would have lent to the senseless wreckage one single note of grace. Stephen was, for a day, the only survivor of the air disaster over New York City, the 50th anniversary of which is on Thursday. Badly burned, he died the next day. He had been a sixth grader at Central School in Wilmette, Ill., a Chicago suburb. He had served devotedly as a Boy Scout. He had played Little League. He had sung in the First Methodist Church choir. He had been plucky enough to be traveling All by Himself.
SOBEL--Terry. To my dearest friend Terry, we shared the fondest of memories filled with laughter and tears. You will be in my heart always. Charlotte Elias

FASHION FORWARD Bonobos raised $18.5 million in a financing round led by the venture capital firms Lightspeed Venture Partners and Accel Partners. Bonobos, which makes menswear, including fitted oxford dress shirts, wool cashmere suits and boat shoes, was started by Andy Dunn, above, and his Stanford Business School roommate, Brian Spaly. Mr. Dunn said several customers from New York's financial industry invested early. Before this round, the company had raised $7.75 million from 75 individuals -- with Wall Streeters representing 20 percent of the investors and 30 percent of the funds. EVELYN M. RUSLI

FEINMAN--Lawrence M.D.,on December 15, 2010. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of Tamara and Joshua, dear brother of Elaine and Silvia and the late Bernard. Service Sunday 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

8:45 p.m. | Updated Federal authorities on Thursday arrested three employees of some of the world's largest technology companies on charges that they leaked confidential corporate information. The charges are the latest brought by the government in its rapidly expanding investigation into insider trading on Wall Street. A fourth employee pleaded guilty and is cooperating with investigators. The four are accused of tipping off hedge funds and others with nonpublic information on sales figures for companies like Dell and Advanced Micro Devices, as well as providing details about new products like the AppleiPhone.

Maynard W. Glitman, a diplomat who led the American side in negotiating the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty, signed by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1987, died on Tuesday in Shelburne, Vt. He was 77 and had homes in Fletcher and Burlington, Vt. The cause was complications of dementia, his wife, Christine, said.
CANTOR--Bernie. Happy Birthday. I will always remember how you touched my life more than ever. Iris

The union which allows actors to get unemployment has announced its favorite performances of the year. The Screen Actors Guild gave high marks to ''The Fighter'' and ''King's Speech,'' which both received four nominations, including best ensemble, the group's version of best picture. The other best ensemble honorees: ''Black Swan,'' ''The Social Network'' and ''The Kids Are All Right.'' ''The Fighter'' scored with nominations for three of its four leads - Christian Bale, Melissa Leo and Amy Adams, who will be competing against each other for best supporting actress. ''The King's Speech'' main cast - Colin Firth, Geoffrey Rush and Helena Bonham Carter - all got nominations. A notable omission from the best actress category: Julianne Moore, whose co-star in ''The Kids Are All Right,'' Annette Bening, did get the nod. (Both women were nominated for a Golden Globe.) What might've been Ms. Moore's spot was taken by Hilary Swank for ''Conviction.'' Michelle Willliams and Ryan Gosling, who do some power-acting in ''Blue Valentine,'' were also snubbed.

WEINSTEIN--Gail, Ph.D.,died at home on December 8. She is survived by her parents, Beatrice and Gene Weinstein, brother Bruce and beloved daughter, Hannah Rebecca Shr. For more information, go to: http://memorialwebsites. legacy.com/gailweinstein biography/homepage.aspx

It's not every day that the barons of the buyout industry find themselves on the shorter end of a sweet deal. But that's arguably the case in the turnaround of BankUnited, a relatively small Florida bank that's about to return to the public markets. John Kanas, who led the deal and runs the bank, is poised to collect nearly $100 million of the profits his private equity partners will make. That's an impressive feat given the caliber of the investors who backed him, a group that includes Carlyle, Blackstone, Wilbur Ross and the LeFrak family. But they won't be crying, either. All told, Mr. Kanas and BankUnited's financiers look set to turn a $940 million investment into a cool $2.8 billion or more, thanks to negotiating a bargain price when buying the bank from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in May 2009.

KAUTZ--Caroline M.,formerly of Summit, NJ and NYC, died on December 11, 2010 in Tucson, AZ from Alzheimer's. Born on December 25, 1933, Carol graduated from Vassar College in 1955 and married Jim Kautz in 1957. She is survived by Jim as well as her children, Leslie Kautz and Dan Kautz. Carol will be remembered for her gracious warmth, intelligence and kindness. A service will be held at St. Philip's in the Hills Church in Tucson on January 8, 2011 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Vassar College, www.vassar.edu.

Schedule information on Monday with a theater review of ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' at the Steppenwolf Theater Company's Downstairs Theater in Chicago, misstated the play's running time. It is about three hours, not two hours.

Enrique Morente, one of the world's most celebrated flamenco singers, whose work embraced both traditional styles and contemporary influences as diverse as George Gershwin and Leonard Cohen, died on Monday in a Madrid hospital. He was 67. Hospital officials confirmed the death to The Associated Press, giving no cause. According to many reports in the European news media, Mr. Morente died as a result of complications of surgery he underwent earlier this month.

GOLD--Peter, of Scarsdale, NY and Wainscott, NY died December 15, age 74. Survived by beloved wife Dorothy. Devoted father of Debra Santora (Robert), Amy McDonald (David), Julie Gold, Richard Lieberman (Lauren), Paul Lieberman and Jodi Moss (Matt). Loving Poppa to Matthew, Gregory, Lilly, James, Alistair, Justin, Theo, Ryan, Lindsey, Zachary, Ellie and Juliette. Healthy and active until the last few months of his life. He was committed to the highest standards in the practice of accounting and enjoyed his career for over fifty years. He enjoyed the camaraderie of his colleagues at work and his golf buddies at play. Funeral Service to be held on Sunday, December 19, at Scarsdale Synagogue, 2 Ogden Road, Scarsdale, NY at 12pm. Memorial contributions in honor of Peter can be made to Animal Rescue Fund, PO Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975.

My Sunday column is a variant of the gift guides that are proliferating everywhere in the news media -- gift guides for electronics, perfumes, clothing, etc. I always find that the question I get asked the most is: What can I do? What's a good group to support? So this column is an attempt to answer those questions, listing a number of little-known charities at home and abroad that I think do good work. Of course it's far from an exhaustive list, omitting in particular the bigger and better-known groups. I also had a similar list a year ago, with different groups. And I'd also welcome your suggestions for other groups (or other humanitarian gifts) that should be on this list.

Disunion readers might want to see two related pieces on Sunday's op-ed page: Jill Lepore writes that Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's most famous poem, published on Dec. 20, 1860, wasn't really about Paul Revere and his famous ride, but a wake-up call about the looming Civil War. And Edward Ball writes that even though neo-confederates like to say the Civil War was about states' rights, a quick glance at South Carolina's ordinances of secession shows that the only right the South cared about concerned the ownership of other human beings.

India's growing popularity among jet-setters continues to translate into new hotels. In these eco-conscious times, many people want to shrink their environmental footprint while still enjoying the trappings of the holiday season. In some cases, the earth-friendly alternative - pass the tofurky - is a pretty obvious choice.

Outright sexism is obviously still a part of the workplace today, but it's also vastly reduced. Foraging in winter has its obvious challenges - freezing temperatures, dying flora, and scarce edible greens save for hardy garlic mustard and field garlic. While artists, foundations and activists continue to protest the Smithsonian Institution's decision to pull an AIDS-themed video from an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery after it was criticized by the head of the Catholic League and some Republican members of Congress, dozens of museums, including the Tate Modern, are lining up to show the disputed video, by the artist David Wojnarowicz. And earlier this week the artist AA Bronson wrote to the director of the National Portrait Gallery, a Smithsonian museum, to ask that the gallery remove one of his works from the exhibition, ''Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portaiture,'' which explores homosexual themes, The Washington Post reported. The Bronson work in question, a wall-sized photograph titled ''Felix, June 5, 1994,'' shows the corpse of Mr. Bronson's partner shortly after he died of AIDS. It is on loan to the exhibition from the National Gallery of Canada. A spokeswoman for the National Portrait Gallery said that the gallery wanted to keep the exhibition intact and therefore would not return the photograph early, according to the blog Modern Art Notes.

COSTER--Peter, 71, died December 11, 2010. He is survived by Sonya, his wife of 51 years; three sons, Daniel and his wife Margaret, Nicholas and his partner Dean, and Patrick and his wife Eleisa; and two grandchildren, Kai and Logan. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the passing of this extraordinary man. We will always be buoyed by the greatness of his spirit, lifted by the memory of his kindness, and inspired by his consideration and compassion, which brought so much joy and laughter to all the people who were fortunate enough to know him. Peter was born in South London, served in the UK Intelligence Corps, and had an illustrious business career highlighted by his 20 years with Marsh & McLennan Companies, from which he retired in 2005. During his time at Marsh & McLennan, Peter led the firm's consulting operations through a period of remarkable and rapid growth, and was instrumental in building the broad, market-leading consulting capabilities the firm offers today. His legacy at the firm is that of an exceptional person who was a strong and transformational leader with a kind heart and a wonderful sense of humor. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in Peter's memory can be made to the Foundation Fighting Blindness. Peter was a trustee of the organization, and its cause remains dear to his family.

As least until recently, we've been in the midst of a refinancing boom. So consumers applying for refinancings should at least expect some delays. While lenders are leery about releasing details about how long refinancings are taking to close today versus a year ago, some are willing to admit that processing times are longer today for a number of reasons, including regulatory changes and historically low rates.

Undertaking an unusual poll-cum-pledge-drive among theatergoers, the producers of the Broadway musical ''The Scottsboro Boys,'' which closed on Sunday because of weak ticket sales, are asking fans and others to commit on the show's Web site to buying $99 tickets if the musical were to reopen on Broadway this spring. Any return would be for a limited run, the producers said in a statement on Thursday. To that end, the return is timed to help the musical's prospects of receiving Tony nominations and perhaps Tonys themselves, dear to any producer's heart; shows that run in the spring fare better with the nominators, who will make their picks on May 2.

8:21 p.m. | Updated A scandal flush with superlatives added yet another on Friday with a $7.2 billion legal settlement, the largest single forfeiture in American judicial history, to benefit the victims of Bernard L. Madoff's global fraud.

The Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' will delay its opening night by four weeks, until Monday, Feb. 7, to provide more time for its creators - the director Julie Taymor and U2's Bono and the Edge - to make changes in the $65 million show before theater critics review it, the lead producer announced on Friday. As a result, the musical will now have a total of 10 weeks of preview performances, one of the longest stretches in Broadway history. Bono and the Edge are set to return to New York this month after a U2 tour and resume work on the superhero musical, which has drawn sharp complaints from a good number of audience members about the clarity of the storytelling, the quality of the music and the overall good time of the show, which is far and away the most expensive in Broadway history. Some show executives are also concerned about the storytelling, particularly some of the narrative complications in Act II. The delay is intended in part to provide time for the creators to stage a new final number, make further rewrites to the dialogue and consider adding and cutting scenes and perhaps inserting new music from Bono and Edge.

The BMO Financial Group, parent company of Bank of Montreal, said Friday that it had agreed to buyMarshall & Ilsley, a bank based in Milwaukee, for $4.1 billion - the latest acquisition of a troubled United States firm by an international bank. Canadian and other foreign banks have been a critical source of capital for United States lenders since the financial crisis.

HERBERT--Miriam E. (Micky), died peacefully at the wonderful age of 96.5 years. All who knew her will always remember her beauty and grace. She and her family were lifelong New Yorkers and she loved the city passionately. Memorial service at a later date.

With the holidays comes holiday tipping. As the etiquette expert Peter Post pointed out in an Ask an Expert series late last year on holiday tipping, the first rule is to tip only what you can afford to tip. Thus, the first step of holiday tipping is to figure out who you want to tip. Then, you should figure out how much you want to give in total and divide that amount among your list.

The Mets' reluctance to make long-term commitments this off-season became the Yankees' gain on Friday. Pedro Feliciano, the left-handed reliever who has played all eight of his major league seasons with the Mets, agreed to terms on a two-year, $8 million contract with the Yankees.

To be a top writer, it takes a strong authorial voice, deft use of imagery, and a facility with language. And - if Thursday night's judges at the monthly author competition, Literary Death Match, are to be believed - it also requires liberal use of the technical terms for our nether regions. Four competitors squared off in pairs on stage at the Bowery Poetry Club in the East Village on Thursday evening; the better of each set was selected by a panel of three judges and will go on to contend again at later installments of the series. The night's two winners, Elissa Bassist and Clay McLeod Chapman, each prevailed with toe-curling tales of sexual humiliation.

The legal dispute between a California man who says a box of glass-plate negatives he bought at a garage sale are the work of Ansel Adams and the famed photographer's trust has entered a new phase. On Thursday, the man, Rick Norsigian, and PRS Media Partners filed a counterclaim against the Ansel Adams Publishing Rights Trust in federal court in San Francisco. The trust, which disputes that the images are Adams's work, filed suit against Mr. Norsigian and others in August, asserting that their sale of prints made from the negatives was a trademark violation.

A chart on Wednesday with an article about the change in race patterns in the New York region mislabeled a town in Connecticut where the median household income has dropped by more than 40 percent since 2000. The town is North Greenwich, not Litchfield.

Has the PGA Tour really decided to de-emphasize Tiger Woods in its promotional materials and switch the focus to the emerging group of strong young players going into 2011? If the first FedEx Cup promotional piece of the new year and remarks by the PGA Tour commissioner are any indicators, the answer is yes. Stressing youth over age in material that saw limited release two weeks ago, Woods is looking over his shoulder and Phil Mickelson is facing off with his frequent practice round partner, Dustin Johnson, in a spot promoting the season-long FedEx points competition, which culminates in a season-ending four-tournament series.

An article on Thursday about the new book ''Representing Justice,'' by Judith Resnik and Dennis Curtis, misstated the relation of Themis, who represented justice in Greek mythology, to Zeus. In addition to being his wife and counselor she was his aunt, not his sister.

VARNEY--Susan M.,died on Friday, December 10 at her home in Darien, Connecticut. Born July 30, 1921 in Brooklyn NY, she survived her husband Norman A. Varney, who she married August 2, 1947. A resident of Darien since 1963, Mrs. Varney was a volunteer with The Darien Community Association. Mrs. Varney is survived by her brother, Robert McNally of River Edge, NJ, her daughter Claire A. Varney of Darien, her sons Robert R. Varney M.D. of San Diego and Norman A. Varney of Philadelphia, and four grandchildren. A Memorial Service was held at St. John's Church in Darien on December 15. Memorial gifts may be made to The Texas Children's Hospital, The Epilepsy Foundation, The Salvation Army, and Father Flanagan's Boys Town.

It is hard to make it in New York - whether in the arts, in finance, politics or fashion. But no endeavor in the city can be more competitive than the one where you try to get the attention of passers-by in Times Square by smiling at them and handing them glossy leaflets intended to make them think. Into that bazaar of mass preoccupation, half a dozen members of an organization called Muslims for Peace fanned out Friday, smiling and offering their wares. They belonged to a sect, the Ahmadiyya Muslim Community, that embraces a pacifist tradition within Islam.

Joined by a dozen of his favorite guests over the decades, Larry King hosted his final edition of ''Larry King Live'' on Thursday, ending a 25-year chapter at CNN. The suspenders will remain, he said, but his nightly forum for newsmakers and noisemakers will not. He said at the beginning of the program, ''Welcome to the last 'Larry King Live.' It's hard to say that. I knew this day was coming. These words are not easy to say.''

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - If you're a regular reader of Wordplay, it's probably hard to remember when Monday crosswords were a challenge. You're no longer in the prime market demographic but you know people who are. In this season of sharing, think about introducing a friend to the sport. Make sure you mention that Monday puzzles are easiest and they get harder as the week goes on. Sudoku and KenKen and most other newspaper puzzles provide a degree-of-difficulty indication but with crosswords, for some reason, it's a secret. Pass it on.

In recent years popular science writing has bombarded us with titillating reports of discoveries of the brain's psychological prowess.  Such reports invade even introductory patter in biology and psychology.  We are told that the brain - or some area of it sees, decides, reasons, knows, emotes, is altruistic/egotistical, or wants to make love.  For example, a recent article reports a researcher's "looking at love, quite literally, with the aid of an MRI machine."  One wonders whether lovemaking is to occur between two brains, or between a brain and a human being.

To the Sports Editor, Re ''By One Measure, a Rotation Second Only to the '76 Mets,'' Dec. 15: I was shocked and dismayed that the list of the greatest four-man rotations did not include perhaps the best of all, the 1971 Baltimore Orioles' staff of Jim Palmer, Dave McNally, Mike Cuellar and Pat Dobson.

My family and I will be in Paris on New Year's Eve. We're having a hard time finding a moderately priced restaurant around the Trocadero or the Eiffel Tower. Or do you suggest we look in some other arrondissement? Dr. Michael MaziusA.In an e-mail, Alexander Lobrano, who lives in Paris and is the author of ''Hungry for Paris: The Ultimate Guide to the City's 102 Best Restaurants,'' recommended several traditional brasseries for dining on New Year's Eve: one of them, Le Stella (133, avenue Victor Hugo; 33-1-56-90-56-00) in the 16th Arrondissement, is about a few minutes' walk north of the Trocadero (above). Others are Le Vaudeville (29, rue Vivienne; 33-1-40-20-04-62; vaudevilleparis.com) in the Second, by La Bourse, the stock exchange; and Brasserie Balzar (49, rue des Ecoles; 33-1-43-54-13-67; brasseriebalzar.com) in the Fifth, the Latin Quarter.

ROSE--John L.,of Lenox, MA and East Chatham, NY, passed away on Friday, December 17, 2010, at the age of 87. John was an environmental engineer who specialized in the design of waste and water treatment plants. Born in Hamburg, Germany, John attended the Eerde International School in the Netherlands as a teenager, came to New York in 1939, and graduated from George Washington High School in Manhattan. He was a veteran of the US Army who served in the Pacific in World War II. John obtained his BS degree in Engineering from Cornell University, and his Masters degree from Columbia University. Beyond his professional accomplishments, he was known by many as a life master contract bridge player, avid railroad enthusiast and world traveler. He loved gardening, nature and classical music, and in recent years particularly enjoyed his work as an usher at Tanglewood. John was an active member of the Unitarian Church, believed strongly in community service, and participated in many political and social causes. He will be missed by his son, Dr. Stan Rose (and wife, Dr. Elise), his two daughters, Diane Holt (and husband Russell) and Audrey Torres (and husband Raymond), his five grandchildren, Danielle Holt, Russell John Holt, Brandi Holt, Amanda Holt, and Theresa Torres, his five great-grandchildren, members of his extended family and many other friends and colleagues whose lives he touched. A service will be held at a later date. Memorials can be sent to Meals on Wheels at: https://www.mowaa.org/sslpage.aspx?pid=202
