CHRIS PAINE, director of the 2006 documentary ''Who Killed the Electric Car?'' says he was shocked by the success of that film and is now preparing its sequel: the far more General Motors-friendly ''Revenge of the Electric Car.'' Mr. Paine's cameras were there as G.M. sent its earlier electric entry, the EV1, to the crusher. The new film, which chronicles E.V. roll-outs through profiles of key people in the industry, will be released late next spring, though its trailer has already been produced.

COLON--Michael A.,died peacefully at home on December 14, 2010. He was 86. He is survived by his loving wife Rafaela, daughter Diane, sons Gary and Jose, sister Alice, brother Frank, five grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

GASTIL--Raymond Duncan Beloved husband and father, died December 14. A social scientist, he worked with Hudson Institute, Battelle Seattle Research Center, USAID, and OECD. He launched the Freedom in the World survey, and served on the Council for a Community of Democracies. He earned his Ph.D. at Harvard, after Fulbright and Ford fellowships in the Middle East. A specialist in democracy and culture, he wrote Cultural Regions of the United States, Social Humanities, and Progress, and was an editor of the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture. Committed to conservation, he served on the Essex Planning Commission, and Essex Land Trust. He is survived by his wife Jeannette, daughter Leila, son Raymond, and brother Gordon. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Phillips Brooks House, Harvard Yard, Cambridge, MA 02138.

If anyone knows how to bottle success, it's Jimmy Choo's founder and chief creative officer Tamara Mellon, who decided to celebrate the footwear brand's 15-year mark with a sexy signature fragrance. The perfume equivalent of a vertiginous heel, it contains come-hither hints of Indonesian patchouli, tiger orchid and toffee. Python-printed packaging and a faceted bottle reminiscent of hand-blown Murano glass make it the perfect powder-room accessory for the unapologetic stiletto set. $95 for 3.3 ounces; available Jan. 15 at Saks Fifth Avenue. Call (800) 347-9177 for more information. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SHUSTER--Edward Joseph, 98, passed peacefully December 10th, a lifelong Brooklynite, in excellent health until a recent fall. Married to Kay Storm, then to the late Rita Marans for 49 years. President AS Perfumers, skier before chairlifts, traveler, gourmet, supporter of AIDS research, Ed adored Rita playing Beethoven. Predeceased by sons Peter and Jonathan, Eddie's memory is now cherished by children Karen and Gilbert, his 'second family' the Hertz's, and his daily companion grandson Morgan Scotland Marans Shuster.

SOMOROFF--Marc, died quietly on November 23, 2010, after a courageous struggle with lung cancer. He was a devoted husband and father, accomplished scholar, a gifted writer, musician, visual artist and raconteur. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from NYU and earned the M.Ph. in political science from Columbia University. Marc won significant academic awards for early achievements in his field and enjoyed college teaching. As an insurance broker, his sincerity and professionalism garnered respect from his colleagues and clients. Marc will be best remembered for his personal integrity, incisive humor and intelligence; he knew how to connect with people. He will be dearly missed by his wife Alice; son Matthew; siblings Michael, Anne, Erik and David; stepmother Janet; aunt Geri; daughter-in-law Beth; and many cousins, nephews and nieces.

LANGE--Phil, Ph.D, of Sun City Center, FL formally of Tenafly, NJ died on December 13, 2010. A retired Columbia University Professor listed both in Who's Who In America and World. Survived by his daughter DenaRae and husband Robert Kelly, grandsons Brandon and Justin Kelly. Predeceased by his wife Irene (Oyen) and son Richard. Chairman of both Education and Psychology Department of Arizona State College at Flagstaff and State University of New York, Fredonia. Training Officer United States Navy. Professor Columbia University Teachers College. Head of Child Psychology and Educational Technology, consultant for SRA Reading, Sesame Street and Xerography. Consultant for State Department UNESCO, AID, Korea, Chile, India, Pakistan, Afghanistan. Filmstrip award Graphic Arts, Community Award National Society Programmed Instruction; Award Educational Press Association Phil and Irene retired to Sun City Center, FL. Phil introduced educational awareness programs called "Issues and Ideas" with over 900 programs. Phil was named Man of the Year 1989, 2001 for his many contributions to the community. Because of his warm generous nature, constant sense of humor and excessive fishing Phil will be missed by many.

AUCH--Walter E. Former Chairman of the Chicago Board Options Exchange and civic-minded executive, died of cancer on December 14, 2010 at his home in Paradise Valley, AZ. He was 89. In 1979, Mr. Auch was named Chairman and CEO of the Chicago Board Options Exchange. Under his leadership, the CBOE became the second largest securities exchange in the United States, built its own building that housed the largest trading floor in the world, developed the most actively traded product in the world (the OEX index option), and built the Options Institute for research and training. Walter E. Auch was born April 12, 1921 in Detroit and was raised in Grosse Pointe, MI by his mother, Beatrice and father, Fred. He was known by everyone as Wally. In 1960, Mr. Auch was asked by Harold Bache to move to New York to become a Senior Partner of the firm, a member of the firm's Management Committee and Head of the Branch Office System. In 1963, he joined Paine, Webber, Jackson and Curtis as a Senior Partner, and member of the Policy Committee with responsibilities that included the branch offices, all products, sales, marketing, research and training. In 1973, at the behest of H. Ross Perot, Mr. Auch became the President and Chief Executive Officer of DuPont Walston Securities. He was particularly proud that he was able to close the firm without a single client losing their investments and that all the personnel of the firm were relocated. For his efforts, Wally received commendation from the Securities and Exchange Commission. In retirement, Mr. Auch remained very active as a consultant to many financial services organizations and served on the Boards of Directors of Thompson McKinnon Asset Management Corp, Fort Dearborn Fund, Bogan Technology Corp, the Smith Barney Trak Funds, Raymond James Financial, The Banyan Funds, First Western Corporation, Sounds Surgical Technologies and the UBS Funds. At Albion College, he was named a Trustee and Chairman of the Endowment Committee. He served as Distinguished Professor and received the college's Distinguished Alumnus Award and Significant Sig Award from the Sigma Chi Fraternity. In 1993, Mr. Auch was appointed to the Board of Trustees of Hillsdale College. Where, he had served on the Board's Investment and Finance Committee. The Auch Scholarship of Business is endowed in his name. During World War II, he served as a commissioned officer and navigator with the Army Air Force from 1941 to 1945 rising to the rank of Captain. An avid golfer, he was a former member of the Country Club of Detroit, the Greenwich Country Club, where he was past President and current member and past President of Crystal Downs Country Club in Frankfort, MI. He had also held memberships at the University Club in Detroit, the City Mid Day Club and Union League Clubs in New York City and the Chicago Club. Mr. Auch is survived by his beloved wife, Patricia (Hogan) Auch as well as three sons, Walter, Jr., Timothy and Terrence; two daughters-in-law, Lynne Bryner Auch and Kathleen Auch; two grandchildren, Ted and Katie; as well as his brothers, Bill, Fred and Tom. A Memorial Service will be held in Paradise Valley, AZ at 10:30am at the Valley Presbyterian Church on January 21, 2011. A burial and memorial service will be held in Frankfort, MI in June. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Mr. Auch's name to Hillsdale College or Albion College.

THOSE bike lanes eating up one or two traffic lanes were only a start: City crews are now out collecting overtime as they convert New York's widest major thoroughfares into Mayor Michael Bloomberg's dream of a vehicle-free paradise -- and all for no more than the cost of a few thousand buckets of white paint! Under the new system, sidewalk parking for all vehicles becomes not only mandatory but also illegal -- a one-two punch expected to fatten the Department of Finance's coffers by an estimated $13 million per day in added traffic summonses!

A sad truth may be defining the legacy of Houston Rockets center Yao Ming: his feet may be too fragile to endure the wear and tear of playing professional basketball. Yao is again indefinitely sidelined due to a significant foot injury. This time, it's a stress fracture in his left ankle. He has been struggling all season with the ankle, which was originally diagnosed as a bone bruise. The Rockets and Yao were hoping he'd be ready to return to play soon, but a routine medical examination and diagnostic testing this week revealed the stress fracture.

BORG--Robert Frederic, P.E..D./d,passed away peacefully on Friday December 17, 2010 at his home in Manhattan, three weeks shy of his eighty-eighth birthday, his family and loved ones by his side. He was the cofounder of Kreisler Borg Florman General Construction Company (KBF) based in Scarsdale NY, and served as its co chairman until the time of his passing. From 1955, when the company's early motto was "pools, schools and shuls," his accomplishments as a builder of hi-rises - over 70 stories tall have impacted the New York City skyline and its environs. A gifted photographer, he traveled the world with cameras in tow, producing numerous images with creativity and precision. He was an intellectual, with impeccable taste and style, a Renaissance man. A loving father (from his marriage to the former E. Winifred Pensh which ended in 1987), his principles of integrity, loyalty and perseverance were emphasized to his children and grandchildren. From humble beginnings in the Bronx, where he attended Dewitt Clinton, and later NYU engineering and law schools and service in the US navy, to a life of depth and accomplishment...he had quite a ride! His four children, seven grandchildren and companion Nancy Pline send him to join his two sons Eric and Neil (who predeceased him) with love and gratitude, he will be missed greatly and forever. Christina, Lisa, Kiri, Dean; Cole, Edward, Matthew, Brent, Devin, Molly, and Lane. Services at 11:30am Tues. Dec 21 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, 81st Street, New York City.

Kelly, 50, a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, led the Bills to four consecutive Super Bowl appearances from 1991 to '94. Q. How excited are you to be a part of this game?

The Phoenix Coyotes seem set to stay in Glendale, Ariz., after last Tuesday's approval by the Glendale City Council to pay $197 million to keep the financially troubled team at Jobing.com Arena. The deal with the prospective owner Matthew Hulsizer puts an end for now to Winnipeg's efforts to lure the Coyotes back to their original home. Manitobans will have to look elsewhere in the Sun Belt for a team to woo.

''Bravo España!'' said President Nicolas Sarkozy of France in late July as he barged into a television interview during the Tour de France to shake hands with the Spanish cyclist Alberto Contador. Bravo, indeed. In that historically heady month for Spain, Contador was well on his way to a third victory in the Tour, Rafael Nadal had won his latest Wimbledon and Spain's national soccer team had sparked the country's party of the century -- so far -- by winning its first World Cup.

In many ways, the garment district of Manhattan has been in decline for decades. But in other ways, it is still very much alive. The district, about one square mile in area, was once a global hub for clothes manufacturing. But, eventually, much of it could no longer compete with much cheaper overseas operations. Nevertheless, it retains the advantage of being right next door to some the most glamorous designers, stores and fashion shows in the world. It is still home to more than 2,000 fashion-related businesses. And incubators have emerged to help up-and-coming designers with a dream of becoming the next Marc Jacobs or Vera Wang.

The editors asked Tyler Cowen, the economist who helps run the blog Marginal Revolution, to read the previous nine Ideas issues and send us his thoughts on which entries, with the benefit of hindsight, struck him as noteworthy. Do any ideas from this year's issue look promising? ''I recall reading the 2001 issue when it came out,'' he says. ''And I was hardly bowled over with excitement by thoughts of 'Populist Editing.' Now I use Wikipedia almost every day. The 2001 issue noted that, in its selection of items, 'frivolous ideas are given the same prominence as weighty ones'; that is easiest to do when we still don't know which are which.'' THE BEST IDEA OF EACH YEAR 2001: ''Populist Editing.'' Wikipedia has since eclipsed the Encyclopaedia Britannica and Microsoft's Encarta project, and many of us use it almost every day.

WHITNEY--Corliss Fyfe, 83, December 13, 2010. Radio City Rockette 1945-1953; Unofficial Rockette Historian. Famous for "A Rockette Remembers" book and lectures, her store "Corliss on the Bay" of Fire Island, "The Seasoned Steppers" senior dance troupe and her amazing drop splits at the end of shows. Survived by husband Frank, sons Jeff, Chip and Scott, daughters-in-law, grandchildren, and wide community of family, friends and fans. Her energy, love of life, and compassion will be missed.

KENNY--Dorothy, passed away on Thursday December 16. She is survived and beloved by her nieces and nephews Nicola Kenny of Ossining NY, Erica Kenny of Boston MA, Russell Kenny of Greenwich CT, Terence and Dorothy O'Brien of Madison NJ, Christopher O'Brien of Brooklyn NY, and many other friends and relatives. Ms. Kenny was a lifelong resident of the Kensington section of Brooklyn NY. She attended St. Rose of Lima School, Catherine McAuley High School, and earned a BA in Business at Pace University in Manhattan. Among other professions, she was a legal secretary in the firm Lord Day & Lord from 1959 to 1986, and a paralegal in the Coudert Brothers firm from 1986 to 1997. After retiring, she served as a poll worker for the NYS Board of Elections. She was a Eucharistic minister, supporter, and lifelong parishioner of the St. Rose of Lima Church in Brooklyn. She was also a volunteer for VITA, providing tax preparation assistance to the elderly, and a VA Hospital chaplain's assistant. A memorial mass will be held on Monday, December 20, 10am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 48 E. 84th St in Manhattan, followed by a funeral in Greenwich CT. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Maryknoll Sisters, PO Box 311, Maryknoll, NY 10545-0311 or through mklsisters.org.

This is the third in an occasional series about Nikola Ivkovic, a Christmas tree seller on Broadway. The second week of December came, and Nikola Ivkovic got his annual phone call from his best customer.

''It's never easy to disagree against a majority.''Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, who, unlike other Fed members, thinks its recent efforts to stimulate the economy risk runaway inflation, asset bubbles and a weakened dollar. ''I'm trying to get out of debt, so why would I want a credit card to get into more debt?'' Sue Talkington of Modesto, Calif., who started working with a credit counselor in September to pay down $17,000 in debt. She was stunned when she received an offer for a pre-approved credit card recently.

An article last Sunday about holiday decorations in building lobbies misstated New York City's policy on the use of cut trees. The New York City Fire Department discourages but does not prohibit them.
We literally are providing medical services for peanuts! KATHY MCCARTY, a nurse who runs a rural hospital in Zimbabwe that lets patients barter crops and livestock for treatment. [1]

As holiday shoppers strolled around Union Square on Saturday with bags in hand, a member of the Mets smiled for cameras at a meet-and-greet appearance, an ambassador for a franchise that has not been a buyer in the off-season. Although the Mets have been quiet in the free-agent market -- the additions of a new general manager and a new manager aside -- many of the fans who showed up for an autograph from first baseman Ike Davis at the recently opened flagship branch of Citibank seemed pleased with the team's restraint in the off-season.

TIMOTHY EGAN It's when John Boehner talks about how he rose from his humble past -- the son of a bar owner, one of 12 children who grew up in a small home with a single bathroom -- that he starts to weep. ''Making sure these kids have a shot at the American Dream like I did is very important,'' he said, choking up, when asked on ''60 Minutes'' about his crying. But a look at Boehner's record during his two decades in Congress shows a man who has voted against nearly every boost for the working stiff. There's no empathy for those with the longest shots at the American Dream in his voting pattern. Instead, we see a politician who is hard-hearted in his legislative treatment of the people now coping with the kind of economic conditions in which the Boehner family grew up.

On the morning of Dec. 16, 1960, a United Airlines DC-8 collided with a T.W.A. Lockheed Constellation, crashing over Park Slope, Brooklyn, and on Staten Island. In all, 134 people died -- 128 passengers and crew members, and 6 people on the ground. City Room marked the 50th anniversary of the crash last week with a series of articles, multimedia features and audio interviews from those who were there. Readers also weighed in with their own personal stories. Here are some of the responses:
WILLNER--Alvin. We miss your love and laughter. You are in our thoughts. Jane (Harold), Jay (Jeanne), Stella.

NEWMAN--Arthur B. The trustees and staff of the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction and the staff and patients of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at the NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Arthur B. Newman who so generously provided his energy, passion and commitment to secure the future of the Institute and the patients it serves. Arthur's active engagement in life and zesty personality were inspiring to all who knew him, and his many contributions to his community were simply monumental. We express our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Eileen, President of the NFFR Board of Trustees, their children, Sondra, David and Allison, and their grandchildren, Leah, Alex, Sarah, Oliver, Zeki and Isabella, who were always so devoted to this good and caring man. John R. Gordon, Chairman of the NFFR Joseph G. McCarthy, Director of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery Whitney Burnett, Executive Director of the NFFR

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the late Elaine Kaufman and her restaurant, Elaine's, misstated the year that a photograph showing the writer Candace Bushnell at the restaurant was taken. It was 2002, not the late 1990s.

An article last Sunday about Representative Ron Paul, a Texas Republican who is in line to become head of the subcommittee that oversees the Federal Reserve, transposed two of the digits in one of the decades in which he served on the House Banking Committee. It was during the early 1980s, not the 1908s.

She will be remembered by her loving family: her son Tony, daughter-in-law Terry, grandchildren Douglas and Jill, and their mother Nancy Herbert, son-in-law Avi and great-grandchildren Lucy and Emma. All who knew her will always remember her beauty and grace. She and her family were lifelong New Yorkers and she loved the city passionately. Memorial service at a later date.

It's Enough to Make the Generous Turn Grinchy There it was in my mailbox, a bulky envelope from a charity I'd never heard of, with headquarters in another state. Inside was a tote bag printed with the organization's logo and an urgent appeal for funds. Three weeks later, it was a fleece blanket from a local charity and, again, an urgent plea.

Eagles (9-4) at Giants (9-4)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Giants by 2 1/2 Neither Tom Coughlin nor Andy Reid has gotten much Coach of the Year buzz this season, but both deserve mention. Coughlin's stern-yet-fair demeanor helped Brandon Jacobs move beyond the helmet-tossing incident and reclaim a role in the offense, and he transformed Matt Dodge from scapegoat to solid punter. The even-keel routine got the Giants through two different two-game losing streaks, and it kept them focused enough to weather a snowbound day in an airport and produce a blowout against an opponent with something to prove. If trapped in an airport terminal for too long, Jets coaches might fiddle with the runway lights just for a joke. Coughlin's disciplinarian credibility yields real dividends.

Arthur has long expressed his love of the Jewish community and devotion to social and humanitarian causes through his exceptional philanthropy. We extend our sympathies to his wife; his children, Sondra, Allison, and David; his son-in-law, Cengiz, and daughter-in-law, Stephanie; his grandchildren; and his entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Stroll along the Cape Fear River in Wilmington, N.C., and you can feel a little Savannah or Charleston just itching to get out. The city's downtown has been that way for years: highly walkable, with pockets of real beauty and charm, forever promising a sleepy coolness that never quite materialized. But the area is starting to wake up. There's a handsomely renovated amphitheater a short hop from the main drag, Front Street. And the dining and night-life scene is finally hitting its stride, with a serious cocktail spot unencumbered by speakeasy shtick, a new farmhouse-inflected restaurant that shows big-time chops in the kitchen, and more. The return of beach weather isn't the only thing to look forward to around here. ROBERT WILLEY

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Seeking an Equation For Wins in Basketball,'' Dec. 16: I played for the University of Redlands for four years in the early 1980s, and I fondly remember our annual conference games against Caltech. The games were blowouts, but I respected the intelligence of the players and how hard they played.

ADLER--Rabbi Dr. Jacob. The Yeshiva University community is deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished alumnus, Rabbi Dr. Jacob Adler, a graduate of Yeshiva University Schools (HS '42, YC '46, RIETS '48), and beloved father of Emanuel J. Adler, Vice Chairman of the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers. May the entire Adler family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President
MAYERS--Lawrence S.,died December 7, 2010. A Memorial Service will be held at 2:30pm, Thursday, December 23rd at The Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, New York City.

Celtics center Shaquille O'Neal has always been a man of many interests. He has rapped, acted, trained with SWAT teams and engaged in amateur philosophy during his many career stops. For the man who nicknamed himself the Big Aristotle, Boston seems to be a bit boring, judging by the ratio of his antics to his playing time.

PETROSSIAN--Catherine. On December 13. Beloved wife of Berge Avedisian. Loving daughter of George and the late Kenarik Petrossian. Cherished sister of George, Lynda and Joann. Family will receive friends on Sunday from 5-7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services are Monday, 10am at St. Vartans Armenian Cathedral, 630 Second Ave at 34th St. Interment to follow at Cedar Grove Cemetery.

ERLANGER--Jack, known for his valor in war, his abiding love of family, and an outstretched hand to all in need, left this world peacefully on December 13 at his home in New York. He was 86. In 1940, at age 16, Jack joined the Royal Canadian Air Force to fight in World War II. He served with the US Air Force in the Pacific and was decorated with bronze and silver medals. In 1948, he fought with the Israel Air Force in the War of Independence. Jack was a textile manufacturer and later became a financial adviser and broker. He was a devoted husband to Meryl and an adoring father to son John Lipman, daughter Jennifer Gebhardt, son-in-law Morgan Gebhardt and grandson Jason Gebhardt. He believed in God, country, and family. Jack, your memory will live on in the lives of those who loved you. Erlanger Family
DORSKIND--Doris. You will always be in my heart. There will never be another you. All My Love, Bob

THE NEWS After a British judge granted bail to Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, an appeal by prosecutors kept him in custody for three more days before he was freed. The British court is weighing whether to extradite him to Sweden, where he is wanted in connection with a sexual misconduct case. But American officials are seeking a way to prosecute him on charges related to the release of secret American military and diplomatic records. THE NEWS Hopes and promises that the Metrodome would be ready for the next Minnesota Vikings home game on Monday were dashed when inspectors found that the stadium's inflatable roof, torn open last weekend by a 17-inch snowfall, could not be repaired in time. Plan B calls for the Vikings to play the Chicago Bears in the University of Minnesota's open-air stadium -- the Vikings' first outdoor home game in 29 years.
Art Robin Pogrebin

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Smaller Teams Feed Green Monsters,'' Dec. 10: Until Major League Baseball stops being a game of money, it will never be a legitimate test of skill and ability based on equitable distribution of talent across all teams. It will continue to be show business, not sport.
CANTOR--Jerome "Jerry". It is with great sadness that family and friends mourn his passing. Funeral services will be held Sunday 11:45am at Parkside Chapel, 9860 Queens Blvd., Rego Park.

MAIZUS--Robert A.,52, former account manager for LDI Technologies passed away suddenly on December 9, 2010. Services were held on December 13, in Fair Lawn, NJ. Robert will be keenly missed by his family and many friends. Contributions can be made to The American Heart Association.

MacMILLEN--Barbara Southack Christy Downing, long time resident of Lawrence, NY, on December 14, 2010, at the age of 98 years. Born March 29, 1912 in New York, NY. Daughter of the late Charles Roland Christy, Jr. and Gladys Tilden (Southack). Barbara was married in 1933 to the late Paul Cook Downing, Jr. and on March 6, 1942 to the late William Charles MacMillen, Jr. of Troy, NY, who predeceased her in January 2009. Barbara is survived by her children, Paul Cook Downing, III (Martha) of Topsham, Maine, Anita MacMillen Bird (Ray) of Bay Head, NJ, William C. III (Kay) of Burbank, CA and Nancy MacMillen Brown (John) of Pomona, NY. Barbara is also survived by seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Her daughter, Sally Downing Candler Johnson, predeceased her. A lifelong amateur athlete, she was an avid skier and won numerous golf, squash and tennis tournaments at the Rockaway Hunting Club and the Saratoga Golf Club, where she met Bill. Barbara was a world traveler, a gracious hostess, a gourmet cook and an active volunteer in her community. Her generosity, engaging manner and tremendous spirit will be remembered and missed by her family and her many friends. A memorial tribute and luncheon will be held at the Rockaway Hunting Club, Lawrence, NY, on Saturday, January 8, 2011 at 11am.

POCKETING $300,000 from the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund in mid-November, Billy Reid did not consider: a) having a Paris runway show; b) spitting out some dresses for the Oscars; or c) inviting his friends over for beer and shrimp. ''There was a day when I would have said it would go for a party,'' Mr. Reid, who operates his men's and women's design business from Florence, Ala., said today, a month after winning the fund's top prize. A fashion company can soak up cash quickly. Designers have to cover the costs of one season's production and then start making samples for the next, leaving them little money to develop new products. But $300,000 is a fair amount of money to play with. Further, Mr. Reid's career may have given him insights not available to other finalists.

NESBITT--Ruth, 93, of New York City, died Thursday, December 16, 2010. Visiting will be at the Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Ave., Caldwell, NJ, on Wednesday, December 22, from 5 to 7 pm. The service will be held at the funeral home on Thursday, December 23, at 11am, followed by the entombment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. Born in Newton, MA, Ms. Nesbitt lived in New York City for more than 40 years. An executive her entire career, she retired in 1982 from the New York YWCA as business manager, after 20 years of service. She was a 1939 graduate of Wellesley College, and earned a Masters degree in Business from New York University in 1962. She was a volunteer with the American Red Cross in the South Pacific during World War II. Ms. Nesbitt is survived by her partner, Paul Kuzmick Jr. of Livingston, NJ; sister, June Gibbs of Middletown, RI; a niece, Elizabeth Gibbs and her husband, Eliot Raymond, of Portsmouth, RI, and cousin, Rosalie Morgan, of Newton, MA. Donations to Wellesley College, 106 Central St., Wellesley, MA., 02481 or Alzheimer's Association National Office, 225 N. Michigan Ave., Fl. 17, Chicago, IL., 60601, in lieu of flowers.

FOR the last five years, a New York photographer, Amy Stein, has been recording people stranded by the side of the road after their cars broke down. The work has appeared in various shows, and she has assembled some of the photos on her Web site (amystein photo.com/stranded.html).

An article last Sunday about people who officially refuse to support their spouses in order to qualify for Medicaid gave an imprecise comparison of the cost of nursing home care and college tuition. While nursing home care in the New York area is indeed twice as much as the yearly cost of the most prestigious colleges, the cost of the colleges includes room and board, not just tuition.

BRUCE HAYNES was never told much about his grandfather George Edmund Haynes, who died in 1960, 10 months before he was born. ''When I was growing up, my father rarely spoke about Pop Haynes or even about his own childhood,'' recalled Dr. Haynes, who was raised in Harlem. ''The subject brought up too many hurts and resentments that he still held tight.''
Dance Claudia La Rocco
Below are selected answers from reader comments on the In Transit blog to a question that ran in the Nov. 28 print edition. More reader responses can be found in this column each week.

NEWMAN--Arthur. His friends and neighbors at 895 Park Ave. mourn the loss of Arthur Newman, a very fine man, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Eileen, his children and all his family. Daniel Brodsky, President

The Mortgages column on Dec. 5, about defaulting on second homes, described incorrectly the ability of lenders to sue homeowners in Florida for the amount owed on a foreclosed property. Florida is a ''recourse'' state, and lenders may sue homeowners there. It is not a ''nonrecourse'' state, where lenders typically are required to accept whatever a property sells for in a foreclosure sale.

TUTTLE--Karen. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Karen Tuttle, a distinguished member of the School's viola faculty from 1987-2003. A dedicated and highly successful teacher, Karen approached all her students with deep respect and creativity. Her teaching created a generation of violists who were expert in solo, chamber, and orchestral repertoire for the viola. Her caring and sensitive personality was a pleasure to experience for colleagues and students alike. Our condolences are extended to her entire family. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

An article on Dec. 5 about ''Three Pianos,'' a theatrical adaptation of Schubert's song cycle ''Winterreise,'' misstated Dave Malloy's role at a contemporary-music concert in 2009 that was a catalyst for creating the play. Mr. Malloy, one of the writers, arrangers and performers for ''Three Pianos,'' attended the concert but was not in it.

Because of an editing error, a brief report last Sunday about desertification in Yemen, with an article about resource needs as a source of conflict, misstated the year in which terrorists attacked the destroyer Cole in a Yemeni harbor. It was 2000, not 1998.

LEVENE--Stephen M.,91, of New York City, passed away quietly in his home on Monday, December 13, 2010. Stephen was a veteran of WWII and a recipient of the purple heart. His career in the menswear industry began as a Buyer with Alexander's in New York City. He continued as a Merchandise Manager with Goldblatts in Illinois and over time became owner of Garston's, a men's department store, and Lady Garston's, in Waterbury, CT. Retail Consulting is also where he achieved success as Executive VP of April-Marcus and ultimately collaborated at Van Dorn Retail Mgmt. Stephen is survived by, his three children, Judith Ann Lorah and husband Stephen H. of Ellington, CT, Stephen Robert, and William Leonard and wife Kathleen of Redding, CT, his three grandchildren, Samantha Lorah, Michael and Christopher Levene and Stephen's sister, Shirley Meyers of Brooklyn Heights, NY. Born January 7, 1919 he was the son of Dr. Samuel A. and Regina Levene. He was preceded in death by his wives Louise Markowitz Levene and Juliet Kalikow Levene. Private funeral services will be held in Connecticut.
STRAUSS--Muriel Newman, 85. Bronx, CCNY, Queens, Boca Raton. Beloved wife, sister, mother, friend; survived by Sheldon, Eleanor, Michael, Amy, and Karen.

HOROWITZ--David H. I am deeply saddened at the loss of my mentor, former boss and friend. I hold dear my memories of his commitment to integrity and honor blended with kindness, generosity, grace and simple elegance. My heartfelt condolences to Susan and the family. Michele Vonfeld

LivingSocial, the Web site that offers daily deals to 10 million subscribers in more than 120 international and domestic cities, last month started a companion travel site called LivingSocial Escapes. The site offers packages for getaways near or within the cities where it already lists daily deals, as well as a few more faraway locales. The packages typically include a discounted hotel stay and a few related perks. For example, LivingSocial Escapes' first package, a rock star weekend in Chicago, included a discounted stay at the Hard Rock Hotel, drinks at its bar, 10 downloads from iTunes and a Gibson guitar rental. New packages are announced every Wednesday.

(13) BAROQUE HOLIDAY WITH THE CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER ''Live From Lincoln Center'' heads to Alice Tully Hall for a concert of festive works by the Baroque masters Matteis, Sammartini, Tartini and Vivaldi. Highlights include Bach's Double Violin Concerto in D minor and Corelli's Concerto Grosso in G minor, popularly known as the Christmas Concerto. Michala Petri, on recorder, and Lars Hannibal, on archlute, join the violinists Ani Kavafian, Erin Keefe, Yura Lee and Cho-Liang Lin; the violist Richard O'Neill; the cellist Daniel McDonough; the double bassist Edgar Meyer; the bassoonist Peter Kolkay; and the harpsichordist John Gibbons. 10 A.M. BELMONT--Jennifer B.,of Washington D.C., died peacefully on December 12, 2010 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved mother of Jessica and Matthew, loyal sister to Anne, Wendy, Doug, Colin, Steve and Will, and loving daughter of Peggy and John. She was adored by her grandchildren, Nate, Will and Madison, and was a cherished mother-in-law to Todd and Michelle. Jenn was a curious, caring, and loving woman, friend and co-worker and she will be dearly missed by all who knew her. A Memorial Service will be held in her honor on Monday, December 20, 1pm at Decatur House, 1610 H Street, NW. Memorial donations can be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation, 115 Broadway, Suite 1301, New York, NY 10006, Attn.: Jennifer Belmont Memorial Fund.

The Medium column on Dec. 5, about the Internet radio service Pandora, misidentified the creators of Deep Junior, a computer that played chess against Garry Kasparov in 2003 and was cited as an example of human interaction with technology and the feelings it stimulates. It was built by Shay Bushinsky and Amir Ban, Israeli computer programmers, with assistance from the chess grandmaster Boris Alterman, not by I.B.M.

PENICK--Joe Edward. Retired Senior Vice President of Mobil Oil, chemical engineer and inventor or co-inventor of over 60 patents died in Princeton New Jersey on December 16. He was 90. Predeceased by Jean, his bride of 67 years, he is survived by his two sons Edward (wife Marsha and children Katherine Penick Taylor (Peter) and Emily) and David (wife Mary Delaney). Joe also had a home in Naples, FL and previously lived in Chappaqua, NY. He will be lovingly remembered by family and friends. Funeral service will be held at Nassau Presbyterian Church, Princeton, NJ Tuesday, December 21st at 2pm, calling hours at 1:30pm.

Delta recently installed iPads for public use at dining areas at several of its gates in Kennedy Airport. The iPads are attached to booths at two new restaurants at Delta gates: Croque Madame, a French restaurant at Gates 25 and 26 in Terminal 2, and Bar Brace, a casual Italian restaurant at Gate 15 in Terminal 3. Customers can order meals directly from the iPads, with delivery to their booth guaranteed in 10 minutes or less. The wireless connection to use the devices is free.

WALLACE--Kenneth D. (1918-2010), an attorney who won a Supreme Court Case setting pension rights for women, died on November 30 in Seattle. Wallace was at Cahill, Gordon and at Bigelow Sanford before practicing in Stamford, CT. Arguing for the plaintiff in Diana Spirit/EOC vs. TIAA, he argued that the defendants had violated the Civil Rights Act by using sex-based mortality tables for benefits. Wallace attended Columbia University Law School and was an editor of the law review. In WWII, he flew cargo planes in Burma, and was awarded two Distinguished Flying Crosses. Married to Ida Harvey in 1948, he had two daughters, Ann and Jane. Following divorce, he married Betty Major in 1965 and was widowed in 2005. He is survived by two daughters, four step-children and four step-grandchildren.

The Megalobster There may be nothing new under the sun, but there's a lot of weird stuff in the water. Way more than we thought, according to the Census of Marine Life, a project 10 years in the making that involved 2,700 scientists in 80 countries who put together ''a map of where we haven't been,'' according to Ron O'Dor, one of the program's senior scientists. Using everything from fancy submersibles to old seafood-restaurant menus, the scientists produced more than 2,600 papers, the highlights of which were released in a 64-page report in October. Among the ''large, active and conspicuous organisms'' that no one knew existed is a new species of spiny lobster, Palinurus barbarae, which was found by a Spanish fishing boat on the Walters Shoals in the Indian Ocean, 400 nautical miles south of Madagascar, and classified by South African marine biologists. It's more than half a meter long. ''This was a lobster that had never been described,'' O'Dor says.

NEWMAN--Arthur B.,a loving family man, died peacefully on December 16, 2010, surrounded by his family at his home in New York City. He was 67. The cause was cancer. Mr. Newman was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Eileen; his children, Sondra, Allison, and David; his son-in-law, Cengiz, his daughter-in-law, Stephanie; and his six grandchildren, Leah, Sarah, Alex, Oliver, Isabella, and Zeki. Mr. Newman enjoyed many lifelong friendships. He especially loved playing cards, solving puzzles, and spending time with family and friends. In a career spanning more that 40 years, Mr. Newman served as an advisor to debtors and creditors to some of the nation's largest and most complex business restructurings, including America West Airlines, American Pad & Paper Co., AMF Bowling, Arch Wireless, The Charter Co., Chiquita Banana, Dow Corning, Eastern Airlines, Enron, Exide Technologies, Eurotunnel, General Electric Credit, Global Crossing, Goodyear Tire & Rubber, Iridium, LTV, Levitz Furniture, Macy's, Manville, Mobile Media, Montgomery Ward, Sunbeam, and Texaco. Mr. Newman began his career in 1966 at S.D. Leidesdorf & Co., a predecessor through merger of Ernst & Young. At Ernst & Young he founded the corporate finance department and restructuring practice, which he led until 1989. After 18 months with Chemical Bank, Mr. Newman joined the Blackstone Group in 1991, launching the firm's restructuring and reorganization practice, which he led until his retirement in June of 2010. Mr. Newman received his BS and MBA from Rutgers University. Mr. Newman served on the corporate boards of Associated Camps, CIT, the Fund for Modern Courts, Lone Star Industries, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Premium Standard Farms, and Toys 'R Us. Mr. Newman's dedication to hard work, fair dealings and equal justice has been honored with various awards, including: the AJC's 2009 Herbert H. Lehman Human Relations Award, the 2007 Justice inMotion Award, and the 1990 award by the Bankruptcy & Reorganization Group of the Lawyers Division of UJA-Federation. Arthur Barry Newman was born in Newark, New Jersey on October 12, 1943. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, 333 E. 30th St., New York, NY, 10016, or the New York Presbyterian Hospital Fund, 425 E. 61st St., Suite 211, New York, NY 10065. Funeral Service, Sunday 11:30am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave., at 81st St.

A column last Sunday about the plight of Texas Democrats, and how they have become the political equivalent of the often-struggling Baltimore Orioles, contained several errors. The Orioles won their division once in the 1990s, not twice. (They were the wild-card team in 1996 and then won the division in 1997.) Ann Richards defeated Clayton Williams in the 1990 Texas governor's race -- not George W. Bush. (Mr. Bush defeated Ms. Richards in her re-election campaign in 1994.) And though Ms. Richards and Earl Weaver, the former Orioles manager, might very well enjoy comparing notes about what went wrong with their respective ''teams,'' they would not be doing so in heaven. Mr. Weaver, unlike Ms. Richards, is still alive.

SHERMAN--Charlotte (Margolies), passed away November 11, 2010 following a lengthy respiratory illness. Survived by two sons and two grandchildren, Charlotte was beloved in her many roles: mother, grandmother, MFA (most favored aunt), friend, colleague, Big Apple Greeter, New York City support group leader for RLS Foundation, Elder Wisdom Circle advisor, and others who sought her warmth and care. A Memorial Service was held November 21 at her apartment to celebrate Charlotte's dynamic life. Honoring her passionate support for research in science and medicine, our mother's remains were donated to Weill Medical College at Cornell University for subsequent cremation.

India's growing popularity among jet-setters continues to translate into new hotels. Marriott Hotel and Resorts, for example, decided to open its 500th property in the historic city of Pune last month. Nightly rates at the hotel, which includes 416 rooms and a convention center, start at 8,000 rupees (about $180). And next month, the Leela Palaces, Hotels and Resorts, a chain of luxury properties in India, will open its next hotel, the 260-room Leela Palace Kempinski New Delhi. Located near the diplomatic enclave of Chanakyapuri, it was inspired by the work of the renowned British architect Edwin Lutyens, who designed much of New Delhi at the turn of the century. Nineteen suites will also be available, three of which will have private pools.

He is survived by his wife Alice, children Catherine Gentile, Carol Meisel, Ross Duncan and six grandchildren. He was predeceased by his daughter Celia Louise, brother Forrest and former wife Lois. BOWERS--Patricia Fritz, died unexpectedly and peacefully at home on December 13, at the age of 82. She was a person of great elegance, a world traveler with an exquisite eye for art. LUPPESCU--Elaine, 89 on December 17, 2010 in Lantana, FL. Beloved wife of 68 years to Harvey. Mother of Stuart (Naoko), Peter, and Neal (Virginia). Grandmother of Sarah (Thomas), Naomi, Caroline, Gregory, Simon, Chinami, and Amelia. Great grandmother of Hanna, Helena and Silja. Born in New York City, Elaine graduated from Julia Richman High School and was a member of the Cornell University Class of 1942. Her passions were her family, golf, the ballet, gourmet cooking (she was a graduate of La Varenne Cooking School in Paris), theater, museums, and travel. She served as a Cornell Class officer for many years and was a 30-year volunteer at North Shore University Hospital. Elaine was truly special and unique. She made the world a better place.

Tatarsky felt a sensation of instantaneous, piercing recognition. The shoes had pointed toes and high heels and were made of good leather. They were a light yellowish-brown, stitched with a light-blue thread and decorated with large gold buckles in the form of harps. It wasn't that they were simply in bad taste, or vulgar; they were the clear embodiment of what a certain drunken teacher of Soviet literature from the Literary Institute used to call 'our gestalt', and the sight was so pitiful, laughable and touching (especially the harp buckles) that tears sprang to Tatarsky's eyes. The shoes were covered by a thick layer of dust: the new era obviously had no use for them. The Soviet Union only factors into our idea of fashion history through its strange encounters with the West: Raisa Gorbachev sitting stone-faced in the front row at a Pierre Cardin runway show; Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Diana Vreeland trying to pry czarist vestments from the Hermitage for a Costume Institute exhibition at the Met; an elegant Pat Nixon, fresh from a shopping trip at Henri Bendel, posing on the cover of Life Magazine with Khrushchev's wife. (Nina was dressed in a frumpy khalat, a babushka frock that's perfect for picking cucumbers at the dacha, or weeping.) Then of course there's this amazing Wendy's hamburger commercial from the 1980s, which treats the whole notion of Soviet fashion as a (hilarious) joke. Yves Saint-Laurent's use of Mother Russia as muse may have caused fireworks in 1976. But the Reds themselves had nothing to contribute to world fashion. Or so we thought.

EPSTEIN--David B.,of Westport, CT and Palm Beach Gardens, FL died peacefully at his home in Westport on December 15th at the age of 77. Born March 21, 1933 in Brooklyn, NY, he was the son of the late Jack and Rose Epstein. He grew up in Bridgeport, CT, and was a graduate of Bucknell University. He began his professional career in advertising, and later established a successful commercial real estate investment and development company. Mr. Epstein co-founded the David and Geri Epstein Private Foundation which provides grants for medical research and educational opportunity. An avid golfer, he was a member of Rolling Hills and Birchwood Country Clubs in Connecticut, Sage Valley in South Carolina and Frenchman's Creek in Florida. He was also a Trustee of The First Tee Foundation. He is survived by his wife Geri (Connell) Epstein; his brothers Robert (Lynn) of Greenwich and Stuart (Judy) of Palm Beach Gardens, FL; six nieces and nephews; and 11 grandnieces and grandnephews. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering's Prostate Cancer Research program and the Visiting Nurse and Hospice of Fairfield County would be appreciated.

WHEN is a dress not just a dress? When it's a part of ''Aware: Art Fashion Identity,'' a show on the mutable nature of sartorial identity, currently on view at London's Royal Academy. Among the works by 30 artists and designers is a Joan of Arc dress by Alexander McQueen, which covers the face and body in a delicate red lacelike chain mail. There's a video of Yoko Ono's ''Cut Piece'' (1965), above, in which the audience strips away her clothes, leaving her with only a shred of humanity. Grayson Perry's ''Artist's Robe'' (2004) is a Merlin-like garment embroidered with flaming eyes and weeping baby faces. And there is Helen Storey's dissolvable dress, made of an experimental enzyme, which disappears over the course of the show, a potent image of fashion's ephemeral nature. LESLIE CAMHI
Film Stephen Holden

Tomorrow's release of ''Tron: Legacy'' updates the Nintendo-era gamer film and brings with it an arcade's worth of clothing and accessories that recall the futuristic costumes designed by Moebius for the 1982 Disney original. The glow-in-the-dark neon aesthetic has even inspired a suite in the Ice Hotel in the Swedish town of Jukkasjarvi and a shoot in the latest issue of Playboy. To create these Light Sandals ($1,650 at Saks Fifth Avenue from February 1.), the designer Edmundo Castillo worked with the same electroluminescent material that was used for the costumes in ''Tron: Legacy.'' Too bad they do not include a BlackBerry charger. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

This is a story about a plan to end chronic homelessness in the United States. It's not an indeterminate "war on homelessness," but a methodical approach to do away with a major social problem. Each day, roughly 700,000 people in the country are homeless. About 120,000 are chronically homeless. They often live on the streets for years and have mental disabilities, addiction problems and life-threatening diseases like heart disease, cancer and diabetes. They are also five times more likely than ordinary Americans to have suffered a traumatic brain injury, which may have precipitated their homelessness. Without direct assistance, many will remain homeless for the rest of their lives - at enormous cost to society and themselves.Against this backdrop, the 100,000 Homes Campaign has set the goal of placing 100,000 chronically homeless people - pinpointing those who face the greatest risk of dying on the streets -  into permanent supportive housing by July 2013. It's the human welfare equivalent of NASA's race to put a man on the moon. Whether the goal is achieved or not, the campaign is shifting the way cities address a problem that has often been seen as more of a nuisance than a public health emergency.

One hundred and fifty years ago today South Carolina declared its independence from the United States. The move had been in the offing since early November, when Abraham Lincoln's election led the state's leaders to fear that Washington would begin to restrict slavery in the territories and in their own state. That was the proximate cause, at least; there was more to it. Beyond the election, South Carolina was no longer happy in a union with the free states, where northern opponents of slavery were allowed to openly denounce the "peculiar institution" in Congress and in their home states.

Last week conservative activist David Horowitz, author of the Academic Bill of Rights, e-mailed me to report, in sorrow, that Penn State University had weakened "the only academic freedom provision . . . worthy of the name." What the university had done was revise an 1987 statement stipulating that "it is not the function of a faculty member . . . to indoctrinate his/her students with ready made conclusions on controversial subjects." That sentence disappeared, as did a warning against "introducing into the classroom provocative discussions of irrelevant subjects not within the field of [the instructor's] study." The National Association of Scholars Web site declares that academic freedom at Penn Sate is "ruined." The left had won again, and the university world remains a bastion of radical political forces.

Poor vision can lead to job loss, social difficulties and the pain and cost of falls and accidents. And though routine eye exams can help to detect the early signs of vision loss and prevent the progression of some eye diseases, few adults make their annual appointments, writes Jane Brody in this week's Personal Health column.

Only YSL can make vintage as good as new. After the success of not one but two environmentally feel-good capsule collections, New Vintage, initiated by YSL's creative director, Stefano Pilati, and Julie Gilhart, is having another go. New Vintage III's moxie is quite simple: reclaim, recycle and sustain. "The collection is materially comprised of garments made from recycled fabric and from existing patterns instead of new ones, to start a dialogue with the market using known codes and a common language that are reassuring and familiar," says Pilati about the 180 pieces that will be available this week. Metallic wide leg trousers, velvet tuxedo suiting jackets and leopard-print wrap dresses with a hint of disco pay a refreshing nod to Saint Laurent's iconic 1970s designs. You'll have a second chance to finally own that missed ready-to-wear piece, and no doubt appreciate the brand's intelligent use and reuse of its existing resources.

Over the weekend I used a new iPhone application,  Word Lens, to perform magic tricks for anyone who would watch. Word Lens isn't really a magic app, but using it was kind of magical for me, almost like  seeing Houdini perform in real life. The app is an augmented reality program that can translate text from English to Spanish, and the other way around, instantly through the iPhone's camera.

For 10 days this month, a group of enterprising young women converted a carriage house in Los Angeles's Echo Park neighborhood into a larder that they called the Cantry. They christened themselves the Pantlers - after the name given to the servant in charge of the bread and the pantry of a great house - built shelves and lined them with an assortment of canned and pickled goods, tinctures and creams, and drawings and zines. Small jars containing tea lights and flowers were tied to bicycle wheels suspended from the ceiling, becoming clever D.I.Y. chandeliers to light the long refectory-style table made by a woodworker friend. Through word of mouth and Facebook posts, people came to trade and barter their own wares for ginger beer, pomegranate jelly, bacon-infused bourbon, pie fillings and sundry items. A neighbor even offered to trade music for goods. Every night a guest chef cooked a family-style dinner while D.J. friends spun tunes and recipes were shared. The Pantlers are all makers, "obsessed with food, gardening and doing things for themselves," and had talked about sharing their kitchen, home lab and garden experiments for over a year before opening the Cantry. If you missed the Pantlers in Echo Park, visit their online trading post and watch for news of the next pop-up larder.

The National Portrait Gallery in Washington will not comply with an artist's request that it remove a work of his from the exhibition "Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture," the gallery's spokeswoman said Monday afternoon. The artist, AA Bronson, asked last week that the gallery remove from the show his photograph "Felix, June 5, 1994," which shows the body of Mr. Bronson's partner shortly after he died of AIDS, to protest the removal of another work after it was criticized by members of the religious right and some congressional Republicans.

If its life-size horse puppets were not sufficiently challenging, the coming Lincoln Center Theater production of "War Horse" will also employ an ensemble of 35 actors, all new to the play. On Monday, Lincoln Center Theater said the cast of its "War Horse," adapted from the Michael Morpurgo novel and first presented by the National Theater in London, would feature Seth Numrich (of the current Broadway production of "The Merchant of Venice") as Albert, a young man whose beloved horse, Joey, is sold to the cavalry at the outbreak of World War I. Other cast members include Boris McGiver (Broadway's "Desire Under the Elms") and Alyssa Bresnahan as Albert's parents; Peter Hermann (Broadway's "Talk Radio") as a German officer; and the singers Liam Robinson and Katy Pfaffl.

Evaluating the success of N.B.A. teams requires assessments in two different frameworks. Objective measures of performance (won-lost record, efficiency differential, the "four factors," etc.) offer a very straightforward, quantitative means of determining a given team's standing. Additionally, because the chief operators of N.B.A. franchises primarily look to achieve very particular goals, the execution of the team's plan also becomes a crucial part of the evaluative process.

The international community should focus on environmental problems like climate change, the Dalai Lama told U.S. diplomats last year. Peter Orszag's well-remunerated transition from the White House to one of the banks that our federal government recently bailed out provoked a thoughtful post from Will Wilkinson, who suggested that the revolving door between Wall Street and Washington illuminates a "tension within the progressive strand of liberal thought." No matter how ingeniously or idealistically progressives deploy government power "as a countervailing force against the imagined oppressive and exploitative tendencies of market institutions," he wrote, "it seems that time and again market institutions find ways to use the government's regulatory and insurer-of-last-resort functions as countervailing forces against their competitors and, in the end, against the very public these functions were meant to protect."

Holiday parties are in full swing. And while it's safe to say we all gladly expect eggnog, Champagne and decorated cookies, run-of-the-mill festive sequined dresses are a bore. This year's look is decorated bright white minimalism. Dress up an easy frock, like the Row's marina dropped-waist silk one, with a printed evening clutch and a sparing spruce of jewels. The real party-gossip piece? Sergio Rossi limited-edition pumps knotted in satin or velvet. You've seen them on Anne Hathaway and Emma Watson, but not like this. It's the perfect cocktail of "It" item splashed with unexpected simplicity.

Last awards season we had Thomas Cobb, the little-known author of "Crazy Heart," the novel which in movie form won Jeff Bridges his long-overdue Oscar. And this year there's Charles Portis, the better-known but far more reclusive writer of "True Grit," the novel remade by the Coen brothers (and, again, a Jeff Bridges vehicle). Mr. Portis is known as "a cult writer's cult writer," according to Charles McGrath, favored for his subtle wit, lustrous dialogue and keen observation. The journalist Ron Rosenbaum has said he is "perhaps the most original, indescribable sui generis talent overlooked by literary culture in America."

Today's parents probably remember the college's counseling office as the place to go with the blues about a romantic breakup or when they were conflicted about their major. Those rites of passage still trouble students, but campus psychologists increasingly treat severe mental illness. Surveys show nearly half of college students who seek counseling on campus today suffer depression, anxiety, eating disorders, self-cutting, alcohol abuse and other serious issues.

Just a handful of television narratives have become synonymous with the holiday season: a misfit reindeer with the help of an outcast elf provides crucial help to Santa Claus on a foggy Christmas Eve night; a sensitive boy takes pity on an underdeveloped would-be Christmas tree; a humanoid alien traverses time and space in a high-tech ship camouflaged as a vintage British telephone booth.

Children go through ups and downs like everyone else. But even in elementary school, some children  are shy and awkward, and they can easily become social outcasts, anxious about social interactions and maybe a tad depressed. Normal adolescent angst can spiral out of control for these young people, taking them on a trajectory that can lead to major depression by adolescence — unless, research suggests, they have a simple but valuable asset: a friend.

In a wide-ranging, at times emotional interview last week, the departing New York governor, David A. Paterson, talked about a variety of topics, including his fears of getting along without the help of his staff, the focus of a front page article on Monday. But that was hardly all. He also discussed how unhappy his son has been over the last four years, how being governor affected his marriage and how difficult it will be to adjust to life as an ordinary citizen.

The Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf were delivered to their first customers last week, and a small fleet of Think City electric vehicles were handed over to the State of Indiana for use in state parks. From the very first hand-stapled issue, sold out of the trunk of a Cadillac back in 1980, i-D magazine popped with the attitude and exuberance of the streets of London. Created by Terry Jones, a former art director for British Vogue, i-D is as fresh faced and as youthful as ever - still featuring a winking smiley-faced model on virtually every cover. As the magazine celebrates its 30th anniversary, those iconic i-D covers, featuring an eclectic who's who of fashion, music, art and film, and photographed by the leading lenses of the day - from Nick Knight to Steven Klein to Terry Richardson to Jones's talented children Matt and Kayt - have been collected into a sumptuous new book by Taschen. The Moment caught up with Jones to talk about i-D and its legacy.

The postgame transcript from the Eagles' DeSean Jackson, as provided by the Giants. A Fifth Down post on Sunday questioned whether it was wise for Jackson to start celebrating before scoring on his 65-yard punt return, especially given his history of mishaps at the 1-yard line. He explains here that he was trying to kill the clock by running sideways as he neared the goal line. But he also added: "Like I said, I like to do some things for excitement. That's what the fans and all the crowd pay for, so I like to bring that out." As it turns out, the clock hit zero before Jackson reached the Giants' 20-yard line.

Phil Cavarretta, who played 20 seasons for the Chicago Cubs and won the National League's most valuable player award and batting championship in 1945, the last time the Cubs captured a pennant, died Saturday in Lilburn, Ga. He was 94. His death, at a hospice, resulted from a stroke he sustained on Dec. 7, his son, Phil Jr., said.

Walt Dropo, one of the University of Connecticut's greatest athletes, who broke into the major leagues with the Boston Red Sox, won the American League rookie of the year award in 1950 and became a reliable hitter and first baseman for 13 years, died on Friday. He was 87 and lived in Peabody, Mass. The university announced his death Saturday.

7:30 P.M. (HBO) THE SPECIAL RELATIONSHIP (2010) HBO presents back-to-back-to-back encores of its three Golden Globe-nominated films, starting with the screenwriter Peter Morgan's examination of what Winston Churchill called the ''special relationship'': the political, diplomatic, cultural and historical alliance between Britain and the United States, and between their leaders. Churchill had Franklin D. Roosevelt; Harold Macmillan had John F. Kennedy; Margaret Thatcher had Ronald Reagan. And, for a while, Tony Blair had Bill Clinton, which is the relationship at the heart of this third installment in Mr. Morgan's trilogy about Mr. Blair. Michael Sheen reprises his role as Mr. Blair, whom he portrayed in ''The Deal'' and ''The Queen''; Dennis Quaid, above right with Mr. Sheen, is Mr. Clinton; Hope Davis is Hillary Clinton; and Helen McCrory is Cherie Blair. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called the performances by Mr. Quaid and Mr. Sheen ''dazzling'' and said that Ms. Davis ''all but steals the film.'' The movie ''provides a captivating peek into the meshing of personality and power and how easily even the strong bonds come unglued,'' she wrote. ''Or, as one British political adviser warns in the film, 'All political friendship is strategic and conditional.' '' 6 P.M. (Flix) MY DINNER WITH ANDRE (1981) The writer and actor Wallace Shawn and the director and actor Andre Gregory, playing versions of themselves, talk about their lives over the course of a meal. Louis Malle directed.

Thirty feet above street level and just west of 10th Avenue near 25th Street, the view westward between a pair of old buildings reveals tall smokestacks and a sliver of the Hudson River in the distance. ''This is a piece of lost New York that still exists,'' said Peter Mullan, a planning official for the next phase of the High Line, set to open sometime next spring.

When Zydrunas Ilgauskas of the Miami Heat took the court at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, the benefit of watching basketball in 3-D became immediately apparent. On ESPN's 3-D broadcast, the 7-foot-3 Ilgauskas towered over the players for the Heat and the Knicks in a manner that has no true equivalent in a standard broadcast. The effect would be familiar to anyone accustomed to watching basketball on television who is sitting in good seats in an arena: a sudden appreciation for the physical size of the players on the court. The biggest story on Friday, of course, was LeBron James's first visit to Madison Square Garden since he signed with the Heat. But Friday also marked the first N.B.A. game that could be watched at home in 3-D, and the N.B.A. and ESPN, which have been experimenting with 3-D production for four years, were hoping that it would help drive wider adoption of a technology that has yet to truly catch on.

Visits to Web sites offering electronic party invitations and birthday greetings fell 16 percent from November 2009 to November 2010. These services offer the benefit of free cards, online R.S.V.P.'s and e-mail reminders before the event. So why are visits down? Perhaps their novelty has worn off. Still, Evite, above, which began in 1998, lists 22 million registered users. It may be that e-card sites are used to reach an established group of people, while social networks have become the place for messages about open-ended gatherings and greetings.

Now the Machiavellian schemes of Stephen Colbert are laid bare: all those highbrow cultural guestshe's been hosting lately on ''The Colbert Report'' weren't there because they're smart and entertaining and make for good television - they were helping Mr. Colbert establish his bona fides for his own erudite artistic pursuits. Next month, Mr. Colbert, the political satirist, will briefly shed his persona of Stephen Colbert, broadcaster, patriot and fear-monger, to become Stephen Colbert, thespian, in a benefit reading of Harold Pinter's ''Betrayal'' for Luna Stage, the West Orange, N.J., theater company, the company announced.

BORG--Robert Frederic, P.E..D./d,passed away peacefully on Friday December 17, 2010 at his home in Manhattan, three weeks shy of his eighty-eighth birthday, his family and loved ones by his side. He was the cofounder of Kreisler Borg Florman General Construction Company (KBF) based in Scarsdale NY, and served as its co chairman until the time of his passing. From 1955, when the company's early motto was "pools, schools and shuls," his accomplishments as a builder of hi-rises - over 70 stories tall have impacted the New York City skyline and its environs. A gifted photographer, he traveled the world with cameras in tow, producing numerous images with creativity and precision. He was an intellectual, with impeccable taste and style, a Renaissance man. A loving father (from his marriage to the former E. Winifred Pensh which ended in 1987), his principles of integrity, loyalty and perseverance were emphasized to his children and grandchildren. From humble beginnings in the Bronx, where he attended Dewitt Clinton, and later NYU engineering and law schools and service in the US navy, to a life of depth and accomplishment...he had quite a ride! His four children, seven grandchildren and companion Nancy Pline send him to join his two sons Eric and Neil (who predeceased him) with love and gratitude, he will be missed greatly and forever. Christina, Lisa, Kiri, Dean; Cole, Edward, Matthew, Brent, Devin, Molly, and Lane. Services at 11:30am Tues. Dec 21 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, 81st Street, New York City.

In manner and rhetoric, Mr. Reid, the flinty Democrat of Nevada, draws unflattering comparisons with his august predecessors. His colorless visage rated only the B-list of Democratic villainy in the 2010 Republican campaign, behind the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California. Fellow Democrats were so convinced that he would lose his seat that they began an intense sotto voce fight to succeed him. ''You couldn't find six or seven people who really thought I could win,'' Mr. Reid said with a smile.

Hide and seek has long been one of the Walt Disney Company's favorite strategies when it comes to home entertainment. To keep demand high, Disney rotates the availability of its animated films, keeping each title off the market for about seven years, then offering it for sale again.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Thursday about a slowing wage growth in Western nations misstated part of the name of the United Nations agency that released the new estimates. It is the International Labor Organization (not Office).

KAHN--Beverly, age 88, died peacefully on Saturday, December 18, 2010 in Boca Raton, Florida. She was born in New York City on June 2, 1922 to Ida and Samuel Goldstein. She was a true pioneer and had a long career as one of the first women on Wall Street. She was a driven, intelligent and dynamic woman who was also an avid world traveler. She was the wife of the late Martin Kahn and the late Emanuel Weisberg. Her daughter, Sandra Kurman, predeceased her. She is survived by her son, Andrew, many grandchildren and great-grandchildren who will all miss "Baba." Beverly had many friend who loved her and will miss her dearly. Services are private.

Off Broadway's Playwrights Horizons is reuniting with the composer and lyricist of its Tony Award-winning ''Grey Gardens'' on a new commission for a musical version of ''Far from Heaven,'' the 2002 film starring Julianne Moore as a 1950s housewife coping with a closeted gay husband and her romantic feelings toward a black gardener. The composer Scott Frankel and the lyricist Michael Korie, who most recently collaborated on the 2009 musical ''Happiness'' at Lincoln Center Theater, will be joined on ''Far from Heaven'' by the playwright Richard Greenberg (the Tony-winning ''Take Me Out''), who will write the book, Playwrights Horizons announced on Friday. There is no deadline for the commission, and the show is unlikely to arrive at the Off Broadway theater before 2012 at the earliest, a spokesman for the theater said.

GASTIL--Raymond Duncan Beloved husband and father, died December 14. A social scientist, he worked with Hudson Institute, Battelle Seattle Research Center, USAID, and OECD. He launched the Freedom in the World survey, and served on the Council for a Community of Democracies. He earned his Ph.D. at Harvard, after Fulbright and Ford fellowships in the Middle East. A specialist in democracy and culture, he wrote Cultural Regions of the United States, Social Humanities, and Progress, and was an editor of the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture. Committed to conservation, he served on the Essex Planning Commission, and Essex Land Trust. He is survived by his wife Jeannette, daughter Leila, son Raymond, and brother Gordon. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Phillips Brooks House, Harvard Yard, Cambridge, MA 02138.

This is my final interview for Wordplay, and I've saved the best for last. The name Will Shortz is on every crossword that The New York Times has published since Nov. 21, 1993. He doesn't create them himself. Rather, he relies on a carefully nurtured army of freelance constructors who flood his mailbox with submissions, all competing for that most coveted spot in puzzledom, the crossword page in The Times. Only a fraction make it to print.

WEDNESDAY'S PUZZLE - This is the second crossword from Michael Sharp. My post on his debut was not only great fun to compose, it generated by far the most e-mail of anything I've written for The New York Times. Judging by my in-box, the self-proclaimed "King of CrossWorld" is a decidedly divisive figure. Blogging under the pseudonym Rex Parker, he's famous for his venomous attacks on puzzles he finds subpar. To his credit, though, he's not afraid to put his own work on the line, knowing it may invite the same kind of criticism.

On Tuesday, presumably one of the last days of the 111th Congress, the House gave final passage to a five-year extension of the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act, which aims to clean up old diesel engines. The bill authorizes the $500 million in spending over the next five years but does not actually appropriate any money; that is a battle for the next Congress.

Last Thursday, after the Federal Reserve floated an aggressive plan to limit the amount banks can collect from retailers for debit card transactions, MasterCard Worldwide registered its disapproval with a statement that provocatively cast the issue as a conflict between retailers and their customers. "If adopted as proposed," Mastercard said, "the regulations would shift merchant costs directly to consumers."
The 2010 World Cup is history. The 2011 Concacaf Gold Cup is on the horizon, as is the 2012 London Olympics. Qualifying matches for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil will be here before you know it.

An 84-year-old Australian man has been sentenced to six months in jail for having fraudulently claimed hundreds of thousands of dollars in veterans' benefits he was not entitled to because his war record was entirely fictitious.

Poetry and prose on the subway may be going the way of the dodo. As The Times reported Tuesday morning, the Train of Thought series, which placed literary quotations from the likes of Kafka and Schopenhauer in the unlikely locale of a packed New York City subway car, is being removed to make way for a promotional campaign by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The Wall Street Journal has an excellent article today on Life Partners, a company that buys life insurance policies from elderly people and then sells interests in them to investors. It seems that -- surprise -- Life Partners almost always forecasts that policy holders will die earlier than they do. It also charges hefty fees to investors, ensuring that it will make plenty of money even if investors do not do very well.

There may be no bigger Christmas booster on this planet than Ronnie Spector. The Rock & Roll Hall of famer and former Ronette has been recording Christmas music for nearly half a century, ever since her renditions of Christmas classics appeared on the 1963 album "A Christmas Gift For You." The "original bad girl of rock" has just released a new Xmas-themed album ("Best Christmas Ever"), played her 10th annual Christmas show at B.B. King Blues Club and apparently already sent her wish list to Santa. The Moment caught up with this quintessential New Yorker to discuss all things Noel.

Angelina Fiordellisi, the artistic director of the nonprofit Cherry Lane Theater, a Greenwich Village institution since 1924, will step down next year, she said on Tuesday. She said that she plans to sell the building, at 38 Commerce Street, and that constant financial struggles in recent years and the changing nature of the business had led to her decision.

"Somewhere," the new drama from Sofia Coppola, was honored earlier this month with a special filmmaking achievement award from the National Board of Review. A look at the highs and lows in the life of a movie star, the film was picked as one of the top 10 movies of the year by A. O. Scott.

Instead of trying to respond to all, as it is obviously impractical, I would like to offer some additional remarks to supplement my previous article as my response.

Hayley Krischer is Jewish. There is a Christmas tree at her house this year, for the first time in her life. As she explains in a guest post today, it is partly for her son, whose dad is Christian, but also for her daughter, whose dad isn't, and mostly because this is the sort of thing that a guilt-ridden, over-compensating, divorced parent does this time of year.

There are dozens of reasons to love Amsterdam, but the food isn't one of them. To be sure, the city has several terrific Indonesian restaurants, like Sampurna and Blue Pepper, legacies of Holland's colonial past. (Indonesia was a Dutch colony for more than three centuries.) And there's De Kas, which serves excellent produce-driven menus in a beautifully restored 1926 greenhouse. I also love running amok at De Kaaskamer, the ideal spot for a tour of Dutch cheeses. But unlike most other major European cities, Amsterdam is a gastronomically deracinated destination. The streets are lined with gauche gaucho steakhouses, middling pasta palaces, wok wielders, burger joints and shawarma stands galore, and, more recently, a torrent of Mad Med tapas taverns.

It's not a trend, so get on the horn to Jack Shafer if anyone says it is, but for the second time my final restaurant review of the year is of an establishment in Kings County. In 2009 it was Purple Yam that got the nod, a gem of Ditmas Park, Cendrillon's ghost. This year it's Anella, way up near the top end of Greenpoint, down the street from the rushing waters of the East River and close to where the Rev. John Merz struts his stuff.

Blueprints and design have just been completed for a visitors' center dedicated to the life and artifacts of Louis Armstrong, according to Michael Cogswell, director of the Armstrong House and Museum, in Corona, Queens. The center will take a year and a half to build, and will sit across the street from the three-story brick house on 107th Street, which has been open to the public since 2003.

Jennings isn't Milwaukee's best player on either end of the court, but his absence from the lineup should serve as a reminder that things can always get worse for the league's worst offense.

Pork, Tar, Red Dog, Beaver: these are not craft beers or bad-idea candle scents, they are the nicknames of the big-haired, big-mouthed sisters in "The Fighter." The seven siblings of half-brothers Micky Ward and Dicky Eklund so captivated the film's director, David O. Russell, that he told the Bagger that he wished he could make a TV show just about them. Earlier this year my colleague David Leonhardt wrote about a new study that found that a good kindergarten teacher could greatly improve students' future earnings. On that basis, an especially strong kindergarten teacher is arguably worth about $320,000 a year, which is the present value of the additional earnings that a full class of students can expect to earn over their careers.
