Like a self-perpetuating argument composed of the phrase "I know you are but what am I?," the Möbius strip that is "The Pee-wee Herman Show" continues to cycle forward and wrap around itself. On Tuesday HBO said it would shoot the Broadway production of "The Pee-wee Herman Show," which stars Paul Reubens as that impish man-child of its title, for a special to be shown next year. Pee-wee historians - and you know who you are - may recall that HBO previously broadcast a "Pee-wee Herman Show" special in 1981, taped at the Roxy Theater in Los Angeles. That show, which Mr. Reubens and his colleagues at the Groundlings comedy theater began performing in 1980, would go on to form the basis of the "Pee-wee Herman Show" currently being presented at the Stephen Sondheim Theater on Broadway. HBO said it would tape its new "Pee-wee" special immediately after the show's Broadway run ends on Jan. 2; a broadcast date wasn't announced.

This isn't the kind of hot act that Kings of Leon wants to be known as: two buses belonging to the band caught fire in London, causing no serious injuries but forcing the postponement of a concert at O2 Arena, BBC News reported. A bus at the arena caught fire, which spread to another tour bus in the loading bay, and about 60 firefighters came to the scene on Tuesday morning to put it out. About a year ago at this time I ran a post titled "How Well Do You Know Your Children." It was specifically about parents' perceptions of their children's nutrition and exercise habits (those with preschoolers reported that their children ate healthy food and exercised regularly, and those with middle-school children reported that theirs did not) and how often our perceptions are wrong (when examined more closely, there was very little difference in eating and exercise between the two age groups.) More broadly, my post raised the question of how regularly there is "a mismatch between what we see when we look at our children, and what is really there."

Should Carter Burwell start working up revenge fantasies? Mr. Burwell, the composer of the scores for "True Grit" and "The Kids Are All Right," recently told the Bagger that he was worried the Academy wouldn't accept his work, deeming it not original enough, and it turns out he was right. "True Grit" was ruled ineligible, as was Clint Mansell's score for "Black Swan," according to a report in Variety. Both were disqualified because they include pre-existing music. ("True Grit" has 19th-century church hymns, and "Black Swan" features Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake.") "The Kids Are All Right" and Michael Brook's score for "The Fighter" are also expected to be banned because they rely too heavily on songs, which the Academy frowns on. Apparently even music professionals tend to prefer things you can sing along to, giving those films an unfair -- in the Academy's view -- edge.

A report by The Associated Press in the World Briefing column on Dec. 8 about a record price paid at a Sotheby's auction in London for a copy of ''Birds of America'' by John James Audubon, making it the world's most expensive printed book, misstated the final price. The first time Jessamyn Conell-Price met Moira Nichols, they had a lively lunch with several of Mrs. Nichols's friends, all of whom volunteer at the community library. Then the two women chatted a bit in Mrs. Nichols's apartment and took a stroll around the neighborhood. They talked easily about books and politics and life in the San Francisco Bay Area. Mrs. Nichols wondered if her new acquaintance spelled her first name the same way as the novelist Jessamyn West, and was delighted to learn that she'd actually been named in her honor. They agreed to meet every few weeks, ''just to have a cup of tea and talk,'' Mrs. Nichols said.

An article on Monday about a 27-year-old woman who killed herself in Manhattan on Saturday described incorrectly the Acumen Fund, an organization for which she volunteered. It invests in businesses that serve the poor in developing countries; it does not make small-business loans.

A picture caption on Monday with an obituary about R. Richard Rubottom, a diplomat who influenced United States policy toward Latin America in the late 1950s, reversed the identifications of the two men shown. Mr. Rubottom was at the right and Representative Wayne Hays of Ohio at the left.

SCHMERTZ--Eric J. Hofstra University and its School of Law are deeply saddened by the death of Eric J. Schmertz, Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Law and Dean of Hofstra Law School (1982-1989). Professor Schmertz was appointed a charter member of the Faculty of Law in 1969 and appointed to the Law School's first endowed chair, the Edward F. Carlough Distinguished Professorship of Labor Law, in 1981. The following year he was appointed Dean of Hofstra Law School. During his seven-year tenure he established many distinguished professorships. His notable public-service record included senior labor relations appointments by Governors Rockefeller, Cuomo and Spitzer, Mayor Dinkins and President George H.W. Bush. Professor Schmertz gave generously of his time and talent to Hofstra over several decades, influencing the lives of colleagues and students at the Law School and the University through his leadership of presidential conferences on Dwight D. Eisenhower, Ronald Reagan and William J. Clinton, as well as cultural studies conferences on Frank Sinatra and Babe Ruth. In recognition of his distinguished service, in 1993 Hofstra University established the Eric J. Schmertz Distinguished Professorship in Public Law and Public Service, and in 2007, conferred upon Professor Schmertz an honorary Doctor of Laws degree. He will be remembered by the Hofstra community as an inspirational teacher and leader, skillful mediator and cherished friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. He will be greatly missed. Marilyn B. Monter, Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz, President, Hofstra University Nora V. Demleitner, Dean, Hofstra Law School

Florman, Co-Chairman Joseph Zelazny, President

As the groom drones on with a tedious wedding toast, the bride's face goes blank. Then her eyes become watery, and her mouth gets wider and wider until, as he nervously makes another unnecessary aside, she looks like the figure in Munch's painting ''The Scream.'' What makes this magnificently staged comic introduction so effective is that the groom's toast isn't a total embarrassment. It's just bad, and the scene is pointedly ordinary until it explodes into fantastical lunacy, then returns to the banal. In ''If That's All There Is,'' delirious jolts of madness emerge out of everyday anxieties. It's a kick.

Beloved grandmother to Charles, Yasmine, Julianne, James, and Kemal. Dedicated employee to the Board of Education in New York. Tireless community volunteer and celebrated Girl Scouts Troop Leader.

More than two years after Lehman Brothers imploded, nearly bringing the global economy to its knees, regulators are preparing to file the first major legal action stemming from the collapse of the investment bank. The charges, however, are not expected to be leveled against senior executives at Lehman, but rather against the accounting firm that audited the firm's financial statements.

PLAN OF ATTACK That the New York attorney general's office may file civil charges against Ernst & Young, Lehman Brothers' outside auditor, is a bit unusual. White Collar Watch asks, is this the beginning of a wave of cases against former Lehman executives and advisers for their role in the firm's collapse? Or could it signal a split between the New York attorney general's office and the Securities and Exchange Commission as they follow their own paths in pursuing cases? PETER J. HENNING NEW FIGHT Seneca Capital, the hedge fund that led the fight to scuttle Dynegy's plan to sell itself to the Blackstone Group, came out against the company's new effort to sell itself to the billionaire Carl C. Icahn for $665 million.

If you're disappointed that 2011 won't offer enough opportunities to see Mark Rylance on Broadway when ''La Bete''wraps up its run on Jan. 9, you won't have to be without him for very long: he'll return next year in ''Jerusalem'' when that Jez Butterworth play transfers to Broadway in the spring, making good on Mr. Rylance's vow in November that it would do so. On Monday, press representatives for ''Jerusalem'' said the Broadway production will be presented at the Music Box Theater, with previews to begin on April 2 and an opening night set for April 21. Mr. Rylance will reprise his Olivier Award-winning role as Johnny ''Rooster'' Byron, the drug-fueled former daredevil he portrayed in the play's original run at the Royal Court Theater in London. Mackenzie Crook (of ''The Seagull'' and Britain's ''The Office'') will also return as Rooster's friend Ginger, and other members of the Royal Court cast are expected to appear in the Broadway production as well. Ian Rickson will direct for Broadway, as he did in London.

British television viewers who looked down their noses at the controversy generated in America by Janet Jackson's wardrobe malfunction at the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show may soon have a sex scandal to call their own. Ofcom, the British office that regulates television and other media, said it would investigate ''The X Factor,'' a talent competition, after a performance by Christina Aguilera and Rihanna on that show generated more than 4,000 complaints, The Guardian reported.

Lush green wreaths and garlands can cost a bundle in Manhattan at Christmastime, but regular users of the Hudson River bike path on the West Side of Manhattan have a better place to gather bounteous boughs by the sack-load for free near 96th Street in Riverside Park. Keepers of the tennis courts there have a little Christmas tradition in December. They set up orange pylon cones with signs -- ''Seasonal Boughs, Help Yourself'' - and then they begin cutting branches off the 40-odd Japanese black pine trees that line the western edge of the courts.

In his role as mentor on the fashion reality show ''Project Runway,'' Tim Gunn listens, consoles, advises and motivates, encouraging the contestants with his trademark catch phrase, ''Make it work!'' Now the fashion guru is offering his sage advice to the rest of us in an entertaining and thoughtful new book, ''Gunn's Golden Rules: Life's Little Lessons for Making It Work.'' While the book is peppered with just enough behind-the-scenes dish to keep ''Project Runway'' fans happy, it's also filled with personal stories and timeless lessons on living a well-mannered life.

STINGI--Nora P. Your legacy lives on in your children - industrious, committed to the next generation, idiosyncratic in our own ways. Your many sacrifices are gifts we treasure. You left us on the darkest day but your light remains. Mom, we love and miss you. Thank you.

If its life-size horse puppets were not sufficiently challenging, the coming Lincoln Center Theater production of ''War Horse'' will also employ an ensemble of 35 actors, all new to the play. On Monday, Lincoln Center Theater said the cast of its ''War Horse,'' adapted from the Michael Morpurgo novel and first presented by the National Theater in London, would feature Seth Numrich (of the current Broadway production of ''The Merchant of Venice'') as Albert, a young man whose beloved horse, Joey, is sold to the cavalry at the outbreak of World War I. Other cast members include Boris McGiver (Broadway's ''Desire Under the Elms'') and Alyssa Bresnahan as Albert's parents; Peter Hermann (Broadway's ''Talk Radio'') as a German officer; and the singers Liam Robinson and Katy Pfaffl. The Lincoln Center Theater production of ''War Horse,'' which is presented with the National Theater and the producer Bob Boyett, is directed by Marianne Elliott and Tom Morris, who both directed the British production. It is to begin previews at the Vivian Beaumont Theater on March 15 and open on April 14. A film adaptation directed by Steven Spielberg is planned for release next year.

The archives of Gwathmey Siegel & Associates Architects have been donated to the Yale University Library by Bette-Ann Gwathmey, the widow of the firm's founding partner, Charles Gwathmey, who died in 2009. He graduated from Yale's architecture school in 1962. Founded by Mr. Gwathmey and Robert Siegel in New York in 1968, the firm has designed residential and institutional projects including a renovation of Whig Hall at Princeton University and an expansion of the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University.

SCHWARTZ--Sylvia Feldman, 95. Died peacefully at home on December 17. Widow of Frank, beloved mother of Ellen (Azorin) and Victor, cherished sister of Alvin Feldman and Bobbie Landau, adored grandmother of Eric, Lisa (Pawlak), and Mark, great-grandmother of three. She had an innate sense of fairness and she lived by her ethics - politically, socially, and in every relationship. She leaves a legacy that includes a love of learning, of music and the arts, of friendships and family. Her passing will be mourned by every life she touched, including legions of students to whom she taught mathematics at Stuyvesant High School. A memorial gathering will be held in January; those wishing to be informed should send an email to: ellenazorin@gmail.com

BORG--Robert Frederic, P.E..D./d,passed away peacefully on Friday December 17, 2010 at his home in Manhattan, three weeks shy of his eighty-eighth birthday, his family and loved ones by his side. He was the cofounder of Kreisler Borg Florman General Construction Company (KBF) based in Scarsdale NY, and served as its co chairman until the time of his passing. From 1955, when the company's early motto was "pools, schools and shuls," his accomplishments as a builder of hi-rises - over 70 stories tall have impacted the New York City skyline and its environs. A gifted photographer, he traveled the world with cameras in tow, producing numerous images with creativity and precision. He was an intellectual, with impeccable taste and style, a Renaissance man. A loving father (from his marriage to the former E. Winifred Pensh which ended in 1987), his principles of integrity, loyalty and perseverance were emphasized to his children and grandchildren. From humble beginnings in the Bronx, where he attended Dewitt Clinton, and later NYU engineering and law schools and service in the US navy, to a life of depth and accomplishment...he had quite a ride! His four children, seven grandchildren and companion Nancy Pline send him to join his two sons Eric and Neil (who predeceased him) with love and gratitude, he will be missed greatly and forever. Christina, Lisa, Kiri, Dean; Cole, Edward, Matthew, Brent, Devin, Molly, and Lane. Services at 11:30am Tues. Dec 21 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, 81st Street, New York City.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Gary Chapman, an expert on the impact of high technology on society and public policy, misstated his date of birth, in 1952. It was Aug. 8. -- not Dec. 8.

Monday, Dec. 13 In the forest camp, the concept of time evolves: hours, days and weeks lose their hold on the mind and are forced to sit this trip out. In the unpredictable Makay, it is better to set your watch to just show the month: ''Hey, does anyone know what month it is?'' The only time that we still let into daily discussion is ''tomorrow,'' as in, ''We can try to finish this tomorrow if the rain stops.''

The National Portrait Gallery in Washington will not comply with an artist's request that it remove a work of his from the exhibition ''Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture,'' the gallery's spokeswoman said Monday afternoon. The artist, AA Bronson, asked last week that the gallery remove from the show his photograph ''Felix, June 5, 1994,'' which shows the body of Mr. Bronson's partner shortly after he died of AIDS, to protest the removal of another work after it was criticized by members of the religious right and some congressional Republicans. Mr. Bronson's photograph is on loan to ''Hide/Seek'' from the National Gallery of Canada. On Friday Marc Mayer, the director of the Canadian museum, urged the National Portrait Gallery to respect Mr. Bronson's wishes and remove the work but did not formally demand its return.

While he previously worked at both the credit scoring agency FICO and the credit reporting agency Equifax, he was not an executive at either company.

Judicial Watch did not sue on those grounds. (It had brought a lawsuit over a Freedom of Information request for documents related to the law's enactment.)

8 P.M. (Bio) JIMI HENDRIX VOODOO CHILD With a soundtrack rich in hits like ''Purple Haze,'' ''Hey Joe,'' ''Fire'' and ''Voodoo Child,'' this two-hour documentary chronicles the life of Jimi Hendrix, above, who revolutionized the vocabulary of the electric guitar, including heavy use of the wah-wah pedal and amplifier feedback. The focus is especially on the period from 1967, when he shot to fame after his performance at the Monterey Pop Festival, to his death at 27 on Sept. 18, 1970. Among the highlights: his headline performances at the Woodstock Festival in 1969 and the Isle of Wight Festival three weeks before his death. The film also features rare photographs and footage from family archives, as well as interviews with Hendrix. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE! WITH REGIS AND KELLY In ''Live's Holiday Skating Party,'' the studio is transformed into a winter wonderland rink, with performances by Bette Midler, Katharine McPhee and cast members of ''Disney on Ice: Toy Story 3,'' as well as an appearance by Santa Claus.

A music review on Monday about a performance of Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem'' in the JapanNYC festival, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the history of the event for which the work was commissioned. It was for the 1962 consecration of a new cathedral in Coventry, England, where an old cathedral was destroyed by German bombing in World War II. It was not for the reopening of the old cathedral, which was not rebuilt.

Beloved husband of Yolana, a devoted father and teacher of Allen and Ruth, perfect grandfather to Ryan and Javed, loving father-in-law of Susan and Qadru. Loyal and supportive friend to so many. We will miss your tremendous presence and your laughter.

A deal with Chrysler Financial's private equity owner, Cerberus Capital Management, could be announced Tuesday morning, said these people, who were not authorized to speak publicly. CARROLL--Hugh J.,M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Hugh J. Carroll, M.D., distinguished teaching professor emeritus of medicine. One of the longest-serving faculty members and most prolific researchers at Downstate, Dr. Carroll increased medicine's understanding of electrolytes and human metabolism; the circulatory system and the properties of human blood; diabetes and diabetes-related coma; kidney disease and its treatment; and acid-based disorders. He was a beloved teacher and mentor who guided the careers of hundreds of students and physicians. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Margaret, and his children, grandchildren, and friends. John C. LaRosa, M.D. President Ian L. Taylor, M.D., Ph.D. Dean of the College of Medicine Jeffrey S. Borer, M.D. Chair of Medicine

There are six living secretaries of state from Republican administrations, and every one of them - from Henry Kissinger through Condoleezza Rice - endorses the New Start arms control treaty with Russia. Yet, as of this writing, the treaty is far from assured of support from even the one in four Republican senators needed for ratification. Why the divergence between the Republican Party's foreign policy brain trust and its legislators? Hoping to find out, I spent part of the past weekend watching C-Span, notably the impassioned utterances of Jon Kyl of Arizona, the leading treaty opponent. On Sunday, there was a stretch of action that may highlight some differences between the Kyls and Kissingers of the world.

Services Tuesday, December 21st at 1pm at Gutterman's Funeral Chapel 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

The broadcaster Tavis Smiley is changing the co-producer of his weeknight PBS talk show to WNET.org, from the Los Angeles station KCET-TV. The half-hour interview program, which is called ''Tavis Smiley'' and begins its eighth season in January, will continue to be taped largely at its rented studios at KCET-TV, which had been Mr. Smiley's production partner. But with KCET's decision to end its affiliation with PBS effective Jan. 1, the show needed to find a new partner within the PBS family.

THURSDAY'S PUZZLE - Never look things up, that's my advice. (Some of the most passionate e-mail I receive on the subject of "obvious errors" comes from deeply offended readers who already live by this adage.) I liked knowing that George Bernard Shaw invented the GHOTI story. I've quoted him. I admire Shaw's plays and loved reading The Perfect Wagnerite. My grandfather who worked for a while as a bobby in London used to listen to Shaw's rants at Speakers' Corner in Hyde Park. (He was not impressed by "that grubby little communist.") Shaw's plays are as fun to read as they are to watch. There's usually a long commentary at the beginning, sometimes longer than the play itself.

Under the new allocation of electoral votes that will go into effect in 2012 as a result of this year's Census, President Obama would have won 6 fewer electoral votes than he did in 2008, gaining 2 in Florida and 1 in each of Washington and Nevada, but losing 2 in both Ohio and New York, and 1 in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Iowa, Michigan and Massachusetts.

Timing is everything. Just ask Bobby Werhane. Choptank, his Maryland seafood restaurant on Bleecker Street, flooded last week. The restaurant is a double storefront and though only half of it was affected by the water gushing down from an upstairs apartment, his attempt to keep the dry half open ended after the health department said that the fruit flies gathering there would result in a C grade. So the whole thing is closed until mid-January.

On Dec. 16, Google released the first version of its Body Browser, a simulation of the human body. Users can travel, as in the 1980s movie "Innerspace," through various layers of human anatomy, zooming in on internal organs, navigating around bones and peeling back layers of the human body until all that's left are the stringy tangles of the nervous system.

Power cuts and blackouts hit factories and residential neighborhoods in central China as coal supplies dwindle at generating stations. Supplies were strained after a surge in power demand after a cold weather front hit the region this week. Two power stations have completely run out of coal, and 14 other stations have only a few days' supply, reports said. [Global Times]

Back in July 2009, the Small Business Innovation Research program seemed on the cusp of a new lease on life and a makeover. The program, in which the big research grant-making federal departments and agencies set aside a small fraction of those grants for small business, was set to expire at the end of the month, but the House had passed H.R. 2965, the Enhancing Small Business Research and Innovation Act of 2009. The Senate had followed suit, renaming the bill the S.B.I.R./S.T.T.R. Reauthorization Act of 2009. (S.T.T.R. stands for Small Business Technology Transfer, a similar program.)

Aaron Rodgers's streak of 46 consecutive starts at quarterback for the Green Bay Packers was interrupted last week after a concussion -- his second this season -- on Dec. 12 against the Lions. And as much as he wanted to play, it wasn't advisable or feasible for him to start against New England last week. Time off and monitoring from the Green Bay medical staff have helped and now, Rodgers appears ready to start in a pivotal matchup with the Giants on Sunday.

Being a schoolteacher doesn't allow me much time for beekeeping maintenance during the shorter days of winter. When the Bagger met Tom Hooper, the director of "The King's Speech" at the movie's New York premiere weeks before Harvey Weinstein started rounding up anybody affiliated with it for promotional duties, we had an interesting talk about how the film's narrative is helped by the formality of the period. "There's a lot of drama created by the constraints of how difficult it is for an Australian guy from a different class to interact with the king," Mr. Hooper said. "It's like what they say about romantic comedies -- what's the obstacle in them getting together? You have to invent them. When you go back in time, often there's so many obstacles, because of the social structures. That's delicious, watching Geoffrey negotiate that with Colin."

The Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1 have added a third partner to their jointly run annual Young Architects Program. The two museums will collaborate with MAXXI, the National Museum of the 21st Century Arts in Rome, in this year's competition to transform the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, for the summer. There will also be a separate installation at MAXXI in Rome.

Growing up on the East Coast, I used to regard mild-clime cities with pity around the holiday season. Winters without snow seemed an unnatural, slightly tacky curiosity (Plastic flamingo Santas? Twinkle-lit palm trees?). Then I moved to San Francisco, where winter is a slow, wet leak from fall to spring. There's no clearly definable season between November and March, and one is as apt to break out the scarf in foggy July as in misty, flower-blooming December. All of which is to say I've gotten more flexible about wintertime expectations.

TOKYO -Sony's gaming chief, Kazuo Hirai, expected by some analysts to be Sony's next president, gave hints on Wednesday to questions that have fascinated the blogosphere for months: Is there a new Sony hand-held gaming device in the works to succeed its PlayStation Portable? If so, what will it look like? Will there be a PlayStation Phone? And what will Sony do to make a splash in a portable gaming market that has been usurped by casual games played on the iPhone and Android devices?

Maybe an airline captain would beam extravagantly anywhere else on the anniversary of his plane crash, but only New York would give him a red-white-and-blue fireboat salute in the bargain. We coolly scarf down deli lunches while we're building skyscrapers one-quarter mile high and expose ourselves to passers-by in the name of art. Go elsewhere if you want to stand on a bridge and watch the river flow by. We stand in a river and watch the bridge flow by.

Lior Lev Sercarz wants you to reconsider your spice rack. The Israeli-born chef, who's worked in the kitchens of Olivier Roellinger and Daniel Boulud would like modern cooks to reconnect with the spices our ancestors used - by which he means not supermarket stalwarts like cinnamon or nutmeg, but exotic ingredients whose names evoke the romanticism of ancient trade routes: Urfa biber, orchid root, white cardamom. "No one knows anything about them," he says. "Not even my fellow chefs."
This holiday season, many people are getting together to swap items rather than buying something new.  It's a movement driven by economics, environmentalism and charity.

Buying gifts online transformed holiday shopping, but it still requires some planning. Miss a store's shipping deadline, and you're left forking over some serious dough for overnight delivery. You think you have all the time in the world to shop and then - bam! - it's Christmas Eve.

From the mean streets of Lowell, Mass., to China: Christian Bale will become the first Hollywood actor to star in a domestically financed Chinese film, Reuters reports. In a news conference in Beijing on Wednesday the filmmakers behind "Thirteen Women of Nanjing," including the celebrated Chinese director Zhang Yimou, announced that they have cast Mr. Bale, currently burning up screens in "The Fighter," as a pious man "who attempts to save a group of young women forced into prostitution by the Japanese Army." The $90 million film, which will be made on location in Nanjing, formerly Nanking, is set during the Japanese occupation of China before World War II; its producers hope that the historical sweep and Western star will help promote China's cultural footprint abroad.

The Beatles had their suggestion for what a road could be used for, and the British government now has its own recommendation for a street closely associated with the Beatles. On Wednesday the stretch of Abbey Road where the Beatles were photographed for the cover of the album of the same title was designated a site of national importance, Reuters reported. The street, in the St. John's Wood district of northwest London, was designated a Grade II listed site by the British Department for Culture, Media and Sport, meaning that it cannot be altered without the approval of the local authorities.

Last year, an influential study examined whether breast cancer survivors with lymphedema could safely lift weights. Lymphedema, a painful and even disabling swelling of the arm, is a dreaded complication of breast-cancer surgery, especially if a woman had lymph nodes removed. Experts long thought that hefting weight of almost any kind would contribute to lymphedema in breast-cancer survivors and advised them to avoid picking up or carrying heavy purses, grocery bags, suitcases or their own children and to steer away, by all means, from formal weight training. But in last year's study, breast-cancer survivors with a history of lymphedema who completed a slow, progressive program of weight training suffered fewer subsequent flare-ups of the condition than women who didn't train, suggesting that weight lifting might actually combat lymphedema, not cause it.

A 73-year-old Polish woman from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, picked up the phone in late November and heard a young man's voice speaking in Polish: ''Hey, auntie, it's me.'' ''I thought it was my sister's grandson, Sebastian,'' said the woman, a retired cook who spoke on the condition that her name not be used. ''Sebastian visited me from Poland twice, so somehow I thought it was him.''

MARTINIS--Nell, died peacefully on December 21, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Justice Joseph Martinis. A wonderful mother and grandmother. A NYU graduate and most of all, a fine lady. She will be deeply missed as she was deeply loved. On Angel's Wings, Mom! Reposing Thursday 2-4pm only at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471. Private funeral and interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

FINKELSTEIN--Jamie Harriet of Brooklyn, NY, born May 20, 1978, age 32, died on December 19, 2010 after a courageous nine year battle with Leukemia, supported by the wonderful people at Memorial Sloan-Kettering and those who loved her. During her illness she graduated with honors as a pastry chef from the French Culinary Institute, and worked as a food stylist. Always brilliant, charismatic, fierce and passionate, this courageous, feminist lesbian humanist, artist and author, fabulous foodie and superb friend saw each day with fresh, trend-setting eyes that inspired and changed lives Devoted sister to David Finkelstein, Jamie was the daughter of the late Joan and Chuck Finkelstein of Oradell, NJ. She graduated River Dell High School and the University of Wisconsin. She will be mourned by her brother, David, her aunt and uncle, Susan and Gary Schneeweiss, cousins Barbara, Josh and Debbie, her aunt, Janet Finkelstein and the many friends whose lives she changed. Donations in her memory: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania bid farewell to the Senate on Tuesday with a stinging critique of the state of partisan politics and the conservative demand for ideological purity in Republican politicians. Mr. Specter, who lost his state's Democratic primary this year after switching from the Republican side of the aisle in 2009, sharply criticized unnamed colleagues as violating Senate tradition and politically undermining members of their own party.

Two ambitious Web campaigns were not enough to prevent a TV talent-show contestant from reaching the top of the British singles chart the week of Christmas -- an annual race that has become something of a national sport for British music fans. The No. 1 song in Britain this week is ''When We Collide,'' a soft-rock number sung by Matt Cardle, 27, who is the latest winner on the hugely popular talent competition ''The X Factor,'' The Guardian reported. Released after Mr. Cardle won the show's seventh season, on Dec. 12, the song sold 439,000 copies.In keeping with the same rebellious spirit that last year sent a song by the politically belligerent American band Rage Against the Machine to No. 1 over another ''X Factor'' winner -- an achievement the band called ''the Anarchy Christmas Miracle of 2009'' -- two songs competed against Mr. Cardle with high-profile online campaigns. One was the original version of the same song; the other was four and a half minutes of nothing at all.

BOWERS--Patricia Fritz, died unexpectedly and peacefully at home on December 13, at the age of 82. She was a person of great elegance, a world traveler with an exquisite eye for art. Pat was employed by the Federal Reserve after receiving her BA degree from Cornell University and her Ph.D. from NYU. She retired after many years as professor of economics at Brooklyn College and Chair of the Economics Department there. She has been a loyal contributor to many educational and art organizations and will be grievously missed by them as well as by her many friends. The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management will get back much of its troubled bet on the auto industry as a result of Tuesday's sale of Chrysler Financial to Toronto-Dominion Bank for $6.3 billion. Toronto-Dominion will acquire about $5.9 billion in net assets and $400 million in good will from Chrysler Financial, the former financing arm of the carmaker. Cerberus will retain more than $900 million in Chrysler Financial assets as part of the deal, according to people briefed on the matter who agreed to speak only on the condition of anonymity.

GREENSPAN--Shirley, 98, on December 20, 2010, predeceased by her beloved Allan. Beloved great-grandchildren Ariella and Aaron Lopez, Michael Greenspan, Ava, Emerie, and Daphne Katz. A woman of enduring strength, whose love for her family knew no boundaries. From her childhood in New York City to her years in Brooklyn and Florida, she lived a life of curiosity and adventure. Her legacy is one of willingness to seek new experiences and willfulness to make them happen. Her courage and ability to persevere is a lesson for all. She is missed greatly by all who knew her. Service at Louis Suburban Chapel, Fairlawn, NJ, today at 11am.

6:23 p.m. | Updated The New York attorney general on Tuesday sued Ernst & Young, accusing the accounting firm of helping Lehman Brothers, its client, ''engage in a massive accounting fraud'' by misleading investors about the investment bank's financial health. The lawsuit, filed more than two years after Lehman collapsed and the global economy buckled, is the first major legal action stemming from Lehman's demise.Ernst & Young, Lehman's longtime outside auditor, certified the bank's financial statements from 2001 until it filed for bankruptcy in September 2008. The suit focuses on Ernst & Young's approval of a much-criticized accounting maneuver that shifted debt off the books before the close of financial quarters.

This isn't the kind of hot act that Kings of Leon wants to be known as: two buses belonging to the band caught fire in London, causing no serious injuries but forcing the postponement of a concert at O2 Arena, BBC News reported. A bus at the arena caught fire, which spread to another tour bus in the loading bay, and about 60 firefighters came to the scene on Tuesday morning to put it out. The BBC said ambulance crews had also arrived to treat six people for smoke inhalation, and a spokesman for the London Fire Brigade said the fire had burned out both buses but had not affected the arena's stage or seating area. A spokeswoman for the arena told the BBC: ''Unfortunately, due to this morning's fire onboard one of the tour buses at the O2, tonight's Kings of Leon concert will now be postponed. Whilst there is no damage to the O2 there is now insufficient time to rig the arena for tonight's performance. We are sorry for the inconvenience and we will announce a new date shortly.''

Church.

MOED--Barbara Lee. The beautiful Barbara died peacefully in her sleep at 90 on December 12, 2010, at Age Song at Laguna Grove in San Francisco. Loving and loved mother of Leslie Moed of Santa Barbara, CA, Alison Paolercio (Michael) of San Francisco, Paula Izumi (Yoshitsugu) of Huntington, LI, and Ed Moed (Ginger) of Columbus, OH. Proud and cherished grandmother of Taemi Izumi and Richard Moed. Preceded in death by devoted husband of 45 years Irwin Moed, and adored brother Richard Bardt. Barbara was born in Washington, DC. She monitored English language broadcasts for the War Department during WWII, after which she moved to New York City and raised their family. She proudly worked for the New York Times for 27 years in Classified Advertising and had a strong head for business. In her retirement, she volunteered for SCORE and Temple Beth Sholom in Queens, NY. In San Francisco, her home for the last five years, she was an Experience Corps volunteer at Paul Revere School. Barbara was a talented and accomplished piano player. She had an innate love of music that she shared as a docent at Carnegie Hall. She loved to dance and was passionate about all things beautiful. In her final days, she taught us about aging with dignity and grace. She will live on in our hearts. Heartfelt thanks to the compassionate staff of Laguna Grove and Pathways Hospice. Private funeral services and a celebration of her life were held in New York on December 14, 2010. Donations may be made in her memory to Carnegie Hall.

INTERNATIONAL A picture caption on Thursday about the wreck of a boat thought to be carrying refugees seeking asylum in Australia misidentified the ocean surrounding Christmas Island, where the wreck occurred. It is the Indian Ocean, not the ''South Pacific.''

8:52 p.m. | Updated Want to watch hours of YouTube videos or sort through Facebook photos on the computer? Your Internet providers would be forbidden from blocking you under rules approved by the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday. But if you want to do the same on your cellphone, you may not have the same protections. The debate over the rules, intended to preserve open access to the Internet, seems to have resulted in a classic Washington solution - the kind that pleases no one on either side of the issue. Verizon and other service providers would prefer no government involvement. Public interest advocates think the rules stop far short of ensuring free speech. Some Republicans believe the rules are another instance of government overreach.

Steve Landesberg, an actor and comedian with a friendly and often deadpan manner who was best known for his role on the long-running sitcom ''Barney Miller,'' died in Los Angeles on Monday. He was 74. The cause was colon cancer, his daughter, Elizabeth, said.

THE ARTS An article last Wednesday about plans by St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue to replace its organ, which was installed in 1913 by the Ernest M. Skinner Company, erroneously included another organ among those installed by that company. While Skinner himself supervised the installation of the original organ at Symphony Hall in Boston, it was built and installed, in 1900, by the George S. Hutchings Company -- not by the Skinner Company, which did not exist at the time. (A similar error -- that Skinner built the Symphony Hall organ -- appeared in an article on Oct. 16, 2008.)

LEVINE--Robert A.,died on December 6, 2010, in Los Angeles. He was 80 years old. A Brooklyn native, Dr. Levine graduated from Harvard College in 1950 and received his Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1957. In 1956, Dr. Levine moved to Los Angeles, where he has lived with his wife, Carol, for most of the last 50 years. From 1974 to 1975, Dr. Levine returned to New York to serve as President of the New York City Rand Institute. A longtime employee of the RAND Corporation, Dr. Levine also served in the Office of Economic Opportunity as Chief Planner for the War on Poverty from 1965 to 1968 and as Deputy Director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1975 to 1979. His published works include The Arms Debate, The Poor Ye Need Not Have With You, and Public Planning: Failure and Redirection. Dr. Levine is survived by his wife of 57 years, Carol Levine, his sons, David, Peter and Joseph, and his grandchildren, Milena Davidson-Levine and Daniel Levine. A Memorial Service is scheduled for February 5, 2011, in Santa Monica, CA.

BORG--Robert Frederic, P.E..D./d,passed away peacefully on Friday, December 17, 2010 at his home in Manhattan, three weeks shy of his eighty-eighth birthday, his family and loved ones by his side. He was the cofounder of Kreisler Borg Florman General Construction Company (KBF) based in Scarsdale, NY, and served as its co chairman until the time of his passing. From 1955, when the company's early motto was "pools, schools and shuls," his accomplishments as a builder of hi-rises-over 70 stories tall have impacted the New York City skyline and its environs. A gifted photographer, he traveled the world with cameras in tow, producing numerous images with creativity and precision. He was an intellectual, with impeccable taste and style, a Renaissance man. A loving father (from his marriage to the former E. Winifred Pensh which ended in 1987), his principles of integrity, loyalty and perseverance were emphasized to his children and grandchildren. From humble beginnings in the Bronx, where he attended Dewitt Clinton, and later NYU engineering and law schools and service in the US Navy, to a life of depth and accomplishment...he had quite a ride! His four children, seven grandchildren and companion Nancy Pline send him to join his two sons Eric and Neil (who predeceased him) with love and gratitude, he will be missed greatly and forever. Christina, Lisa, Kiri, Dean; Cole, Edward, Matthew, Brent, Devin, Molly, and Lane. Services at 11:30am Tuesday, December 21 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., 81st Street, New York City.

BRENNER--Edgar H. The trustees and staff of the Stella and Charles Guttman Foundation, Inc. mourn the loss of our longtime colleague and friend, Edgar H. Brenner. Ed served as a conscientious member of the Board for 49 years, including service as President from 1995-2001. He was deeply committed to the Foundation and the charitable legacy of its founders. Ed was the nephew of Charles Guttman. We will miss him greatly and extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Janet Brenner, and the entire Brenner family.

FRIEDMAN--Wilbur H. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our cherished friend and benefactor Wilbur Friedman. Mr. Friedman was a dedicated member of The Rockefeller University Council for twenty-five years, helping six University presidents achieve their ambitious goals. With his beloved wife, Frances, he embraced the efforts of Rockefeller scientists working at the frontiers of biomedicine. He helped advance studies on cancer, antibiotic-resistant bacteria, vision, and neuroscience. He also supported our Science Outreach and Women and Science initiatives. Mr. Friedman will be remembered for his keen mind and impassioned commitment to the many causes and institutions that engaged him through his prodigious pro bono work. We celebrate a life remarkably well lived, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his cherished wife, Frances; to their children, Joan and Roy; and to the entire Friedman family. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chief executive of the Blackstone Group, is Paris-bound. Mr. Schwarzman will spend the next four to six months in France working on international opportunities for Blackstone. The timing is propitious. Mr. Schwarzman has been private equity's most vocal critic of American economic policy. His recent comments and venture abroad jibe with conventional wisdom: the United States is overregulated, and private equity's great investment opportunities lie across the oceans.

Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi sought Tuesday to clarify remarks he had made about his hometown during the civil rights era, calling it a ''difficult and painful era,'' especially for African-Americans. Mr. Barbour, a Republican who is considering a presidential run, endured a day of criticism on Monday for remarks in The Weekly Standard, in which he said of the civil rights struggles of the 1960s, ''I just don't remember it as being that bad.''

Archie Andrews, the famous redhead from Riverdale, will deal with a death in the extended family in the next issue of ''Life With Archie,'' which goes on sale Dec. 29. Geraldine Grundy, one of the gang's high school teachers, will lose her battle with cancer. The story is part of an exploration of two possible futures for Archie: one in which he marries Betty and another where he is wedded to Veronica. The first issue of the dual story line sold nearly 60,000 copies and led the company to start ''Life With Archie,'' a magazine-size publication that follows both futures. Jon Goldwater, co-chief executive of Archie Comics, said the death of Ms. Grundy had been planned since the beginning. ''The goal was to tell stories with important, real-world issues that people deal with like death, financial hardship and marriage issues,'' he said.

Deutsche Bank agreed to pay $553 million and admit to criminal wrongdoing on Tuesday, settling a long-running investigation into tax shelter fraud that prosecutors say generated billions of dollars in bogus tax benefits. In an agreement with the United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan, Deutsche Bank will avoid prosecution for helping 2,100 customers evade taxes through 2,300 financial transactions. The arrangements, which took place between 1996 and 2002, helped wealthy Americans report more than $29 billion in fraudulent tax losses, according to the Justice Department.

My older sister gave me a copy of ''A Way of Seeing,'' in which Helen Levitt captured New York street life as it existed in the 1940s. She immediately became my favorite photographer and still is. I've always admired that she was never shooting for publication or exhibits. No editors looking over her shoulder or second-guessing her work. She wandered the streets of New York following her own compass. Books, magazine layouts and exhibits would eventually come to her, but her goal was simply to record the world around her with a private point of view. What she captured on film has now all but disappeared -- a city before its vitality was lured indoors by television. Roam these same streets today, and there are no remnants of what she saw. Now her images are a time machine. Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

Like a self-perpetuating argument composed of the phrase ''I know you are but what am I?,'' the Mobius strip that is ''The Pee-wee Herman Show'' continues to cycle forward and wrap around itself. On Tuesday HBO said it would shoot the Broadway production of ''The Pee-wee Herman Show,'' which stars Paul Reubens as that impish man-child of its title, for a special to be shown next year. Pee-wee historians - and you know who you are - may recall that HBO previously broadcast a ''Pee-wee Herman Show'' special in 1981, taped at the Roxy Theater in Los Angeles. That show, which Mr. Reubens and his colleagues at the Groundlings comedy theater began performing in 1980, would go on to form the basis of the ''Pee-wee Herman Show'' currently being presented at the Stephen Sondheim Theater on Broadway. HBO said it would tape its new ''Pee-wee'' special immediately after the show's Broadway run ends on Jan. 2; a broadcast date wasn't announced. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

(CBS) THE 12TH ANNUAL A HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS Melissa Etheridge (above), Maroon 5, Ricky Martin, Nelly and Katy Perry perform in support of the more than 114,000 children in the United States foster-care system, at least 25,000 of whom reach 18 each year without having been adopted. Mira Sorvino and the hosts of ''The Talk'' -- Julie Chen, Sara Gilbert, Sharon Osbourne, Holly Robinson Peete, Leah Remini and Marissa Jaret Winokur -- introduce film segments focusing on families and organizations that have dealt with foster-care adoption, while some of the children featured in past years appear with their new families. The country singer Jimmy Wayne tells of his own experiences with foster care and adoption after a childhood of abuse and homelessness. On Jan. 1, 2010, Mr. Wayne inaugurated Project Meet Me Halfway, in which he pledged to walk halfway across the United States, from Nashville to Phoenix, to raise awareness of homeless children and teenagers, especially those who are too old to be eligible for support from the foster-care system. 6 A.M. A young, healthy patient called me recently requesting a CT scan of his head because of his headaches. He described his symptoms, and they sounded to me like migraines. His clinical picture was not suggestive of a brain tumor and I told him so, but he was persistent. "What if I'm the one 35-year-old who drops dead of a brain tumor while you try to figure out what's wrong?" he asked.

Although it's lovely to have a fresh Christmas tree, the sight of all those bedraggled branches left at the curb in January is nothing short of depressing. But in London this season, there's an alternative to the wood chipper: the Christmas Tree Project, a collaboration between Gallery Libby Sellers and the up-and-coming designer Fabien Cappello. The project is an extension of Cappello's 2009 graduation work at the Royal College of Art, and will recycle spruces, pines and firs into unique, handcrafted three-legged stools designed by Cappello. The stools, which cost about $621 each, can be ordered from the United States too. Obviously, a buyer from the States won't be able to send in a tree to be recycled, but there will be plenty of "orphans" available in London, where it's estimated that most of this year's 976,000 Christmas trees will simply be thrown away. And not only will the trees get new lives; the Woodland Trust, a leading conservation organization in Britain, will get a portion of the profits.

10:00 p.m. | Updated The long-awaited completion of the takeover of NBC Universal by Comcast will have to wait until the new year. The companies said Wednesday that full regulatory approval of the deal, under which Comcast would initially acquire 51 percent of NBC Universal from General Electric, would not be completed by the end of December, as Comcast executives had hoped.

ANAHEIM, Calif. -- During the California, Berkeley men's basketball season opener last month against Cal State Northridge, the Straw Hat Band and the student cheering section tried to rattle Matadors forward Michael Lizarraga with chants of ''tuna'' every time he touched the ball. Singling out a skilled opponent and trying to throw him off his game is a Cal tradition. It started decades ago with a successful attempt to rattle a U.C.L.A. player in a No. 42 jersey at the free-throw line by shouting, ''Forty-twoooo!'' Over the years it has been shortened to ''Tuna!''

Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the former commander of American and NATO forces in Afghanistan who was relieved of his duties in June, will have his say in a ''leadership memoir'' to be released in 2012, his publisher said Wednesday. General McChrystal was abruptly recalled to Washington and relieved of his command after the publication of an article in Rolling Stone that quoted the general's aides - many anonymously - making dismissive comments about President Obama, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and some of their staff members, and belittling the general's civilian counterparts in the Afghanistan war effort. He retired in July.

BENIS--Martin. Extraordinary husband, father, brother, stepfather, professor died December 20, 2010. Martin faced his world bravely with a loving heart for his family, friends and students. He lived his life to the fullest and wanted those people close to him to be happy. Donations may be made to: Firstbook.org supporting anti-poverty organizations with children's books.

On Dec. 16, Google released the first version of its Body Browser, a simulation of the human body. Users can travel, as in the 1980s movie ''Innerspace,'' through various layers of human anatomy, zooming in on internal organs, navigating around bones and peeling back layers of the human body until all that's left are the stringy tangles of the nervous system. The Body Browser works only in browsers that support WebGL, a new 3-D graphics tool that is appearing in the latest versions of popular browsers like Chrome 9 Beta from Google and Firefox 4 Beta. With WebGL, users do not need plug-ins like Flash or Java - the browser itself can handle complex graphics tasks.

On the Billboard album chart this week Taylor Swift edges past Susan Boyle to return to No. 1, and Michael Jackson's posthumously assembled new album opens at No. 3, with strong sales around the world. Ms. Swift's ''Speak Now'' (Big Machine), which was released in October and spent its first two weeks in the top slot, returns to No. 1 for a third time this week with sales of 259,000 in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It beat Ms. Boyle's latest, ''The Gift'' (Syco/Columbia) -- the top seller for four of the last five weeks -- by only 5,000 copies, sending that album to No. 2 with 254,000.

An obituary on Saturday about the German scientist Walter Haeussermann, who directed the laboratory that developed guidance systems for NASA's Saturn program, referred incorrectly to rockets launched by that program between 1967 and 1973. They were Saturn V rockets, not Saturn rockets, and 13 were launched, not 12. The obituary also misidentified the government entity that ran the Project Paperclip, the program under which Dr. Haeussermann was brought to the United States three years after World War II. It was the Joint Chiefs of Staff -- not the Office of Strategic Services, which was dissolved in 1945.

An article on Monday about a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow a vote of the states to overturn any act of Congress referred incompletely to the methods by which a constitutional amendment can be proposed and sent to the state legislatures for approval. Besides being passed by both houses of Congress, an amendment can also be proposed at a convention called by Congress upon petition by two-thirds of the states. (In either case, the legislatures of three-fourths of the states must approve the amendment.)

BANDEL--Esther, late of New York, NY died December 19. She was 91 and worked as a Principal Court Analyst at the New York County Clerk's Office. She had been employed there for 68 years. She was a native New Yorker; her parents were the late Bertha Mandell and Beryl Witowsky (nee Vitofski) She graduated from William Seward High School and received a BA from Brooklyn College. She was a woman of substance who possessed a remarkable knowledge of court rules and practice. She had a remarkable memory for names and faces, and was a stalwart of the Court System in New York State. She was married to the late Nathan Bandel, who died in 1969. She is survived by her daughter Judith, of Manhattan. The funeral will be December 26, at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., 1145am. Burial is to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in her name to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

DAVIS--Joyce Ellen, teacher and writer, 85, passed away peacefully at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in Manhattan on October 19th after a long illness. Ms Davis was born in Madras, India to William John Davis and Gerda (Goranson) Davis where her father was associated with the British Government Press. The family remained in Madras before moving to Wales where Ms Davis spent her childhood and was very active in the Girl Guides Organization. Her family then moved to Guilford, Surrey where they lived during WWII. As a young woman in England Ms Davis lived and worked in London for the Rank Organization for several years before emigrating to the United States in 1956. In New York Ms Davis was assistant to the President of BOAC while attending Hunter College where she received a B.A degree, graduating suma cum laude, followed by her M.A degree from NYU. A writer and teacher Ms Davis taught at the Grace Church School in Greenwich Village until her retirement. She is remembered as a loyal and supportive colleague and was loved and respected by her students. Joyce E. Davis traveled extensively throughout Asia, Europe and the Middle East, and lived in Athens, Greece during the early 1970's. She is survived by her long time partner Judith Godwin of Manhattan, her sister Marion Davis of Southbury, Connecticut and cousins in England and Sweeden. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

Panthers (2-12) at Steelers (10-4)Thursday, 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NFL NetworkLine: Steelers by 131/2 For John Fox, the writing is literally on the wall. Panthers fans hung banners around Bank of America Stadium last Sunday thanking Fox for his years of hard work. The signs were not meant to be ironic; bedsheet-and-poster-paint is not the ideal medium for irony, anyway. Panthers fans genuinely respect Fox for his dedication and professionalism, and they can appreciate the good times even though the Panthers are now 2-12 and have scored more than 20 points in only two games all season. The Philadelphia Inquirer, under new management and out of a Chapter 11 bankruptcy restructuring, has a new editor, Stan Wischnowski. Mr. Wischnowski, who oversaw the paper's front page for a decade and had been serving as interim editor since October, is the Inquirer's fifth editor in 10 years. Gregory J. Osberg, the new publisher, made the announcement as the staff gathered for a holiday party on Tuesday.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the annual televised question-and-answer broadcast by Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in which he addressed a broad range of questions submitted by Russians, misstated one of them. It was, ''What is the secret of your success?'' -- not ''What is the secret of your secret?'' The article also misstated the origin of the response given by Mr. Putin when he was asked if the imprisonment of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, was justified. Mr. Putin's answer, ''A thief should sit in jail,'' a well-known quotation from the beloved Russian singer Vladimir Vysotsky, was originally spoken by Mr. Vysotsky in the 1979 film ''The Place of the Meeting Cannot Be Changed.'' It is not from one of Mr. Vysotsky's songs.
An article on Tuesday, about the stuffed animals from the ''Winnie-the-Pooh'' series, misspelled the given name of the E. P. Dutton publicist who cared for them. He was Elliot Graham, not Eliot.

The faces of Brook Lopez and Devin Harris are on top of the elves' bodies. Santa storms out of his office when he hears the noise, but the elves get back to work before they're caught. Ho hum.

Despite being described as ''instantly forgettable'' and ''a theatrical lump of coal'' by some critics, ''Elf,'' the adaptation of the Will Ferrell movie, has become a huge hit, grossing more than any show on Broadway last week except for ''The Lion King'' and ''Wicked.'' Audiences have also ignored the dismissive reviews for ''Donny & Marie: A Broadway Christmas,'' one of only a handful of shows that topped $1 million in weekly ticket sales. The reason for these blockbuster successes is obvious to anyone who has tried to organize a large family outing this time of year. Audiences want to see uplifting, holiday-theme family fare, and if it provides a respite from shopping, cooking and struggling to get along with the in-laws, they will pay top dollar for it.

Service today 10am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

From the mean streets of Lowell, Mass., to China: Christian Bale will become the first Hollywood actor to star in a domestically financed Chinese film, Reuters reports. In a news conference in Beijing on Wednesday the filmmakers behind ''Thirteen Women of Nanjing,'' including the celebrated Chinese director Zhang Yimou, announced that they have cast Mr. Bale, currently burning up screens in ''The Fighter,'' as a pious man ''who attempts to save a group of young women forced into prostitution by the Japanese Army.'' The $90 million film, which will be made on location in Nanjing, formerly Nanking, is set during the Japanese occupation of China before World War II; its producers hope that the historical sweep and Western star will help promote China's cultural footprint abroad. ''We invited Bale to join because I am thinking about the market and because we want the world to better understand Chinese culture,'' said Zhang Weiping, chief producer at New Pictures Film, which is developing the movie. ''Hollywood stars are expensive, but they are worth it because they can influence the whole world.''

FRIEDMAN--Wilbur H. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our cherished friend and benefactor Wilbur Friedman. Mr. Friedman was a dedicated member of The Rockefeller University Council for twenty-five years, helping six University presidents achieve their ambitious goals. With his beloved wife, Frances, he embraced the efforts of Rockefeller scientists working at the frontiers of biomedicine. He helped advance studies on cancer, antibiotic-resistant bacteria, vision, and neuroscience. He also supported our Science Outreach and Women and Science initiatives. Mr. Friedman will be remembered for his keen mind and impassioned commitment to the many causes and institutions that engaged him through his prodigious pro bono work. We celebrate a life remarkably well lived, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his cherished wife, Frances; to their children, Joan and Roy; and to the entire Friedman family. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

An international team of scientists has identified a previously shadowy human group known as the Denisovans as cousins to Neanderthals who lived in Asia from roughly 400,000 to 50,000 years ago and interbred with the ancestors of today's inhabitants of New Guinea. All the Denisovans have left behind are a broken finger bone and a wisdom tooth in a Siberian cave. But the scientists have succeeded in extracting the entire genome of the Denisovans from these scant remains. An analysis of this ancient DNA, published on Wednesday in Nature, reveals that the genomes of people from New Guinea contain 4.8 percent Denisovan DNA.

A Broadway revival of Garson Kanin's play ''Born Yesterday'' is in the works for spring 2011, possibly with a relatively unknown actress in the lead role that Judy Holliday made famous more than 60 years ago, two theater executives familiar with the plans said on Tuesday. Nina Arianda, who received rave reviews last spring and several acting awards for her first major Off Broadway performance, as Vanda in the dark comedy ''Venus in Fur,'' is in discussions to play Billie Dawn, the showgirl mistress of the corrupt businessman Harry Brock, according to the two executives who spoke on condition of anonymity because the revival was still in unofficial planning stages.

Time Inc. is splitting its signature magazine division in two, the latest and final piece of a broader reorganization by the new chief executive, Jack Griffin, to realign swiftly the many diffuse and distinct units within the world's largest magazine publisher. The company said on Wednesday that it would separate its lucrative sports group, which publishes Sports Illustrated, from its news and business magazines, Time, Fortune and Money.

A report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about young female chimpanzees' mimicking motherly behavior omitted the context for a quotation by Sonya Kahlenberg, a biologist at Bates College in Maine. When she said, ''The monkeys tell us there is something different there,'' Dr. Kahlenberg was referring to previous research on captive monkeys that indicated a biological influence in their choice of toys, as opposed to societal stereotypes that may dictate what human boys and girls play with. She was not referring to her research involving chimpanzees, which are apes, not monkeys.

A bitter legal dispute between two of the world's largest hotel chains has come to an end. Hilton Worldwide and Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide have reached a settlement over claims that Hilton executives stole confidential documents related to Starwood's successful W chain, according to documents filed on Wednesday in federal court in White Plains, N.Y.

The spotlight was shining on her at last, and Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the oft-overshadowed junior senator from New York, did not hold back. Pounding the lectern on the Senate floor, raising her voice almost to a shout, Ms. Gillibrand hectored, reasoned with and sought to shame her colleagues into ending the 17-year-old ban on gays' serving openly in the military.

6 A.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: MICKEY ROONEY Turner Classic Movies continues its Thursdays-in-December tribute to Mr. Rooney, a larger-than-life 5-foot-2 package who married eight times, made and lost millions of dollars and has enjoyed a career spanning more than 80 years. Highlights include four of Mr. Rooney's signature roles: ''National Velvet'' (1944), starring Mr. Rooney as a young drifter who tames the wild steed of a 12-year-old British girl (Elizabeth Taylor, above with Mr. Rooney), training it for the Grand National steeplechase, at 3:30 p.m.; ''The Black Stallion'' (1979), about a boy (Kelly Reno) and the horse he bonds with after they are shipwrecked off Africa, featuring Mr. Rooney as a once-successful trainer who teaches the stallion to race like the wind, at 6; ''The Human Comedy'' (1943), in which Mr. Rooney portrays a small-town telegraph boy growing up during World War II, at 8; and ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' (1939), with Mr. Rooney as Mark Twain's troublemaker, at 10:15. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Two male a cappella ensembles -- Chanticleer and Committed, which just won ''The Sing-Off'' -- perform.

LONDON - Investment bankers advising on mergers and acquisitions from their offices in London are counting on business from China, India and other developing economies to make 2011 a busy year for European takeovers. This year appeared to have started well, with a multibillion-dollar bid by the Swiss drug maker Novartis for a stake in the eye care firm Alcon, but then Greece's economy went into a tailspin. The sovereign debt crisis and concern about the future of the euro sapped confidence among European chief executives, and takeover activity in the region slowed.

PETERKIN--John Gilbert, 82, a resident of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL passed away December 16, 2010. He was born on March 27, 1928 to the late Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Peterkin of Garden City and Westhampton, Long Island, NY. His family has been traced back to the Long Island area going back 300 years. He moved to Ponte Vedra Beach over 50 years ago where he has been an active member of Christ Episcopal Church of Ponte Vedra. He loved to travel and learn from other cultures. He traveled to over thirty-four countries and made three trips to China. At the age of 10, John enrolled in the Kent School (Connecticut) where his brother attended. After graduating from Kent he enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps in October of 1946. Four months later was involved in a battle with North China. Five months after that battle the C CO., 1st Battalion, 5th Marines, 1st Division was attacked at midnight by 600 People's Republic soldiers, killing five marines and wounding fifteen others. John was the last American to be wounded in China which disabled him for the rest of his life. John received numerous medals including citations from the Nationalist Republic and The Purple Heart. John graduated from Syracuse University Business School and worked for Proctor, Gamble and Owens Illinois Glass Co. and then went on to work for twenty-five years on Wall Street specializing in managing institutional sales. He also was involved with Young Republic events and was a former Vice President of The Investment Association. John founded the Long Island's Cedar Swamp Historical Society in 1976 and had a membership of 400 in the 1990s while living in "Glenhill", a 1786 homestead. He attended forty years of municipal meetings, was a New York Conservation and Environmental appointee for Long Island, a former Police Commissioner for Old Brookville's five villages and once asked by Democrats to run for State Senate. An avid golfer since 1934, John was once a three handicap and shot his age at 81, but never had a hole-in-one. He played several times with Byron Nelson becoming a close friend, exchanging letters for over 30 years. He was a member of The National Golf Links of America, Piping Rock Club of Cherry Valley, Ketchebonic Club of Westhampton, and TPC Sawgrass of Ponte Vedra Beach. He played on over 24 of Scotland's courses. John was a collector with eighteen of the best golf prints, dozens of hickory golf clubs over 100 years old, including Tom Morris' putter, an original 1723 golf rules book, forty trophies and very early American glass bottles and golden retriever prints. John was predeceased by his siblings: Dewitt Peterkin, Mrs. John K. Gurney (Jane Peterkin) and Donald Scott Peterkin. He is survived by many nieces, nephews and scores of cousins on Long Island. A Wake will be on Monday, December 27, 2010 at Follett & Werner, 60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach, NY from 7:00-9:00pm. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, December 28, 2010 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church located at 40 Main Street, Westhampton Beach, NY at 11:00am. The Interment will follow at the Westhampton Cemetery. John will also be remembered at a memorial service at 11:00am, Tuesday, January 4, 2011 at Christ Episcopal Church of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL with the Rev. Richard Westbury officiating. A special thank you goes to the staff and nurses at both Vicar's Landing and Beaches Baptist Medical Center for the exceptional care and kindness shown to John during the last few months. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Christ Episcopal Church, 400 San Juan Dr., Ponte Vedra Beach, FL 32082. Please visit our online Tribute at www.quinn-shalz.com. Services under the direction and care of Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL.

The Web site Cool Hunting has a temporary brick-and-mortar residence at the Gap rotating store space on Fifth Avenue. Cool Hunting collaborations include a limited-edition weatherproof cycling cap from the Brooklyn brand Outlier ($90); 3Sixteen ties from locally sourced, dead-stock fabric ($80); and Zillion Kimono skateboards, boards covered in vintage kimono fabric handmade in Tokyo ($850). The Klik Klik Edie Bracelet, named after Edie Sedgwick, is magnetic and can be rearranged into different sizes ($95). The last day is Jan. 2; Cool Hunting for Gap Pop-Up, 680 Fifth Avenue (54th Street), (212) 977-7023; coolhunting.com/gap.

In early 2008, Matt Dorey, founder and chief executive of Curve Dental, was at a loss. Three years into building a comprehensive Web-based software package for dentists, he felt the product was ready, but he was not sure how to make Curve a market leader. ''The company was getting complicated,'' Mr. Dorey said. ''I was starting to become conscious of what I didn't know. It was almost a feeling of loneliness.'' Then he learned of a chief executive, Jim Pack, who was looking for new opportunities after a private equity firm bought his medical-billing software company, AdvancedMD. Mr. Dorey reached out with a LinkedIn invitation. ''This was someone I had been following for four years,'' he recalled. ''He was really open about sharing knowledge and letting us know about the challenges we face. I immediately knew there was nobody better to be the C.E.O. of this company.''

MAYA LIN: One of my favorite childhood memories is of an aluminum tabletop Christmas tree light in the living room. I loved it. It was the last thing we turned off before going to bed, and it would project starry lights onto the ceiling and walls. Later I found it again in our parents' house, where my brother and I grew up. I put it up each Christmas for my children to enjoy. But a few years ago I sent the light to my brother, so his little girl could have it for her Christmas too.

Chestnuts roasting on an open fire may be a Christmas tradition in many places, but in Flushing, Queens, they are roasted in hot pebbles and not just for a holiday comfort snack. Hot chestnuts are a wintertime dietary staple for the many recent immigrants from China here on Main Street, where Tiffany Jin, 40, and her husband, Ping Ren, 46, each operate a stand selling chestnuts for $10.99 a pound. Ms. Jins amplified voice rings out all day long. She uses a headset-microphone attached to a small speaker clipped to her waist, and she sings the phrase freshly roasted chestnuts nonstop, in Chinese.

Peggy, a caring friend and loving family member devoted many years to special education rights. BENIS--Martin. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Martin "Marty" Benis, Ph.D, a beloved educator whose service as a former chair of Baruch College's Department of Accountancy and professor of accountancy at Baruch's Zicklin School of Business will have an enduring impact for generations of students. In addition to our indelible memories of wonderful times with Marty and his devoted wife, Marie Jean, we witnessed firsthand Marty's steadfast commitment to his students, the craft of teaching and to public higher education. We are proud of his exemplary dedication and grateful for his extraordinary service. We extend our deepest sympathy to the extended Benis family and friends. Maggi Sedlis Goldstein, Matthew Goldstein

The Beatles had their suggestion for what a road could be used for, and the British government now has its own recommendation for a street closely associated with the Beatles. On Wednesday the stretch of Abbey Road where the Beatles were photographed for the cover of the album of the same title was designated a site of national importance, Reuters reported. The street, in the St. John's Wood district of northwest London, was designated a Grade II listed site by the British Department for Culture, Media and Sport, meaning that it cannot be altered without the approval of the local authorities. In a statement, John Penrose, the minister for tourism and heritage, said, ''It is a fantastic testimony to the international fame of the Beatles that -- more than 40 years on -- this crossing continues to attract thousands of visitors each year, trying to mimic their iconic Abbey Road album cover.''

She was a force of nature who inspired and often amazed. Commemorative donations may be made to Planned Parenthood, Ballet Tech, or the New York Public Library. A celebration of her life will be held on Sunday, January 23, 2011, at 1:30pm at 285 West End Avenue, (73-74 Streets), Manhattan.

The case, which was closed, was at or near where garbage is normally placed in front of the building.

Angelina Fiordellisi, the artistic director of the nonprofit Cherry Lane Theater, a Greenwich Village institution since 1924, will step down next year, she said on Tuesday. She said that she plans to sell the building, at 38 Commerce Street, and that constant financial struggles in recent years and the changing nature of the business had led to her decision. In September, Ms. Fiordellisi announced that the Cherry Lane would not produce plays on its main stage for a year or longer to buy time to cope with a deficit that now stands at $250,000. Ms. Fiordellisi attributed the shortfall to a steep drop in income from government and foundation support, ticket sales and rental fees.

LONDON -- Investment bankers advising on mergers and acquisitions from their offices in London are counting on business from China, India and other developing economies to make 2011 a busy year for European takeovers. This year appeared to have started well, with a multibillion-dollar bid by the Swiss drug maker Novartis for a stake in the eye care firm Alcon, but then Greece's economy went into a tailspin. The sovereign debt crisis and concern about the future of the euro sapped confidence among European chief executives, and takeover activity in the region slowed.

Mary Devitt's family counted on certain traditions each Christmas. Her mother cooked the entire meal and served it on the good china, carefully arrayed on a tablecloth she'd appliqued with holly sprigs. The centerpiece was always the same, a Royal Doulton figurine of a little boy with a Christmas tree. Her father sliced the turkey, using the carving set reserved for special occasions.

The U20 World Championship in Buffalo and Niagara that starts on Sunday might well be the most important I.I.H.F. event USA Hockey has ever hosted outside the Olympics. It is an event guaranteed to be successful at the box office because of its proximity to Canada (more specifically, southern Ontario), but it is also a chance for American hockey fans to assert themselves at the world's premier pre-N.H.L. event. In some respects, it might come to define USA Hockey's presence in the American sporting landscape.The World U20 (Junior) Championship started in 1977 in Czechoslovakia. The host cities of Zvolen and Banska Bystrica were considered small -- appropriate sites for the inaugural event. The next year the tournament went to Quebec and games were played primarily in Q.M.J.H.L. cities like Chicoutimi, Hull, Cornwall and Quebec City. A few games were played in Montreal but the event's profile didn't get a huge boost across Canada because the gold-medal game featured the Soviet Union and Sweden (the former winning, 5-2).
