Three people were arrested for stealing an antique violin worth nearly $2 million from an internationally acclaimed musician while she stopped for a snack at a London sandwich bar, the Associated Press reported on Friday. The South Korean violinist Min-Jin Kym was eating at a sandwich shop outside Euston Station on Nov. 29 when she noticed that her black violin case - which contained a Stradivarius and two valuable bows - was missing, according to the police. The violin, made in 1696, is one of about 400 made by Stradivarius that are still known to exist. The police arrested and charged John Maughan, 26, and two teenagers on Wednesday. The names of the youths, 16 and 14 years old, were not included in news reports because of British law. Mr. Maughan is in custody and the two teenagers are free on bail. The instrument has not yet been recovered and an insurance company has offered a reward for information. Ms. Kym, who is 32, began playing the violin at 6, made her international debut with the Berlin Symphony Orchestra when she was 13 and has performed with other leading orchestras.

A New York film production company has sued its former president, claiming that "gross lapses in judgment" cost the company millions of dollars in lost revenue and a producer credit on the movie "Black Swan," Reuters reported on Thursday. The defendant, Aaron Kaufman, called the claims baseless. "Black Swan," starring Natalie Portman, is considered an Oscar favorite and has been nominated for four Golden Globe awards. In a lawsuit filed in Manhattan federal court, the production company, Overnight L.L.C., led by Rick Schwartz, accuses Mr. Kaufman of misrepresenting his skill and experience and pretending "to be knowledgeable about the financing of motion pictures when he was not." Mr. Schwartz, who was credited as executive producer on "Black Swan," has helped produce the movies "Machete," "Gangs of New York," "The Aviator" and "The Others." Mr. Kaufman said it was only after he joined the company and helped secure a role in the production of "Machete" and "Black Swan" that Mr. Schwartz was able to produce any films.

Thailand's film board has banned a movie about a transgender father struggling to raise two children, The Associated Press reported on Friday. I went on safari this season to track down the true Santa Claus. I found whole herds of them. But which was real? At my first stop, the annual parade of Sidewalk Santas sponsored by the Volunteers of America, I saw several dozen walking up Fifth Avenue as tourists gawked. The next stop was SantaCon, an event that defines itself as a chance for "guys and girls of legal age" to "dress up like Santa and go cavorting around town." I was startled by the sight of hundreds of Santas crowding streets and bars before gathering at Bethesda Fountain in Central Park. Among them was at least one Jack Skellington Santa, channeling the spirit of "The Nightmare Before Christmas," alongside a Santa whose suit was adorned with a much-repeated line from "A Christmas Story": "You'll shoot your eye out, kid." I found a rickshaw wallah who dresses like Santa. I asked him why. "It seems to make people happy," he said. I tracked down the Santa of the "Radio City Christmas Spectacular" - a Kentucky native, it turns out - in his dressing room at the music hall, where he's been reporting to work for 24 years. Of course, I went to the prime preserve, at Macy's Santaland. There, I found a 4-year-old girl curled up on Santa's lap and thought of Edmund Gwenn's portrayal of Kris Kringle in "Miracle on 34th Street." It dawned on me that everyone I'd seen was the real Santa, because Santa is whomever we want him to be.

BENIS--Martin. Extraordinary husband, father, brother, stepfather, professor died December 20, 2010. Martin lives in all our hearts: Wife Marie Jean; sons John and Tony; daughter Valerie; sister Harriette Jahss; daughter-in-law Elaine Goldman; stepson Mark Lederman and our extended families. Martin faced his world bravely with a loving heart for his family, friends and students. He lived his life to the fullest and wanted those people close to him to be happy. Donations may be made to: Firstbook.org supporting anti-poverty organizations with children's books.

The Los Angeles County Museum of Art said on Thursday that it had completed an agreement with the City of Los Angeles that puts the museum in charge of efforts to repair and preserve the Watts Towers, the cathedral-like spires and crockery-encrusted forms built by the self-taught artist Simon Rodia in his spare time over more than three decades. The towers, which were once almost demolished by the city and then later designated a national landmark, were damaged slightly in the 1994 earthquake and again during a 2008 windstorm. The museum, with $150,000 supplied by the city's department of cultural affairs, will collaborate with other art institutions and with community groups in the Watts neighborhood to assess the site's condition and make a plan for repairs and conservation. The hope is that the effort will lead to greater philanthropic attention and a source of long-term financing to maintain the towers, two of which soar more than 90 feet and have become symbols of Los Angeles's cultural history.

A column last Friday about Dr. Mitchell H. Katz, who will soon leave his job as the director of the San Francisco Department of Public Health, misstated the name of the agency for which he will be the new director. It is the Los Angeles County Department of Health Services, not the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health.

The Toledo Museum of Art has agreed to return a $1 million Meissen centerpiece, stolen from a castle where it was hidden during World War II, to a German royal family, the United States Attorney in the Eastern District of New York announced on Thursday. The centerpiece, which features a smiling sea nymph holding aloft a sweetmeat stand in the form of a shell, is part of the Swan Service, a dinner service for 100 commissioned in 1737 by Count Heinrich von Bruehl, a leading figure in the court of Saxony. In 1920, the von Bruehl family put 25 pieces of the service, including the ''Nereid Sweetmeat Stand,'' on permanent loan to the Dresden Museum. During the war the pieces were hidden at a castle called Reichstaedt, outside Dresden; at the war's conclusion, the boxes were found broken open and the Nereid stand and several other pieces were missing.

Frank Baldino Jr. who founded the pharmaceutical company Cephalon, best known for the drug Provigil, which is used to increase alertness, died Thursday in Philadelphia. He was 57. The cause was complications related to leukemia, the company said in a statement. In August, Dr. Baldino, who lived in West Chester, Pa., had taken a leave of absence from his posts as Cephalon's chairman and chief executive.

8 P.M. (TCM) THE BISHOP'S WIFE (1947) On a night of Christmas classics, Henry Brougham (David Niven), an Episcopal bishop, prays for help in raising money to build a new cathedral and receives guidance in the form of Dudley, a dapper angel played by Cary Grant. Soon enough, Brougham starts to wonder if maybe Dudley isn't out to replace him -- both at work and in the affections of his family. And that includes his wife (Loretta Young, above, with Grant). The evening begins at 6 with ''Scrooge'' (1970), starring Albert Finney in the title role and Alec Guiness as Marley's ghost. In ''Make Way for Tomorrow'' (1937), at 10 p.m., Victor Moore and Beulah Bondi portray an elderly couple who are forced to live separately, each with a different child, after they lose their home to foreclosure. In ''Remember the Night'' (1940), at midnight, Fred MacMurray plays an assistant district attorney who takes a beautiful shoplifter (Barbara Stanwyck) home with him for the holidays. Judy Garland sings ''Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas'' in ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' (1944), about a close-knit family swept up in the excitement of the impending 1904 World's Fair, at 2 a.m. And in ''Bell, Book and Candle'' (1958), at 4, James Stewart plays a publisher who falls under the spell of a bookstore owner (Kim Novak) on Christmas Eve. 4:10 P.M. (Cinemax) CRAZY HEART (2009) Jeff Bridges, in his Oscar-winning role, stars as Bad Blake, an aging country singer with a wayward streak, and Maggie Gyllenhaal is Jean Craddock, the small-town reporter in whom Bad finds inspiration, in this tale of second chances, written and directed by Scott Cooper. ''Some of Mr. Bridges's peers may have burned more intensely in their prime, but very few American actors over the past 35 years have flickered and smoldered with such craft and resilience,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Neither blandly likable nor operatically emotional, this actor has a sly kind of charisma and a casual intelligence.'' The film ''owes an obvious debt to'' Bruce Beresford's 1983 drama ''Tender Mercies,'' Mr. Scott added, ''but there can never be too many songs about drinking, loving and feeling bad, and there is always room for another version of that old song about the guy who messed it all up and kept on going. Especially when that guy can play the tune as truly and as well as Mr. Bridges.''

An article on Dec. 3 about the first murder in Celebration, Fla., a community built 14 years ago by the Walt Disney Company, referred incorrectly to the average sales price of homes there when the real estate market peaked. The median sales price in Celebration peaked at $712,000 in 2006, according to Trulia, a Web site that aggregates real estate listings. The average sales price was not $1 million.

The executive body of the European Union has ruled that, for tax purposes at least, works by the artists Dan Flavin and Bill Viola are not art but mere electrical devices, and thus subject to a much higher value-added tax, The Art Newspaper reported. The decision stems from a legal dispute that began in 2006 when the gallery Haunch of Venison imported to Britain from the United States six disassembled video installations by Mr. Viola, and prepared to import a light sculpture by Mr. Flavin. The gallery sought to declare the works as art, which is subject to a 5 percent value-added tax, significantly less than the standard rate, which in Britain will be 20 percent as of Jan. 1. (The rate varies among European countries.)

A little over two years ago, Mark Titus, then a seldom-used reserve forward for the Ohio State Buckeyes, started writing a blog that quickly became an Internet sensation. Titus and two of his bench mates named the blog Club Trillion as a nod to the games in which they would play one minute and register zeros in every other box score category. Although Titus's blog brought the Trillion to a larger audience, the term has been around for quite a while. According to the longtime Philadelphia 76ers statistician Harvey Pollack, the former N.B.A. player Scott Hastings came up with the name in the 1980s.

The first spin-off of ''Jersey Shore'' was all-but-announced on Wednesday when MTV said it had inked a contract with Paul Delvecchio, better known as Pauly D on the boozy reality show. The contract is the equivalent of a promise ring: it gives MTV the option to produce a series with Mr. Delvecchio, a deejay, but it does not mark the start of production. In a news release the channel said it is interested in showing his ''life away from the shore,'' but an MTV spokeswoman said there was no timetable yet for a series.

This week, City Room's James Barron asked readers to recall the worst Christmas gifts they had ever received. Here is a selection, lightly edited. Merry, um, Christmas. I'd tell you the worst Christmas gift I ever got, but I don't, to this day, know what it was. It was a secret Santa gift from someone at a company I do consulting work for. I can't describe it. It was something like a plastic, brown mushroom/toadstool thing, with things glued on it, in a box with clear plastic over it. I really don't know. I showed it to a friend of mine, an older gentleman who was fond of collecting interesting objects, and he asked me if he could have it. Not because it was worth anything, but because it was the oddest, most inexplicable object he ever saw, and he wanted it as a conversation piece (or as he called it, a corpus delicti). I gave it to him. Someday, scientists will discover the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider. It will look like this thing, but much smaller.- Tom Neile

'The Wreath: Interpretations' (through Jan. 6) A wreath shaped like a sea serpent may not be welcoming to many, but curious visitors might find it just the ticket at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park, above, where a display of 30 offbeat holiday wreaths is on view. ''Giant Sea Serpent Wreath (Wreath of Revitalizations of Life)'' by Takeshi Yamada is an amalgam of, among other things, a taxidermic jaw, steel, paper and sand from Coney Island; other wreaths are made of sticks and stones, bottle corks and drink umbrellas. They can be viewed Mondays through Fridays, including Christmas Eve, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. And for those who think one of the wreaths would look perfect on a door, many are on sale (prices, $100 to $12,000), with a portion of the proceeds to benefit a public arts program administered by the Department of Parks and Recreation; Fifth Avenue and 64th Street, third floor; free. (Anne Mancuso)

An article on Monday about a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow a vote of the states to overturn any act of Congress referred incompletely to the methods by which a constitutional amendment can be proposed and sent to the state legislatures for approval. And a correction in this space on Thursday referred incompletely to the methods by which an amendment can be approved. Besides being passed by both houses of Congress, an amendment can also be proposed at a convention called by Congress upon petition by two-thirds of the states. And besides being approved by the legislatures of three-fourths of the states, an amendment can also be ratified by conventions in three-fourths of the states.

Kenneth R. Feinberg, President Obama's former pay czar, received a lukewarm reception from Wall Street earlier this year, when he suggested that firms adopt a so-called brake provision that would allow employee compensation agreements at big banks to be broken if the government were forced to step and bail them out. On Thursday, Goldman Sachs disclosed in a regulatory filing that it had adopted just such a brake proposal. The filing says that, if the government is forced to bail Goldman out, most of the firm's outstanding compensation awards ''shall immediately terminate.'' The move was applauded by some pay experts as a good corporate governance practice.

She was the wife of Marc Eisenberg, MD, and mother of Janis Kelman (David) of Chattanooga, TN, and Laney Eisenberg of Cheshire, CT. She also leaves granddaughters Bethany and Autumn Kelman of Chattanooga, TN. Plans for a private memorial are pending.

An obituary on Dec. 6 about the architect and artist John Diebboll referred imprecisely to a course for which Sandy Davis of the piano-restoration company Klavierhaus asked him to design a 21st-century piano in 1997. It was being developed at the Bard Graduate Center in Manhattan -- not at Bard College, which is in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and is affiliated with the graduate center.

Jo-Ann Stores agreed to a $1.6 billion buyout offer on Thursday from Leonard Green & Partners, the latest private equity deal for a retail company. The $61-a-share bid for Jo-Ann Stores, which sells fabric and crafts, represents a 34 percent premium to the company's closing price on Wednesday.

BRODLIEB--Theodore, passed away peacefully on December 22 at his home in Delray Beach, FL at the age of 94. He was surrounded by his loved ones and family. Loving husband of Shirley, father of Barbara, Ken, and Marc, father-in-law of Andrea, grandfather of Oliver, Tim, Kim, Andrew, Samantha, Leah, Alex, Jesse, Lonnie, Liz and Timmy, great-grandfather of Teddy, Baker, and Sayres, step-father of David and Susan Wexler, Jim and Michi Wexler and Elise and Ira Goldman. From a humble beginning in Brooklyn where he graduated from Brooklyn College, to a life of depth and great accomplishments, he lived life to the fullest. He will be greatly missed forever. Services at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel 5808 West Atlantic Ave Delray Beach, FL, December 26 11am. Donations can be made in Ted's memory to the Hospice of your choice.

7:49 p.m. | Updated A crucial cooperating witness in the most recent round of arrests stemming from the federal government's insider trading investigation pleaded guilty this month, according to court documents unsealed on Thursday. From 2007 to 2009, Karl Motey, an independent consultant in California, received inside information about the Marvell Technology Group from sources working there, then passed that information to a handful of hedge fund clients, according to the plea. During the same period, he also got tips from a source at United Microelectronics and received inside information from employees at a hedge fund in California.

7:26 p.m. | Updated The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Julius Genachowski, signaled his approval of Comcast's acquisition of NBC Universal on Thursday, but that approval will come with conditions. Among the anticipated stipulations is that Comcast not withhold NBC programming from its competitors in the online video market and that it allow rival distributors to have reasonable access to NBC Universal programming.

An art review on Dec. 10 about ''Stop, Repair, Prepare: Variations on 'Ode to Joy' for a Prepared Piano,'' a work by Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla that is currently at the Museum of Modern Art, referred imprecisely to John Cage's ''prepared'' pianos. According to Richard Bunger Evans, author of ''The Well-Prepared Piano,'' which has a foreword by Cage, he placed objects between the piano strings, not under them, and the objects did not include stones.

An article on Dec. 15 about the New York Americans hockey team, which preceded the New York Rangers in playing at Madison Square Garden, misstated one of the years the Rangers won the Stanley Cup before the Americans folded in 1942. Besides 1933, the Rangers won in 1928, not 1927. The article also referred incorrectly to the purchase of the team by the New York bootlegger, Big Bill Dwyer. He paid $80,000 to buy the rights to the Hamilton Tigers players; he did not buy the franchise.

FRIEDMAN--Wilbur H. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Wilbur H. Friedman, and send condolences to his family.

The week before Christmas is usually news-free on Broadway, so the announcement on Tuesday from the producers of ''Driving Miss Daisy'' - that the Vanessa Redgrave-James Earl Jones-Boyd Gaines hit had become the first play of the season to turn a profit - normally would have rated as the Rialto's story-of-the-day. But a certain other show has been generating more news and attention than any Broadway production in many years; even if the ''Daisy'' folks put wires on Ms. Redgrave and sent her flying above the audience, it still would've been hard to break through the press coverage over at the Foxwoods Theater this week. (Anyway, Ms. Redgrave flies just fine with her feet on the ground, thank you.) But attention must be paid: The producers of ''Daisy'' have recouped their $2.6 million investment in less than nine and a half weeks, a very quick pace, making it one of only 30 percent or so of Broadway shows that earn a profit each year. The production of the Alfred Uhry play, directed by David Esbjornson, opened to generally strong reviews on Oct. 25 and recently extended its run on Broadway through April 9; its three stars are staying in the show. This is the first Broadway run of ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' which ran Off Broadway from 1987 to 1990, won the Pulitzer Prize in drama in 1988 and was turned into a 1989 film.

RHODES--Joseph, much loved father of Kate, Buffy, and Amy, and husband of Barbara for 38 years until her death in 1981, died on December 22nd at the age of 89. Joe was a warm, generous and easy-going man who played a mean game of bridge and was an active member of The Players Club for nearly 40 years where he served as Honorary Lifetime Director. Joe was also the proud grandfather of Joseph and Jacob Clancy of Melbourne, Australia. A Memorial Service will be held in January at the Players Club.

BANDEL--Esther, late of New York, NY died December 19. She was 91 and worked as a Principal Court Analyst at the New York County Clerk's Office. She had been employed there for 68 years. She was a native New Yorker; her parents were the late Bertha Mandell and Beryl Witowsky (nee Vitofski) She graduated from William Seward High School and received a BA from Brooklyn College. She was a woman of substance who possessed a remarkable knowledge of court rules and practice. She had a remarkable memory for names and faces, and was a stalwart of the Court System in New York State. She was married to the late Nathan Bandel, who died in 1969. She is survived by her daughter Judith, of Manhattan. The funeral will be December 26, at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., 1145am. Burial is to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in her name to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

Moller-Maersk, the Danish shipper, said Thursday that it had agreed to pay $2.4 billion in cash to SK Energy of South Korea to acquire its Brazilian assets, a move that gives it access to the huge pre-salt oil deposits off Brazil. My Sunday column argues that as we debate budget cuts in the coming year, we should remember that we have invested enormously in military power and far, far less in diplomacy, education and other fields. If we're trying to figure out how to raise our standard of living, or at least preserve it, the evidence is pretty good that we'll get a better return on investment in early childhood education than in, say, a military base in Germany.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan -- Eleven members of Pakistan's paramilitary Frontier Corps were killed and nine were wounded on Friday when about 150 militants launched simultaneous attacks on five security posts in the northwestern Mohmand tribal region close to the Afghan border, a senior security official said. The official, who asked not to be named because he was not authorized to speak to the media, said that the security forces had received a tip about an impending assault, ''but frankly, we didn't expect an attack of this scale and magnitude.''

You can imagine what the schedule-makers were thinking when they slapped a bow on this game and dropped it onto the Christmas prime-time television schedule in the spring: What a gift for fans! The mighty, beloved Cowboys, who will no doubt be 11-3, facing the scrappy Cardinals, who will probably be around 8-6 and scoring 42 points per game. Surely Tony Romo will throw for four touchdowns, and we can cut away to luxury-box images of his lovely girlfriend, Candice Crawford, cheering him on in a fetching Santa hat. Heck, Kurt Warner will probably come out of retirement to save the Cardinals by October. Crawford did receive an engagement ring from Romo this week, but it's the only ring anyone involved with the Cowboys is likely to see for a while. And the Cardinals are stuck with the rookie quarterback John Skelton, whom announcers sometimes compare to Ben Roethlisberger, because both are tall. If this game becomes too tedious, sift through the obscure cable channels and check out the ''Renovation Realities'' marathon on DIY, which may include an episode on renovating the N.F.C. West.

From a humble beginning in Brooklyn where he graduated from Brooklyn College, to a life of depth and great accomplishments, he lived life to the fullest. He will be greatly missed forever. Services at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel 5808 West Atlantic Ave Delray Beach, FL, December 26 11am. Donations can be made in Ted's memory to the Hospice of your choice.

FRIEDMAN--Wilbur H. The Bard College community mourns the passing of Wilbur Friedman, a longtime friend and benefactor of the college. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. He will be sorely missed. Leon Botstein, President Charles P. Stevenson Jr., Chairman

A New York film production company has sued its former president, claiming that ''gross lapses in judgment'' cost the company millions of dollars in lost revenue and a producer credit on the movie ''Black Swan,'' Reuters reported on Thursday. The defendant, Aaron Kaufman, called the claims baseless. ''Black Swan,'' starring Natalie Portman, is considered an Oscar favorite and has been nominated for four Golden Globe awards. In a lawsuit filed in Manhattan federal court, the production company, Overnight L.L.C., led by Rick Schwartz, accuses Mr. Kaufman of misrepresenting his skill and experience and pretending ''to be knowledgeable about the financing of motion pictures when he was not.'' Mr. Schwartz, who was credited as an executive producer on ''Black Swan,'' has helped produce the movies ''Machete,'' ''Gangs of New York,'' ''The Aviator'' and ''The Others.'' Mr. Kaufman said it was only after he joined the company and helped secure a role in the production of ''Machete'' and ''Black Swan'' that Mr. Schwartz was able to produce any films.

Grimbilas, President, Parents Association

An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about retro design for high-tech electronics misspelled the surname of the filmmaker and actor whose distinctive voice was recalled in describing the abilities of a high-fidelity microphone made to look like one from the golden age of radio. He was Orson Welles, not Wells.

Peter Post, an etiquette expert at the Emily Post Institute, offers some suggestions about whether employees should give their bosses gifts and vice versa. While he recommends showing appreciation to bosses and co-workers, he doesn't recommend giving each individual a unique gift. Instead, he said managers should consider giving group gifts to their employees. Employees, meanwhile, he said, should consider pooling $15 to $20 each and buying their manager a gift from the group.

A call came in to the newsroom on a quiet Christmas Eve day with this little gem: Seems that the Clintons -- that's the former president, Bill; the current secretary of state, Hillary; and this summer's Bride of the Century, Chelsea -- stopped by the Cafe Carlyle on Thursday night. They were there to toast Steve Tyrell, the singer who took over when Bobby Short died in 2005. Mr. Tyrell, whom Stephen Holden, a music reviewer for The Times described as ''a Burt Bacharach protege with one foot in New Orleans,'' is to be married on Sunday -- at the Carlyle, natch -- to Karen Pulaski. President Clinton and Chelsea were said to have danced to Mr. Tyrell's rendition of ''The Way You Look Tonight,'' from the movie ''Father of the Bride,'' at Chelsea's wedding to Marc Mezvinsky in Rhinebeck, N.Y., on July 31, according to our tipster.

Conversation turned to taxidermy as a couple of friends and I awaited the start of ''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson'' recently. This is not a favorite topic, needless to say, but it sprang naturally to mind because our seats at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater were directly underneath a stuffed horse suspended upside-down from the ceiling. The horse was an atmospheric accent in the riot of bric-a-brac blanketing the stage, the proscenium and the auditorium of the theater, designed to put the audience in the proper frame of mind for Alex Timbers and Michael Friedman's acerbic musical essay on current affairs, ingeniously disguised as a history lesson. The set, by Donyale Werle, doesn't stop decorously at the edge of the stage, where that fourth wall is supposed to be. Instead vintage paintings and chandeliers and piles of antique-looking gewgaws crawl up and around the sides of the theater. It is as if the entire contents of a Brooklyn flea market had been scooped up and flung around. (Some of the decorations actually were gathered at Brooklyn flea markets.)
An editorial on Wednesday about property taxes misstated the size of the New York City school system. It has about 1,700 schools, not 1,100 teachers.

NEUBERGER--Roy Rothschild, 107, died peacefully at his home in New York City on December 24, 2010 of natural causes. He is survived by his daughter, Ann Neuberger Aceves and her partner James Sullivan, his sons, Roy Salant Neuberger and James Alfred Neuberger and their spouses Linda Villency Neuberger and Helen Stambler Neuberger, his grandchildren, Andrea London Zweigenbaum, Patricia London, Matthew London, Sarah Lancry, Yaffa Jungreis, Miriam Hess, Aharon Neuberger, and Nechama Slatus, all of their respective spouses, and thirty great-grandchildren. Roy was a truly remarkable person, beloved by many, who had an enormous impact both in the world of finance and art. His legacy will live on both through Neuberger Berman, the Neuberger Museum of Art, and the countless people whose lives he touched in so many ways. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue in New York City, on Sunday, December 26th at 1:15pm, with burial at Mount Neboh Cemetery in Queens. A Memorial Service will be held at a time to be announced. Shiva/Mourning will be observed at his home this Sunday, December 26th after 5pm and on Monday from 4 to 8pm, and will continue from Tuesday to Friday at the home of his son Roy Salant Neuberger.

Nikola Ivkovic's fraser firs were drying up. Needles were dropping on the sidewalk on Broadway near 73rd Street where he has been selling Christmas trees since Thanksgiving. His deliverymen had called in sick, or maybe they were just sick of waiting for trees to deliver. The bulk of the buying was now over. With most celebrants already treed-up, only a few stragglers were interested in Mr. Ivkovic's stock.

Hamas renewed its commitment on Friday to a cease-fire with Israel apparently in an effort to head off further escalation. ''We declare our commitment to the lull as long as the occupation does,'' said Mahmoud Zahar, a senior Hamas leader, referring to Israel. Militant groups in Gaza have recently stepped up rocket and mortar fire against Israel, and Israel has responded with the first airstrikes against Hamas targets in Gaza since the end of a military campaign there in early 2009. Mr. Zahar warned that Israel must refrain from pinpoint killings of leaders of armed groups and ease the Gaza blockade if it wanted Hamas to continue to show restraint.

In a case that has outraged human rights advocates, Dr. Binayak Sen was sentenced Friday to life imprisonment on charges that he committed sedition by aiding Maoist rebels. Nobel laureates had appealed for his release and human rights activists condemned the verdict as unjustified.

Let the wine keep flowing: ''Three Pianos,'' a boisterously irreverent salute to Schubert in which three pianists get increasingly party-hearty while running through the whole of his 24-song cycle ''Winterreise,'' has extended its run at the New York Theater Workshop by a week. The show will finish on Jan. 16, making room for rehearsals of the theater's next production, ''Peter and the Starcatcher.''Created and performed by Rick Burkhardt, Alec Duffy and Dave Malloy, ''Three Pianos'' originated at the Ontological-Hysteric Theater and after a short successful run was added to the New York Theater Workshop schedule, where critics were again largely positive. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Three people were arrested for stealing an antique violin worth nearly $2 million from an internationally acclaimed musician while she stopped for a snack at a London sandwich bar, the Associated Press reported on Friday. The South Korean violinist Min-Jin Kym was eating at a sandwich shop outside Euston Station on Nov. 29 when she noticed that her black violin case - which contained a Stradivarius and two valuable bows - was missing, according to the police. The violin, made in 1696, is one of about 400 made by Stradivarius that are still known to exist. The police arrested and charged John Maughan, 26, and two teenagers on Wednesday. The names of the youths, 16 and 14 years old, were not included in news reports because of British law. Mr. Maughan is in custody and the two teenagers are free on bail. The instrument has not yet been recovered and an insurance company has offered a reward for information. Ms. Kym, who is 32, began playing the violin at 6, made her international debut with the Berlin Symphony Orchestra when she was 13 and has performed with other leading orchestras. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

9 P.M. (Showtime) NINE (2009) Daniel Day-Lewis, above, plays Guido Contini, a director with a creative block and way too many women, in Rob Marshall's adaptation of the musical, first staged in 1982 and revived in 2003, with songs by Maury Yeston and a screenplay by Michael Tolkin and Anthony Minghella. ''Occasionally a flicker of genuine style emerges from all this busy, gaudy fuss,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Mr. Day-Lewis does not overdo the Italian-ness, and the sardonic smile playing around his mouth may be a sign of what he thinks of it all,'' while Marion Cotillard ''attains a measure of wounded dignity as Louisa, Guido's former leading lady and much-betrayed wife.'' He added: ''None of the rest of Guido's ladies are so lucky. It must be said that 'Nine' is an impressive feat of casting, with a shocking number of Oscar winners and nominees assembled in the service of its dubious and incoherent cause.'' Among them: Judi Dench as Guido's costume designer and confidante; Penélope Cruz as his married mistress; Nicole Kidman as a Nordic actress; Sophia Loren as Guido's mother; Kate Hudson as a Vogue reporter; and Stacy Ferguson, a k a Fergie of the Black Eyed Peas, as a prostitute. (Mr. Marshall's 2002 adaptation of the musical ''Chicago,'' starring Catherine Zeta-Jones and Renée Zellweger, will be shown on Starz at 6 p.m.) 6:30 P.M. (Cinemax) FOUR CHRISTMASES (2008) Reese Witherspoon and Vince Vaughn star as Kate and Brad, an unmarried San Francisco couple who each Christmas invent a charity project as an excuse to take a hedonistic vacation and avoid festivities with their dysfunctional families. But when a news reporter points a camera their way just as their trip to Fiji is canceled, they have no choice but to make the rounds. Robert Duvall and Sissy Spacek play Brad's divorced parents; Mary Steenburgen and Jon Voight are Kate's. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that, in a break from holiday movie tradition, the film, ''briskly directed by Seth Gordon from a snappy, many-authored script, is refreshingly tart and lean, forgoing the usual schmaltz and syrup.''

GE Capital has provided mortgages in the country since 2002.

The Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1 have added a third partner to their jointly run annual Young Architects Program. The two museums will collaborate with MAXXI, the National Museum of the 21st Century Arts in Rome, in this year's competition to transform the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, for the summer. There will also be a separate installation at MAXXI in Rome. There are two juries, one in New York and one in Rome, and curatorial representatives from each organization sit on both and will choose the winning architects in February. MAXXI's finalists include three Italian firms - Raffaella De Simone and Valentina Mandalari of Palermo, Ghigos Ideas of Lissone and and stARTT of Rome. The others are Asif Khan of London and Langarita Navarro Arquitectos of Madrid.

Growing up, Cherie Zhang tended to eat dim sum for breakfast while her parents preferred rice with soup or noodles. Today, Ms. Zhang, 30, who lives in Shanghai, regularly gives her 2-year-old son bread or cake for breakfast. Baked goods are not a staple of a traditional Chinese diet, but they have been quickly catching on among China's urban middle class over the last 10 years.

I went on a photographic safari this season to discover Santa in New York. I started the day after Thanksgiving, with the Volunteers of America annual parade of Santas. It's a quizzical display of 40-plus Santas walking up Fifth Avenue as tourists look on that has been running for more than a century. The gawking continued Dec. 11 at SantaCon, which billed itself as a ''nondenominational, noncommercial, nonpolitical and nonsensical Santa Claus convention that occurs once a year for absolutely no reason'' (in 25 countries!). The sight of hundreds of Santas crowding the streets and bars before gathering at the fountain in Central Park was startling. There were costumes inspired by the Jack Skellington character of Tim Burton's ''Nightmare Before Christmas'' alongside a man in a pink outfit with a quote from ''A Christmas Story'': ''You'll shoot your eye out, kid.''
Customer satisfaction with credit unions is starting to decline, according to the results of a new study, and it may be because of all of the new customers looking for a better experience.

Thailand's film board has banned a movie about a transgender father struggling to raise two children, The Associated Press reported on Friday. The National Film Board ruled on Wednesday that the film, ''Insects in the Backyard,'' cannot be shown in Thailand because it contains scenes that are immoral and pornographic. The board objected to several scenes, including at least one that showed an explicit depiction of two men having sex, culture and film officials said. The film's director, Tanwarin Sukkhapisit, said the scenes were crucial to the story line and could not be cut. She said she plans to appeal the ban. Ms. Tanwarin, 37, said the movie was loosely based on her own life; she was born as a boy and began cross-dressing as a teenager.

We are in a season traditionally devoted to good will among people and to the renewal of hope in the face of hard times.  As we seek to realize these lofty ideals, one of our greatest challenges is overcoming bitterness and divisiveness.  We all struggle with the wrongs others have done to us as well as those we have done to others, and we recoil at the vast extent of injury humankind seems determined to inflict on itself.  How to keep hope alive?  Without a constructive answer to toxic anger, addictive cycles of revenge, and immobilizing guilt, we seem doomed to despair about chances for renewal.  One answer to this despair lies in forgiveness.

NEAR THE HEIGHT OF the 1980s merger boom, C. K. Prahalad and Gary Hamel sat down at Prahalad's home in Ann Arbor, Mich., to hash out a new theory of business success. The two men, both business-school professors, had already written about an idea they called strategic intent, which held that a company's aspirations mattered at least as much as its resources. The history of business, they pointed out, was in large part a history of Davids knocking off Goliaths, as Microsoft did to I.B.M., Wal-Mart did to Sears and Toyota did to Detroit. Their new theory added a twist. Not only was size overrated, but the combination of two companies that sold similar products -- then in vogue -- was overrated, too. Apple and Dell might both be computer companies, but they would make terrible partners because their expertise -- design in one case, logistics in the other -- differed so much. Companies instead tended to thrive when they focused on what they knew best, Hamel and Prahalad wrote. They called their idea ''core competence.''

As the week ended, the Dallas Stars were fighting Detroit for the top spot in the Western Conference, which was surprising because few observers considered Dallas a playoff team this season. But General Manager Joe Nieuwendyk has assembled a blue-collar team that over the last month has picked up 25 of a possible 32 points. Nieuwendyk has done so despite the financial problems of the owner Tom Hicks, which have forced the team to keep the payroll well below the salary cap.

Looking back at 2010, I can only wonder why, in an era when the unimaginable has become doable, have some tasks we had down become more complicated? Using the Facilities Why do increasing numbers of bathrooms have self-flushing toilets? Flushing is a skill that we master when we are potty trained and that we retain till we return to diapers. Do we need help during the intervening years? Who has not been drenched by a prematurely activated bowl mechanism that thinks you are finished (before you are) or has not been forced to stare at leavings while waiting for a slow flusher?

Graveside service on December 28 at 1pm at Wellwood Cemetery, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity.

An article on Dec. 12 about the little-known, remote ski area of Disentis, Switzerland, misstated the length of time it takes to reach the town by train from the region's airports. The train from Zurich's airport is about three hours, not five and a half, and the train from Geneva's airport is about five and a half hours, not six.

''This practice was a house-of-cards business model designed to hide billions in liabilities in the years before Lehman collapsed.''Andrew Cuomo, the New York attorney general, after filing a suit accusing the accounting firm Ernst & Young of helping Lehman Brothers mislead investors about its financial health. Ernst & Young denies the lawsuit's claims. ''They said they couldn't help.'' Sharon Bell, a California retiree who needs a loan modification to keep her home. Lawyers have refused to aid her because a law -- meant to keep homeowners from being swindled -- restricts how even honest lawyers who work on loans can be paid.

IT was (another) year of political upheaval: (another) governor ensnared in scandal; a Congressional fixture censured by his colleagues; two rising stars with legal troubles ousted from the State Legislature; and a new governor, son of an old governor, easily elected -- but only after a mad-as-hell man from Buffalo had his say. It was a year of upheaval, too, on Second Avenue (bottom left), where subway construction disrupted many businesses. And it was a year of upheaval, at least for trees, in Brooklyn, where a weekend storm knocked out power in March (opposite page, bottom right) and where two tornadoes struck in September.

WOLFE--Henry B.,retired dentist, died on Tuesday, December 21, 2010. He will be remembered with much love by his wife, Lita, his devoted children, Dr. Oliver (Lynn) and Vicki, his cherished grandchildren, Kate, Sam, Logan and Brooke. This lovely man will be greatly missed.

PAUL JASMIN'S photographs are rich with the potential of youth. His subjects, often young beautiful ''dreamers,'' as he calls them, plucked from the artistic and hipster sets of Los Angeles, pause for a languorous moment in his frame before the sturm and drang of success or failure, madness or mediocrity can touch them. His latest book, ''California Dreaming'' (Steidel, $60), is a portfolio of young people passing through; many of the subjects lived in or near his Koreatown apartment house and qualify as dreamers because, as Mr. Jasmin put it, ''If you don't have a dream at that age you're dead in the water.'' CHRIS WALLACE
International IN AFGHAN PROVINCE, INSURGENTS CHALLENGE TROOPS
Television Ginia Bellafante

The creative store windows on Fifth and Madison, many with an exotic travel theme, show no signs of recession. At Van Cleef & Arpels (Nos. 1 to 7), Douglas Little (6) framed Jules Verne's adventures in 19th-century silhouettes. Bergdorf Goodman's Fifth Avenue and 58th Street windows by David Hoey (8 to 12) are the jewel. At Saks, travel fantasies (13 to 15) include one-of-a-kind dresses. In Ralph Lauren's new mansion, windows drenched in Edwardian charm (16) recall the Sargent painting of the Boit daughters. Macy's (17) tells the ''Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus'' story. The Barneys food theme includes an 1870 bustle dress made from silver coffee bags (18). Lord & Taylor (19 and 20) has moving facades showing Christmas in different eras. Anthropologie has 10-foot-tall pine cones from burlap sacks (21). Perhaps the most glittering holiday sight on Fifth is the restored New York Public Library (22). At Calvin Klein on Madison (23), minimalists are in control. Outside Barneys, the holiday spirit was seen in the kindness of a gentleman (24), who paused to help a stranger with her coat. As intriguing as the windows was a menagerie of headgear topping the spectators (bottom).

An article on Dec. 12 about a trade show at baseball's winter meetings misstated, in some editions, the surname of the chief executive of Pocket Radar, a company that developed a radar gun the size of an iPhone that could revolutionize scouting and coaching. He is Steve Goody, not Woody.

KAZ--Nathaniel. March 9, 1917-December 13, 2010. Nathaniel Kaz lived and breathed art; it was the essence of his being and the power behind his great love of life. He defied trends and was steadfast in his beliefs. His sculpture is both original and timeless. In 1998 "Mother Earth," a 1935 marble sculpture created by Kaz when he was 18, was exhibited in "The Human Figure in Transition 1900-1945, American Sculpture from the Museum's Collection" at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City. He is one of the best known and respected American figurative sculptors of the 20th Century, with a lifetime of accolades and awards including, most recently in 2006, the National Sculpture Society's Gold Medal and Maurice B. Hexter Prize at the 73rd Annual Exhibition at the Quick Center for the Arts, Fairfield, CT and Brookgreen Gardens, SC. In the same year, he was awarded the Lifetime Achievement in Sculpture Award by Westchester County and the Sculptors' Guild at "The Sculpture Forum on the Plaza" exhibition in White Plains, NY. In addition to his prolific career as a sculptor, he was an instructor at the Art Students League for more than 50 years. He leaves a legacy of enduring work in stone, wood and bronze that is testament to his immortal spirit. Today, his art is well represented in countless private collections and museums both here and abroad. His commissioned works for public buildings, such as "Growth" on the facade of Public School #

IN THE LATE 1980S, if you were lying in bed one weekend morning, reading an article dedicated to the best rock 'n' roll albums of all time, toward the back, long past ''Born to Run,'' ''Highway 61 Revisited'' and ''Exile on Main Street,'' there were quieter masterpieces, maybe even one that a fairly dedicated participant in the age of record shops had never heard of, like Kate and Anna McGarrigle's self-titled 1976 debut. Part of the pleasure of hurrying off to buy and then play it was the special frisson that comes with listening to a great album that you sense a relatively small number of people know about; it feels more yours. This is especially true when the music is as intimate and vulnerable as the five songs Kate wrote for that album. She was not yet 30 when ''Kate and Anna McGarrigle'' was produced, but she described the stages of an unhappy marriage so vividly that they took on transcendent qualities; she seemed somehow to be thinking back across an entire life she had still to live. McGarrigle was making music out of her own youthful disappointments. In 1969, after studying engineering at McGill University, she left her home in Montreal for New York City to become, says her sister Anna, ''the character she wanted to be.'' She, Anna and a third sister, Jane, had spent most of their childhood in what Kate's son, Rufus Wainwright, calls ''a very odd, out of the way place'' -- the Quebec mountain village of St. Sauveur. Raised by older parents and schooled in choral masses by French Catholic nuns, Kate had a yesteryear quality even in girlhood. She learned traditional American ''heart songs'' out of a book she found around the house and taught herself to play banjo by plucking along with Appalachian string-band records. Displaced persons who left Europe after World War II also lived in St. Sauveur, some of them bohemians wearing berets, others with concentration-camp tattoos on their arms, and Anna says that because of them, Kate developed an outsider's sense that the heat of life was happening elsewhere. ''She saw herself as one of those people who had to move on, to get out,'' Anna says.

They may not be getting the headlines, but the Mavericks have become one of the hottest teams in the league, winning 16 of their last 17 to give them the second-best record (23-5) in the Western Conference. Dallas has been at its best against the league's elite. The Mavericks snapped the Spurs' 12-game winning streak when they won in San Antonio on Nov. 26, and they snapped the Heat's 12-game winning streak when they won in Miami last Monday. In fact, the Mavericks beat the Heat twice during their run and are the only team to beat Miami since late November. The Mavericks have been great on the road, going 10-1 this season, including a victory at Orlando last Tuesday.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

In the midst of the recession, designers could actually help their hard-hit businesses by focusing on e-commerce and social network connections. The ones who did that are looking pretty smart right now, because there are even more new ideas to try in 2011. Probably the most important accomplishment for Web-resistant designers was to recognize that their customers talk to one another online; they want girlfriend advice and they want designers to listen. As a result, many more designers this year began using Facebook and Twitter. Customers also want more access to a designer's world, and they want to be able to do that through their cellphones and tablets. ''Chanel launched an app and everyone panicked,'' said James Gardner, the co-founder and chief executive of Create the Group, a leading interactive agency. '' 'Oh, we need an app.' ''

FORTY-EIGHT DEGREES south latitude, 161 degrees east longitude. Picture Dodge Morgan, on Day 80 of a trip around the world, navigating his way through 50-foot waves in the southern Pacific Ocean, waves so high they left his boat corkscrewing its way back down at a stomach-turning angle. Exhausted, before going to sleep, he did what he did every night, unsealing a plastic bag that held papers inside. After a day of taking on the vastness of the ocean, he now confronted small, printed questions on a psychological exam, contemplating whether he agreed with statements like these: I seldom feel like hitting someone. I like my parents. I am the life of the party. Morgan was well situated for soul searching. Around him, there was no party and no life except for the churning underwater marine world all but hidden from view.

The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety revealed on Wednesday its picks for the safest vehicles of 2011. Sixty-six models -- including 40 cars, 25 sport utility vehicles and one minivan -- earned the Top Safety Pick award. Only 27 vehicles received that distinction last year after the Insurance Institute added a roof-strength parameter to its test criteria.

An article in some editions last Sunday about transplant experts and patients who questioned data that Arizona lawmakers used in deciding to cut some state-financed coverage of organ transplants omitted part of the name of the state's Medicaid program. It is the Arizona Health Care Cost Containment System, not the Arizona Health Care Containment System.

Cliches are best avoided, but when a Lamborghini Gallardo Spyder or a Bentley Continental GT is enlisted to ferry hot meals around town, the fast-food rejoinders naturally follow. On Monday, volunteers working with the Pascack Valley, N.J., chapter of Meals on Wheels were chauffeured to the homes of elderly people in cars provided by Gotham Dream Cars, an exotic-car rental company and club with locations in Englewood, N.J., and Miami. Event organizers hoped the partnership would raise public awareness of older people who are incapacitated or otherwise unable to leave their homes to buy food on their own.

''Hands down, he's the greatest modern-day caricaturist and one of the great artists of the last half-century,'' wrote Michael Kimmelman in The Times after David Levine died almost a year ago. And it's true: he was. As wonderful (and occasionally brutal) as his caricatures were, however, painting was David's truest passion. In 1958 he founded the Painting Group with the artist Aaron Shikler, and for more than 50 years it met every Wednesday evening to work from a live model. For the last 35 years, I was a member of the group. Watching David work was a revelation. He handled watercolors unlike anybody else. He liked to experiment and, as he put it, ''play.'' He would draw, redraw, ''schmeer,'' sponge out and paint again. It was not uncommon to see him rub out a work we'd been marveling over, saying, simply, ''I didn't get what I was going after.'' Three years ago, Levine's eyesight began to fade rapidly. He lost his ability to see the model, to draw those beautifully crosshatched caricatures for The New York Review of Books, to spend summer days painting the bathers at Coney Island. ''I always knew I was a degenerate,'' he said, ''but I didn't know it was macular.'' He still came to class every Wednesday and sat among us talking about Degas, Sargent and Daumier. After giving a precise critique, he always offered encouragement. ''Keep playing,'' he'd say.

IT'S easy to paint Alex Eylar as your typical nerd. He keeps a list of every movie he's seen since 2001 -- 1,627 films and counting. He has an annual pass to Disneyland. And, at 22, he has an enormous Lego collection (an estimated 30,000 pieces) that can't exactly help things with the ladies. But Mr. Eylar has found a way to merge his geeky pursuits (he's currently going for a master's degree in film at Chapman University) into an online art project that's turned him into something of a celebrity, at least on Flickr. That's where you'll find more than 20 of his carefully constructed Lego tableaus, each of which recreates famous movie scenes, like the 007 gun barrel sequence and the dream reverie in ''American Beauty,'' above. Go to flickr.com/photos/hoyvinmayvin. SARAH OWEN

''He goes along, pre-tends to be a gentleman,pretends to be accommo-dative, pretends to be seri-ously committed to thelaw, and turns around,sending people, beating uppeople, using violence tocoerce and to literally de-fend power for the sake ofdefending power.'' NEUBERGER--Roy Rothschild, 107, died peacefully at his home in New York City on December 24, 2010 of natural causes. He is survived by his daughter, Ann Neuberger Aceves and her partner James Sullivan, his sons, Roy Salant Neuberger and James Alfred Neuberger and their spouses Linda Villency Neuberger and Helen Stambler Neuberger, his grandchildren, Andrea London Zweigenbaum, Patricia London, Matthew London, Sarah Lancry, Yaffa Jungreis, Miriam Hess, Aharon Neuberger, and Nechama Slatus, all of their respective spouses, and thirty great-grandchildren. Roy was a truly remarkable person, beloved by many, who had an enormous impact both in the world of finance and art. His legacy will live on both through Neuberger Berman, the Neuberger Museum of Art, and the countless people whose lives he touched in so many ways. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue in New York City, on Sunday, December 26th at 1:15pm, with burial at Mount Neboh Cemetery in Queens. A Memorial Service will be held at a time to be announced. Shiva/Mourning will be observed at his home this Sunday, December 26th after 5pm and on Monday from 4 to 8pm, and will continue from Tuesday to Friday at the home of his son Roy Salant Neuberger.

ROBBINS--Joseph C.,92, passed away peacefully following a long illness on December 4th at his Roslyn Estates, New York home. Rhoda, his best friend and beloved wife of 68 years, was at his side. Joe was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. He was the last to survive of seven lifelong friends who were members of Sempitern Amicinovem Nine Everlasting Friends formed by the boys when they were six years old. He attended the United States Military Academy at West Point and New York University, where he was awarded his BS degree in 1939 and received his MBA in 1940. He was cited for academic excellence, having graduated second in his class. It was at NYU that he met his future wife who also received her MBA. He was particularly proud of his service during WWII, having served in the Army Engineer Corps in the European theater from 1942 to 1946. He landed with the first wave on Utah Beach during the Normandy Invasion on D-Day, and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. He was awarded, among other medals, the Legion of Merit, two Conspicuous Service Crosses, two Bronze Stars and Bronze Arrowheads. He retired from the army as a Lt. Colonel. In 1947, while teaching at NYU's business school, now known as the Stern School of Business, he founded Centre Lumber & Plywood Co., a distributor of hardwood plywood serving the millwork industry. He was President of the company for almost 60 years, continuing to be active in the business through his mid 80's. He was supportive of a number of charitable organizations, but was particularly devoted to various veterans groups. He was an avid golfer and an active member of Glen Head CC where he served as president, Delaire CC and Glen Oaks Club. He was also a member of the Friars Club. He loved travel, museums, chess, reading and drawing. He was everyone's favorite companion at cocktails, dinner and sporting events of all kinds. He was truly grateful for everyday of his life, and was devoted to his family, friends and country. He will be sorely missed. In addition to his wife, Rhoda, he is survived by his daughters, Elizabeth R. Davidson and Susan L. Robbins, sons-in-law William C. Davidson and Jonathan L. Koslow and grandchildren, Lauren, Stephen and Allison. He was interred with military honors following a private service on Long Island. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to a veterans' organization of your choice.

9 P.M. (13, 49) FRAMED The eccentric residents of an offbeat Welsh village discover that the National Gallery in London is storing its art collection, including priceless Leonardos, Raphaels and Donatellos, in a nearby mine while the museum is renovated, leading to some strange encounters between a local schoolteacher (Eve Myles) and a forlorn curator (Trevor Eve). He thinks of art in terms of composition, genre and genius; she believes that art is nothing without people to appreciate it -- and perhaps have their lives changed in the process. David Tennant hosts this ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' production based on the children's novel about art, life and Ninja Turtles by Frank Cottrell Boyce. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOURIn a tribute to members of the United States military and their families, Bob Woodruff looks at the growing number of veterans who find themselves homeless after returning from Iraq and Afghanistan. Ms. Amanpour interviews Gen. Peter W. Chiarelli, the vice chief of staff of the Army, about the longterm consequences of repeated deployments. And David Rohde, a reporter for The New York Times, and his wife, Kristen Mulvihill, discuss their new book, ''A Rope and a Prayer,'' which traces the couple's ordeal after Mr. Rohde was kidnapped in November 2008 by members of the Taliban in Afghanistan and held hostage for seven months before escaping.

Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 26, 2010 at 12:00pm noon at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Avenue, Scarsdale, NY followed by a graveside service at Westchester Hills Cemetery at 400 Saw Mill River Road in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. THE WORLD COULD be so cockaludicrous, so full of snools and dickspeakers. Everybody was losing their gynergy. For Mary Daly, this was the biggest problem. She didn't blame men individually for the woes of modern life -- violence, pollution, inequity -- but collectively, institutionally, they were at fault. She held their power against them. She had names for what she was fighting. ''Phallocracy, penocracy, jockocracy, cockocracy -- call it whatever,'' Daly said. In 1987, with a co-author, she published her own dictionary -- seventh in a line of nine books she wrote -- meant to spell out a new lexicon for women, a more precise way of articulating both her rage and her vision for a world in which women shook themselves free of all forms of patriarchy. Anyone who didn't bother to question male dominance was a snool; anyone who promoted it, a dickspeaker. If you were a man, you stood little chance of winning over Mary Daly.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel finds treasures just beyond Boston during daytrips to Lexington, Concord and Salem.

WHERE do you go when you've already opened some of the best bars in the world? For Romée de Goriainoff, Olivier Bon and Pierre-Charles Cros, the founders behind a triumvirate of Parisian cocktail lounges, the answer is London. They've recently replicated their original venture, the Experimental Cocktail Club, on the streets of Chinatown. Since the bar opened on Dec. 1, London's spirit-chasers have come out in full force despite the city's blizzardlike conditions. The cozy bricked interior designed by Dorothée Meilichzon is obviously nice. But it's the booze itself, like the 1930s rye that tops off the bar's Vieux Carré, or the cigar-infused bourbon drink called the Havana, or the shiso-infused vodka with goji liqueur and poppy seeds, that has London Town lit. ECC Chinatown, 13A Gerrard Street, London; 011-44-20-7434-3559. JILL SINGER

WAITING TO BOARD a flight from Columbus, Ohio, to Washington in January 1991, the former Representative Donald Lukens hid in a toilet stall in the men's room to escape reporters and photographers. It was a testament to his fighting spirit that Lukens believed he still had dignity to protect. Buz Lukens first arrived in Washington three decades earlier. A handsome and energetic former Air Force officer, Lukens became chairman of the capital's Young Republicans. With much of Washington and the world in thrall to liberal Camelot, Lukens plotted its overthrow.

Getting around the more than 60 islands that make up the British Virgin Islands usually involves a boat rather than an airplane. But with the recent reopening of Virgin Gorda International Airport, travel options have expanded in time for the high season. The single airstrip was closed for 11 months to regrade and widen it to meet safety regulations. This month, the airport reopened to charter lines including Fly BVI (bviaircharters.com) and Island Birds (islandbirds.com), though the island still lacks a commercial carrier.

THEY WERE A COUPLE of Tennessee boys -- one from Nashville, one from Memphis -- who surfaced within a year of each other, and before they were done, they affected the lives of just about anyone who has given a whit about pop music since the mid-'60s. One built his audience with a clear-and-hold (some would say catch-and-release) musical strategy that spanned decades and musical incarnations. The other did it with exactly one song. Bobby Hebb was the singer and composer of ''Sunny.'' One of the all-time summer top-down spins, it raced up the charts in 1966 even as it had no precise musical destination. It was too jazz to be pop, too pop to be soul, too soul to be country, too country to be rock, too rock to be jazz and back round again. It was one of those rare songs that by serving no one musical god, served them all. And its back story was almost as compelling as the song itself.

IN 1956, VISITING the Cedar Tavern in Greenwich Village with the specific purpose of meeting Jackson Pollock, a 26-year-old Elizabeth Taylor look-alike witnessed the entrance of the artistic genius, by then 44 and bloated with booze, and marveled at ''an electric current'' that ''seemed to float through the dingy bar.'' She called him there a week later (it was his home away from home) and arranged a meeting. An ardent love affair began. At its height, he took her to his house on Long Island and told her he wanted to live with her and leave his wife, the artist Lee Krasner. Meanwhile, he was drinking prodigiously and dissolving frequently into pools of sentimental self-loathing. She felt she had the power to rescue him, but she was wrong. The story ended violently on a fateful summer night, when the great painter, sodden with gin, gunned the accelerator of his car, veered off the road and smashed into a tree. They were both thrown from the automobile. He died. She survived. But for the young woman, Ruth Kligman, that story never really ended. Her supporting role in the death of Pollock would define the remaining half century of her life. ''Death Car Girl,'' the poet Frank O'Hara indelibly called her. Other sobriquets were even less flattering. ''Miss Grand Concourse,'' sneered the painter Franz Kline, who had a brief affair with her after the accident. Only a year after Pollock's death, Willem de Kooning began a tempestuous four-year relationship with Kligman. ''She really puts lead in my pencil,'' he said. He named a brightly colored painting with especially sensuous brushwork ''Ruth's Zowie,'' because ''Zowie!'' is what she exclaimed upon seeing it for the first time. The artists' friends remarked that even after Pollock's death, de Kooning was continuing the rivalry.

PARADIS--Donald E. 86, died peacefully in Washington, DC on November 28. Born in a small mill town in Rhode Island, he served in a remarkable career as an attorney for the United States Marshall Plan in Paris, as Chief Advisor to the Imperial Government of Ethiopia from 1957-1968, as a lawyer in New York and London, and as an international arbitrator. Graduate of Wesleyan University (1943) and Harvard Law School (1950), he commanded minecraft in the Pacific in WWII. Predeceased by loving wife of 49 years Elizabeth Reid and daughter Nancy. Survivors include daughter Martha, son Tim, son-in-law Bob Evans, grandchildren Alex and Rebecca, his beloved companion Teresa deGavre, and numerous nieces and nephews. Donations in his honor may be made to Moffitt Cancer Center of Tampa, FL to the Nancy Paradis Memorial Fund.

THE FOX BEGAN lurking outside Lucille Clifton's home when the poet was in her 50s. It sat on the lawn, its red coat and lush tail illuminated by a porch light. Though she knew it was harmless, the animal frightened her, Clifton's friend and fellow poet Anne Caston remembered. ''Lucille would kind of crouch behind me as we went up to her door,'' Caston said. ''Or she would call me. She would be checking out her window and say, 'Anne, that fox is out there, sitting in my yard, staring at my door -- what do you think she wants?' '' Clifton, whose lean poetry won an abundance of honors, among them the National Book Award and a Frost Medal, is best known for writing compressed anthems about race and womanhood. The African-American daughter of parents whose classroom education ended in elementary school, she wrote many poems that can be traced back to a moment of extreme surrender. As a child in Buffalo, she watched her mother, a self-taught poet, burn the verses she wrote after Clifton's father, a steelworker, forbade her to publish them. ''The smell of that burning paper always stayed with me,'' Clifton told her youngest child, Alexia. And in her 1993 poem''fury,'' Clifton wrote: ''remember this./she is standing by/the furnace . . . ./her hand is clutching/a sheaf of papers . . . ./her eyes are animals./each hank of her hair/is a serpent's obedient/wife.'' Clifton's mother's verses were formal; Clifton's own poetry, which she began publishing in 1969, was spirited and fierce and sculptured to feel raw. In it, she elicited pride and paid tribute: to Malcolm X and the Native-American warrior Crazy Horse, to deltas of menstrual blood and to the seductive powers of a woman's ample hips.

AS SOON AS HIS head hit the gym wall, Allan Tibbels knew his arms and legs would never work again. He was 26 -- a bearded, rangy, Christian youth worker with passions for rock music, pickup basketball and tales of religious sacrifice. Avid about whatever he pursued, Eagle Scouts or drugs, he was busted in high school for smoking weed but never doubted that Jesus loved him. He liked the troubled youth of suburban Baltimore, having been one, and they liked him. In his biblical readings, he was focused on Job, which may have steadied him for the trials he would face as a quadriplegic. Uncapping the toothpaste was such an advance that his wife, Susan, would mark the event in the family scrapbook. In the months after his freak accident (he tripped driving to the basket), Tibbels wasn't immune to despair -- just determined to push past it. ''Breaking my neck is God's will for my life,'' he wrote from the hospital. He bought a wheelchair and returned to youth work, from a home with lots of ramps. A few years later, Tibbels startled Susan by insisting they move to the ghetto. Along with his friend Mark Gornik, he had been reading John M. Perkins, an evangelist and civil rights worker in Mississippi who urged the privileged to live with the poor. Christ came down from heaven; Jesus was no commuter! Susan was once the Ivory soap girl of the Christian youth set, destined for suburban contentment. She understood the theory -- God dwells among the poor -- but she had two young daughters, a disabled husband and a terror of rats. She followed under howling protest, to a neighborhood called Sandtown. Baltimore's crack-addled streets in the mid-1980s were as mean as any, and there was hardly another white person for miles. Those who did not assume Tibbels was a cop thought he was buying drugs. When a robber held a knife to his throat, he invited him to church.

The Atlanta Thrashers, who are battling Tampa Bay and Washington for the top spot in the Southeast Division despite having the lowest payroll in the league, have been another surprise team in the season's first half. Fortified by players they received from the Devils last season for Ilya Kovalchuk and by off-season trades that brought in members of the champion Chicago Blackhawks -- including Dustin Byfuglien, the league's top scorer among defensemen, and Andrew Ladd, who became the team captain -- Atlanta accumulated 26 of a possible 32 points from mid-November until mid-December.

''They need to wake up and eat some breakfast,'' the fan told the paper. ''I'm just trying to help them out with a balanced diet.''

LUDWIG WITTGENSTEIN once said that in philosophy, it is hard to work as slowly as you should. When the British philosopher Philippa Foot finally published ''Natural Goodness,'' her first and only book-length statement of her thinking, at age 80 in 2001, an editor at Oxford University Press recalled Wittgenstein's challenge. ''Well,'' he said, ''that is a problem that Philippa seems to have solved.'' Foot's philosophical voyage, her ''painfully slow journey,'' as she put it, was long in part because it was uphill. Though born into a family of privilege -- her father was a wealthy British industrialist, her mother a daughter of the U.S. president Grover Cleveland -- she was given no formal education (''I was extremely ignorant,'' she later said) and, being a woman, was not expected to go to college. Spurred on, however, by a governess who recognized her intelligence, Foot educated herself via correspondence courses and eventually attended Somerville College at Oxford. There, in the clubby, masculine atmosphere of high British learning, she cultivated friendships with a group of young female philosophers, among them Elizabeth Anscombe, who would become a prized student and editor of Wittgenstein's, and Iris Murdoch, the future novelist. (Philippa would marry one of Murdoch's former boyfriends, the historian M.R.D. Foot.)

WITH ALL THE terrible images we have accumulated of Afghanistan -- killing and drugs and corruption and cruelty to women -- most people might wonder why the country cast such a spell on generations of travelers, adventurers, aid workers and seekers. When asked to explain themselves back home, these enchanted wanderers usually stutter something inadequate like ''Oh, the mountains'' or ''The people, they're so hospitable and proud.'' And as their friends and families listen skeptically, they will be busy devising a way to go back. Karen Woo was one of them, a young English doctor who went to Afghanistan in 2009 to visit her boyfriend, who was working there. They broke up; but Karen was smitten by the Afghans. In the week she was there, she visited a charity for street children and toured hospitals. She was appalled by the desperate need and wanted to help.

THEY MET BACKSTAGE at a 1972 Renaissance-themed Sid and Marty Krofft television special (Ricky Nelson as a betighted troubadour; Mickey Rooney as head torturer; Howard Cosell, Cyd Charisse, Ann Sothern, Yma Sumac, Billy Barty and plenty of nightmarish puppets). Lorene Yarnell was a dancer in the wimpled chorus line, Robert Shields the silent jester who opened the program. She was seven years older than he was and divorced, and she had been dancing on television variety shows for years, had been in the films ''Sweet Charity'' and ''Bye-Bye Birdie.'' He was a street performer who had begun as Robbie the Mechanical Man in a traveling sideshow in Canada before being invited to study with Marcel Marceau. She taught him to dance; he taught her to mime. ''It was destiny,'' she would say later. The nonmime woman who falls in love with a mime man may be forgiven for a hesitancy to convert, but she did. She followed him to San Francisco, where they worked separately, she in Ghirardelli Square and he in Union, before performing together. They were married the same year, in the way of his people: a pantomimed ceremony in Union Square. The bride wore whiteface and a bandleader's uniform. So did the groom.
Theater Steven McElroy

Devoted Grandfather of Alex, Zack and Ross Solomon, Brad, Kyle, and Meredith Doppelt, Pamela and Grant Siegel. His love will remain in our hearts always. May his spirit soar. Services and burial are private. Buddy, we'll be looking at the moon, but we'll be seeing you.

HERE IS A mathematician's nightmare I heard in the 1980s when that irritating, unconforming, self-regarding provocateur Benoît Mandelbrot was suddenly famous -- fractals, fractals everywhere. The mathematician dreamed that Mandelbrot died, and God spoke: ''You know, there really was something to that Mandelbrot.'' Sure enough.

USDAN--Melvin, February 22, 1920-December 21, 2010. He had two brothers, Sonny and the late Jerome with whom he shared The Perfect Thread Co. Mel was an inventor in the textile business. He was devoted to his three sisters, Francis, "Duddie" and the late Evelyn. Mel was married for 50 years to Beverly who pre-deceased him. He was a loving father to Dennis and Wind and to Dennis' wife Carole. His grandson Jordan and wife Rachel filled his heart with joy. His adored companion has been Lucille Frand. He leaves behind Deni, Ricki and Nina, and their families. Services Monday December 27, 11am at I.J. Morris Funeral Directors, West Palm Beach, FL 1-800-947-4256.

ACCORDING TO THE going wisdom, the hordes of teenage boys (myself among them) who made the mid-'60s TV series ''I Spy'' such a success were drawn, first and foremost, by the groundbreaking biracial casting. We tuned in to watch the young Bill Cosby banter with his white counterpart, Robert Culp, while the two of them, spies disguised as a tennis pro and his trainer, cracked cases in exotic locales. The going wisdom is not wrong, but goes only so far. Cosby brought a hip new black persona into the white wasteland of '60s TV; the trade-off was that he had to assume the mantle of an Eagle Scout. A Rhodes scholar and master of languages, his character, Alexander Scott, was also a teetotaler, and when the beautiful girls showed up in the hotel room he shared with Kelly Robinson (Culp), he typically made a quick exit. (''You don't mind my going out and leaving you alone with Tia?'') The show was clear about how the spoils were to be divided. While Culp complimented Cosby on ''the wonderfulness of your mind,'' Cosby's rejoinder to Culp was a homage to ''the wonderfulness of your charm.'' Culp's ''charm'' was something peculiar to the mid-'60s, and the dirty little secret of teenage white boys like myself was that, progressivism and Cosby's wit aside, we really watched the show because of what Culp had to teach us about how masculinity was changing. The movies of the mid-'60s oversaw the rise of a number of not very good-looking, and previously barely noticed, supporting actors -- Lee Marvin and James Coburn prominent among them. It was their non-Eagle Scout attitude, combined with an air of sexual entitlement, that made them stars in an age being resculptured by the combined forces of Johnny Carson, Hugh Hefner, James Bond and the new sexual freedom made possible by the availability of the pill. No one could ever call Robert Culp bad-looking, but his looks had an off-centeredness perfect for the time. He was a more louche Robert Redford, with a dash of the smarmy, ''Of course you'll go to bed with me'' attitude of the singer Jack Jones. That loucheness, that smarm were qualities boys wanted in male stars in 1965. When Frank Sinatra and Rock Hudson played playboys in the '50s and early '60s, there was always a catch: Debbie Reynolds or Doris Day waiting to corral them to the altar.

BORN INTO A FAMILY of regal thespians, the youngest of three children, she was the tall, chubby, slightly awkward girl who loved her nanny and her chestnut pony, Rosalinda. Lynn Redgrave may never have been quite the hapless ugly duckling she would play in the era-defining 1966 movie ''Georgy Girl,'' but she was a lonely, sickly child, forever afraid of her ''perfectionist'' father, Sir Michael Redgrave (who failed to note her birth in his long diary entry for March 8, 1943), and dazzled by her good-looking and self-possessed siblings, Vanessa and Corin. In one of the childhood games they played together, Lynn recalled in her memoir-cum-diet-book, ''This Is Living,'' Vanessa was president of the United States, Corin was prime minister of England and Lynn had to make do with impersonating the royal dog. Named for the actress Lynn Fontanne, Redgrave was exposed to the excitement of the theater as a child, taking in the works of Shakespeare as performed by her parents in revolving repertory. Despite her habitual shyness and bad posture -- and despite receiving little parental encouragement -- she conceived the idea of following in her parents' and siblings' footsteps while still in her teens after seeing Peter Hall's production of ''Twelfth Night'' no less than 17 times. ''Shakespeare's immaculate play of mistaken identity transformed me,'' she wrote. ''I thought if I could only step into that magic world for a few hours a day, become someone else, take on her looks, her voice, her thoughts, her passions, then I could not only become a great actress. I could also escape from me, the me that I couldn't abide. I could be a butterfly, emerging from my caterpillar's cocoon.''
