He was a member of Queens Community Bd 8 and his local Democratic Club. He and the late Miriam Easton were charter members of Queens Ethical Culture Society. Survived by daughters, Suzanne Michelle, of Dobbs Ferry, NY and Elizabeth (Lisa), of Barcelona; son-in-law Philip Jones, grandson, Sushil; and long-time companion, Renee Nelson. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Center of Excellence on Brain Aging, 145 E. 32nd St, 5th Fl, New York 10016; or Ethical Humanist Society of Queens, 73-12 35th Ave, D55 Jackson Hts, NY 11372.

She is survived by her three children: Pamela Franzheim Forrestal, Sabrina Franzheim Fleming and Daniel Dror, II; her grandchildren: Sass Allen, Whitney Tower III, Pandora Forrestal, Jared Forrestal, Phoenix Melita Fleming and Atticus Mungo Fleming; one sister, Doris Tansey Lausten and nieces, Donnamarie Saultz and nephew, Joseph Tansey. A patron of the arts to end, she was a woman truly devoted to studying, appreciating and recognizing beauty and passion in the world. Lewis & Sons to obtain specific details regarding the February service in Houston.

SHE WAS SCHOOLED to build a nuclear bomb. As a sophomore at Bennington College, Joan Hinton -- a physics major, a violinist and a champion slalom skier who shunned high heels, lipstick and her mother's attempt to make her ''graceful'' by sending her to dance school -- built her first cloud chamber to detect subatomic particles. A few years later, after colleagues from her physics grad program disappeared one by one for secret locations, it was her turn: it was 1944, and she was 22 when she joined the Manhattan Project. By day, in a canyon in Los Alamos, N.M., she and a team of scientists built reactors to test enriched uranium and plutonium. By night, she played in a quartet with the physicists Edward Teller and Otto Frisch.

BY 1982, conservatives emboldened by Ronald Reagan's election were looking to drive ideological dissenters from the Republican ranks. Their top target was Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the blustery Connecticut senator who was an acid critic of Reagan and his vice president, George H. W. Bush. (The normally charitable Reagan referred to Weicker, in his diaries, as a ''pompous, no good fathead.'') A group of Washington consultants went searching for a candidate who might take on Weicker in a primary, someone who could both raise cash and symbolize loyalty to the new administration. They settled on the perfect man: Prescott Bush Jr., the vice president's older brother. Those close to Pres Bush never would have pegged him for a politician, or at least not beyond the Greenwich scene where he dabbled for years. He preceded George to Yale, but the lack of vision in one eye -- a birth defect -- kept him from excelling on the ball field or fighting overseas as his brother did, and Pres didn't seem to have the same swagger or ambition. You would think these differences would have given rise to some resentment at watching his younger brother soar into national politics while Pres did quiet and respectable work as an insurance man. But if Pres lugged around any of that baggage, he kept it hidden. He seemed, instead, to revel in family, spending off-hours with his wife and three children and working tirelessly for his brother George, whom he adored, and his father, whose Senate campaigns Pres helped run in the 1950s.

I lived about half a mile from George in Bay Village [Ohio]. We really knew each other in the elementary years, fifth and sixth grade, in the 1930s. . . . In elementary school, he was the one with the white shirt and a tie. The rest of us were in knickers. -- IKE GANYARD (Childhood friend) George is directly responsible for my owning the Bulls. He was a minority owner of the team. We were having dinner in New York one night in the summer of '84. He was complaining about what a bad investment it was and about how he was tired of having to write checks every year to cover losses. I told him that his partners who were running the thing didn't know what they were doing and that I'd love to own the Bulls. A week later, I got a call from one of his partners asking me if I was serious and saying he wanted to get out. At that time, they had drafted [Michael] Jordan, but he hadn't played yet, so they really didn't know what they had. Whenever I was with George and a group of people after that, he'd say, ''This is the guy who screwed me out of the Bulls.'' -- JERRY REINSDORF (Owner, Chicago White Sox, 1981-present, and Chicago Bulls, 1985-present)

LITTMAN--Allan N.,a determined and superb trial lawyer, an accomplished writer on the law, and a beloved husband, father and grandfather, died of cancer on December 20, 2010, at his home in Marin County, California. He was 81 and actively practiced law until his death. Born in England in 1929, Mr. Littman was evacuated with his mother and siblings to New York during World War II. After graduating from public high school, he returned to England to take his BA with first class honors from University College, University of London in 1949. Mr. Littman studied law at Harvard, where he met his wife Caroline. In April of 1951 they were married and the next year he graduated cum laude from Harvard Law School. Hired by Pillsbury, Madison & Sutro of San Francisco, he practiced with the firm for 42 years, leading his own litigation group. He tried many cases for motion picture companies, International Harvester, Potlatch Corporation, United Parcel Service and others. He was also special trial counsel to the California State Board of Accountancy and the chief trial counsel for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of San Francisco in its investigation of what later became the Lincoln Savings & Loan Corporation/ Charles Keating scandal. Mr. Littman joined BartkoZankel as counsel in 2002 where he worked in major commercial litigation, including a leading California court decision against Price Waterhouse that confirmed the right of all parties to a jury trial regardless of pre-dispute waivers. An expert in litigation involving accountants, Mr. Littman recently published the book The Fraud Triangle, detailing the century-long breaches by auditors of their public trust to detect and expose fraud that played a key role in the nation's recent financial crisis. Active in community affairs and professional associations, Mr. Littman was a Trustee of the Bancroft Library, a key fundraiser for the building of the Belvedere-Tiburon library, and a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Caroline; his sons Jeremy, Jonathan and Peter, and their wives, Tajali, Sherry and Barbara; and his adoring grandchildren, Alex, Elizabeth, Jesse, Katherine, Nicholas and Sam, and his step-grandchildren Isaac and Felicia, and son-in-law, Anton. This fall he was deeply saddened by the loss of his daughter Victoria. He was an intellectual gentleman with ecumenical interests and impeccable style, who fiercely questioned assertions and half-truths. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and professional colleagues.

As if there were a need for more evidence of the hole created by LeBron James's departure from Cleveland beyond the team's 8-21 record, there is the effect on dollars from ticket receipts - not for the Cavaliers but for their opponents. One year after trailing only the Los Angeles Lakers in road attendance at an average of 19,200 a game, the Cavaliers have fallen to 14,410, by far the lowest in the league, before Saturday's games.

IT WAS THE call I dreaded most. Hours after an Afghan colleague and I escaped from Taliban captivity last year, an American diplomat told me that Richard Holbrooke was demanding to speak with me. I expected him to be fuming, because it was the second time my being captured had exacerbated the already complex challenges he faced. For the previous 14 years, the boisterous and at times overbearing legend of American diplomacy had been ribbing me for complicating the Dayton peace talks to end the war in Bosnia. I was a hostage then too. Now it had happened in South Asia, an even more complex place to wrest peace than the Balkans. Back in 1995, Holbrooke browbeat President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia into releasing me after Serbian forces arrested me at a mass grave I discovered near the town of Srebrenica, site of the massacre of 8,000 Bosnian Muslims. My editors and family later regaled me with stories of how Holbrooke and his wife, the journalist Kati Marton, rattled Serbian officials during the peace talks. In one meeting, Holbrooke picked up the Bosnian Serb vice president's wool plaid fedora and intimidated him. ''Maybe I can hold your hat hostage,'' Holbrooke said. He told Milosevic that the peace talks would be halted until my release. Days later, I was freed.

THORNE--Ann Cobb, died December 9, her 68th wedding anniversary, at Geer Village, Canaan, CT, surrounded by her family. Born August 16, 1922, in Hewlett, NY, she was educated at the Lawrence School, Milton Academy, Milton, MA, and Bennington College, VT. On December 9, 1942 she married Francis Burritt Thorne, Jr., whom she met at age 14. After World War II, they lived in Bay Shore, NY, then in New York City, where she chaired the Heart Fund and served on the committees of the Boys Club of New York and the Film Society, which rated films for children. From 1958-1964, the family lived in Florence, Italy. A painter and photographer, she exhibited her work on behalf of the Unites States Information Service and at the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto-and, back in New York, in the city, Palm Beach, Minneapolis and at the Boston Athenaeum. Recovered from alcoholism, in 1976 she co-founded and served for over 30 years as a board member of Freedom Institute, a not-for-profit resource center for individuals and families affected by alcohol and drug dependency. An active member of the Colony Club, she served on its board and Literature & Arts and Library Committees, initiating a series of conversations with authors and editors. She is survived by her husband; daughters Bo Niles, Wendy Forsyth, and Candace Canton; four grandsons; and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10022.

Sometimes a glance at properties for sale in a given week reveals a lot more than prices in the ever-changing - or not-changing-fast-enough - New York real estate market. The history of three town houses on the market winds through the worlds of poetry and the Harlem Renaissance; art and Norman Rockwell; and genteel old Murray Hill, where a polo champion called Lawrence Waterbury once lived.

FEAR IS A GREAT motivator. For Jimmy Dean, it was the constant suck of poverty that drove him to become one of the first multihyphenates, a popular entertainer who put his name on a product so successful that it eclipsed his earlier accomplishments. Until his death in front of the television on his 225-acre Virginia estate, the high-school dropout worried that he could end up back on the farm in Plainview, Tex., where he wore shirts made out of sugar sacks. His mother ran a barbershop out of their home to make money. Every fall he and his grandfather made sausage in a washtub from one of their hogs and put it in jars so they could have meat in winter. As he told Esquire, ''When I was a kid, I thought, Man, if I could ever afford all the ice cream I want to eat, that's as rich as I want to be.''

SIMON--Leonard S. The Board and Staff of Volunteers In Medicine-Berkshires mourn with great sadness the untimely passing of our founder, friend and colleague on December 24, 2010. We join with our volunteers and patients to offer our most heartfelt condolences to his wife, Marion, sons Andrew and Jon and their families. Leonard's vision, leadership, passion, dedication and generosity have been instrumental in bringing free health care services to those without insurance or the ability to pay. His legacy will serve as an inspiration to all of us to continue his endeavors. Arthur M. Peisner, Chairman Board of Trustees Volunteers In Medicine- Berkshires

The newest amenity at the four-month-old W New York in downtown Manhattan (123 Washington Street; 646-826-8600) might also be the coolest -- literally. Through Feb. 15, the wraparound outdoor terrace on the fifth floor has been transformed into an ice-skating rink, complete with a corner ice bar. The 12-foot-by-40-foot rink holds up to 20 people, said the general manager, Sofia Vandaele, and will have a manager on hand to make sure it doesn't get overcrowded. The rink's surface is actually synthetic hybrid-ice panels, which means that it doesn't need refrigeration units, generators or electricity, and is made with a recyclable polymer compound.

I have a $1,500 flight credit with Continental that I need to use, and I'm planning a 9- or 10-day trip sometime in January or February, but I don't have my heart set on a destination. My only stipulations are that the destination be reasonably inexpensive (looking to spend around $100 to $150 a day) and reasonably safe for a 24-year-old female solo traveler. I've traveled solo to Indonesia, Jordan, Syria and Tanzania. Any ideas would be greatly appreciated. Lydia B., New York A.Why not use your $1,500 flight credit to explore Delhi and Rajasthan in India? A recent online search found round-trip, flights to New Delhi in January, starting at $1,137 on Continental. In an e-mail, Kabir Chibber, a contributor to the Travel section, including ''36 Hours in Rajasthan'' (Nov. 22, 2009), agreed. Mr. Chibber suggested staying in Delhi for two or three days to take in sites like the 17th-century Red Fort and Jama Masjid mosque (above) in Old Delhi. He added that the city has a brand new subway, which is clean and safe. But avoid walking around alone at night, he said. Delhi is a sprawling city, so it is easy to get lost; stay central and avoid buses.

GOLDBERG--Leslie Daniel, of North Salem, NY passed away on December 22, 2010 after a sudden illness. He was 67 years old. Les is survived by his daughter Elizabeth DeRose and her husband Christopher of Ann Arbor, MI; his son Andrew Goldberg and his wife Kim of New York, NY; his grandchildren, Madeline and Evan DeRose and Alexa and Benjamin Goldberg; and his sister Gloria Shaffer and her husband Richard of New York, NY. Les was born in New York, NY on January 28, 1943 as the youngest child of Mauri and Edythe Goldberg. He graduated from New York University in 1964, and was a proud member of Phi Sigma Delta fraternity where he made many life-long friends. Les began his career at WVOX Radio in New Rochelle, NY in 1964. He transitioned into the radio advertising rep industry at Peggy Stone and Associates later that year. He then worked for McGavren-Guild Radio starting in 1968 and became manager of the Detroit office. In 1974 Les was promoted to Executive Vice President to lead McGavren-Guild's West coast office in Los Angeles. In 1986 Les was named President and COO of Interep Radio in New York, parent company of McGavren-Guild Radio. Les was a pillar of the radio advertising community and had a successful career that spanned nearly four decades. He served as a board member to many organizations, including: The Radio Advertising Bureau, The National Association of Broadcasters, The Southern California Broadcasters Association, The Broadcasters Foundation and The Bayliss Foundation. He was also a Past Chairman of the Radio Mercury Awards. Les retired from the McGavren-Guild/Interep family in 2005. While many in the radio advertising industry will recall Les as a passionate, dedicated and principled leader, he will be better remembered as a wonderful friend and mentor, and in particular a devoted father, grandfather, brother and uncle. His passion for Native American art led him to become a strong supporter of Native American museums and foundations. His friendly and upbeat personality and wonderful sense of humor will be greatly missed. A memorial service is being planned for late January. Donations in Les' honor can be made to either The Hopi Foundation (www.hopifoundation.org) or The Broadcasters Foundation (www.broadcastersfoundation.org).

FIXES Historically, homeless people had to be deemed ''housing ready'' -- typically drug- and alcohol-free -- before they could become eligible for permanent housing. In reality, this screened out most of the chronically homeless. In the early 1990s, a group called Pathways to Housing pioneered an approach called ''housing first'' that showed that permanent housing was, in fact, the first thing people needed to stabilize their lives. Today, it has been adopted as government policy. But even as a solution to chronic homelessness is within sight, housing agencies, and other groups, need to change the way they work to implement it. Even when housing is available, public systems remain slow, complicated and confusing, and disconnected from the streets. They don't focus on the neediest people.

Angela Christiano, an associate professor of dermatology and genetics at Columbia University Medical Center, studies the genetics of alopecia areata, a condition that causes sudden hair loss. NEUBERGER--Roy R. The Board and staff of the Neuberger Museum of Art, and the faculty, staff, and students of the Purchase College SUNY community will miss Roy R. Neuberger - our gregarious supportive friend; visionary museum founder; humanist; activist promoter of the as-yet unsung talented artist; brilliant passionate collector; enthusiastic educator to those of all ages; and generous patron. A fighter in the court room and a fighter until the end, he is survived by his bride of 51 years, Mary Jane, son Thomas, daughters Christine, Susan and Kathleen and their husbands, brother Richard, and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations to help children with cancer, Manitos (manitosparaguay.com) would be deeply appreciated.

9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) GENIUS WITHIN: THE INNER LIFE OF GLENN GOULD ''Even to his most passionate admirers the phenomenally gifted if wildly unconventional pianist Glenn Gould, above, was a tangle of personal tics and complexes,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times. ''Sometimes he seemed a provocateur bent on riling the public with extreme interpretations and odd behavior. Other times he came across as a fragile, fearful man, at ease only when making music.'' This ''American Masters'' presentation of the documentary by Peter Raymont and Michèle Hozer ''shows the sad progression of a brilliant, garrulous musician with a fiercely original artistic vision as he becomes increasingly obsessive and isolated,'' Mr. Tommasini said of Gould (1932-1982), who made his New York City concert debut in 1955, earned renown for his interpretations of Bach and, by 1964, had abandoned live performances in favor of the recording studio. ''Yet it also provides valuable insights into the inner workings of Gould's distinctive technique and unorthodox interpretive approach.'' 5:45 P.M. (HBO2) SLUMDOG MILLIONAIRE (2008) A young man from a poor area near Mumbai (Dev Patel, right) becomes a game-show contestant and explains how he knows the answers to all those questions in this Oscar-winning contemporary fairy tale from Danny Boyle. The film is ''a gaudy, gorgeous rush of color, sound and motion,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times. ''In the end, what gives me reluctant pause about this bright, cheery, hard-to-resist movie is that its joyfulness feels more like a filmmaker's calculation than an honest cry from the heart about the human spirit (or, better yet, a moral tale).''

Karen Tuttle, a violist and teacher whose singular approach to her instrument -- which entailed the expression of deep feeling, the attainment of great physical comfort and occasionally the literal rending of garments -- drew disciples from around the world, died on Dec. 16 at her home in Philadelphia. She was 90. The cause was complications of Alzheimer's disease, her daughter, Robin Herskowitz Heald, said.

Instagram, a social photo-sharing company that opened its shutters to iPhone owners just two months ago, announced Tuesday that it passed a milestone of one million registered users. The company began offering its simple photo service in mid-October that allows people to share images from a mobile phone and then add unique and fun filters. Since then, Instagram has quickly become the talk of the tech community as people have flocked to the service even with stiff competition from a number of well-financed competitors, including PicPlz, Flickr and Path.

Armed with new models and prices, companies have been battling for a larger share of the consumer electronics market. It was anything but civil. On Jan. 7, 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood exhorted New York's Board of Aldermen to declare the city's independence from Albany and from Washington - a bold stroke of self-preservation that he maintained ''would have the whole and united support of the Southern States.'' Two years later, the federal government diverted Union troops fresh from the Gettysburg battlefield to quell bloody draft riots in Manhattan, a defensive military maneuver that might have allowed Robert E. Lee to escape and prolonged the war.

BERNSTEIN--James Hanley. Passed away on December 24, 2010 after a lengthy battle with COPD. He was born in New York City on November 28,1931 and attended the Bronx High School of Science. After entering at age 16, he graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania in 1952, where he was a member of Pi Lambda Phi fraternity and remained an active alumni, chairing the Gifts committee for his 50th reunion. After graduation, he volunteered to serve in the army (against the wishes of his family) where he was stationed in Japan as...an airplane mechanic from 1953-1954. Jim joined his father's firm, Tailorbrooke, a leading manufacturer of women's suits. Notably, the company manufactured all the WAC and WAVE military uniforms during World War II and received the rare Outstanding Civilian Medal of Honor from the US government. After his father's death, Jim ran Tailorbrooke until his retirement. He is past President of the New York Fashion Creators. Jim married Joan Wertheimer in 1955 and moved from NYC to Tenafly, NJ in 1959 with their daughter Jan. Their son John was born in 1960. Jim was an avid tennis player, boater, maven of home maintenance and improvement, known to some as "Mr. Fix It". His greatest passion was for horticulture, producing breath-taking flower gardens and prolific vegetable gardens. Friends brought ailing plants of all kinds to Jim, who would nurture them back to health. Jim was the consummate gentleman, known for his kindness, open mind, charm, easy smile and honorable character. Due to his generosity, his children and grandchild enjoy wonderful lives "at the beach". He will be missed by all who knew him. Jim leaves behind his wife Joan, children Jan and John, daughter-in-law Diana, beloved granddaughter, Samantha., and numerous "extended" family members, whom he loved. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the COPD Foundation, 2937 SW 27th Avenue- Suite 302, Miami, Florida 33133. The funeral will take place on Tuesday, December 28th 2010 at 11am, at Gutterman Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, 201-489-3800.

NEUBERGER--Roy R.,December 24, 2010 in New York City. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Ann, Roy S. and Jimmy with the passing of their beloved father Roy R. BEIJING -- Star-crossed love between Alexander the Great and his teenage male slave. Ferocious battles that defined an empire. The bloodshed and romance of Ancient Greece. The novel ''The Persian Boy,'' by Mary Renault, has it all. In the West, the book, which is filled with scenes of pederasty and homosexual passion, raises a few eyebrows nearly four decades after it was first published. But in China, where omnipotent censors regularly smother sensitive content and portrayals of sexuality are illegal, one would think a book like this would never make it to the bookstore shelf, let alone past a publisher's desk.

The injuries suffered by Christopher Tierney in ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' could have been far worse if he had not tucked his body and rolled sideways midair as he fell more than 20 feet at Monday's performance, doctors have told his family. ''My understanding is that Chris is fortunate to be alive,'' Mr. Tierney's father, Timothy Tierney, said in a telephone interview on Sunday. In the fullest accounting yet of the accident and injuries, Mr. Tierney's father said that his son, a 31-year-old actor and veteran dancer, was falling headfirst but managed to land on his right side in the basement below the stage at the Foxwoods Theater. That is where he plummeted midperformance when a safety tether to his harness malfunctioned during an acrobatic maneuver. He sustained a hairline fracture in his skull, a broken scapula, a broken bone close to his elbow, four broken ribs, a bruised lung and three fractured vertebrae, his father said. Mr. Tierney is one of several performers who play Spider-Man during stunt sequences.

Apple on Tuesday confirmed that it had removed from its online store an iPhone and iPad app that let users view the content on the WikiLeaks site and follow the WikiLeaks Twitter account. Trudy Muller, an Apple spokeswoman, said the company had removed the app ''because it violated our developer guidelines.'' Ms. Muller added: ''Apps must comply with all local laws and may not put an individual or group in harm's way.''

Those hoping to stop the Falcons' robotic assimilation of the N.F.C. may finally have found a bug in their program: run defense. The Falcons have allowed 454 rushing yards in their last three games. Opponents like the Panthers and the Seahawks were not able to capitalize; when a team is trailing, 34-10, a few 20-yard runs aren't much good. The Saints are ill-equipped to exploit the Falcons' weakness. Pierre Thomas and Reggie Bush are healthy, joining Chris Ivory to give Sean Payton so many rushing options that the only fair thing to do is abandon the run completely so no one can complain about his carries. That's a slight exaggeration, but Payton can never call for an off-tackle run when the fake-double-reverse screen to Bush is available. Pick: FalconsMIKE TANIER

Linear accelerators create X-ray beams aimed at cancer or other problems. Some are retrofitted with a cylindrical assembly — called a cone — which concentrates the radiation for more precise treatments. Because the beams are so intense, a single error can cause serious injuries or death.

Few people in the North welcomed South Carolina's secession in December 1860, but Frederick Douglass, America's most prominent former slave and African-American abolitionist, was one of them. From his editorial desk in Rochester, N.Y., Douglass heaped scorn on the Palmetto State's rash act, but he also relished it as an opportunity. He all but thanked the secessionists for "preferring to be a large piece of nothing, to being any longer a small piece of something."

With 3 minutes 24 seconds left in the fourth quarter Monday night against the Atlanta Falcons, Drew Brees found the rookie tight end Jimmy Graham for a 6-yard touchdown pass. The throw gave New Orleans the lead and eventually a victory, and it clinched an N.F.C. playoff berth. But the pass also kept alive an impressive streak: Brees has thrown for a touchdown in 26 consecutive regular-season games (he also threw a touchdown pass in all three postseason games last season). Brees is still far from breaking the record, 47, set by Johnny Unitas 50 years ago.

"I have a new bread we are doing, a breakfast bread," Katzie Guy-Hamilton told me by e-mail from her new post as executive pastry chef at the Grand Hyatt Hotel's barely opened restaurant New York Central. "Nobody makes it in New York, and I would like to think ours is amazingly delicious." What was this bread? Its name sounds a lot like gibberish, literally. It's gibassier, and Guy-Hamilton explained that hers is an enriched dough with anise seeds, orange blossom water and candied peel. "I shape it into rounds, cut little 'claws' and then it gets a showered with sugar before baking."

The writer Charles Bock made a great many literary friendships during the years while he struggled to complete his first novel, "Beautiful Children." When Mr. Bock's wife, Diana Colbert, was discovered to have leukemia and underwent a bone marrow transplant in the fall of 2009, many of those friends pitched in to offer household help. In October, Ms. Colbert's leukemia returned (she is scheduled for another transplant next month), and three of the Bocks' friends, the novelists Fiona Maazel and Mary-Beth Hughes and the writer Leigh Newman, decided they needed to help even more. "We said everything that can be done, should be done," Ms. Maazel recalled. So on Feb. 6th, at P.S. 122 in the East Village, the Bock friends are throwing what they're calling "the most literary rent party ever."

With the regular season nearly at an end, N.F.L. owners and players are expected to intensify negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement. The existing agreement expires in March, and although Commissioner Roger Goodell said recently that he thought it was possible a deal could be reached by the Super Bowl in early February, two union leaders said on a conference call Tuesday that they had not seen progress on one of the key elements of a new deal: the move to an 18-game regular season.

An accident at the Dec. 20 performance of "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" that injured the actor Christopher Tierney had no immediate effect on that Broadway musical at the box office. According to data released Tuesday by the Broadway League, "Spider-Man," which canceled two of its planned performances for the week ending Dec. 26 while new safety protocols were put in place, grossed $944,138 for its four shows and played to 100 percent capacity. That figure, however, does not reflect any money that might be given back to audience members at the Dec. 20 show, which ended abruptly after the accident. They have been offered refunds or tickets to later "Spider-Man" performances.

LEVINE--Jules B. We mourn the loss of our dearest friend and "Boss" Jules B. Levine. We benefited from his leadership, experience, warm friendship, humor and deep sense of loyalty. LOOKING BACK Kenneth C. Griffin, below, founder of the Citadel Investment Group, offered investors some thanks, apologies and wisdom on the 20th anniversary of his firm. In his year-end letter to clients, obtained by DealBook, he took the opportunity to outline the four main lessons gleaned over the period: hire the best people and create a culture of opportunity, take calculated risks, embrace opportunities and never lose sight of what is important. Mr. Griffin's letter, by turns personal and professional, reflects on the growth of the firm, which started with $4.6 million in seed money and today is a $12 billion behemoth. SCHER--Martin M.,July 8, 1922-December 27, 2010, son of the late Murray and Mildred, loving and beloved father of Peter and Michael (wife Karen), grandfather of Roxanne and Travis and companion of Sylvia Chavkin. First and foremost he cherished his family. He believed in economic and social justice. He loved art, literature and theater. Graduated from the University of Maine as a chemical engineer and enlisted in the Army, serving in military government in occupied Japan. Long-time executive at Erving Paper Mills. Revolutionary in recycling-he helped design the first newspaper de-inking plant in America more than 50 years ago. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Wednesday December 29, 2:15pm.

FRIED--Abraham David, 89, of Manhattan, NY, passed away Saturday evening, December 25, 2010 at the NYU Langone Medical Center with his family by his side. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on March 20, 1921 to Joseph and Helen Fried. A lifelong resident and true New Yorker, he was a graduate of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn and received his undergraduate degree from Brooklyn College. Ab proudly served in the Army Air Corp. during World War II. Returning to New York City, he began his successful career as an Executive for Macy's and then Stiffel Lamps. He was an avid golfer and loved attending the theatre and opera. Ab lived his life with dignity and grace. A devoted family man, he is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Richard and Gail Fried of Upper Saddle River, NJ; his grandchildren Jamie and Daniel Fried; his sister, Hilda Levitan of Rockville Centre, NY; beloved nieces and nephews; and many close friends. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, December 28, 2010 at Parkside Memorial Chapel in Forest Hills, NY at 1:15pm. Burial will follow at Beth Moses Cemetery in Wyandanch, NY. In lieu of flowers, we welcome donations to The Hebrew Home at Riverdale in his honor.

JABBOUR--Mary Bou, 84, of Manhasset, NY passed away peacefully in the presence of her loving family on December 26, 2010. Wife of the late Edmond J. Jabbour, Mother of Maria Jabbour Scotti, Anita Jabbour, Donna Jabbour Quinn, the late Hon. Regina A. Jabbour, Lisa Jabbour Idol, Alicia Jabbour McCrudden, beloved grandmother and great-grandmother. Visitation, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd.,Manhasset. Funeral Mass, Thursday 10am, St Mary's Church, Manhasset. Interment St.John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

FUDIM--Jay, died in Florida on December 22 after a valiant struggle with cancer. Born June 24, 1936. Longtime resident of Queens, NY. Member of the New York Police Department. Graveside service on December 28 at 1pm at Wellwood Cemetery, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity.

American International Group said on Monday that it had signed $4.3 billion worth of credit deals with 36 lenders - in yet another step by the insurer to get off government life support. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, A.I.G. disclosed that it had entered into a $1.5 billion credit agreement for three years on Dec. 23 and a $1.5 billion agreement for 364 days. Its subsidiary Chartis will get another $1.3 billion.
KORWIN--Joan, gone one year leaving an aching void. You are with me at the opera & "in all the old familiar places". Rhoda

As the Giants began a fateful final week of the season, they remained unable to get away from their haunting 45-17 loss to Green Bay. Instead of being back home in New Jersey, planning for a game Sunday that they have to win to have any chance of making the playoffs and perhaps saving their coach's job, the Giants were moored to a hotel in Appleton, Wis., on Monday just a half hour from where they were pounded by the Packers the day before. In a season already filled with some unusual twists, the Radisson Paper Valley Hotel -- a 390-room facility with throwback jerseys of Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers in the gift shop and a steakhouse that bears Vince Lombardi's name -- became the Giants' operating center.

PINTO--Michael Anthony, 73, of Shrewsbury, NJ died December 25 from complications of Alzheimer's disease. Following graduation from college he joined Price, Waterhouse & Co. before becoming Director of International Accounting for The American Institute of CPAs. When the Financial Accounting Standards Board was founded in 1973, he was its first Director of Finance and Administration. Mike and his family lived in Wayne, NJ for 25 years and spent summers in Bay Head, NJ before moving to the Shore Area in 1990. Mike served on the Board of Directors of the Greater Wayne Area Chamber of Commerce the Wayne Area Foundation and Passaic County Economic Development Committee. He lectured frequently on accounting and business issues and served on the faculties of Montclair State University and Fairleigh Dickinson University. Surviving are his wife of 48 years, Terese, their daughter Pamela (Patrick D. Bonner, Jr.), sons: Michael F. (Tracy) and Andrew M. (Frances); seven grandchildren, and one sister, Sister Justine Pinto. For funeral details please visit www.sidun.com.

RUDNER--Beulah Steinman, 95, electrical engineer. BA, Hunter College; MA, Brooklyn Polytech. Researcher and Professor at Poly until 1981. Respected for her intellect, vitality, integrity, and lifelong stance against injustice. Survived by daughter, Andrea, and granddaughter, Isabel of Brooklyn, NY. Fiercely loved, greatly missed. Memorial January 15, 2011.

NEUBERGER--Roy Rothschild. UJA-Federation of New York extends its condolences on the passing of Roy Rothschild Neuberger, whose long-standing commitment to philanthropy has touched the lives of millions in New York, in Israel, and around the world. His generosity will live on through Neuberger Berman. We extend our sympathies to his children; his grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and to the entire Neuberger family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

ISAACS--Abner H. of Merrick, NY. Beloved husband of Mildred (nee Hoffman). Cherished father of Jonathan (deceased) and Charlotte LaRue Isaacs and Jane and James Fox. Proud grandfather of Robert and Catherine Isaacs, Adam (deceased), William, and Amanda Fox. A long-time executive with the Alexander Doll Co., he graduated from the City College of NY, received his J.D. from New York Law School, and served as a Major in the U.S. Army Air Force Alaskan Division during WWII. Funeral service Wednesday, December 29 at 12 noon at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Osborn, 101 Theall Rd. Rye, NY 10580.

TRANSPORT--Natalie B. on Monday, December 27, 2010. Loving and devoted wife to the late Herman B. Transport. Beloved mother of Ira and Mark. Loving mother-in-law of Robyn and Meryl. Adoring and adored grandmother of Zachary, Annie and Jillian. Services to be held Wednesday, December 29, 10:00am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

LEVINE--Jules. The Board of Trustees of Long Beach Medical Center records with profound sorrow, the passing of our esteemed colleague Jules Levine. A man of boundless energy and commitment, Jules faithfully served the Medical Center for 24 years as a vice president of the Board. As a member of its Executive and Finance Committees, Jules was instrumental in guiding the Medical Center through the challenges of our time to meet the needs of the community. His wisdom, intelligence and caring spirit will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Mary Ann, his son Benjamin and daughter Annie. Alfred I. Osterland, Chairman, Board of Trustees Bernard Kennedy, President, Board of Trustees Douglas L. Melzer, Chief Executive Office

POULOS--Lynne, Brooklyn, NY on December 22. Survived by: her children, Carla Joanna of Brookline, MA and Joseph Mark of Brooklyn, NY; brother Nicholas Guletsky III and wife Deborah, nephews Nicholas IV and Alexander all of Wakefield, MA. Gathering for family and friends will be held, call 347-432-0304. Donations can be made in her name to Amnesty International.

WELNER--Rose (nee Nudelsztyn), born: Naleczow, Poland, May 1, 1922, died of natural causes at home on December 26, 2010. She was the beloved wife of Motek for 63 years, devoted mother to Alan and Renee, adored and proud adoring grandmother to Ben and Sam, and dear to Alan Barasch, Diana London, and many friends. With bravery and resourcefulness she survived the Holocaust and lived a full life in America. She was a loyal, honest and generous soul. She was an honors graduate of Queens College in 1978, operated her own business, and continued to the last day of her life to read Shakespeare and to seek wisdom and goodness. She will be deeply missed but her fierce determined spirit lives in us. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, Wednesday December 29, 2010 at 12:30pm.

LEVINE--Jules. The Board of Directors, store owners, and staff of Key Food Stores Co-operative Inc. are deeply saddened to learn of the passing of our friend and President, Jules Levine. Mr. Levine has been an active member of Key Food's Board of Directors. Jules was a highly respected leader who was never afraid to speak his mind and always encouraged debate. He was a man of great character, strength, integrity and honor. He will be dearly missed by all of us. The Key Food family extends its heartfelt sympathy to his wife Mary Ann, and his children, Ben Levine and Annie Krimstock.

NEUBERGER--Roy R. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Roy Neuberger, whose passion for art and whose philanthropic spirit enriched the collections and activities of scores of museums, colleges, and arts organizations including the Metropolitan. Here he was a devoted friend and advisor who served for several decades as Honorary Trustee, Benefactor, and member of the Department of Modern Art's Visiting Committee. He donated works of modern, American, medieval, and Asian art, lent additional works from his expansive private collection, and -- personally and through the Roy R. and Marie S. Neuberger Foundation -- provided major funding for the Museum's capital campaigns and acquisitions. His generosity will benefit this Museum, the cultural life of New Yorkers, and the broader arts community for generations to come. We extend condolences to his entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

MAGIDA--Alfred, died peacefully on December 26 in Fairfield, CT. Beloved husband of the late Harriet Magida, beloved father to Edward and Martin, beloved grandfather to Dayle, Jake, Dylan and Cameron.

Good evening, snow-globe city. You survived the great post-Christmas whiteout of 2010. You frolicked and/or shoveled. You made molasses-on-snow. Now, perhaps, you can relax. Unless you're trying to get home. The trains and buses and subways are still messed up.

NEUBERGER--Roy R. Women's City Club of New York mourns the passing of our extraordinary friend, husband of our beloved past president Marie. Their compassion continues to guide our work of shaping public policies to improve New Yorkers' lives. Ruth Acker, President

GERSTEN--Louis M.,on December 18, 2010, age 88. Beloved husband of the late Bess Gersten; devoted son and family member, respected colleague, and cherished friend. Those who knew him know he would have wished to be remembered as one who served his country with great honor in the 8th Air Force during WWII, but was deeply opposed to America's roles in some of the conflicts that followed. He was one of the founders of New York Business Executives Move Against the War in Vietnam (BEM). As an executive with the State of Israel Bonds organization he helped strengthen Israel's economy through the marketing of her securities. Following the death of his beloved wife, Bess, he became actively involved with the National Stroke Association and served on its Board of Directors. He was active with the Creative Education Foundation where he served on the Board for four years and was a Trustee Emeritus. During his later years, and as a life-long lover of poetry, he became an active member of the Jefferson Poetry Workshop which included his poems in their annual Chapbook. In keeping with his wish to advance medical science, his body has been donated for research and organ transplant purposes. In lieu of memorial services, consider a gift in his name to Creative Education Foundation, 48 North Pleasant Street, Suite 301, Amherst, MA 01002. A memorial reception will be held in the spring (for further information call 508-928-6000).

DREVERS--Louise S.,80, of New York City, died on December 18 at the Bentley Senior Living nursing home in Pennsauken, NJ. She lived in the city's West Village, having moved there from Philadelphia more than 40 years ago. Mrs. Drevers was a member of the Screen Actors Guild and enjoyed an intermittent stage career in both Philadelphia and New York, in addition to occasional television commercial work. For 12 years, until the early 1980s, she was the owner of Drevers' Endeavors, a knitting-supply shop that thrived more as a West Village social hub than as a moneymaking business venture. Mrs. Drevers had many interests, including volunteering with AIDS organizations, Gilda's Club and inmate reading programs in city prisons. Good times and friends were paramount in her life. She was predeceased by her husband, Richard Drevers, and her sister and only sibling, Celine Queroli, of Cinnaminson, NJ. Mrs. Drevers is survived by her caretakers, nephew Jack and Miss Scanlon's partner, Judy Eldridge, both of Voorhees, NJ. Friends are invited to a brief memorial service at 11am, Tuesday, December 28, at the Blake-Doyle Funeral Home, 226 W. Collings Ave., in Collingswood, NJ. Donations may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association, PO Box 96011, Washington, DC, 20090-6011.

Jones; and the television personality and producer Oprah Winfrey, above with Mr. McCartney, are honored for their contributions to American culture in this ceremony taped on Dec. 5, with President Obama and the first lady attending. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. 8 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS BENEATH THE ICE Can Antarctica's past offer clues about what might happen to our planet? ''Nova'' explores that question by following a drilling probe deep into the ice, down through the water and three-quarters of a mile into the seafloor to recover rock cores from a time when Earth was a few degrees warmer than it is today. These cores offer clues not only about the past but also about the future.

The Saturday Profile article last week about Nurul Izzah Anwar, a rising political star in Malaysia who is the eldest daughter of Anwar Ibrahim, the opposition leader in parliament, misspelled, at one point, the name of the American graduate school where she completed a master's degree in international relations. It is the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, not John Hopkins.

SECHSTER--Estelle. December 18, 1921-December 27, 2010. Survived by her children, Andrea (Douglas) Braswell and Martha (Edward) Weisel, her grandchildren Nate (Rebecca) Weisel, David (Abbi) Weisel and Harold Braswell, her greatgrandchildren, Rina and Mordy Weisel and her husband Bud Stirber. Predeceased by her first husband Harold Sechster.

ATLANTA -- Around Sept. 11, 2001, not long after she founded the Islamic Speakers Bureau of Atlanta, Soumaya Khalifa heard from a group whose name sounded like ''Bakers Club.'' It wanted her to come deliver a presentation. The address was unfamiliar, but she went anyway. The group turned out to be the Bickerers Club, whose members love to argue. Islam was their topic du jour, and their venue was a tavern. Ms. Khalifa laughed, and made the best of it.

A listing on Friday of New Year's Eve shows recommended by the pop and jazz critics of The Times misstated the surname of the abolitionist quoted at the end of a song by the band Titus Andronicus, which plays at the Ridgewood Masonic Temple in Brooklyn on New Year's Eve. He was William Lloyd Garrison, not Gibson.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about Michael Lizarraga, a Cal State Northridge forward who is the only deaf men's basketball player in Division I, misidentified the Northridge coach shown on the team's bench with Lizarraga and his sign language interpreter, Erin Matthews. He is the assistant coach Bob Lowe, not the head coach Bobby Braswell.

TSANG--Patrick Chun-Kwok, age 57 years, beloved husband of Teresa and devoted father of Justin and Brian, passed away on December 8th, 2010. Graduated from New York University's Stern School of Business with Bachelor and MBA degrees in 1980, Patrick led a remarkable career in banking in the United States. In 1992, Patrick relocated his base to China and held senior management positions at several international companies. In 2008, he retired as Chief Financial Officer of Tencent, where he took the company public in 2004. Memorial service, January 4, 2010, 1:00pm St James Episcopal Church 865 Madison Avenue, New York City.

BRENNER--Edgar H. The trustees and staff of the Stella and Charles Guttman Foundation, Inc. mourn the loss of our longtime colleague and friend, Edgar H. Brenner. Ed served as a conscientious member of the Board for 49 years, including service as President from 1995-2001. He was deeply committed to the Foundation and the charitable legacy of its founders. Ed was the nephew of Charles Guttman. We will miss him greatly and extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Janet Brenner, and the entire Brenner family.

Having yielded someimprovedreviews for ''Love Never Dies'' with his recent changes to that ''Phantom of the Opera'' sequel, Andrew Lloyd Webber is now tinkering with an older chestnut of a musical that's apparently in need of some updating: namely, ''The Wizard of Oz.'' In an interview with The Telegraph of London, Mr. Lloyd Webber said his production of ''Wizard of Oz'' at the London Palladium, which will star Michael Crawford as the Wizard and Danielle Hope, the winner of a BBC reality competition, as Dorothy, will also have four new songs when it begins previews in February. Mr. Lloyd Webber told The Telegraph the new songs were added ''because it didn't have anything for either of the witches or the wizard.'' He added that the musical will have ''a slightly longer opening sequence'' as well as ''an ending that is closer to the book than the film was.'' (''I'm not going to give it away,'' Mr. Lloyd Webber said, ''but a lot of fans of the film have always quibbled with the ending. In the book Oz is a real place.'')

FERRARO--John, 64, on December 7, 2010. An actor with Andre Gregory's famed Manhattan Project, he performed in numerous plays including "Alice in Wonderland" and Wallace Shawn's "Our Late Night." Later as a director, he directed the national and Australian companies of "The Pirates of Penzance," John Ford Noonan's "Some Men Need Help" and numerous productions at LaMama E.T.C. and the Public Theater. He received an Emmy nomination for his work on "Sesame Street." Most recently he taught acting and directing at the University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts. He is survived by his wife Karen Emonts of Los Angeles, his son Gregory Ferraro and former wife Clare Ferraro of New York. A Memorial Service will be held on January 24, 2011, at 6:30pm at Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42 Street, New York.

Lincoln often cracked jokes about his homeliness. During a debate with Stephen Douglas, the story goes, Douglas called him two-faced. ''If I had another face,'' Lincoln asked, ''do you think I'd wear this one?'' Calvin Jackson took this photograph in Pittsfield, Ill., on Oct. 1, 1858. By the mid-1850s, talk of a ''beard movement'' was sweeping the nation, but Lincoln had not yet joined. A lithograph by Charles A. Barry and J. E. Baker, June 1860.

A red-hot trading market has developed in the shares of the world's leading social-networking companies: Facebook, Twitter, Zynga and LinkedIn. What is unusual is that none of the companies are listed on a public stock exchange. Each is privately held. Now, the Securities and Exchange Commission wants to learn more about the business of these stock trades. The agency has sent information requests to several participants in the buying and selling of these four companies' stocks, according to two people with direct knowledge of the inquiry who requested anonymity because they were not authorized to speak about it.

The Giants' playoff hopes were left teetering Sunday after their 45-17 road loss to the Green Bay Packers. To make matters worse, the team was stranded Monday morning because of the blizzard that swept across the Northeast, giving the players idle time to stew. Through early Monday afternoon, the Giants were staying at a hotel in Appleton, Wis., about a 40-minute drive from Green Bay, waiting for the New York-area airports to reopen.

BERNSTEIN--James Hanley. Passed away on December 24, 2010 after a lengthy battle with COPD. He was born in New York City on November 28,1931 and attended the Bronx High School of Science. After entering at age 16, he graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania in 1952, where he was a member of Pi Lambda Phi fraternity and remained an active alumni, chairing the Gifts committee for his 50th reunion. After graduation, he volunteered to serve in the army (against the wishes of his family) where he was stationed in Japan as...an aviation mechanic from 1953-1954. Jim joined his father's firm, Tailorbrooke, a leading manufacturer of women's suits. Notably, the company manufactured all the WAC and WAVE military uniforms during World War II and received the rare Outstanding Civilian Medal of Honor from the US government. After his father's death, Jim ran Tailorbrooke until his retirement. He is past President of the New York Fashion Creators. Jim married Joan Wertheimer in 1955 and moved from NYC to Tenafly, NJ in 1959 with their daughter Jan. Their son John was born in 1960. Jim was an avid tennis player, boater, maven of home maintenance and improvement, known to some as "Mr. Fix It". His greatest passion was for horticulture, producing breath-taking flower gardens and prolific vegetable gardens. Friends brought ailing plants of all kinds to Jim, who would nurture them back to health. Jim was the consummate gentleman, known for his kindness, open mind, charm, easy smile and honorable character. Due to his generosity, his children and grandchild enjoy wonderful lives "at the beach". He will be missed by all who knew him. Jim leaves behind his wife Joan, children Jan and John, daughter-in-law Diana, beloved granddaughter, Samantha., and numerous "extended" family members, whom he loved. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the COPD Foundation, 2937 SW 27th Avenue- Suite 302, Miami, Florida 33133. The funeral will take place on Tuesday, December 28th 2010 at 11am, at Gutterman Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, 201-489-3800.

KOHNS--Lee. New York, NY, May 14, 1935 Sedona, AZ, December 11, 2010. Kind, witty soul. Loving, beloved father. Adored son, brother and uncle. Cherished friend to many. Passionate filmmaker. Talented TV news editor. Rest easy in the red rocks forever. Love you so much, Aba.

An article on Wednesday about a rush by investors to acquire large expanses of arable land in poor developing countries such as Mali misspelled the given name of a United Nations Development Fund economist in Mali, who said such acquisitions threaten to displace a large percentage of the rural population. He is Kalfa Sanogo, not Kalfo.

Authorities arrested Don Chu, a Primary Global Research executive from Somerset, N.J., at 6:05 a.m. on Nov. 24. Within 24 hours, employees halfway around the world in the expert-network firm's Manila office received a directive from their chief: stop recruiting outside consultants and do not return to work until Dec. 2. By then, Primary Global's Manila outpost was effectively closed, according to a former employee. A vice president, James Fleishman, soon e-mailed some senior employees in Manila, bidding farewell and complimenting them on a job well done.

HEIMANN--Herb, 80, in Ewing, NJ on December 25, 2010. Father of the late David Heimann, survived by his beloved family; wife, Carol, son, Mark (Lara) Heimann, grandchildren, Olivia and Jonah, sisters Julia Waixel, Hanna Adler and Ruth Oppenheim. Herb was born in Werner, Germany, survived Kristalnacht and emigrated to the US in 1940. He was a Korean War veteran (military police). Mr. Heimann was a bank financial and insurance advisor. Funeral services and burial are Wednesday 1pm at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. NY. Donations to Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Foundation, Inc. or Greenwood House, 53 Walter St., Ewing, NJ 08628.

The Mets made another low-key move Monday, acquiring Chin-Ling Hu, a shortstop with little major league experience who team officials hope can be their backup middle infielder. Hu, 26, was acquired from the Los Angeles Dodgers for the minor league left-hander Michael Antonini. Hu has played in only 96 major league games over four years, but the Mets hope he can back up shortstop Jose Reyes and whoever is their second baseman. Luis Castillo struggled again last season as the Mets' everyday second baseman and is still owed roughly $6 million. The other options at second base are Ruben Tejada, 21, who is a good fielder but not a very good hitter, and Daniel Murphy, who is trying to learn to play second as he returns from a series of injuries.

LEEDS--Gloria Altschul, 84, died peacefully at home on December 24, surrounded by her family. She is survived by her husband of 63 years, Ira F. Leeds, their daughter and son-in-law Ellen and Lawrence D. Saidenberg, their son Jeffrey T. Leeds and their grandchildren Katie and Douglas Saidenberg and Katie's spouse, Spencer Berg. The funeral will be private.

Steven W. Fisher, a New York State justice who presided over the trial of two men who killed five employees of a Wendy's fast food restaurant in Queens in 2000, died on Dec. 18 at his home in Queens. He was 64. The cause was lung cancer, his son-in-law, David Kerpen, said.

LENNOX--Mildred, died peacefully at her home on December 25, 2010 at the age of 91. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street), Wednesday 7-9pm. Funeral Service at Frank E. Campbell, Thursday at 9:30am.

GIULINI--Charles A. Jr.,age 78, of Pelham Manor, NY succumbed to lung cancer on December 26, 2010. Charles was a New York City attorney at law in private practice and a passionate advocate of Second Amendment rights. A proud American, he was also a US Army Veteran who served in the Korean War. A fighter in the court room and a fighter until the end, he is survived by his bride of 51 years, Mary Jane, son Thomas, daughters Christine, Susan and Kathleen and their husbands, brother Richard, and four grandchildren. Calling hours are at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass will be held on Thursday at 11am at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, NY.

At 55 years old, William Lloyd Garrison - president of the American Anti-Slavery Society and arguably the nation's most prominent abolitionist - was balding, square-faced and bespectacled. With his genteel manners and formal sartorial tastes, including black suits and severe black cravats, he could be mistaken for a conservative schoolmaster. But appearances masked a steely resolve capable of soaring to messianic heights.

When does football become more than a sporting event? It's not when the president comments on the redemption of a player who served prison time for a vicious felony. That's a slow news week. Nor is it when a former Super Bowl quarterback crudely hits on a young woman not his wife or girlfriend. That's an even slower news week.

The town of Parsons, Kan., is - for the moment - the worldwide epicenter of color film photography. That is where Dwayne's Photo, a small family business, is processing the last rolls of Kodachrome. A. G. Sulzberger is there and has filed this report. Eastman Kodak stopped making the film in 2009 and gave the last roll to Steve McCurry. He shot the last three frames of that roll in Parsons before handing it in to Dwayne's. They are displayed above.

This year will not be remembered as a good year in travel. There was at least one improvement for passengers traveling in America: the limitation on how long a plane could idle on the tarmac. As part of a project I've been working on, I've been doing some US-Europe comparisons, and have a curious parallel: by the numbers, Ireland looks a lot like Nevada. The populations are similar; the housing bubbles were comparable in their extremity; both currently have roughly 14 percent unemployment.

The impact of BP's oil spill on threatened and endangered sea turtles in the Gulf of Mexico was serious but not catastrophic, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Jane Lubchenco, writes in an essay published Wednesday. Furthermore, the majority of the 600 dead turtles found during the spill appear to have been killed by fishing operations, not oil. "The heightened scrutiny of the Gulf of Mexico during the oil spill brought to light the need for stronger cooperation between N.O.A.A., the gulf states and the fishing industry to address the significant ongoing problem of sea turtles drowning in fishing operations," Dr. Lubchenco says. [Miami Herald]

On Jan. 3 and 4, an independently produced event modeled and named after the Rolling Stones' 1968 Rock and Roll Circus hits Lincoln Center, with a lineup of indie music darlings like So So Glos, Amazing Baby, Japanther and Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. But it's more than just a concert staged under the big top: food trucks from Mexicue, Van Leeuwen and Asia Dog will be present, and Tuesday's show includes Big Apple Circus performances. The Moment caught up with Jessica Resler, founder of the brand development firm Muffincupcake, who engineered the project along with the event producers Adarsha Benjamin and Vance Garrett.

Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanist at Southern Methodist University, writes from Ethiopia, where she is studying fossils of ancient plant and animal life. The current field season in the Mush Valley of Ethiopia is financed by a grant to Ellen Currano of Miami University, Ohio, from the National Geographic Society Committee on Research and Exploration.

While just over 15 years have elapsed since Billy Crudup made his Broadway debut in Tom Stoppard's "Arcadia," the actor is moving ahead two centuries to portray another character in a Broadway revival of that play slated for next year. I see a lot of innovative design; that's why my job is so much fun. But it's not often that I see something that offers a glimpse into the future. That's how I felt when I walked into Sony's exhibition in Milan during the 2010 furniture fair. The Japanese company had asked the British designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby, of the firm BarberOsgerby, to create an exhibition to showcase its Monolithic Design concept, in which its home entertainment products are seamlessly integrated into interior design. The exhibition itself was indeed interesting - BarberOsgerby designed an anechoic chamber, lined with foam blocks in the shape of triangular solids, in which to demonstrate projects like Sony's pairing of a big-screen TV and near-field speakers to create a personal entertainment "space," and a TV cabinet, made with a 3-D printer, that was porous enough to transmit sound from the speakers inside it. This was all very cool, but the part of the exhibition that was really thrilling was a group of objects that combined light and sound.

One could imagine the likes of Rhett Butler raising a glass at the bar at Husk, the award-winning chef Sean Brock's new restaurant in the historic center of Charleston, S.C. Husk offers hearty, somewhat masculine fare with a common theme: "If it ain't Southern, it ain't walkin' in the door," Brock says. This manifesto carries over to the bar, which is adjacent to the restaurant in a restored antebellum structure and boasts a killer bourbon list. Exquisite small-batch varieties are served in glasses made from recycled wine bottles, each with a "punt" in the bottom, which creates a kind of "moat" for the amber liquid. When a hand-molded sphere of clear ice is set on top (for cooling without dilution), the only real contact between one's 23-year-old Pappy Van Winkle and its icy companion is while sipping. It's a pretty neat experience.

The world's largest clearinghouse for credit-default swaps, ICE Trust, has had second thoughts about registering with regulators, citing concerns over new rules devised to bring transparency to the $600 trillion derivatives market. ICE Trust, a division of the Intercontinental Exchange, the big derivatives exchange, applied to be a derivatives clearing organization with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in November. Last week, the company quietly withdrew its application.

SCIENCE TIMES An article on Tuesday about participatory ''citizen science'' projects described incorrectly an online protein-folding game known as Foldit. Each puzzle in the game represents a sequence of amino acids, not a single amino acid.

One of the young parents made famous by MTV's ''Teen Mom'' was arrested Monday on charges of battery that stem from a September episode of the reality show, according to news reports. The woman, Amber Portwood, faces three counts of battery and one of neglect in Madison County, Indiana, a local newspaper, The Herald Bulletin, reported. She was expected to be released on bail on Tuesday.

LETIS--Michael A. In New Haven, CT, December 24, 2010, Michael A. Letis, beloved husband of Susan Clancy Letis of Goshen, CT. He was born March 28, 1941 in New Haven, son of the late George T. and Mildred Lindhardt Letis. He was a resident of Greenwich for 35 years, prior to moving to Goshen. Besides his wife, Mike is survived by his children, Michael Dodd Letis of Goshen and Megen E. McKinney of Fairfield, and his grandchildren, Matthew, Graysen, and Kate McKinney all of Fairfield, and his brother, Tommy Letis of East Haven. He enrolled at Dartmouth, class of 1963, where, as a freshman, he broke the then existing passing records for quarterbacks. Following graduation he had significant contributions to the marketing departments of Mobil Oil Company and New York Times. Mike became one of the country's most brilliant sports marketing executives, where he directed the marketing and television properties of the Breeders Cup, Pitch, Hit and Run, a program for Major League Baseball and the Super Stars, along with being instrumental with marketing for several Olympic Games. In 1984 he founded SMTI, Sports Marketing & Television International, with Mike Trager. Mike was a "towering figure in sports marketing" according to Jimmy Gluckson, a SMTI executive, with a national reputation for creativity and successful marketing outcomes. Relatives and friends may call Thursday evening from 47pm, with a Tribute Service at 7:00 in the W. S. Clancy Memorial Funeral Home, 504 Main St., Branford. For directions and online memorial, visit www.wsclancy.com.

NELSON--Dr. Irving, a warm and caring pediatrician for thousands of children in Westchester County for over 60 years, passed away peacefully at his home in Ardsley, NY on December 27, 2010. He was 95 years old. Dr. Nelson had a long, illustrious career as a pediatrician. Following graduation from New York University in 1935 and Long Island College of Medicine in 1939, he joined the US Air Force and was stationed in Italy. He served as a Flight Surgeon from 1941-1946 and was a highly decorated Lt. Colonel. He completed his pediatrics training at Cumberland Hospital, where he was Chief Pediatric Resident in 1947. Dr. Nelson was Director of Pediatrics at White Plains Hospital from 1957 to 1971, and was Attending Pediatrician at Grasslands Hospital in Valhalla and St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was elected Chairman of the Pediatrics Section of the Westchester Academy of Medicine in 1962 and 1963. Dr. Nelson proudly volunteered for several community organizations. He participated in the Westchester County Department of Health Well Baby Clinics in Tuckahoe and White Plains, volunteered for many years as the Physician for the Town of Greenville Volunteer Fire Department, and was the pediatrician for Hartsdale Public Schools. Dr. Nelson was born in Brooklyn, N.Y. on June 10, 1915, and was older brother to Howard and Ruth. He is survived by his beloved wife Gloria, his devoted children Francine and Mitchell, and five adoring grandchildren Kate, Jeffrey, Josh, Scott, and Tommy. Private funeral services will be held on Friday December 31, 2010. Donations may be made to White Plains Hospital.

BEIJING -- The photograph is so graphic that it appears cartoonish at first glance. A man lies on a road with his eyes closed, blood streaming from his half-open mouth, his torso completely crushed under the large tire of a red truck. One arm reaches out from beneath the tire. His shoulder is a bloody pile of flesh. His head is no longer attached to the flattened spinal cord.

CITIGROUP'S 'REBIRTH' Vikram S. Pandit, below, Citigroup's chief executive, took a brief pause from a family vacation in India to praise the bank's employees for what he called a ''crucial year'' in the ''transformation and rebirth of the company.'' In an internal memo sent late Monday night, Mr. Pandit lauded virtually every business and region for the strides made on his turnaround plans, and pointed to several signs his strategy was working. ERIC DASH HIGHER FEES The Institutional Investor Council, which represents Britain's biggest investors, released a report this month saying the organization was consistently told by corporate issuers that the fees on rights offerings, or stock sales to existing investors, were too high. But banks charge twice as much for secondary common stock offerings in the United States -- which are sold to a broader universe of investors -- than firms charge for rights offerings in Britain. ANITA RAGHAVAN ENERGY DEAL PetroChina agreed on Tuesday to sell its stake in a gas pipeline operator to the Kunlun Energy Company for $2.85 billion, the latest in a flurry of energy deals.

A memorial service will be held for Blanca Lilia Perez vda de Castaneda, beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister of 12, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, January 12, 2011, 11am. SHAPIRO--E. Donald. The New York Law School community mourns the passing of E. Donald Shapiro, Dean Emeritus and Joseph Solomon Distinguished Professor of Law at New York Law School. Born in 1931 in York, Pennsylvania, E. Donald Shapiro graduated summa cum laude from Dickinson College in 1953 and went on to attend Harvard Law School, where he graduated in 1956. A life-long teacher and pioneer in the field of medical law, he taught at leading institutions including Boston University School of Law, the University of Michigan School of Social Work, Harvard Medical School, Hebrew University and New York Law School. E. Donald Shapiro served as dean of New York Law School from 1973 to 1983, leading the Law School through difficult economic times. He is credited with helping to build the wonderful faculty, ushering in a more modern approach to legal education, and beginning the steps that led to the Law School's establishment of a campus, including a new academic building, in TriBeCa. His pride and love of New York Law School was felt long after his departure as dean. The Law School is grateful for his leadership as a dean and professor, for his dedication to his family, and for his many accomplishments. He will be remembered and missed by us all. We extend our condolences to his wife Merle and his children and grandchildren. Arthur N. Abbey, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Richard A. Matasar, Dean and President

An article on Tuesday about companies' steering charitable dollars to neighborhood playgrounds misidentified the city in which KaBoom, a nonprofit that promotes the creation of play spaces, is located. It is in Washington, not New Haven, Conn.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Tuesday about the singer Teena Marie referred incorrectly to the Fugees' album ''The Score,'' on which they sampled and reconfigured her 1988 song ''Ooo La La La.'' It was their second album, not their first.

Here, Noah and Lucas de Necochea of Washington Heights in Manhattan hold a 1946 photograph taken by their great-granduncle Pete Padilla, then the only professional photographer in Calexico, Calif., the border town where I grew up. Their grandfather Gordy is at bottom left. Their great-grandparents Fernando and Margarita hold Chacita, their great-aunt. Pete Padilla opened his portrait studio in 1934 and documented families and celebrations for over 50 years. Celebrities came from afar to be photographed by him. Pete became my first mentor. As a child I loved to draw and paint. One day, he handed me a blow-up of a vast crowd cheering at a bullfight and said: ''So you want to be an artist? Here, draw each one of these faces.'' I did, and in so doing so

Should old news items be forgot, and never brought to mind? Of course not! As the year draws to a close, we present 100 or so questions to test your recollection of the highs and lows of 2010 -- for the sake of auld lang syne.

''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles on Broadway'' has recouped its initial investment of $2 million in seven weeks, the show's producers announced on Monday. The biographical show, with four cast members impersonating the Beatles in a concert setting, opened on Oct. 26 at the Neil Simon Theater. In a rare move for a Broadway show, ''Rain'' recently announced that it will close Jan. 15 at the Simon before resuming performances five blocks south at the slightly smaller Brooks Atkinson Theater on Feb. 8 for at least 16 more weeks. It had originally planned a 12-week run on Broadway, but the musical ''Catch Me If You Can'' is scheduled to move into the Simon in the spring for an open-ended run. ''Rock of Ages,'' which has been running at the Atkinson since March 2009, will close there on Jan. 9 and move three blocks south to the Helen Hayes Theater, where performances will start in March.

Warner Brothers confirmed that a stuntman involved in the filming of its coming comedy, ''The Hangover Part II,'' was hospitalized after he was injured during a shoot, The Hollywood Reporter said. In a statement the studio said the stuntman was hurt in a sequence filmed in Thailand on Friday involving a truck and a car. ''The truck and car were both driven by stunt drivers,'' the statement said. ''An ambulance immediately took the injured stuntman to the local hospital, and he has since been transported to a hospital in Bangkok, where advanced care is being provided. We are awaiting further details concerning his condition.''

BUSINESS DAY An article on Tuesday about the struggles of expert-network firms, which connect large investors with outside specialists, misstated the actions by federal authorities who are conducting an insider trading investigation. Over the last two months the authorities have raided three hedge funds, but they have not raided any mutual funds. (Some mutual funds have received subpoenas.)

Facebook likes big numbers - it now has more than 500 million users, each one of whom can have as many as 5,000 friends. Yet as a privately held company, its ownership base must remain small, or it will have to disclose publicly its financial results. A surging shadow market in the privately held shares of Facebook is making such restraint difficult and could spur the company to go public - even as its executives try to tamp down speculation about an initial public offering - much as similar pressure helped push Microsoft and Google toward their own initial public offerings.

BERNSTEIN--James Hanley. Passed away on December 24, 2010 after a lengthy battle with COPD. He was born in New York City on November 28, 1931 and attended the Bronx High School of Science. After entering at age 16, he graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania in 1952, where he was a member of Pi Lambda Phi fraternity and remained an active alumni, chairing the Gifts committee for his 50th reunion. After graduation, he volunteered to serve in the army (against the wishes of his family) where he was stationed in Japan as...an aviation mechanic from 1953-1954. Jim joined his father's firm, Tailorbrooke, a leading manufacturer of women's suits. Notably, the company manufactured all the WAC and WAVE military uniforms during World War II and received the rare Outstanding Civilian Medal of Honor from the US government. After his father's death, Jim ran Tailorbrooke until his retirement. He is past President of the New York Fashion Creators. Jim married Joan Wertheimer in 1955 and moved from NYC to Tenafly, NJ in 1959 with their daughter Jan. Their son John was born in 1960. Jim was an avid tennis player, boater, maven of home maintenance and improvement, known to some as "Mr. Fix It". His greatest passion was for horticulture, producing breath-taking flower gardens and prolific vegetable gardens. Friends brought ailing plants of all kinds to Jim, who would nurture them back to health. Jim was the consummate gentleman, known for his kindness, open mind, charm, easy smile and honorable character. Due to his generosity, his children and grandchild enjoy wonderful lives "at the beach". He will be missed by all who knew him. Jim leaves behind his wife Joan, children Jan and John, daughter-in-law Diana, beloved granddaughter, Samantha., and numerous "extended" family members, whom he loved. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the COPD Foundation, 2937 SW 27th Avenue- Suite 302, Miami, Florida 33133. Funeral service took place on December 28, 2010 at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ 201-489-3800.
