FISHER--Janet Cane, the widow of Avery Fisher, passed away in New York on December 28th, at the age of 94. Raised in Tuckahoe, New York, she graduated from Goucher College in 1938. On a return trip to Goucher from Grand Central Station, she met Avery who happened to be there with friends. He was so taken with her that he proceeded to call every "Cane" in the Westchester phone book until her found her. They were married on August 9, 1940. Janet was an accomplished and dynamic woman who dedicated her life to the causes she believed in. She was a Board Member of the 92nd St. Y for over 50 years, and a Board Member of Young Audiences Inc., Children's Orchestra Society, City Meals-on-Wheels, and The New Milford Hospital Foundation. She established the Janet and Avery Fisher Music Residency program at Goucher College. Janet and Avery were frequently seen at concerts at Lincoln Center. Classical music was a shared passion. She had warm relationships with many of the young musicians who received Avery Fisher Career Grants or the coveted Avery Fisher Prize. Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax gave private birthday "concerts" for her twice, true highlights in her life. Janet loved their Washington, CT home and spent many hours in her gardens. She created beautiful dried flower arrangements and gave them as gifts to her friends. When she was in her seventies, Janet was spotted by a modeling agent as she was bringing an armload of lilacs to her physician. The agent insisted that she was the perfect face for a GAP ad. Janet became the one and only senior citizen to be so featured. True to form, she donated her fee for this work to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, encouraging awareness of a cause not yet in the public consciousness at the time. Janet is survived by her beloved children, Barbara, Nancy (Marc), Chip (Susan), five grandchildren: Christopher, Philip, Diana, William, and Matthew, and her step-sister Betty. Funeral services will be private. A memorial will be held at a later date. Donations may be made to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts for the benefit of the Avery Fisher Career Grants or to the 92nd Street Y Nursery School.

WILNER--Stefanie, psychologist, teacher and artist, died peacefully at home Sunday, surrounded by family, after a valiant struggle with cancer. Graduated Cum Laude from City College, she received a PhD in psychology and worked at LIJ/Hillside Hospital. Devoted wife to late husband David for 56 years, beloved mother to Paul, Gregg (Leila) and Lori, adored grandmother of Jordan and Harris, cherished sister of George, Morris, Jean, Sadie, Mary, Sam, Stanley and Evelyn, treasured aunt, and inspirational friend and mentor to many. She is survived by Lori, Gregg, Evelyn and Stanley. Her generosity, wisdom and integrity will be greatly missed. Services on Thursday December 30, 10:15 at Gramercy Chapel, 353 2nd Ave. at 21st St. Memorial contributions may be made to National Breast Cancer Fdtn.

BAIM--Sheldon B.,84, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving wife, children and grandchildren on December 27, 2010 at his Long Island home, after a difficult bout with prostate cancer. Sheldon was born in Brooklyn, NY on May 8, 1926. He attended Lafayette High School, the University of Miami and Bucknell, served in the Navy during World War II and then joined his family as a partner at Manufacturers Corrugated Box Company. He was an honored supporter of the UJA-Federation of New York and Israel State Bonds. He was a long standing member of The New York Friars Club. He loved tennis and fly fishing, and always had a joke or story to share. Most of all, though, he cherished his family, and he was a wonderful husband of Gale, adoring father of Ilene Becker, and Jill and Michael Gold; loving and very proud PopPop (grandpa) of Alex, Peter and Madi Gold; devoted and loving brother of Carol and Walter Lieb, Carole and the late Jerry Baim, and Jerry and Judy Koch; and beloved uncle and cousin to many in his large, close-knit family. Services will be held on Thursday, December 30th at 12:30pm at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation.

BARNETT--Elizabeth P. The Board of Trustees of the Edna St. Vincent Millay Society mourns the passing of Elizabeth P. Barnett, the poet's literary executor and a Board trustee, who died peacefully in Eugene, OR on December 26, 2010. Born in Hackensack, NJ in 1924, Barnett grew up in Rhinebeck, NY, where she attended Rhinebeck High School before continuing her studies at The College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, VA. An aspiring actress, Barnett moved to New York to attend the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. While living in Manhattan, she and her husband Richard, a writer, met another young actor, Roscoe Lee Browne, through their mutual friendship with the singer Mabel Mercer. In 1952, two years after Millay's death at Steepletop, the poet's country home in Austerlitz, NY, Barnett, her husband, and Browne visited the site and met Millay's sister Norma, then the poet's literary executor, and her husband, Charles Ellis. That meeting resulted in lifelong friendship and literary partnership between Barnett and Norma Millay. Known for her deep love for the arts, meticulous attention to detail, and elegant writing style, Barnett worked as an editor at Houghton Mifflin in Boston for many years before devoting her time to Millay Society initiatives, primarily the preservation of the house and grounds at Steepletop. After Norma's death in 1986, Barnett served as literary executor and lectured at schools and other venues about the poet's life and work. She is survived by her daughter Vincent Barnett of Eugene, OR, her first husband Klaus Kolmar, and a devoted staff and Board of Trustees of the Millay Society. A memorial service for Elizabeth Barnett will be held at Steepletop in the spring. In accordance with her wishes, in lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Edna St. Vincent Millay Society, Steepletop, Box #

8 P.M. (13) DUDAMEL: CONDUCTING A LIFE ''I see the music in general, the culture, as a right for the people,'' says Gustavo Dudamel, above, the 29-year-old music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. ''This is my dream to have art as a right to the people in the country and in the world.'' In this edition of ''Tavis Smiley Reports,'' Mr. Dudamel talks about his career as the youngest conductor of a major orchestra; his quest to provide music education for American children; and El Sistema, the publicly financed program in Venezuela that he credits with changing his life by instilling a passion for music at a very young age -- and by keeping him out of trouble. Mr. Smiley also interviews José Abreu, the founder of El Sistema, and four graduates of the Abreu Fellows Program at the New England Conservatory in Boston, which provides tuition-free training for postgraduate musicians committed to helping develop El Sistema programs in the United States and abroad. At 9 on Channel 13 and 10 on Channel 49, ''Celebración! Gustavo Dudamel and the LA Phil With Juan Diego Flórez,'' a ''Great Performances'' presentation taped on the orchestra's Oct. 7 opening night at Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, features the ensemble and Mr. Flórez, the Peruvian tenor, in bel canto arias by Rossini and Latin American canciones by Granda, Lara, Moncayo, Grever, Gutiérrez and Márquez. 8 P.M. (TLC) EXTREME COUPONING Something for virtually nothing: four big-time shoppers stockpile goods using coupons, some of which they retrieve from garbage bins and Dumpsters. ''My Strange Addiction,'' a new series at 9, looks at obsessive behaviors, like eating chalk, running nonstop, compulsive shopping and excessive tanning. And at 10, ''Toddlers & Tiaras'' returns from hiatus with some young Arizona beauty pageant contestants, including the year-old twins Scarlett and Isabella.

NEUBERGER--Roy R. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sorrow the passing of Trustee Roy R. Neuberger. One of the first Museum Trustees from outside the Whitney family and longtime Honorary Trustee after his tenure, he was more than an arts patron; he was a true arts patriarch. An avid collector who applied his sharp business acumen to his passion for supporting the work of living artists, Mr. Neuberger inspired a generation of collectors and his profound gifts to the arts community will live on for many generations to come. Our deepest sympathies to his children, Ann Neuberger Aceves, Roy S. Neuberger, and James A. Neuberger, his family, and to his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. FIELDS--Bertram. The Brooklyn College Foundation mourns the passing of Trustee Emeritus, Bertram Fields who graduated in 1942 with a degree in economics. A founder of Fields Management Company and the husband of renowned soprano Roberta Peters, his steady support of the college included his role in helping to form the Alumni Fund in 1967, and in establishing two scholarships awarded each year to two students majoring in economics. We are deeply grateful for his loyalty to the college throughout the years.

PINTO--Michael Anthony, 73, of Shrewsbury, NJ died December 25 from complications of Alzheimer's disease. Following graduation from college he joined Price, Waterhouse & Co. before becoming Director of International Accounting for The American Institute of CPAs. When the Financial Accounting Standards Board was founded in 1973, he was its first Director of Finance and Administration. Mike and his family lived in Wayne, NJ for 25 years and spent summers in Bay Head, NJ before moving to the Shore Area in 1990. Mike served on the Board of Directors of the Greater Wayne Area Chamber of Commerce the Wayne Area Foundation and Passaic County Economic Development Committee. He lectured frequently on accounting and business issues and served on the faculties of Montclair State University and Fairleigh Dickinson University. Surviving are his wife of 48 years, Terese, their daughter Pamela (Patrick D. Bonner, Jr.), sons: Michael F. (Tracy) and Andrew M. (Frances); seven grandchildren, and one sister, Sister Justine Pinto. For funeral details please visit www.sidun.com.

Year-end is a time for professors to grade. In a similar spirit, I end this year by highlighting the lowlights of the year's deal making. These are, by category, the Deal Professor dropouts, the deal makers who deserve an F. SHAREHOLDER RIGHTS Cedar Fair failed hands down. After missing earnings estimates and suspending its dividend, Cedar Fair, an amusement park operator, announced a $2.4 billion sale in December 2009 to the private equity firm Apollo Global Management. Cedar Fair is based in Sandusky, Ohio, and has a large local shareholder base.

MORRISROE--Garyowen. The lawyers and staff of Chadbourne & Parke LLP mourn the untimely passing of our longtime partner, colleague and friend, Garyowen Morrisroe. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Susan and his children, Lauren, Daniel and Thomas, to whom he was a devoted and loving husband and father. Gary passed away peacefully in his sleep on December 22 at the age of 53, after a long illness. Widely recognized for his expertise in products liability litigation, an area in which he focused almost exclusively for more than two decades, Gary was head of the firm's products liability practice, as well as a member of Chadbourne's Management Committee. Gary played a pivotal role in some of the most noteworthy and complex products cases ever tried in U.S. courts. He was well known throughout the legal community for his longtime representation of British American Tobacco Company and other clients in landmark litigation, both in the United States and abroad. Gary joined Chadbourne as an associate in 1987 and was elected partner in 1994. Those of us who worked closely with Gary, primarily at our offices in New York and London, knew him as a remarkably gifted lawyer, a man of boundless energy, good humor, and impeccable integrity, a patient and generous mentor, and always a warm and responsive friend. Notwithstanding his dedication to his clients, the focus of Gary's life was his wife and children. He took great pride in their many accomplishments. An avid sportsman, Gary will be fondly remembered for his wit and charm, the gift of his company, and his abiding passion for literature. We will miss the warmth of his friendship, the benefit of his sharp intellect, and his grace and humility. Friends may call at Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, Connecticut on Sunday, January 2 from 3pm to 8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Michael's Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, Connecticut on Monday, January 3 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Sarcoma Foundation of America, www.curesarcoma.org. Our thoughts and prayers are with Gary's family during this most difficult time. Chadbourne & Parke LLP

With 3 minutes 24 seconds left in the fourth quarter Monday night against the Atlanta Falcons, Drew Brees found the rookie tight end Jimmy Graham for a 6-yard touchdown pass. The score gave New Orleans the lead in a 17-14 victory that clinched a playoff berth for the Saints. But the pass also kept alive an impressive streak: Brees has thrown for a touchdown in 26 consecutive regular-season games (he also threw a touchdown pass in all three postseason games last season). Brees is still far from the record, 47, set by Johnny Unitas 50 years ago.

The opposing human tides slipped past each other on Newkirk Avenue this morning, heads bent, feet sliding, people in possession of bad news and people about to get it. No Q train service. No B train service. No explanation. No excuses. No estimate on when the subway lines might run again.

The Library of Congress is surely serious in its enthusiasm for ''Airplane!'': that David Zucker-Jim Abrahams-Jerry Zucker comedy is one of 25 films that it announced on Tuesday had been added to the National Film Registry, a roster maintained by the National Film Preservation Board to safeguard films deemed ''culturally, historically or aesthetically significant.'' Among the 24 other additions to the registry that were chosen from 2,112 nominations are ''All the President's Men,''Alan J. Pakula's drama about the Watergate scandal; ''Grey Gardens,'' David and Albert Maysles's documentary about Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter -- Big Edie and Little Edie; and ''The Exorcist,''William Friedkin's adaptation of the William Peter Blatty horror novel about a particularly ill-behaved girl. Also on this year's roster are ''The Pink Panther,'' the 1963 comedy in which Peter Sellers first played the bumbling Inspector Clouseau and whose director, Blake Edwards, died earlier this month; as well as ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' the blockbuster ''Star Wars'' sequel whose director, Irvin Kershner, died in November (as did Leslie Nielsen, above, one of the stars of ''Airplane!''). A further distinction for the ''Star Wars'' series creator George Lucas: his 1967 short film ''Electronic Labyrinth: THX 1138 4EB,'' which spawned his first feature, ''THX 1138,'' will also be added to the registry. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Irish law prohibits all abortions except those necessary to save a woman's life, and as a practical matter it imposes daunting obstacles to terminating life-threatening pregnancies as well. In a secularized Europe, Ireland is noticeably out of step. Of the 47 countries covered by the European Convention on Human Rights, only in the fairytale countries of Andorra, Malta and San Marino, where all abortions are illegal, is the law any stricter.

Steve Boros, who died Wednesday at 74, spent half a century in baseball. He was a bonus baby, a major league infielder, a minor league M.V.P., a manager, a coach, a scout and a quiet pioneer, rarely with a high profile and sometimes at odds with what baseball expected.

Michael Cohl, the lead producer of the Broadway musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark," formally announced in a statement on Thursday that the actress Natalie Mendoza was leaving the show. Ms. Mendoza, who portrayed the mythical spider-woman Arachne in the musical, suffered a concussion in the show's first preview performance in November and had not appeared in it since Dec. 20, when a co-star, Christopher Tierney, was injured in a mid-performance accident. Word of Ms. Mendoza's exit surfaced earlier this week, but neither she nor Mr. Cohl nor the "Spider-Man" director, Julie Taymor, had commented on it at the time.

THE notion that film inspires fashion is one of the style world's hoariest clichés. But in the case of "Black Swan," in which Natalie Portman plays an ambition-maddened dancer, that chestnut bears some truth. Darren Aronofsky's Grand Guignol of a film both reflects - and anticipates - a trend in the making, its multilayered tutus, feathers and cobwebby knits attesting to a shift in the fashion wind.

With polenta, there are many ways to go. First, there's the initial decision about whether to use fine or coarse grind and white or yellow cornmeal, and the choice of liquid (water? stock?). Then we face the question of consistency (soft or firm), and finally there are all the possible mix-ins and garnishes. You see a lot of butter and cheese, for instance, and milk, cream or mascarpone are not unknown. That said, the best polenta I've ever eaten was in Venice, and it was just white corn meal and water - served with spectacular, sweet tiny gray shrimp from local waters.

While you're trying to decide whether you should spend your New Year's Day watching a Three Stooges marathon on AMC, a "Doctor Who" marathon on BBC America or a "Twilight Zone" marathon on Syfy, think of the people of North Korea, whose television options consist of state-run "news" programs. But on Sunday, The Associated Press reported, North Korean television audiences were given a rare break from this routine when the British comedy "Bend It Like Beckham" was shown there. The film, which stars Parminder Nagra as a young woman from a Sikh family with dreams of soccer stardom; Keira Knightley as her best friend; and Jonathan Rhys Meyers as the dreamy coach they both have eyes on, was shown over the weekend by the arrangement of the British Embassy. According to the BBC, a message was shown during the film saying that the broadcast was done to mark the 10th anniversary of diplomatic ties between North Korea and Britain.

The year cannot end, it seems, without a fight over the fees paid for television programming. Last year, there was an end-of-the-year dispute involving Time Warner Cable and the News Corporation. This year, Time Warner Cable is sparring again, this time with the Sinclair Broadcast Group, the owner of local stations in dozens of markets across the country. Separately, DirecTV is in down-to-the-wire negotiations with another station owner, Hearst.

While just over 15 years have elapsed since Billy Crudup made his Broadway debut in Tom Stoppard's ''Arcadia,'' the actor is moving ahead two centuries to portray another character in a Broadway revival of that play slated for next year. In the original Broadway production of ''Arcadia,'' which shuttles in time between the 19th century and the present, Mr. Crudup played Septimus Hodge, a tutor and friend of Lord Byron. In the revival, which is headed for the Ethel Barrymore Theater, Mr. Crudup will play Bernard Nightingale, a modern-day professor investigating Byron's life. Press representatives for the Broadway revival of ''Arcadia'' said on Wednesday that its cast would also feature Raul Esparza (''Speed-the-Plow'') as Valentine Coverly, a graduate student involved with Nightingale's investigation, and Lia Williams (''Skylight'') as Hannah Jarvis, an author pursuing her own research. The British actor Tom Riley (''Lost in Austen'') inherits the role of Septimus Hodge. Other cast members will include Margaret Colin (as Lady Croom), Glenn Fleshler (Captain Brice), Grace Gummer (Chloe Coverly), Edward James Hyland (Jellaby), Byron Jennings (Richard Noakes), Bel Powley (Thomasina Coverly), Noah Robbins (Gus Coverly/Augustus Coverly) and David Turner (Ezra Chater).

If you're a heavy iPhone user who also owns a PC, you've probably experienced the annoyance of having to get up from a comfy couch or an office meeting to go back from your phone to your computer for something. For 99 cents, Splashtop's new iPhone app, Remote Desktop, lets you fire up your computer's display on the iPhone. You can control apps, click and type at them, even play audio and video from your computer over the iPhone.

SCULLY--William P.,died December 25, 2010. He was born in New York City. He is survived by his wife Cecilia, sister Judith, brother Gary, many nieces, nephews, and good friends. He was predeceased by his daughter Melissa. He was retired from Haskins Laboratories. Services are private.

BAIM--Sheldon B.,84, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving wife, children and grandchildren on December 27, 2010 at his Long Island home, after a difficult bout with prostate cancer. Sheldon was born in Brooklyn, NY on May 8, 1926. He attended Lafayette High School, the University of Miami and Bucknell, served in the Navy during World War II and then joined his family as a partner at Manufacturers Corrugated Box Company. He was an honored supporter of the UJA-Federation of New York and Israel State Bonds. He was a long standing member of The New York Friars Club. He loved tennis and fly fishing, and always had a joke or story to share. Most of all, though, he cherished his family, and he was a wonderful husband of Gale, adoring father of Ilene Becker, and Jill and Michael Gold; loving and very proud PopPop (grandpa) of Alex, Peter and Madi Gold; devoted and loving brother of Carol and Walter Lieb, Carole and the late Jerry Baim, and Jerry and Judy Koch; and beloved uncle and cousin to many in his large, close-knit family. Services will be held on Thursday, December 30th at 12:30pm at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation.

Comply Foam Tips are .well, foam tips that replace the run-of-the-mill tips that come with most earbuds - those phenomenally popular products that are supposed to fit comfortably inside one's ear (the ear canal, specifically), block out ambient noise and, in a perfect audio world, enhance the sonics of the music. I picked up a set of these goodies for about $13, and the package included six tips-two small size, two medium, two large. I can't say that replacing the rubber tips on my Monster Beats Tour model earbuds with the medium Comply tips changed my life. But the difference in the sound made the music emerging from an iPod more rich and detailed, and punched up the bass in an earphone that excels in bass. They put me in my own little musical world for a time, precisely what headphones of all stripes are supposed to do.

When does football become more than a sporting event? It's not when the president comments on the redemption of a player who served prison time for a vicious felony. That's a slow news week. Nor is it when a former Super Bowl quarterback crudely hits on a young woman not his wife or girlfriend. That's an even slower news week. But when a game that was supposed to be played in a face-lacerating blizzard by bare-armed behemoths is postponed because of the weather, then it's an affront to national character.

Is the N.C.A.A. working hard to seem more transparent in its enforcement decisions, or becoming defensive? It posted a statement on its Web site Wednesday responding to criticism of its recent ruling in the case of five Ohio State players. The players were suspended for five games next season but left eligible for the Sugar Bowl on Tuesday. In the statement, the N.C.A.A. took issue with comparing this ruling to the reinstatement of Auburn quarterback Cam Newton.

Holiday shopping gave a boost to Taylor Swift last week and also helped two songs rack up big sales of digital downloads, Billboard reported. Ms. Swift's ''Speak Now'' (Big Machine) was released in October with the biggest sales of any new album in five years, and it has remained a hit. In the week that ended Sunday -- the day after Christmas -- it sold 276,000 copies, according to SoundScan, a 6.6 percent bump from the previous week. It holds at No. 1 on Billboard's chart for the second week in a row; since its release, ''Speak Now'' has been in the top spot four times and sold just under 2.9 million copies.

The John Hancock Tower, a 62-story glass skyscraper in Boston's Back Bay, was one of the first real estate trophies to run into trouble when the speculative property boom abruptly ended two years ago. With the market in free fall, Normandy Real Estate Partners and Five Mile Capital Partners bought the building at a foreclosure auction 18 months ago for $660.6 million, or about half the price in 2006.

Frances Ginsberg, an American soprano heard regularly with the New York City Opera in the 1980s, died on Friday in the Bronx. She was 55 and had lived in Manhattan and Milan. The cause was brain and spinal cancer, said, Hagai Kamil, a longtime friend. Ms. Ginsberg had previously been treated for breast and ovarian cancer.

FIELDS--Stephen H.,born on October 15, 1932 in Boston, Massachusetts, died at the age of 79 of natural causes on December 27, 2010 at his Florida residence in Del Ray Beach, in the presence of his life partner and soulmate, Pamela Neefus. Mr. Fields was one of three children of Gertrude Fitel Gershfield and Louis Gershfield, who emigrated to the United States from Russia. A resident of Hampton Bays, New York, Mr. Fields is survived by his four children, David Fields of Hoboken, Janine Fields of Philadelphia, and Claudia Rogers (Christopher), and Lizbeth Jansen (Jay) of New York, his seven beloved grandchildren, with whom he shared a joie de vivre: Camille, Andrew, Isabelle, Amelia, Theodore, Samuel, and Lily. Mr. Fields is also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Sandra and Leon Shear. A survivor of childhood cancer, Mr. Fields lived each of his days to its fullest, by serving as a devoted anchor for his family, dedicating more than fifty years to the practice of law, traveling extensively in Europe, Asia, and South America, and becoming an avid collector of fine art. As a young man, Mr. Fields graduated from Boston College and Fordham University School of Law. He was admitted to the bar in the State of New York in 1958 and became a pioneer in the field of admiralty and maritime law, practicing with the law firms of Fields & Rosen and then Stephen H. Fields & Associates. Despite numerous claims of retirement, he continued to practice law until his death. A funeral service will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, January 2, 2011 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York City. A private burial will follow on Long Island. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations are made to Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th Street, New York City, NY 10021.

A rare West African ivory mask, taken by the British during a 19th-century invasion of the city-state Benin in present-day Nigeria, was withdrawn from a Sotheby's sale after online protests, The Independent reported. The mask, which dates from the 16th century and is thought to have been worn by the king of Benin on ceremonial occasions, is the last known example of its type in private hands and was expected to fetch as much as $7 million. It was one of several items scheduled to be sold in February at Sotheby's in London by the descendants of Lt. Col. Sir Henry Gallwey, a vice consul of a British protectorate in Nigeria who took part in the 1897 invasion of Benin when the British deposed the king and burned and looted the city. They auctioned off much of their booty to pay for the offensive; several objects, including a mask similar to the one withdrawn from the auction, ended up in the British Museum.

4:15 P.M. (TMC) TWO LOVERS (2009) Joaquin Phoenix portrays Leonard Kraditor, a Brooklynite in his 30s who, after a breakup and a breakdown, lives in Brighton Beach with his parents (Moni Moshonov and Isabella Rossellini), works for his father's dry-cleaning business and dabbles in photography. Gwyneth Paltrow (above with Mr. Phoenix) is Michelle, a sophisticated, slightly unstable beauty newly arrived in Leonard's apartment building, where she is being kept by a married lawyer (Elias Koteas). And Vinessa Shaw is Sandra, the daughter of an important business associate of Leonard's father and an advantageous catch. But how can Leonard ever choose? Reviewing the film in The New York Times A. O. Scott said that this story from the director James Gray ''is modest in scale, but the feelings that run through it are large and intense.'' In the end ''the flaws in 'Two Lovers' are inseparable from its strengths,'' he added. ''You could, I suppose, criticize the movie for being too sincere; too generous to its imperfect, self-deluded characters; too absorbed in their small crises and disproportionate reactions. But that criticism might sound a lot like praise.'' 6 A.M. (Fuse) NICKI MINAJ TAKEOVER Ms. Minaj, the rapper, fills the airwaves in 20 hours of programming.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Saturday about Sally Goodrich, who established a foundation to help students in Afghanistan, misidentified the state in which she worked for a school system as a program coordinator for at-risk children. The program was in Massachusetts, in North Adams -- not in Vermont.

MORRISROE--Garyowen. The lawyers and staff of Chadbourne & Parke LLP mourn the untimely passing of our longtime partner, colleague and friend, Garyowen Morrisroe. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Susan and his children, Lauren, Daniel and Thomas, to whom he was a devoted and loving husband and father. Gary passed away peacefully in his sleep on December 22 at the age of 53, after a long illness. Widely recognized for his expertise in products liability litigation, an area in which he focused almost exclusively for more than two decades, Gary was head of the firm's products liability practice, as well as a member of Chadbourne's Management Committee. Gary played a pivotal role in some of the most noteworthy and complex products cases ever tried in U.S. courts. He was well known throughout the legal community for his longtime representation of British American Tobacco Company and other clients in landmark litigation, both in the United States and abroad. Gary joined Chadbourne as an associate in 1987 and was elected partner in 1994. Those of us who worked closely with Gary, primarily at our offices in New York and London, knew him as a remarkably gifted lawyer, a man of boundless energy, good humor, and impeccable integrity, a patient and generous mentor, and always a warm and responsive friend. Notwithstanding his dedication to his clients, the focus of Gary's life was his wife and children. He took great pride in their many accomplishments. An avid sportsman, Gary will be fondly remembered for his wit and charm, the gift of his company, and his abiding passion for literature. We will miss the warmth of his friendship, the benefit of his sharp intellect, and his grace and humility. Friends may call at Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, Connecticut on Sunday, January 2 from 3pm to 8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Michael's Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, Connecticut on Monday, January 3 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Sarcoma Foundation of America, www.curesarcoma.org. Our thoughts and prayers are with Gary's family during this most difficult time. Chadbourne & Parke LLP

BUSINESS DAY Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a decision by KCET-TV in Los Angeles that it will no longer carry PBS programming misstated the day on which that change will occur. It is Saturday, not Sunday.

As the last few days of 2010 play out, it appears that the movie box office will be down for the year, but not by much. Paul Dergarabedian, the box-office analyst for Hollywood.com, estimates that total ticket sales for 2010 will weigh in at $10.556 billion, just under the $10.6 billion posted last year, which was a record. The revenue number, as has been usual in recent years, was helped along by ticket price inflation.

WEEKEND A picture caption on Friday with the Antiques column misidentified the board game shown. It is an ancestor of Monopoly made by John Heap early in the 20th century -- not a 1933 Monopoly set painted on canvas by the game's principal early promoter, Charles Darrow. (As the column noted, the National Museum of Play in Rochester bought both sets this year.)

Simon and extend their heartfelt condolences to Marion and their sons Jonathan and Andrew. Robert E. McGill W. Reed Foster Clifford F. Boyle Robert E. McGill III
BAIM--Sheldon B. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Sheldon B. Baim. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Friars Club

MYDANICK--Stephen J. SATH, the Society for Accessible Travel and Hospitality, mourns the loss of Stephen J. Mydanick, a dedicated officer, fundraiser and passionate advocate for disability travel. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

SELIG--Marvin, an innovative steelmaker and entrepreneurial engineer, founded in 1947 and served as Chairman of Commercial Metals Steel Group. He passed away from natural causes December 27, 2010 at age 87 in San Antonio, Texas. Selig was in the vanguard of steelmakers who displaced integrated steel mills beginning in the mid 20th century and was recognized within his industry as one of its transformative leaders. Originally from Spring Valley, New York, he and his deceased wife Eleanor (Ellie) Berg Selig, pioneered, supported and lead many social, educational and political initiatives in their adopted and favored State of Texas through their goodwill, dedication and generosity. He is survived by three sons: Zachary of Los Angeles; Peter and his wife Lyn of San Antonio and Jeff and his wife Walton of Columbia, SC as well as five beloved grandchildren, a brother, Clyde, and special nieces and nephews. Predeceased by his parents Sam and Jennie Selig, sister, Hilda Selig Kirsch and in laws, Dr. Samuel and Fanny Berg, all of Spring Valley.

BERMAN--Mary. Beloved mother of Michael, David and Laura, grandmother of Daniel and Megan, aunt of 12 nieces and nephews, died peacefully December 29, 2010. A remarkable woman, artist and world traveler. Loved by everyone she met. She will be missed.

TAYLOR--Dr. Billy. I mourn the loss of my dear friend of 45 plus years. He was a devoted husband, father, and mentor to so many. A jazz pianist, composer, and educator extraordinaire, he nevertheless found time to give to others, but especially to Jazzmobile, the Kennedy Center and to his friends. It will take a while for all of us to realize this great loss, but fortunately he has left behind an amazing body of art, including over 300 musical compositions, which the world will forever appreciate. Kenneth D. Laub

Federal authorities charged another technology consultant with conspiracy and securities fraud on Wednesday in a widening investigation of insider trading. The charges were filed against Winifred Jiau, 43, a consultant for an expert-network firm, Primary Global Research. She is accused of leaking confidential information about the Marvell Technology Group and Nvidia to two money managers at different hedge funds.

FRONT PAGE A picture caption last Thursday with the continuation of an article about flaws in the official Russian inquest into the mysterious death of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a Russian lawyer who had found evidence of an enormous tax accounting fraud by police investigators, gave an incorrect identification from Reuters for the woman shown viewing his open coffin in November 2009. It was his mother, Nataliya Magnitskaya -- not his widow, Natalia Zharikova. The article also misstated the age of Valery V. Borschev, the leader of an oversight panel investigating Mr. Magnitsky's death, who suspected doctors had lied to the panel. He is 68, not 76. And because of a transcription error, the article misstated the middle initial of a prominent foreign investor in Russia who had accused police investigators of corruption, based on Mr. Magnitsky's findings. He is William F. Browder, not William S.

On Wednesday, John J. Doherty, like countless other New Yorkers, was stuck in the snow, and had to hire a couple of enterprising shovelers to remove his Chevy Tahoe from a drift in Brooklyn. It would have been an unremarkable moment, were Doherty not the city's sanitation commissioner, the man responsible for unburying the rest of us. "It was," he told The Times's Sam Dolnick, "very embarrassing." Well, perhaps he can take comfort in the fact that he's not the only one red in the face on this New Year's weekend.

Readers of The Caucus offered up more than 100 ideas for their top political moments of 2010. But the year was so chock-full of excitement that they forgot a few. So before the year ends, here are a few of our favorites.

Throughout Act One of Alexei Ratmansky's new production of "The Nutcracker" for American Ballet Theater, you're in the hands of a master. I can question perhaps 10 moments in it (the fight between soldiers and mice is relatively weak, for instance, while the concluding pose for the Snowflakes, lying back onto the floor as if exhausted, is a puzzle), and those incidental problems hardly matter. His version of the story is completely original in feeling, the whole tone of the drama frequently changes as you watch, and I have seen no work by this choreographer that better shows his powers.

In the Book Review this weekend, we asked six essayists to consider the question: What is the role of the critic today? In an accompanying feature, "Masters of the Form," we briefly surveyed, through a series of quotations, the pantheon of critics who have puzzled over this same question - Alfred Kazin in 1960, T.S. Eliot in 1923, Matthew Arnold in 1864, as well as several in between.

Speculation about a possible reunion of the Swedish pop group ABBA, perhaps the most popular band in the world during the 1970s, is bubbling up again, following remarks by two members of the quartet. In an interview published in the British magazine M, the singer Agnetha Faltskog ruled out reuniting for a full-fledged tour "like the Rolling Stones and other old bands do now," but said, "I could see us doing something together in the future," perhaps in connection with a charity event.

The N.C.A.A.'s finding that Cam Newton's father, Cecil, sought payment for his son's enrollment at Mississippi State is only the latest in a long history of "pay to play" schemes in college sports. It has caused plenty of discussion, not only over whether Cam Newton shuold be allowed to play for Auburn in the B.C.S. championship game against Oregon on Jan. 10, but also over whether players like him should be paid.
The year 2010 was a fascinating one in the hockey world. And since it's almost over, everyone who writes about hockey is required by law to do a "year in review" piece.

Hedo Turkoglu is back in a Magic uniform, and all is supposedly well again. On Thursday night Turkoglu had 17 points and 9 rebounds against the Knicks, and he scored a season-high 20 points in New Jersey only three days before. On first glance, a disappointing two-year stretch of Turkoglu's career seems to have come to a close thanks to a midseason return to Orlando; he is scoring more, handling the ball more, and has again assumed the role of a late-game shotmaker.

Oprah Winfrey's new cable network, scheduled to begin broadcasting Saturday, has announced the 10 finalists who will compete on "Your OWN Show: Oprah's Search for the Next TV Star" for the right to become hosts of a program on the network. They include Zach Anner, a travel guide who uses a wheelchair, who was involved in an online-voting controversy related to the selection of the contestants over the summer; a minister from Texas who dropped out of high school and lived on the streets; and three aspirants who want to be hosts of cooking shows.

"Superman: Secret Origin," published by DC Comics, enters our hardcover list at No. 3 this week. The six-part story, written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Gary Frank, is a retelling of the formative days of the Man of Steel - from his childhood in Smallville to his move to Metropolis. This recipe for this retelling of the super-saga contains a smidgen of the television series "Smallville" (like the brief friendship between Clark Kent and Lex Luthor) and a pinch from the 1978 "Superman" film - Mr. Frank's depiction of Superman is obviously based on the actor Christopher Reeve.

On Thursday, Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, the cinematic identical twins who claim to have come up with the original idea for Facebook, almost gave up their quest to undo their settlement with the company, as I reported in Friday's paper. It's not hard to understand their indecision. They are sitting on a deal whose value has soared along with the steep rise in Facebook shares. By some estimates, the settlement is now worth more than $140 million, so risking that amount for a chance to get more seems, well, risky.

Numerous British arts figures, including writers and pop stars, are included in Queen Elizabeth's annual honors list, which was released in London on Friday. She led the group and was designated a dame, the female equivalent of a knight, for her contributions to literature.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

This is mainly an excuse to play with some of the features of FRED, the wonderful data site of the St. Louis Fed. On the horizontal axis are quarterly averages of weekly new claims for unemployment insurance over the past decade. On the vertical axis are quarterly changes in nonfarm payrolls. If I had been more careful, I would have taken out the Census jobs somehow, or just done private payrolls. Anyway, yes there is a strong relationship. The recent fall in unemployment claims bodes well for positive job growth; however, we'd really want to see numbers in the low 300s or below; only then would we be seeing the kind of job growth needed to climb out of our deep jobs hole in any reasonable length of time.

Chrysler is recalling about 56,600 Ram 1500 pickups from the 2011 model year because the rear axle might seize. Meanwhile, Ford is recalling about 14,700 trucks and crossovers after two fires at an assembly plant, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Rapid construction of wind turbines in the Midwest will put several iconic bird species at risk, a conservation group warns. "Golden eagles, whooping cranes and greater sage-grouse are likely to be among the birds most affected by poorly planned and sited wind projects," said a spokeswoman for the American Bird Conservancy. The concept of a "holiday" is an elusive one for the over 28 million people in the United States who provide care for someone age 75 or older. A 2009 National Alliance for Caregiving/AARP study found that 88 percent of family caregivers never get a break from this full-time job. As readers here know all too well, the non-stop effort can take both a physical and emotional toll over time.

Bon Jovi was the top draw for concert audiences in 2010, a tumultuous year for the touring industry that experienced a drop in ticket grosses overall. Bon Jovi's tour, which began the year in support of its most recent studio album, ''The Circle,'' and continues on the heels of a new hits collection, had $108.2 million in ticket sales in North America, according to Pollstar, a trade publication that collects sales data from concert promoters and theaters.

(ABC) DICK CLARK'S NEW YEAR'S ROCKIN' EVE WITH RYAN SEACREST 2011 For the 39th consecutive year Mr. Clark, with the help of Mr. Seacrest, counts down to midnight from his throne above Times Square while the evening's correspondent, Jenny McCarthy, chats with revelers in the street. Fergie of the Black Eyed Peas oversees festivities in Los Angeles. Natasha Bedingfield, Jason Derulo, Drake, the Far East Movement, Jennifer Hudson, La Roux, Avril Lavigne, Mike Posner, Ne-Yo, Willow Smith and Train are scheduled to perform. 8 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) FOX LEGACY WITH TOM ROTHMAN Mr. Rothman, a chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, analyzes the making of ''All That Jazz'' (1979), the semi-autobiographical drama written (with Robert Alan Aurthur), directed and choreographed by Bob Fosse about a man confronting his mortality. (Fosse died at 60 in 1987.) Roy Scheider plays Joe Gideon, Fosse's substance-abusing, womanizing, workaholic filmmaker and choreographer stand-in. The cast includes Jessica Lange as the angel of death; Ann Reinking, one of Fosse's real-life partners, as Joe's mistress; Leland Palmer, in a nod to Gwen Verdon, as his ex-wife; and Erzsebet Foldi as his daughter. (Fosse and Verdon's own daughter, Nicole, has a bit part.) The movie earned nine Oscar nominations, winning awards for art direction, costume design, film editing and original song score.

The reasons for voting for one player for Hall of Fame induction over another are as varied as the 500-plus writers, statisticians and bloggers who vote for the Hall of Fame. Generally, a player's candidacy comes down to how a voter views the player's career record and contribution to the teams he played for. These are, not coincidentally, the areas that sabermetrics (the analytical study of baseball) is most focused on. Since I'm interested in baseball statistics and how player performance affects team win-loss totals, I lean strongly toward an analytical take on who should be in the Hall of Fame. Voters have long favored traditional benchmarks like 500 home runs and 300 wins, but as our knowledge of how player performance relates to a team's success has grown, we now see the limitations of those statistics. This is why I prefer to use Wins Above Replacement, a statistic that isolates each player's contributions to the team.

The 30-year-old founder and chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, could raise as much as $950 million from investors in the next few weeks, laying the groundwork for a multibillion-dollar initial public offering in 2011. The social buying site, which offers coupons for local businesses, has so far locked up $500 million in fresh capital from Fidelity Investments, Morgan Stanley, T. Rowe Price, and other large investors - allowing Mr. Mason and eight other directors to take a significant amount of cash off the table.

An article on Monday about Caveon Test Security, a company that analyzes answer sheets from standardized tests to identify cheating, misstated an example of a statistical threshold the company would use to identify suspicious tests. Tests with anomalous answers would be flagged as suspicious if the chance of the anomalies occurring randomly is less than one in one million, not greater than one in one million.

Less than two months before pitchers and catchers report to spring training, Major League Baseball and Anheuser-Busch said on Thursday that they had reached a new, multiple-year marketing agreement, ending an unusually public dispute between the league and one of its most prominent sponsors. The two sides agreed to drop their pending litigation in federal court, where M.L.B. contended that the two sides had signed only a nonbinding letter of intent in April to renew their sponsorship deal. Anheuser-Busch claimed that M.L.B. tried to renegotiate a deal that was completed.

7:50 p.m. | Updated The federal government said on Thursday that it was planning a complex transaction that would temporarily increase its ownership position in the former lending arm of General Motors to nearly three-fourths of the company while also paving the way to cash out its stake. The Treasury Department said it would exchange $5.5 billion of preferred stock into common shares, raising its equity stake to 74 percent, from 56 percent, of the outstanding common stock. The government, as part of its bailout of the financial system, had poured a total of $17.2 billion into GMAC, now known as Ally Financial, to stabilize the troubled auto and mortgage lender at the height of the crisis.

A new set of commemorative stamps announced by the United States Postal Service may not send your mail to infinity and beyond (barring any routing errors), but it can send your correspondence to its destination bearing the grinning lantern-jawed countenance of Buzz Lightyear. Characters from the Disney/Pixar features ''Toy Story,'' ''Cars,'' ''Ratatouille,'' ''Up'' and ''Wall-E'' will be among the entertainment figures honored on stamps that the Postal Service will begin selling next year. (The Disney/Pixar stamps, which will go on sale Aug. 19, can be seen in their entirety by clicking here or on the image above.) Other cultural-themed stamps scheduled for next year are a Latin Music Legends series (on sale in March) honoring Selena, Carlos Gardel, Carmen Miranda, Tito Puente and Celia Cruz; Helen Hayes (in April); Gregory Peck, depicted as Atticus Finch in ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' (April 29); Mark Twain (in June); and the art of Romare Bearden (September). A stamp commemorating the life of Ronald Reagan, who went from Hollywood to an even bigger spotlight, is planned for Feb. 10.

An article on Dec. 16 about the possibility of prosecuting Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, after his Web site disclosed classified government documents referred incorrectly to Wired magazine's publishing of excerpts of Internet chat logs that may be relevant to the investigation. The excerpts, recording online conversations between the main suspect in the leaks, Pvt. Bradley Manning, and an ex-hacker who turned him in, Adrian Lamo, do in fact contain references to communications between Mr. Assange and Private Manning, and to a server for uploading files to WikiLeaks. It is not the case that Wired's excerpts omitted mention of such contacts.

SAPADIN--Elmer. It is with sadness that the Sapadin family announces the passing of Elmer Sapadin on December 20, 2010 at the age of 84. Elmer, who was born in Brooklyn in 1926 is survived by his three children Randall, Michael, and Janet, as well as five grandchildren, and four nephews and four nieces. Elmer was a World War II veteran and dedicated his life to his wife Lottie and family. His second family were the inner city children where he worked as a teacher and assistant principal in Harlem for 25 years. He retired as principal of P.S. 189 in Washington Heights in 1991. Elmer was a great athlete and played soccer for a Brooklyn College championship team in the 1940's. Elmer had a passion for nature, opera, and gardening, he traveled the world including all seven continents on bird watching expeditions. Our father was our mentor. His energy and love for life was infectious. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Rest, with love his family. One of our Dads loves were the city parks, any donations in his name would be made to the City Parks Foundation. Fort Tryon Park Trust P.O Box 1044 Fort George Station New York, NY 10040.

9:02 p.m. | Updated The financier Steven L. Rattner has agreed to pay $10 million to settle civil charges that he engaged in a kickback scheme involving New York state's pension fund, ending a scathingly personal and public feud between Mr. Rattner and the New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo. Under the settlement announced Thursday - just two days before Mr. Cuomo becomes New York's governor - Mr. Rattner will pay restitution to the state pension fund and will be barred from appearing in any capacity before a public pension fund within the state for five years. He did not admit any wrongdoing.

FAVORITE paintings in New York museums? You don't have to be an art critic to have a few, or a few dozen. Winnowing these treasures down to five -- the assignment here for three critics for The New York Times -- is a pleasant, invigorating yet implicitly arbitrary endeavor. The resulting lists can only be characterized conditionally, as personal, partial or provisional. All told the city offers one of the world's great accounts of the medium. The paintings selected here range from Giovanni Bellini's ''St. Francis in the Desert,'' from 1480, in the Frick Collection to ''Do the Dance,'' from 2005, by Elizabeth Murray in the Museum of Modern Art. (The choices are on Pages 26 through 28.)

The executors of Michael Jackson's estate have condemned a coming television program that may feature a re-enactment of the singer's autopsy. The how, ''Michael Jackson's Autopsy: What Really Killed Michael Jackson,'' is to be telecast on the Discovery Channel in Britain next month. The co-executors, John Branca and John McClain, wrote to Discovery on Wednesday and asked the company to ''reconsider and cancel this program,'' Reuters reported. The representatives objected to an ad that showed a sequined glove alongside a body draped in a sheet. The ad, they said, was ''debased, sick and insensitive.''

FIELDS--Stephen H.,born on October 15, 1932 in Boston, Massachusetts, died at the age of 79 of natural causes on December 27, 2010 at his Florida residence in Del Ray Beach, in the presence of his life partner and soulmate, Pamela Neefus. Mr. Fields was one of three children of Gertrude Fitel Gershfield and Louis Gershfield, who emigrated to the United States from Russia. A resident of Hampton Bays, New York, Mr. Fields is survived by his four children, David Fields of Hoboken, Janine Fields of Philadelphia, and Claudia Rogers (Christopher), and Lizbeth Jansen (Jay) of New York, his seven beloved grandchildren, with whom he shared a joie de vivre: Camille, Andrew, Isabelle, Amelia, Theodore, Samuel, and Lily. Mr. Fields is also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Sandra and Leon Shear. A survivor of childhood cancer, Mr. Fields lived each of his days to its fullest, by serving as a devoted anchor for his family, dedicating more than fifty years to the practice of law, traveling extensively in Europe, Asia, and South America, and becoming an avid collector of fine art. As a young man, Mr. Fields graduated from Boston College and Fordham University School of Law. He was admitted to the bar in the State of New York in 1958 and became a pioneer in the field of admiralty and maritime law, practicing with the law firms of Fields & Rosen and then Stephen H. Fields & Associates. Despite numerous claims of retirement, he continued to practice law until his death. A funeral service will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, January 2, 2011 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York City. A private burial will follow on Long Island. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations are made to Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th Street, New York City, NY 10021.

THREE KINGS DAY PARADE (Thursday) Papier-mâché puppets of the kings -- from left, Melchior, Balthazar and Gaspar -- re-enact the gift-bearing visit to the infant Jesus in Bethlehem, in 12-foot designs (now in their second year) by El Museo del Barrio's artist educator Polina Porras Sivolobova, who has incorporated elements from Taíno American Indian cosmology. The symbolic gifts of a turtle in a seashell, a ceiba tree trunk and a celestial bat, along with real toys, will be bestowed on children in East Harlem participating in El Museo's 34th annual parade, with floats, musicians and live camels. It will be led by three ''honorary kings,'' recognized for leadership and dedication to building community: Lynda Baquero, correspondent for WNBC; Jesús (Papoleto) Meléndez, poet and playwright; and Julián Zugazagoitia, former director of El Museo del Barrio. The parade will begin at 10:30 a.m. at 106th Street and Madison Avenue. Registration to march is now closed, but everyone is invited to watch; (212) 831-7272, elmuseo.org. (Sunita Reddy)

MORAN--Brendan, Sr. Born August 31, 1941 in Banagher, County Offaly. He was with the New York City Fire Department for 27 years and is a retired Battalion Chief, formerly Captain of 50 Engine, Lieutenant at 28 Engine and Firefighter at Engine 93. His surviving children are Brendan Moran Jr., (Susan Resnick), Theresa Bell (Terry) and Michael Moran (Molly). Father of the late Maureen Moran. He is survived by his two grandchildren, Conor and Margaret Moran, his loving companion Lyn Porpora and many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. He was predeceased by his loving wife Margaret, his mother Bridget, his father Michael and his brothers, Daniel and Terence and sister Maureen. In his memory, please make a donation to any of the worthy causes associated with the FDNY - information on these may be found by visiting www.ufanyc.org. Mass of Christian Burial, January 3, 2010 at Visitation Church, 10am. (Bronx, NY). Services to follow at Woodlawn Crematory

MORAN--Maureen. Born January 2, 1964 in Yonkers, NY and resided primarily in Riverdale, Bronx, NY. COFIELD--Peter. Sunday Productions mourns the sudden and untimely loss of our friend and colleague. His extraordinary musical talent gave life to many television ads for companies such as Pepsi Cola, General Electric and Gillette. COFIELD--Peter, who died of a heart attack December 27 at the age of 61, is mourned by his many friends and admirers from BBDO, with whom he created memorable and award-winning commercials for Pepsi, GE, Gillette, Wrigley, Pillsbury, and Quaker Oats among many others. GOODMAN--Hyman, of Manhasset Hills died on December 19th. He was the beloved husband of Frances who died in 1986, father of Alan and Carolyn, grandfather to four grandchildren. Hy grew up in Brooklyn, attended NYU, received a JD from Brooklyn Law School, and an LLM from NYU. He joined the Army in 1942 and served in WWII. He was a member of the US Army Judge Advocate General's Corp. He was recalled from the Reserves during both the Korean War and the Berlin Crisis. He practiced law in Manhattan from 1940 until he retired in 2002 and was active in the New York County Lawyer's Association.

BLUMENTHAL--Elliott, D.,MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center community mourns the passing of our beloved and longtime former colleague, Elliott D. Blumenthal, MD, who served the patients of the hospital with great distinction for over 40 years. Elliott served in many distinctive leadership roles in the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology, including tenure as Interim Chairman. He also served for many years on the Beth Israel Medical Board, including a term as its President. He will forever be remembered for his extraordinary commitment to patient care and to the education of future physicians and he will be greatly missed by all who knew him, worked with him and were cared by him. To his dear wife Julia, his children Elliott, David and Mary, the entire Blumenthal family, and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Harris M. Nagler, MD President Louise M. Klebanoff, MD President, Medical Board Arnold J. Friedman, MD Chairman Dept. of Obstetrics & Gynecology

CHANKO--Robbin Perrie, on December 30, 2010. Beloved wife of Jimmy, loving sister of Bruce Fadem, cherished aunt and grandaunt. Noted fine arts insurance executive. She was an avid skier, golfer and lover of life. In lieu of flowers, contributions to: The American Cancer Society/ Strides Against Breast Cancer. Services 10am Sunday at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

HAUG--Dorothy H.,died peacefully on December 29, 2010 at the age of 101. Widow of the late Frederick J. Haug, with whom she enjoyed a 64-year marriage. She is survived by daughters Gretchen Stone (Hon. Lewis B.) and Hedi White (Thomas), grandchildren Pamela Stone (Jim Humphrey), Bart Stone (Irene Chae) and Timothy White (Aileen Avalos) and great-grandchildren Riley and Tanner Humphrey and Chae Caspar Stone. A native of Chicago, she was a graduate of the University of Chicago. During her single, working years, she was involved in the organization of the Museum of Science and Industry and then as Executive Secretary to Sewell Avery, Chairman of Montgomery Ward and Co., one of the greats of American Industry. When she married her beloved Fred, she relocated to New York. A life-time member of the American Association of University Women, she was an early advocate for equality of higher education for women. She and Fred resided 46 years in Manhasset, NY where she was an active member of the Congregational Church. A devoted member of The Daughters of the American Revolution, she served as Regent of the North Riding Chapter, Long Island, and as chair of the New York State National Defense Committee. Dorothy was above all a gracious lady whose intelligence and practical, sound wisdom enriched the lives of everyone who knew her. Her family will miss her greatly. Friends may call Monday, January 3, 2011 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st. Street with a service at Frank E. Campbell, on Tuesday at 11:30am.

While you're trying to decide whether you should spend your New Year's Day watching a Three Stooges marathon on AMC, a ''Doctor Who'' marathon on BBC America or a ''Twilight Zone'' marathon on Syfy, think of the people of North Korea, whose television options consist of state-run ''news'' programs. But on Sunday, The Associated Press reported, North Korean television audiences were given a rare break from this routine when the British comedy ''Bend It Like Beckham'' was shown there. The film, which stars Parminder Nagra as a young woman from a Sikh family with dreams of soccer stardom; Keira Knightley as her best friend; and Jonathan Rhys Meyers as the dreamy coach they both have eyes on, was shown over the weekend by the arrangement of the British Embassy. According to the BBC, a message was shown during the film saying that the broadcast was done to mark the 10th anniversary of diplomatic ties between North Korea and Britain. In a message on his Twitter account, Martin Uden, the British ambassador to South Korea, wrote: ''Happy Christmas in Pyongyang. On 26/12 Bend it like Beckham was 1st ever western-made film to air on TV.'' The A.P. said the North Korean broadcast of the two-hour movie was only an hour long, so please, no spoilers about the film's subplots about religion and sexuality, or which of the women Mr. Rhys Meyers character ultimately chooses.

The figure above illustrates Okun's Law -- the relationship between growth and unemployment. (Gah -- I've tried to remove the connecting lines, to no avail.) The horizontal axis shows annual growth rates of real GDP; the vertical axis shows the year-to-year change in the unemployment rate. Two things are clear. First, the economy has to grow around 2 1/2 percent per year just to keep unemployment from rising. Second, growth above that level leads to a less than one-for-one fall in unemployment (because hours per worker rise, more people enter the work force, etc.). Roughly, it takes two point-years of extra growth to reduce the unemployment rate by one point.

Michael Cohl, the lead producer of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' formally announced in a statement on Thursday that the actress Natalie Mendoza was leaving the show. Ms. Mendoza, who portrayed the mythical spider-woman Arachne in the musical, suffered a concussion in the show's first preview performance in November and had not appeared in it since Dec. 20, when a co-star, Christopher Tierney, was injured in a mid-performance accident. Word of Ms. Mendoza's exit surfaced earlier this week, but neither she nor Mr. Cohl nor the ''Spider-Man'' director, Julie Taymor, had commented on it at the time. The statement issued Thursday characterized Ms. Mendoza's departure from the musical as the actress's decision. Ms. Mendoza was quoted as saying: ''It has been a difficult decision to make, but I regret that I am unable to continue on 'Spider-Man' as I recover from my injury. I wish Julie and the cast and crew every success with this production.'' Ms. Taymor said: ''Natalie is a talented performer. We've appreciated her contributions to the show and we wish her all the best.''

The writer Charles Bock made a great many literary friendships during the years while he struggled to complete his first novel, ''Beautiful Children.'' When Mr. Bock's wife, Diana Colbert, was discovered to have leukemia and underwent a bone marrow transplant in the fall of 2009, many of those friends pitched in to offer household help. In October, Ms. Colbert's leukemia returned (she is scheduled for another transplant next month), and three of the Bocks' friends, the novelists Fiona Maazel and Mary-Beth Hughes and the writer Leigh Newman, decided they needed to help even more. ''We said everything that can be done, should be done,'' Ms. Maazel recalled. So on Feb. 6th, at P.S. 122 in the East Village, the Bock friends are throwing what they're calling ''the most literary rent party ever.'' Some 18 writers will be on hand, including Susan Cheever, Jonathan Franzen, Richard Price and Mary Gaitskill, and many of them will be auctioning off their services. Amy Hempel will walk your dog, Ms. Maazel explained over the phone. Rick Moody will write a song for you. And Gary Shteyngart will ''buy you a hot dog and flatter the pants off you.'' The Cleaver Co., a caterer, is providing its services at a discount; P.S. 122 is donating its space; and the Brooklyn Brewery is contributing free beer. John Wesley Harding, among others, will perform, and Ms. Maazel said there might some booths where for, say, a dollar a minute one could obtain literary advice.

BARITZ--Elliot M.,age 82, passed away on December 30, 2010. Those who loved and mourn him are his wife Margie, his children, Eric and Nelly, Neil and Robin, Marc and Felice, and Cindy, his grandchildren, Claudia and Bobby, Jake, Jesse, Andrew, Katie and Peter, and his great-granddaughter, Shayna. He is also survived by his brother, Lenard. Elliot was truly a gentle and remarkable man, a Phi Beta Kappa Dartmouth College graduate, a Korean War Veteran and a five day Jeopardy champion. Most recently, Elliot led the Norwalk chapter of SCORE, for which he received national accolades. Those who knew him know he never lost his way and will be missed by everyone. Services will be held on Sunday at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains, NY at 1pm.

Following a barrage of complaints by some heirs and fans of Michael Jackson, the Discovery television network on Friday ''postponed indefinitely'' its plans to broadcast a re-enactment of the singer's 2009 autopsy. ''Michael Jackson's Autopsy: What Really Killed Michael Jackson'' was scheduled to be shown in several countries in Europe, though not the United States, on Jan. 13. Jackson fans around the world last month began circulating a petition demanding cancellation the broadcast, which was being promoted with an advertisement showing a sequined glove, one of Jackson's trademarks, alongside a body draped in a sheet. On Wednesday, the co-executors of the Jackson estate wrote to Discovery to say the program was ''in shockingly bad taste'' and cited ''common sense and decency'' in urging the program be pulled from the air.

12 P.M. (OWN) OPRAH'S GUIDE TO OWN: THE NEW OPRAH WINFREY NETWORK Ms. Winfrey kicks off her latest endeavor with this hourlong primer offering her vision for the network and sneak peeks at forthcoming programming. In ''Kidnapped by the Kids,'' at 1, children stand up to their workaholic parents, as in the family above, snatching away cellphones and computers in exchange for family time. In ''Oprah Presents Master Class,'' at 2, Jay-Z shares his secret for success, turns philosophical about his triumphs and failures and discusses the greatest lesson he has learned so far. ''Enough Already! With Peter Walsh,'' at 3, follows Mr. Walsh, a professional organizer, as he helps victims of clutter free themselves of burdens both physical and emotional. In ''Searching for ...,'' at 4, the genealogist Pam Slaton guides her clients to long-lost loved ones. In ''Miracle Detectives,'' at 5, two investigators -- Randall Sullivan, who believes in the inexplicable, and Indre Viskontas, who does not -- try to provide rationales for incidents that defy logic. The inaugural programming concludes with two episodes of ''Season 25: Oprah Behind the Scenes,'' at 8 and 9, which goes backstage at Harpo Studios as Ms. Winfrey and her team put the finishing touches on the final season of ''The Oprah Winfrey Show.'' 11 A.M. PFEFFERLE--William Charles, Jr.,Ph.D., 87 beloved husband, father, scientist and inventor died December 28th. Bill's delight in problem solving and invention showed through his every action. As 3rd asst engineer he saved his ship from Nazi U-boat destruction by improvising an engine repair; he made multiple major innovations throughout his career and at age 63 he co-founded Precision Combustion where he continued to invent until his death. He held over 100 issued US patents including 7 in 2009-2010. Inventions included the ultra-low NOx catalytic combustor, Magnaforming for high octane gasoline, the Microlith catalytic reactor for fuel and chemical processing and combustion. He was inducted into the New Jersey Inventors Hall of Fame in 1990 and in 2003 he received the ACS Industrial Innovation Award. A Quaker and pacifist, he sought scientific solutions to societal problems ranging from energy efficiency to pollution to oil and gas production. His passion, creativity and insight into scientific problems inspired a host of engineers and scientists. He will be greatly missed by this wife Eleanor of 61 years and his family, friends and colleagues.

After 50 years writing criticism for newspapers, magazines and literary journals, John Simon has become a blogger. His first post is on ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.'' And -- surprise, surprise -- he's got a contrary take. Not on the merits of the show itself, which he hasn't seen. Rather, Mr. Simon, who wrote theater criticism for New York magazine and Bloomberg News, among other places, takes issue with fellow journalists who chose to write quasireviews of the musical before its official Feb. 7 opening date.

If you're traveling abroad this holiday season or in the coming cold-weather months, be sure to bring instructions for calling the United States collect. Why? On the off-chance that you'll need to call your bank or credit card issuer, you'll need to know how to call the number on the back of your card collect, assuming the issuer doesn't provide detailed collect-calling instructions. I learned this the hard way from personal experience.

BANGKOK -- Don't be fooled by the skyscrapers, the roads clogged with the latest luxury cars or the high-tech gadgetry in pockets and purses. This country of 65 million people has embraced modernity, yes, but many Thais will tell you that ghosts and spirits still wander the streets and inhabit buildings. Important business decisions often require consultations with a fortune teller. Cabinet ministers and military officers are sometimes so concerned with numerology and advice from their shamans that politics in Thailand could be called the black art of the possible. ''We still have our ghosts, we still have black magic,'' said Todsaporn Jamsuwan, the co-founder of Holy Plus, a company that makes ''spirit houses,'' the ubiquitous miniature structures that resemble dollhouses and serve as dwellings for protective ghosts.

Most people are familiar with the pay gap between women and men, but here's a gap you may not have been aware of. According to a recent post on the blog BoingBoing, lesbian women are paid more than heterosexual women. According to the research the site pointed to, lesbians make about 6 percent more than heterosexual women when factors like race, education, profession, location and number of children are accounted for.

After winning the election in November, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vowed to recruit the “best and brightest talent” to his administration. In the end, Mr. Cuomo decided he did not need to look very far. In announcing key appointments, he leaned mostly on familiarity: Many of Mr. Cuomo’s top aides in the attorney general’s office will be part of his central staff. Experience in law enforcement is another theme. His secretary, counsel, chief of staff and special assistant are all former federal prosecutors. Many stones have been thrown since we first met here in May. Some have shattered windows of received wisdom; others have bounced off walls of resistance. Some have plopped quietly into inviting ponds of assent; others have rattled down unexplored alleys of thought.

In a recent New York Times article, "Giving Alzheimer's Patients Their Way, Even Chocolate," I looked at caregiving for people with Alzheimer's disease and described how scientists and researchers are studying approaches to caregiving that appear to ease some of the most troubling symptoms, like wandering or agitated and aggressive behavior. Certain approaches to caregiving can make life more pleasant for patients, who, research suggests, continue to feel emotions like joy or sadness even if they have no memory of the experiences that caused those emotions. And they can, in turn, make things easier for caregivers, allowing people to care for relatives with Alzheimer's at home and delay placing them in nursing homes.

For ESPN, the decision to show all of the Bowl Championship Series games began to pay off when Texas Christian's 21-19 victory over Wisconsin in the Rose Bowl on Saturday generated an 11.7 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating. While the game's rating was the highest for any program on cable except for N.FL. games since 2001, it fell from what it had been on ABC, where it had 13.8 last year, a 12.6 in 2009 and a 12.1 in 2008.

LANDOVER, Md. - The Giants held on to beat the Redskins, 17-14, but their season was over when the Packers' Nick Collins intercepted a Jay Cutler pass with 10 seconds left at Lambeau Field. The Bears-Packers game was closer than a lot of people expected (the betting line kept rising during the week and settled around 10 points). Lovie Smith stuck to his word and played his starters the whole way in a 10-3 loss. The Bears knew heading into the game that they had nothing to play for, but led into the third quarter as the Packers struggled to run the ball and do much of anything on offense. The Giants did their job; it wasn't pretty, but they survived the loss of Rich Seubert to injury and finished 10-6. Now the question turns to Tom Coughlin's future. But how can you fire a coach who won 10 games? The Giants are not known for such impatience. Toni Monkovic The live analysis of the game, by Mark Viera, is below. Pregame:

Lyon, France's second largest city, is stepping out of Paris's shadow and looking toward the future with the creation of an entirely new district called Confluence, after the two rivers -- the Saône and the Rhône -- that border it. The area's gleaming new buildings are rising on a stretch of barren industrial land once home to slaughterhouses and the city's two prisons. While an art museum and a shopping mall are scheduled to open in 2011, the area is already a showcase of modern architecture, cutting-edge art and international cuisine. PLACE NAUTIQUE This huge inner harbor development brings the Saone River into the heart of the new district. Bordered by ultra-modern apartment buildings and the new Parc de Saone, Place Nautique, opened in June, is an idyllic place for a stroll and provides a stopping-off point for pleasure boats.

Three years after a National Highway Traffic Safety Administration official told me that the agency would consider permtting convex driver's-side mirrors on vehicles, the change might finally be on the horizon. Anyone who has driven a car in Europe knows these mirrors. In contrast to the United States, where vehicles must have flat (or planar) outside mirrors on the driver's side, European cars can have convex, wide-angle mirrors on both sides of their vehicles.

TARAIL--Helen, December 18, age 93. Survived by sister Muriel Kantrowitz of Del Ray Beach, FL, daughter Judy Tarail of Somers, NY, son Michael Tarail (Mary) of Holyoke, MA. Seven grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren.

Steven W. Fisher, a New York State justice who presided over the trial of two men who killed five employees of a Wendy's fast food restaurant in Queens in 2000, died on Dec. 18 at his home in Queens. He was 64. The cause was lung cancer, his son-in-law, David Kerpen, said.

LEVENTHAL--Charles, on December 31 at the age of 99. Devoted and loving father of Terry Lerman (Marvin) and the late Linda Warner. Grandfather of Scott Lerman (Tal), Stacy Masi (James) and Lisa Babcock (Rich), great-grandfather of Jake and Joshua Lerman, Emily Masi, Lindsay and Ashley Hall and Kiley Babcock. He lived a long and happy life. We will cherish many wonderful memories forever.

The University of Pittsburgh fired Coach Mike Haywood on Saturday in the wake of his arrest on a charge of domestic battery in Indiana against the mother of his child. Pittsburgh hired Haywood, who was the coach at Miami (Ohio), on Dec. 16 to replace Dave Wannstedt. Pittsburgh Chancellor Mark Nordenberg said in a statement that the decision ''reflects a strong belief that moving forward with Mr. Haywood as our head coach is not possible under the existing circumstances.'' The university said that Haywood had been informed of the decision Saturday afternoon.

KRAETZ--Howard, on December 31, 2010. Loving husband of Adele. Devoted father of Susan and Randy Deutsch and Lois and Larry Gilman. Cherished grandfather of Jessica and Alexa. Former Vice President of Dun and Bradstreet. Funeral services 1pm at "Gutterman Inc." 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.
