The heavy snowfall last Sunday caught many tourists unprepared, especially those from Asia and warmer climates. Fifth Avenue, unplowed, had a snowbank down the center with a cow path on either side. The stranded cabs didn't help, especially the one abandoned right under the crystal snowflake at 57th Street in the middle of Fifth Avenue. Even the fire trucks, on call, got stuck in front of Bergdorf's. By Wednesday, one youngster carrying a tube to play in the snow could have used it as a life preserver instead.

Only YSL can make vintage as good as new. After the success of not one but two environmentally feel-good capsule collections, New Vintage, initiated by YSL's creative director, Stefano Pilati, and Julie Gilhart, is having another go. New Vintage III's moxie is quite simple: reclaim, recycle and sustain. ''The collection is materially comprised of garments made from recycled fabric and from existing patterns instead of new ones, to start a dialogue with the market using known codes and a common language that are reassuring and familiar,'' says Pilati about the 180 pieces that will be available this week. Metallic wide leg trousers, velvet tuxedo suiting jackets and leopard-print wrap dresses with a hint of disco pay a refreshing nod to Saint Laurent's iconic 1970s designs. You'll have a second chance to finally own that missed ready-to-wear piece, and no doubt appreciate the brand's intelligent use and reuse of its existing resources. Pilati adds, ''New Vintage is meant to be part of a process, a general attempt to give a sensibility and an education to our public so that it can act consciously toward its environment.'' Today, progressive cultural shifts in consumption and sensibility seem more modern than ever.
Machines will definitely be able to observe us and understand us better. Where that leads is uncertain. HARTMUT NEVEN, a computer scientist and vision expert at Google. [1]

TO mark the 20th anniversary of Colors magazine, its winter 2010-11 issue, ''Collector,'' visits people who have amassed holdings of everything from banana stickers, pictured, to Concorde memorabilia. With the exception of the British photographer Martin Parr (political mementos), not one of the 19 collectors featured is famous, but they all see ordinary things in extraordinary ways. Sam Baron -- the French designer who is the creative director of Fabrica, the design-research arm of the retailer Benetton, which publishes Colors -- is the issue's guest editor. (Colors was founded by Tibor Kalman and Oliviero Toscani in 1991.) For his first foray into magazines, Mr. Baron said, ''I didn't want to do another design magazine, so I thought about people who love objects, then about collectors, who are mad about objects.'' GORDON--Walter H. September 2, 1926-December 28, 2010. To the rock of our family and the perfect gentleman, you will be greatly missed by your family who were your pride and joy. Walter leaves behind his loving wife Adrienne, his adored sons Gregory and Scott, daughters-in-law Erika and Beth, and his grandchildren: Ross, Andrew, Lauren, Jonathan, Samantha, and Alexandra.

An obituary last Sunday about the scholar and adventurer Frank Bessac misstated the years he worked for the Office of Strategic Services, the precursor to the Central Intelligence Agency. He was there from 1943 to 1945, not from 1945 to 1947. (The O.S.S. was dissolved in 1945.) The obituary also rendered incorrectly the surname of an American diplomat who accompanied Mr. Bessac on his journey across China. He was Douglas S. Mackiernan, not MacKiernan. (This error also appeared at least half a dozen times in articles in 1950 -- the year Mr. Mackiernan was killed while on that journey -- and once in 1954.)

KAGAN--Roderick H.,died peacefully on December 14, 2010, in Sun Valley, Idaho, after a brief illness. Rod was born on March 25, 1940, in South Orange, NJ. He grew up in Short Hills and graduated from Bernardsville High School. Rod moved to Chocolate Gulch just north of Ketchum/Sun Valley in 1975. Here he designed and built his octagon-shaped home, workshop and studio, which are now surrounded by his awe-inspiring sculpture garden. Today the Idaho columns soar 25 feet above his home while the 14-foot North Fork columns stand sentinel in front. These monumental steel columns are complemented by Rod's works in bronzetotems, benches, chairs, reclining and standing ladies, tri-points, wall sculptures and a series of bronzes that Rod numbered for each year of his age. Rod used a most personal and unusual process to create his sculptures. He did not make drawings or maquettes for casting by a foundry. After he conceived each work in his mind, he worked directly with the metal. He would sketch his designs on the metal surfaces, then cut and bend the shapes and weld the pieces together to complete his sculptures. Rod's sculptures are in private collections and public spaces throughout the United States and abroad. A collection of his sculptures is in the Boise Art Museum sculpture garden, and three totems grace the corner of Eighth and Idaho streets in Boise. In addition, an 8-foot Hanukkah menorah is at the Wilshire Boulevard Temple in Los Angeles. In 1990 Rod was an honored recipient of the Idaho Governor's Award for Excellence in the Arts; in 1984 he received a National Endowment for the Arts fellowship grant; and in 1983 he participated in the Art From Idaho exhibition at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American Art. Rod was the devoted son of the late Alfred Blanchard Kagan and Marie Hill Kagan of Jupiter, Fla. He is survived by his brother Alfred B. Kagan Jr. (Tim) and Tim's, wife, Sally, of Easton, Md., and his brother Peter H. Kagan (Pete) of Ennis, Mont., Pete's son, Andrew Kagan (Andy) and Andy's wife, Rebecca (Beckie), and Andy and Beckie's son, Wesley Kagan of Westcliffe, Colo. All are grateful to Rod's many friends for their love and support, in particular to Julie Firestone, Monica Scully and everyone at the Wood River Hospice for their care and caring. Rod was a most kind and gentle man who, when not in his shop or studio, loved to be with his friends hiking in the Sawtooths, skiing on Baldy and fishing in the Big Wood River. Rod not only created his sculptures, but also established lasting relationships and a living legacy. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Donations may be made in Rod's memory to the Hospice of the Wood River Valley, Box 4320, Ketchum, ID 83340 or to the charity of your choice.

In early 2010, as our readers were no doubt whittling down their list of New Year's resolutions, we asked them a question that is a bit more fun to contemplate: where do you want to travel this year? The question, in a multimedia presentation, accompanied our 2010 Places to Go issue.

THE NEWS A powerful storm system produced blizzard conditions up and down the East Coast for a day and a half, dumping heavy snow from the Carolinas to maritime Canada, with New York and the rest of the Northeast taking the brunt. Twenty inches of snow fell in Central Park, and some suburbs got as much as 32 inches. BEHIND THE NEWS Officials in some areas, including New York City, seemed to be caught unprepared for the storm's ferocity. Travel by air, rail or road was severely disrupted, with service shut down and passengers stranded for hours in stalled trains, packed terminals and stuck vehicles as crews struggled to cope with the snow.
WOODBURY CONTEMPORARY $1,499,999

WHAT is it about a mermaid gown that so captivates the Hollywood crowd? Swimsuit bodices and fishtail hems made their customary, um, splash on the red carpet in 2010, in an awards season that elicited as many titters as thrills. This year's ubiquitous sea creature silhouette -- Lypsinka channeling Rita Hayworth -- suggests that the stars, and their stylists, were mired in some campy vision of Hollywood's last Golden Age. But steeped in nostalgia or not, the red carpet processions still are among fashion's chief spectator sports, the style world's equivalent of the Super Bowl providing the stars with this year's most dazzling photo opportunities. Small wonder then that the savviest nominees and presenters missed no chance to play to the camera, dressed in photo-ready marvels of construction that were refreshingly free of frills.
1. Cupcake breasts (a look that even Charlize Theron, left, couldn't pull off). 2. Hedgerow brows.

A Museum of the City of New York listing in Friday's Spare Times column misstated how much it costs to go to the exhibition ''Denys Wortman Rediscovered.'' Entry is free with admission to the museum (which is $10), not $29.

IT should surprise exactly no one that the owner of every ''It'' bag, including almost 100 Birkins, is trying her hand at designing handbags. Victoria Beckham's first collection, a modest offering of just six styles ($1,800 to $13,950), focuses on a central and alluring theme: 24 hours in the life of Victoria. The pieces -- including a navy handbag in buffalo and matte calf (pictured, $3,500) -- blend Ms. Beckham's jet-set, red-carpet-friendly life with mainstream polish. Available at Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus Los Angeles and net-a-porter.com.

With an outstanding 46-save performance last Monday against Colorado, the Red Wings' Chris Osgood became only the 10th N.H.L. goalie to record 400 career victories. The debate over whether Osgood belongs in the Hockey Hall of Fame began almost at the final buzzer and was surprisingly passionate, eliciting long blog posts from each side, including one that offered a 15-point Bill James-style analysis that concluded Osgood was not Hall worthy.

When members of Elite Plus (www.expediaeliteplus.com), Expedia's frequent-guest rewards program, stay at selected properties, they are automatically upgraded on arrival, if a higher-grade suite is vacant. Since October, the online travel agency has been slowly rolling out the service, beginning at 84 hotels in Miami, Fort Lauderdale and other cities in Florida. By the end of this month, hotels in Atlanta; Charleston, S.C.; Denver; Los Angeles; Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; San Francisco; San Jose, Calif.; and Seattle will be offering the upgrades. Participating hotels display the ''VIP Access'' logo on their Expedia listings.
International TOP TEHRAN PROSECUTOR VOWS

THE notion that film inspires fashion is one of the style world's hoariest clichés. But in the case of ''Black Swan,'' in which Natalie Portman plays an ambition-maddened dancer, that chestnut bears some truth. Darren Aronofsky's Grand Guignol of a film both reflects -- and anticipates -- a trend in the making, its multilayered tutus, feathers and cobwebby knits attesting to a shift in the fashion wind. The kinky costumes in ''Black Swan'' were the brainchild of the costume designer Amy Westcott, working with Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte, a label known for its fusion of chastity and chills. The Mulleavy sisters, celebrated for their raw (and often goth-inflected) fabric treatments, conceived a look for Ms. Portman's dancer in the dark that echoes the movie's alternating moods of innocence and iniquity.

SHIMM--Robert A.,M.D. Dr. Shimm retired from the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine as a Clinical Professor Emeritus of Medicine in 1992, after 36 years on our faculty. He was an honors graduate of Columbia College and its College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1948. After postgraduate training in Internal Medicine and Cardiology at Columbia-Presbyterian, Duke University, Mount Sinai and NYU, he came to Einstein in 1956 where he organized and ran the Medical Out-patient Department. In later years he was an esteemed member of our voluntary faculty, and physician for many students, members of the Einstein faculty, their families and others. Our condolences to his wife Patricia and their children. Victor L. Schuster, M.D. Chair, Medicine Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

If you celebrate New Year's Eve in one of the city's trendy bars, you may find yourself wondering: what has happened to the once simple, relatively inexpensive pleasure of drinking? Every new restaurant or lounge I read about or venture into these days features cocktails with a list of ingredients so long and complicated that the person who assembles them can no longer bear to simply be called a bartender; he is a ''mixologist.'' ''Artisanal,'' ''locally sourced'' and ''hand-picked'' have replaced ''cold'' and ''straight up'' on drink menus, but mixologists need to remember that somewhere in the list of ingredients should be a dash of fun, or else it is all just hard to swallow.

CHECKET--Everett "Chet," peacefully departed this Earth on November 24, 2010, having given it significantly more than he ever asked or took from it. From his service in the Pacific Theater of Operations during World War II (where he rose quickly through the ranks to Lieutenant Colonel), to his international business career with Mobil Oil Corporation, where his rise was equally as swift, Chet had an uncanny ability to bridge divides and unite those both under and above him to reach whatever common goal he had been charged to achieve. Whether it was directing the prosecution of war criminals under General Douglas MacArthur (including that of General Yamashita Tomoyuki, The Tiger of Malaya), negotiating complex international shipping agreements on behalf of Mobil Oil, or testifying before the United States Congress on international trade issues, Chet's attention to detail and professionalism consistently permitted him to persevere and prosper. During his 35-year career with Mobil, he held many positions, including as a director and vice president of Mobil Oil Corporation, executive vice president of its International Division, president of its Worldwide Marketing and Refining Division, and president of its Marine Transportation and Marine Sales Division. His international experience included work in Europe, The Middle East, South Africa, the Philippines, Singapore, and Japan, which bestowed upon him the Order of the Sacred Treasure. After his retirement, he continued to consult in the international business arena and in 2001 published "Principles of Negotiation - A Primer for Intercultural Strategies". A graduate of Drexel University, Chet is a member of The Drexel 100, the university's hall of fame of alumni chosen for their lifetime achievements. He also was a lifetime honorary member of the Japan Society, as well as a member of the American Bureau of Shipping. Chet is survived by his beautiful wife, Kathleen, to whom he was married and devoted himself for over sixty years, her daughter, Dale Raggio (Nevada State Senator William J. Raggio), her grandson, David Everett Joffick, of Sydney, Australia and her great-grandsons, Thomas Joffick and Harrison Joffick, of Sydney, Australia. Over 20 years ago, Chet and Kathy founded the Checket Cup, which quickly became and remains a popular stop on the USTA's Les Grande Dames Women's Tennis Tour. The 2011 event will be held at The Tennis Club in Fort Lauderdale during the first week of February where, at 5:00pm on February 3rd, there will be a Celebration of Life honoring Chet for his contributions to women's tennis and to the world around him. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 3333 Forest Hill Blvd., Suite 101, West Palm Beach, Florida 33406 or the American Cancer Society of Broward County, Florida, 3363 West Commercial Blvd., Suite 100, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33309.

The modest American four-square home in Hope, Ark., where the 42nd president lived his first four years will become the latest National Park historic site on Sunday. The President William Jefferson Clinton Birthplace Home National Historic Site, 117 South Hervey Street, was owned by Mr. Clinton's maternal grandparents, Eldridge and Edith Cassidy. Billy, as Mr. Clinton was called, and his widowed mother, Virginia, lived there until in 1950, when Virginia remarried. He continued to spend weekends and summers there until his grandfather died in 1956.

Xue Xiang (Snow Village), Harbin Province, China, Feb. 19 We were climbing all the way up to the mountain peak, hoping that the storm would stop and we could get a panorama view of the village at dusk. It was supposed to be the most beautiful moment of the day, with the sunset and the smoke spiraling from kitchen chimneys of every cottage. Sadly, the storm didn't stop until the next morning. So we were stuck there in knee-deep snow, vision blurred, with colorfully dressed strangers and lonely trees as our company. Yiqing Wang, Beijing

MILLIKEN--Roger, One of the last in the tradition of those great industrialists who built America's manufacturing success, passed away on December 30, 2010 at the age of ninety-five. Mr. Milliken lived by ideas and principles from which he never wavered. He believed that America's manufacturing leadership was the foundation of his nation's economic achievement. His personal examples of uncompromising integrity, of hard work in any just cause, and an inexhaustible passion for excellence shone in his every undertaking. His beliefs were his commitments, whether to life-long education, to quality, to innovation, or as demonstrated in his absolute commitment to the health and safety of all of his associates. He was an unabashed patriot and an ardent Conservative. He trusted in the ability and wisdom of people acting of their own accord. His devotion to country, to community, to his associates and to his family were fully in harmony with the beliefs that guided his life. In his love of trees he found joy and beauty, and through them he expressed his commitment to the future. They were nature's gift to him, which he in turn gave to his fellow citizens. Even in the last years of his long and fruitful life, he continued to plant more trees, knowing well that they would not attain their full, noble majesty for the span of yet another very long human lifetime. Roger Milliken became President of Milliken & Company in 1947, and served as its Chairman until his death. Roger Milliken was born October 24, 1915 and was a graduate of Groton School and Yale University. He was married to the late Justine Van Rensselaer Hooper. They are survived by five children, Jan, Nancy, Roger, David and Weston and nine grandchildren.

KEATING--Gerald Maurice, 74, of Yorktown, VA, died Saturday, November 27, 2010. He is survived by his companion of many years, Nancy McBride Hogg. Gerald is also survived by his cousin Page Davis Ikard of Connecticut and by former wife Jean C. Keating of Williamsburg, VA. Gerald was a world expert on planetary atmospheres. He studied the Aeronomy of planetary atmospheres generally at altitudes above 100km where escape of the planetary atmosphere begins to occur. His experiments have been flown to Venus (Pioneer Venus and Magellan), Mars (Mars Global Surveyor, Mars Odyssey, and Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter), and Earth (Explorers 9, 19, 24, and 39). For Earth, he discovered the Winter Helium Bulge and the Cooling of the Thermosphere due to increases in CO2. At Venus, he discovered a cryosphere in the upper atmosphere and also detected the super-rotation of the upper atmosphere. In the upper atmosphere of Mars he discovered a winter polar warming of the thermosphere, determined exospheric temperatures regulating escape of the planetary atmosphere, mapped the thermosphere as a function of local solar time, latitude, season, and solar activity, detected enormous increases in the thermospheric density caused by dust storms and discovered planetary scale waves that cause variation in thermospheric density by a factor of two. He and his colleagues showed the first compelling evidence of the response of the Earth's ozone layer to solar variability. Recently he discovered strong greenhouse cooling in the Earth's thermosphere caused by the global rise of anthropogenic CO2. Some of his last ideas reflected the cooling vs heating of the atmosphere debate. Both are happening in a simultaneous fashion. The outer atmos- phere is cooling and shrinking as a result of CO2 build-up. The Ion layer shrinks and drops, gets thicker, deflects CO2 back to the surface which makes the near-surface atmosphere get thicker and hotter. The outer atmosphere shrinking was important to Gerald because that's where satellites fly. The decrease in density in the outer atmosphere affects satellite orbits. Gerald went directly to work for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Hampton, VA after schooling as a Physicist. Bitten by the "space bug" in the form of Sputnik 1, there was no other place he wanted to work. At NASA Langley, he received the top NASA award for scientific studies, the Medal for Exceptional Scientific Achievement; the NASA Langley Award for the "most outstanding paper" of 1974, the H.J. E. Reid Award; plus a number of other awards for various discoveries. As a teenager, Gerald invented an adaptation to the popcorn machine at Woolworth's that eliminated the "widows" (un-popped kernels) from the bags of popcorn sold at that chain. At the beginning of his career, he figured out the orbital mechanics for the first US communications satellite. He said he "got extra points for doing a 'dogleg' over Moscow to hear what the Russians were saying." Gerald retired from NASA Langley in 1995. Until his death, he was a Senior Staff Research Scientist at The George Washington University. After retiring from NASA, Gerald took about four months to decide he really could not play golf and he was bored. He chose The George Washington University to continue his search for discoveries. While at GWU, Gerald was Principal Investigator/Team Leader for the accelerometer experiments on MGS, MO and MRO. Gerald was the first author of the Mars Thermosphere Planetary Quarantine Model for the Viking Extended Mission. He developed the thermospheric model for the Venus International Reference Atmosphere. This VIRA model was used for Magellan aerobraking and for Pioneer Venus Operations. He was responsible for generating The International Reference Atmosphere of the Earth's Ozone for COSPAR. COSPAR is the International Committee for Space Research established by the International Council of Scientific Unions. He was Chairman of COSPAR'S Sub-commission on Planetary Atmospheres and Aeronomy and Chairman of COSPAR's Task Group on Reference Atmospheres of Trace Species. He headed the Mars International Reference Atmosphere. His bibliography includes more than 150 publications. Gerald was an adventurer, photographer and dare-devil. For many winters, he went skiing down the black diamond slopes of the Matterhorn, in Switzerland. He liked to tell people he "had been to over 100 countries and two other planets." For a month, in the 1960's, he explored and traveled down, by canoe type boat, the Orinoco River, in Venezuela, near where it connects to the Amazon River. Around that time frame, he once, in Peru, bribed (with liquor) a crop duster to fly him over Machu Picchu - an illegal act at the time - so he could look and take pictures. He also, in a similar fashion, got a flight to look at the glyphs in Chile. He took an eye-level (in a bit larger airplane) photo of Mount Everest. One stunt, even he admitted was foolhardy, was taking a picture of a tiger in a zoo in India while being on the same side of the fence as the tiger. In India, Gerald photographed the Taj Mahal, went to Tiger Tops and Lake Dahl. He went on safari in Africa. He got to Mount Kilimanjaro and the Pyramids. He photographed, up close, tree lions in Tanzania and leopards and other lions in Kenya. When he heard the border crossing had been opened in Berlin and Berliners were partying on the wall; he grabbed a flight and joined the party. Gerald walked on the Great Wall in China. One could go on about his adventures. A memorial party will be held on January 8, 2011 from 3pm to 6pm, at the Air and Space Center in Hampton, Virginia.

LOWIN--George. Passed away peacefully in New York City on December 29, 2010. He is survived by his loving wife and soulmate Erica (nee Schafran), his beloved sister Joan Davis, his trusted brother-in-law Jim Davis, his cherished nieces Rachel Davis and Leanne Smith, and the newest addition to our family Bryan Smith. George's passion for opera will be remembered by all who knew him. His support of emerging opera singers was legendary. Interment private. A Memorial Service will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in George's honor to: George London Foundation for Singers-Leonie Rysanek Award, 460 West 49th St., New York, NY 10019. Lebewohl.

The map of the quaint Ohio River town of Elgin Park indicates that, approaching from the northeast, one could drive in via Koscs Way. The street bearing my surname parallels Boundary Boulevard, which separates Elgin Park from, well, the real world. Until last winter, Elgin Park existed only in the mind of the artist and photographer Michael Paul Smith of Winchester, Mass., and in hundreds of his photos posted on Flickr. I became one of millions around the world (23 million at last count) to visit Mr. Smith's ''town,'' which was inspired by his childhood memories of growing up in 1950s Sewickley, Pa., north of Pittsburgh. Last March, I wrote about Mr. Smith and his Internet phenomenon for The New York Times.

''CATS actually have good body proportions for clothing, and they're adorably photogenic,'' said Thuy Pham, who with Miho Aoki designs United Bamboo. Don't expect a line for felines anytime soon -- even one just for the Japanese market. But the duo has brought back its Cat Calendar for this year ($50 at unitedbamboo.com), which includes feline models in beaded and sequined gowns and puffy parkas. Even though the calendar's subjects are a little untraditional, Ms. Aoki and Mr. Pham didn't cut corners on production. ''We went through the same process really as producing a look-book,'' Mr. Pham said. ''Casting director, photographer, stylist. No hair or makeup, though. That would be taking it too far!'' Meow! 8 P.M. (Cinemax) GREENBERG (2010) In what A. O. Scott called Noah Baumbach's ''funniest and saddest movie'' so far, ''and also the riskiest,'' Ben Stiller, above, plays Roger Greenberg, a 40-year-old former musician who, after a mental breakdown, house-sits in the large Los Angeles home of his vacationing brother. Greta Gerwig portrays Florence Marr, Roger's brother's 25-year-old assistant and Roger's on-again, off-again love interest in his quest to recapture his youth. ''Mr. Stiller, suppressing his well-honed sketch comedian's urge to wink at the audience, turns Roger into a walking challenge to the Hollywood axiom that a movie's protagonist must be likable,'' Mr. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times. ''But Mr. Baumbach, relishing his antihero's obstinate difficulty -- which is less an inability to connect with other people than a stubborn refusal, on hazy grounds of principle, to try -- treats Roger with compassion, even tenderness.'' Only at the end does Mr. Baumbach reveal that the film has been ''a romantic comedy all along,'' Mr. Scott said. ''And suddenly a movie about a man who is defiantly difficult to like becomes very hard not to love.'' 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION The topic is the new Congress. Representatives Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota; Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida; Anthony Weiner, Democrat of New York; Darrell Issa, Republican of California; and Mike Kelly, Republican representative-elect of Pennsylvania, discuss.

RAWN--Stanley R.,Jr. died at home on December 25, 2010. He was an entrepreneur and a Trustee of the California Institute of Technology. He was much beloved by family and many friends. He was a truly kind and generous person with a wonderful sense of humor and a great zest for life. He was an avid tennis player. Life brought him many opportunities, and he had the talent, work ethic and tolerance for risk required to capitalize on them. He was born in Duluth, Minnesota in 1928 to Stanley and Violet Rawn. He joined the Navy at age 17 and left to receive BS and MS Degrees in Chemistry and Chemical Engineering from Cal Tech. After working as a research engineer for Chevron Research Corporation, he left to co-found a series of oil exploration companies, including Pan Ocean Oil Corporation, with his longtime partner Louis Marx, Jr. He was subsequently involved in venture capital investments. He is survived by his wife Barbara, his children James, Robert, and Carol Lee, eight grandchildren, and his sister Ralcie Ceass. A Memorial Service will be held in March. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to: First Congregational Church, 108 Sound Beach Avenue, Old Greenwich, CT 06870 or Team Heart www.teamheart.org or Greenwich Hospice, 201 W. Putnam Ave., Stamford, CT 06902.

A certain house in the Buenos Aires neighborhood of Recoleta has a window that is doubly privileged. It overlooks a courtyard garden of the kind known here as a pulmón de manzana -- literally, the lung of a block -- which affords it a view of the sky and an expanse of plants, trees and vines that meander along the walls of neighboring houses, marking the passage of the seasons with their colors. In addition, the window shelters the library of my late husband, Jorge Luis Borges. It is a real Library of Babel, full of old books, their endpapers scribbled with notes in his tiny hand. As afternoon progresses and I look up from my work to gaze out this window, I may be invaded by springtime, or if it's summer, by the perfume of jasmine or the scent of orange blossom, mingled with the aroma of leather and book paper, which brought Borges such pleasure.
Television Mike Hale

SAPADIN--Elmer. It is with sadness that the Sapadin family announces the passing of Elmer Sapadin on December 20, 2010 at the age of 84. Elmer, who was born in Brooklyn in 1926 is survived by his three children Randall, Michael, and Janet, as well as five grandchildren, and four nephews and four nieces. Elmer was a World War II veteran and dedicated his life to his wife Lottie and family. His second family were the inner city children where he worked as a teacher and assistant principal in Harlem for 25 years. He retired as principal of P.S. 189 in Washington Heights in 1991. Elmer was a great athlete and played soccer for a Brooklyn College championship team in the 1940's. Elmer had a passion for nature, opera, and gardening, he traveled the world including all seven continents on bird watching expeditions. Our father was our mentor. His energy and love for life was infectious. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Rest, with love his family. One of our Dads loves were the city parks, any donations in his name would be made to the City Parks Foundation. Fort Tryon Park Trust P.O Box 1044 Fort George Station New York, NY 10040.

Last week, it was perfectly legal to walk into a Chicago smoke shop and buy any variety of K2 incense, a synthetic marijuana product. At 12:01 a.m. Jan. 1, it became a felony offense to buy, sell or possess the drug. But the authorities worry the ban will not be effective for long. K2, which is increasingly popular with high school and college students, is little known to anyone older than 25. Its chemical-laced herbs are sold online and in stores as incense ''for aromatherapy and intense meditation,'' as one distributor puts it. In reality, users smoke K2 products because they contain one or more chemicals developed to mimic the effects of THC, the active ingredient in marijuana.
ERTEL--Robert. Our wonderful happy years together will always be in our thoughts. You were our special friend. Our love to Rita, Laura, Michel and Andrew. Naomi and Freddy

GONZALEZ-RAMOS--Dr. Gladys Maria on December 22, 2010; age 56. A native of Cuba, Gladys was the beloved wife of Ernesto Loperena, loving sister of Juan C. Gonzalez and aunt to Juan Carlos, Christina and Victoria Gonzalez, beloved niece to Mercedes and Jorge Ramos, a loving cousin, and a devoted friend to Elaine V. Cohen and many others. A gifted teacher and mentor, Gladys was Associate Professor of Social Work at the NYU Silver School of Social Work and Adjunct Associate Professor of Neurology at the NYU School of Medicine. Her interests spanned mental health, delivery of care to Hispanic children and families, mothers' cultural child-rearing values, the role of social work, interdisciplinary team training and care delivery in Parkinson's Disease (PD). She developed/taught social work study in Puerto Rico, co-developed a disability curriculum for health professionals and an elective on the impact of chronic and neurological illness on individuals/families, and co-led a program for Hispanic immigrant children in NYC schools. Inspired by her parents' experiences (her father was caregiver to her mother who had Parkinson's), Gladys became a national leader in PD. Consultant to the National Parkinson Foundation (NPF), she co-developed NPF's two signature programs: Allied Team Training for Parkinson (ATTP), training social workers, physicians, nurses and allied health professionals across the US about PD, and a national outreach program for diverse/medically underserved communities to access PD information, resources and care. Co-founder of the NYU Parkinson & Movement Disorders Center, she co-developed the NYU/JCC in Manhattan Parkinson's Wellness Program. Her work was imbued with intelligence and passion, coupled with warmth, wit, a genuine caring about people and an unparalleled love for family and friends. We are blessed with many wonderful memories and will continue her legacy to expand access to social work services and improve care for PD families. Donations can be made either to: The Gladys Gonzalez-Ramos Memorial Lecture Fund to educate social workers/other professionals (check payable and sent to the NYU Silver School of Social Work; 1 Washington Square North, New York, NY 10003) and/or the Gonzalez-Ramos Community Lecture Series to educate PD individuals/families (check payable to NYU Parkinson & Movement Disorders Center; Send to NYU Development Office, One Park Avenue, 17th floor, New York, NY 10016: Attn: Colby Collier). A Memorial Service will be held at Grace Church in Manhattan (Broadway and 10th Street) on Saturday, January 29, 2011 at 11am. May her memory be a blessing.

SHIMM--Robert A.,M.D. Dr. Shimm retired from the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine as a clinical Professor Emeritus of Medicine in 1992, after 36 years on our faculty. He came to Einstein in 1956, where he organized and ran the Medical Outpatient Department. In later years he was an esteemed member of our voluntary faculty, and physician for many students, members of the Einstein faculty, their families and others. Our condolences to the entire Shimm family. Victor L. Schuster, M.D. Chair, Medicine Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

VOJTA--George J. Born November 13, 1935, died peacefully on December 22, 2010. He is survived by his wife, Susan Hubbard, sons Christopher and Timothy, grandchildren George II, Charles and Grace, and daughters-in-law Deneen and Amber. He received Bachelors and Masters Degrees from Yale University. He spent most of his career at Citigroup -- then First National City Bank -- where he rose to Executive Vice President. Most notably, he ran Strategic Planning and the International Division. The remainder of his career was spent at top-tier financial institutions, in particular Bankers Trust, where he was Vice Chairman of the Board. He was known for his expertise in financial strategy and risk management. In addition, he played a prominent role in the restructuring of the global financial system and banking reform following the financial crises of the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s, consulting with the World Bank, the Bank for International Settlements, and individual countries. He also served as a board member of many distinguished enterprises, including: Northwest Airlines, Private Export Funding Corporation (PEFCO), Miles Laboratories and Urstadt-Biddle Properties. He was also a Director of the New York State Banking Board, Member of the Council on Foreign Relations, Fellow of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, Chairman of the Financial Institutions Center of the Wharton School and Board Member of International Executive Service Corps. He was Chairman of the Board of the Yale Center for Corporate Governance & Performance, a Trustee of Lawrence Hospital, Founding Board Member of the Bronxville School Foundation, Chairman of the Bronxville Public Schools Long Range Planning Committee, Chairman of the Investment Committee for Sarah Lawrence College and member of the board of St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital. He advocated for financial standards and corporate reform throughout his career, writing numerous books and articles. His most well-known publications include the article "Bank Capital Adequacy" in 1974, the book "Beyond Human Scale" co-authored with Eli Ginsberg in 1983 and the book "Globalization for All" in 2010. After he retired, he founded the eStandardsForum, a formal platform for his advocacy. He was an avid golfer, fisherman, hunter and piano player. He was a member of The Blind Brook Club, Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club, The River Club, Siwanoy Country Club and The Lost Tree Club. He leaves behind a legacy of compassion and service. His family and friends will miss him. A Memorial Service will take place at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, January 29 at 11:00am In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent in his name to the following: The Lawrence Hospital Cancer Center 55 Palmer Avenue Bronxville, NY 10708.

As I lay in savasana at Yoga High on the Lower East Side, intoxicated by the sound of a bluesy harmonica, it struck me that yoga and music belong together, like a popping fire on a snowy day. Not everyone agrees. Musical taste is overwhelmingly subjective (a Boy George oldie during pigeon pose is not easily forgiven) and pacing is critical (a hip-hop warm-up is too fast, too soon). And there is nothing inherently wrong with silence - the music of choice for many traditionalists. It helps focus the breath and settle the mind, and some slower-moving forms of yoga, like Iyengar, demand it.

EISENSTADTER--Herta (Herti), 88 years old, died peacefully in New York City on December 28. Born in Vienna, Austria on April 28, 1922, she came to the US in 1939 as a teenager. She became an expert seamstress, craftswoman, and eventually owned her own store, Reflections, a boutique for women who had had mastectomies, and ran it for many years. She was married to Alfred for 58 years and is survived by her two children, Peter and Ingrid, and three grandsons: Liberty Thomas McAteer, and David and Matthew Eisenstadter. She was strong, compassionate, and friendly to everyone. She maintained her independence and sense of humor until the day she died, surrounded by her family. There is no better example of a life well-lived, with grace, humor, simplicity, strength, skill and love.

Neuberger - our gregarious supportive friend; visionary museum founder; humanist; activist promoter of the as-yet unsung talented artist; brilliant passionate collector; enthusiastic educator to those of all ages; and generous patron. FISHER--Janet Cane, the widow of Avery Fisher, passed away in New York on December 28th, at the age of 94. Raised in Tuckahoe, New York, she graduated from Goucher College in 1938. On a return trip to Goucher from Grand Central Station, she met Avery who happened to be there with friends. He was so taken with her that he proceeded to call every "Cane" in the Westchester phone book until her found her. They were married on August 9, 1940. Janet was an accomplished and dynamic woman who dedicated her life to the causes she believed in. She was a Board Member of the 92nd St. Y for over 50 years, and a Board Member of Young Audiences Inc., Children's Orchestra Society, City Meals-on-Wheels, and The New Milford Hospital Foundation. She established the Janet and Avery Fisher Music Residency program at Goucher College. Janet and Avery were frequently seen at concerts at Lincoln Center. Classical music was a shared passion. She had warm relationships with many of the young musicians who received Avery Fisher Career Grants or the coveted Avery Fisher Prize. Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax gave private birthday "concerts" for her twice, true highlights in her life. Janet loved their Washington, CT home and spent many hours in her gardens. She created beautiful dried flower arrangements and gave them as gifts to her friends. When she was in her seventies, Janet was spotted by a modeling agent as she was bringing an armload of lilacs to her physician. The agent insisted that she was the perfect face for a GAP ad. Janet became the one and only senior citizen to be so featured. True to form, she donated her fee for this work to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, encouraging awareness of a cause not yet in the public consciousness at the time. Janet is survived by her beloved children, Barbara, Nancy (Marc), Chip (Susan), five grandchildren: Christopher, Philip, Diana, William, and Matthew, and her step-sister Betty. Funeral services will be private. A memorial will be held at a later date. Donations may be made to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts for the benefit of the Avery Fisher Career Grants or to the 92nd Street Y Nursery School.

He is survived by his four children; Peter Hitchcock Stephaich, Paul Mellon Stephaich, Peggy Hitchcock Guinness and Pauline Mellon Stephaich; and his two grandchildren, Andrea Daher Stephaich and Laura Daher Stephaich. Lewis B.) and Hedi White (Thomas), grandchildren Pamela Stone (Jim Humphrey), Bart Stone (Irene Chae) and Timothy White (Aileen Avalos) and great-grandchildren Riley and Tanner Humphrey and Chae Caspar Stone. A native of Chicago, she was a graduate of the University of Chicago. During her single, working years, she was involved in the organization of the Museum of Science and Industry and then as Executive Secretary to Sewell Avery, Chairman of Montgomery Ward and Co., one of the greats of American Industry. When she married her beloved Fred, she relocated to New York. A life-time member of the American Association of University Women, she was an early advocate for equality of higher education for women. She and Fred resided 46 years in Manhasset, NY where she was an active member of the Congregational Church. A devoted member of The Daughters of the American Revolution, she served as Regent of the North Riding Chapter, Long Island, and as chair of the New York State National Defense Committee. Dorothy was above all a gracious lady whose intelligence and practical, sound wisdom enriched the lives of everyone who knew her. Her family will miss her greatly. Friends may call Monday, January 3, 2011 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st. Street with a service at Frank E. Campbell, on Tuesday at 11:30am.

SEOUL, South Korea -- In an annual New Year's commentary that is widely seen as an indicator of the country's political and economic goals for the coming year, North Korea on Saturday called for dialogue with South Korea and a relaxation of tensions ''as soon as possible.'' ''If a war breaks out on this land, it will bring nothing but a nuclear holocaust,'' said the editorial, carried in the leading official newspapers in the North and read on state television there. The commentary, which called for ''an atmosphere of dialogue and cooperation'' with the South, was reported by local news agencies in Seoul.

In McIntyre v. Ohio Elections Commission (1995) the Supreme Court overturned a statute requiring any person who prints a notice or flyer promoting a candidate or an issue to identify the communication's author by name. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the majority, grounded his opinion in an account of meaning he takes from an earlier case (First National Bank of Boston v. Bellotti): "The inherent worth of . . . speech in terms of its capacity for informing the public does not depend upon the identity of its source, whether corporation, association, union, or individual." Or, in other words, a writing or utterance says what it says independently of who happens to say it; the information conveyed does not vary with the identification of the speaker.

The New York theater company Naked Angels, which develops new plays and had its first production on Broadway last year with the drama "Next Fall," announced on Monday that Andy Donald would succeed Geoffrey Nauffts as artistic director in July. Mr. Donald, a theater director and producer, has been associate artistic director of Naked Angels since April 2009. Mr. Nauffts, an actor, director, and long-time company member of Naked Angels, became artistic director in September 2007 but soon found himself celebrated as a writer for "Next Fall," his first play. The Naked Angels production of "Next Fall" had a critically acclaimed run Off Broadway in 2009, then transferred to Broadway the next year. While receiving strong reviews there as well as Tony Award nominations, including for best play, the production was not a commercial success and ran for about five months. Mr. Nauffts said in a statement that he planned to continue to write and direct for Naked Angels, and advise on artistic matters as a board member. Mr. Donald, the founding artistic director of the Charlie B. Theater Company in Los Angeles, said in the statement that he looked forward to bringing new writers and others into the company. Among the company's offerings this season is the world premiere of the play "A Long and Happy Life," by Bekah Brunstetter, and another world premiere, "Outside People," by Zayd Dohrn.

LOS ANGELES - "I am now an attorney of record in the case." So said Martin Garbus, in a brief phone conversation after a closed-door hearing Monday in the child custody dispute between Mel Gibson and his former girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva. Mr. Gibson's lawyers had opposed a request by Mr. Garbus, who is from New York, to be allowed to represent Ms. Grigorieva in the Los Angeles County Superior Court case. They cited, among other things, his public remarks about the dispute during a November interview on one of Larry King's final televised interview shows for CNN. On the program, Ms. Grigorieva described how she had recorded Mr. Gibson's obscene rants to her because she feared he might kill her. Mr. Garbus, who appeared with her on the program, had said that Mr. Gibson did not want to pay any support for his daughter with Ms. Grigorieva.

Rounding out the Bagger's day of "things you may have missed in The New York Times" - give us a break, we're probably suffering from social jet lag - is the awards season best-ofs from our colleagues. A. O. Scott praises Natalie Portman in "Black Swan," for "participating in the invention of a new kind of screen performance." As Nina, the unraveling ballerina, she inverts Method acting to tell a story about the artistic interplay of "instinct and technique" - which is, at its heart, what the movie is about. Manohla Dargis writes that in one minute of screen time, Christian Bale summons his character's entire life in "The Fighter." Stephen Holden calls Colin Firth's performance as a stammering monarch in "The King's Speech" "a tour de force of body language concentrated on the eyes and mouth." And Larry Rohter takes stock of the humbleness of Javier Bardem in "Biutiful." There's all that and more, including the critics' lists of those they think should be nominated. Worth catching up while we recover/wrangle some outside material.

Aside from a good straight-razor shave, grooming doesn't offer a man many indulgences. But there's one simple luxury that should be in every dopp kit: a great bar of soap. The latest specimens to catch my eye are black - they smell of earth and ash and their color gives them a primal ruggedness, as if you're back in the cave, washing yourself with mud. They don't, counterintuitively, lather black. The way this nonchemist understands the science is that the particles in these bars aren't actually black but completely opaque, and when they're compressed into soap, no light gets in. No light equals black. But never mind all that. Let's suds them up.

Roni Brunn and Olena Sholomytska, the duo behind Thursday Friday, were looking to create a bag that could be used for everything, including the groceries, when inspiration hit. The Israeli artist Absalon died in Paris in 1993 at age 28. But before his untimely death, he produced a large body of work, including six tiny all-white dwellings that he wanted to install in downtown Tokyo, Paris, Zurich, New York, Tel Aviv and Frankfurt. The artist designed these "Cellules" (cells), as he called them, to fit his precise dimensions in a totally scaled-down living environment so that he would, in his own words, be "obliged to live my ideas." Now, the KW Institute for Contemporary Art (Auguststrasse 69; 49-30-243-4590; www.kw-berlin.de) has brought together all six cells under one roof.

SIMON--Abdallah H.,88, on January 1, 2011. Beloved husband of Francine (Iny), father of Jamil and Michael, father-in-law of Julia Reidhead, grandfather of Lucy, and brother of Rachel Sopher and Juliette Elias. Ab's warmth and generosity of spirit touched family, friends, colleagues, acquaintances, and all who crossed his path. Abdallah (or "Ab" as he became known) was born in Baghdad, Iraq and graduated from university at 17. He emigrated to the U.S. in 1944 at age 21 and served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Army in occupied Germany. After discharge, from a job with a small wine importing company, Ab built a remarkable career in fine wines that culminated in the 1970's with his founding of the Chateau & Estate Wines division of Seagram, which became the largest importer of fine French wines in the U.S. During his 29 years at Seagram's Chateau & Estate, he became the dominant figure in the fine wine business on both sides of the Atlantic, and in 1980, the French government awarded him the Legion of Honor medal to recognize his contributions to the French wine industry. He treated others fairly and with respect. His word was his bond, and his agreements with suppliers were sealed by handshakes, not written contracts. He championed many causes in Israel among them the Tel Aviv Foundation and Hebrew University, and was involved with many other charitable activities. Ab's greatest joy was his family, both immediate and extended. Services at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 11:15am, Tuesday, January 4th.

VOJTA--George J. Born November 13, 1935, died peacefully on December 22, 2010. He is survived by his wife, Susan Hubbard, sons Christopher and Timothy, grandchildren George II, Charles and Grace, and daughters-in-law Deneen and Amber. He received Bachelors and Masters Degrees from Yale University. He spent most of his career at Citigroup -- then First National City Bank -- where he rose to Executive Vice President. Most notably, he ran Strategic Planning and the International Division. The remainder of his career was spent at top-tier financial institutions, in particular Bankers Trust, where he was Vice Chairman of the Board. He was known for his expertise in financial strategy and risk management. In addition, he played a prominent role in the restructuring of the global financial system and banking reform following the financial crises of the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s, consulting with the World Bank, the Bank for International Settlements, and individual countries. He also served as a board member of many distinguished enterprises, including: Northwest Airlines, Private Export Funding Corporation (PEFCO), Miles Laboratories and Urstadt-Biddle Properties. He was also a Director of the New York State Banking Board, Member of the Council on Foreign Relations, Fellow of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, Chairman of the Financial Institutions Center of the Wharton School and Board Member of International Executive Service Corps. He was Chairman of the Board of the Yale Center for Corporate Governance & Performance, a Trustee of Lawrence Hospital, Founding Board Member of the Bronxville School Foundation, Chairman of the Bronxville Public Schools Long Range Planning Committee, Chairman of the Investment Committee for Sarah Lawrence College and member of the board of St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital. He advocated for financial standards and corporate reform throughout his career, writing numerous books and articles. His most well-known publications include the article "Bank Capital Adequacy" in 1974, the book "Beyond Human Scale" co-authored with Eli Ginsberg in 1983 and the book "Globalization for All" in 2010. After he retired, he founded the eStandardsForum, a formal platform for his advocacy. He was an avid golfer, fisherman, hunter and piano player. He was a member of The Blind Brook Club, Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club, The River Club, Siwanoy Country Club and The Lost Tree Club. He leaves behind a legacy of compassion and service. His family and friends will miss him. A Memorial Service will take place at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, January 29 at 11:00am In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent in his name to the following: The Lawrence Hospital Cancer Center 55 Palmer Avenue Bronxville, NY 10708.

8 P.M. (IFC) MONTY PYTHON AND THE HOLY GRAIL (1975) Partly financed by the rock bands Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin, this movie spoofs the legend of King Arthur (Graham Chapman) and his knights in their quest for the Holy Grail. When it came time to begin shooting, there was not enough money for horses, so coconuts were used to simulate the sound of their hooves. An argument in the first scene over how coconuts could have wound up in medieval England sets the style and logic of the film. The Python troupe members Terry Gilliam (above right, with Chapman) and Terry Jones shared directing duties and played multiple characters, as did the others: John Cleese, Eric Idle, Michael Palin and Chapman. In the original conclusion King Arthur was to have arrived at Harrods, the London department store, where he would have found a large selection of grails at the grail counter. This was ultimately abandoned for a more chaotic ending in which some of the principals are rounded up by modern-day police officers. 8 P.M. WASHINGTON -- Soon after the 112th Congress convenes Wednesday, Republicans in the House plan to make good on a campaign promise that helped vault many new members to victory: voting to repeal President Obama's health care overhaul. The vote, which Republican leaders pledged would occur before the president's State of the Union address later this month, is intended both to appeal to the Tea Party-influenced factions of the House Republican base and to emphasize the muscle of the new party in power. But it could also produce an unintended consequence: a chance for Democrats once again to try their case in support of the health care overhaul before the American public.

BAER--Fernand Ben Jr. ("Tony"). Born October 10, 1935, Tony Baer died at his home in New York City on Tuesday December 28, 2010. Raised in St. Paul Minnesota, he served in the U.S. Army and was national President of the Young Republicans under Dwight Eisenhower. After attending the University of Minnesota, he boarded a bus with eighteen dollars in his pocket and went to New York City where he would spend the rest of his life. His career in the investment industry spanned 50 years in association with firms such as Andresen & Co., Hambrecht and Quist, Unterberg & Towbin, and Allen & Company. He was one of the original venture capitalist investors in Cray Research and Data General and founded his own investment firms Baer & Co. in 1983 and the Wellesley Capital Group in 1998. Tony was an avid collector of the French artist SEM and was a member of many clubs around the world. He was also a sponsor of the opera, the ballet, and the theater of New York City. He is survived by his son Brandon, his sister Barbara, and his two grandchildren Natalie and Dylan. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday January 25th 5:30 to 7:30pm, at the University Club, One West 54th Street.

BAIM--Rose, 92, of Great Neck, NY died Saturday January 1, 2011 in Hartford CT. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, great-aunt, gave selflessly to both her family and the community. Youngest daughter of Nathan Diamond and Sarah Polikoff, was born May 21, 1918 in New Haven, CT. Rose began a career as a bookkeeper for the Centre Box Company at the age of 18. Years later she fell in love with the principal of the company, Maurice Baim, and they married in 1953. She continued to work with him for the rest of their life together until his death in 1982. They lived in Great Neck NY and raised three children. During World War II, she volunteered for the Red Cross to aid the war effort. She was treasurer for the North Shore Hebrew Academy in Great Neck for many years, and played an important role during the formative years of the school. She also volunteered and served as treasurer for the Women's League for Israel Great Neck Chapter, and was honored by the organization for her years of dedicated service. She is survived by her sons Steven and Neil, daughter Marlene and son-in-law Michael, grandchildren Lily, Max, Ari and Liam, and her sister Anne.

Wrestling is taking over another hour of cable television. World Wrestling Entertainment will announce Monday that it is resurrecting ''WWE Tough Enough,'' a competition to cast a new member of the organization's roster. The program was retired by MTV in 2003, but the USA network is bringing it back and pairing it with the hit franchise ''Monday Night Raw.'' The return of ''Tough Enough'' deepens WWE's relationship with USA channel's parent, NBC Universal, the media company that Comcast is on the cusp of acquiring. For years, USA has been the home of ''Raw,'' and last year the Syfy Channel became the home of ''Friday Night Smackdown.'' WWE executives have spoken publicly about wanting to start a cable channel, and the relationship with NBC and Comcast may prove useful.

MILLIKEN--Roger, One of the last in the tradition of those great industrialists who built America's manufacturing success, passed away on December 30, 2010 at the age of ninety-five. Mr. Milliken lived by ideas and principles from which he never wavered. He believed that America's manufacturing leadership was the foundation of his nation's economic achievement. His personal examples of uncompromising integrity, of hard work in any just cause, and an inexhaustible passion for excellence shone in his every undertaking. His beliefs were his commitments, whether to life-long education, to quality, to innovation, or as demonstrated in his absolute commitment to the health and safety of all of his associates. He was an unabashed patriot and an ardent Conservative. He trusted in the ability and wisdom of people acting of their own accord. His devotion to country, to community, to his associates and to his family were fully in harmony with the beliefs that guided his life. In his love of trees he found joy and beauty, and through them he expressed his commitment to the future. They were nature's gift to him, which he in turn gave to his fellow citizens. Even in the last years of his long and fruitful life, he continued to plant more trees, knowing well that they would not attain their full, noble majesty for the span of yet another very long human lifetime. Roger Milliken became President of Milliken & Company in 1947, and served as its Chairman until his death. Roger Milliken was born October 24, 1915 and was a graduate of Groton School and Yale University. He was married to the late Justine Van Rensselaer Hooper. They are survived by five children, Jan, Nancy, Roger, David and Weston and nine grandchildren.

Oprah Winfrey said that she wanted to create a cable network without a trace of ''mean-spirited'' programming, and she has wrung every drop of it from the Oprah Winfrey Network. The unveiling of her 24-hour cable network, OWN, which began at noon on New Year's Day, was most striking for what it lacked: nowhere in that opening gush of feel-good highlight reels, self-improvement plans, spiritual quests, aha! moments, celebrity master classes, and people finding their truths and living their own best lives was there a snicker of malice or a hint of raillery. At times, it seemed almost like a comical conceit, like those movies that pivot on the sudden disappearance of a basic pillar of life, ''Death Takes a Holiday'' or even ''The Invention of Lying.''

''The Daily Show'' could soon return to Hulu, the premier Web site for television viewing. The show and its counterpart on Comedy Central, ''The Colbert Report,'' were removed from Hulu in early 2010 when the two parties could not agree on a fair price for distribution.

The deal could double the personal fortune of Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's co-founder.Facebook, the popular social networking site, has raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and a Russian investor in a deal that values the company at $50 billion, according to people involved in the transaction. The deal makes Facebook now worth more than companies like eBay, Yahoo and Time Warner. The stake by Goldman Sachs, considered one of Wall Street's savviest investors, signals the increasing might of Facebook, which has already been bearing down on giants like Google. The new money will give Facebook more firepower to steal away valuable employees, develop new products and possibly pursue acquisitions - all without being a publicly traded company. The investment may also allow earlier shareholders, including Facebook employees, to cash out at least some of their stakes.

SHANNON--Philip Jr.,72, retired co-founder and CEO of loan software firm Online Financial Corporation and president of the Philip and Mary Shannon Foundation, died suddenly on December 30 at his vacation home on Lake Lanier. Services will be held 2:00pm on Wednesday, January 5 at St. Peter Chanel Catholic Church in Roswell, Georgia with the Reverend Father Peter Rau officiating. Mr. Shannon was born April 24, 1938 in Bayonne, New Jersey. He graduated in 1960 with a degree in business from Seton Hall University, with which he started his career in the emerging technology industry first as a systems manager for Olivetti of America, then as sales manager of Docutel Corporation. In 1984, Mr. Shannon moved from Bernardsville, New Jersey to Atlanta, Georgia with his family to cofound the pioneering Online Financial Corporation with his good friend, the late Jack Wells. The innovative programs written by Mr. Wells and sold by Mr. Shannon are still used in banks in nearly all of the fifty states today. Mr. Shannon never fully retired. After selling his company in 1992, he embarked upon ventures that took him all over the world, in the service of family, neighbor, and God. Mr. Shannon was an ardent believer in education. He acted on Seton Hall University's Board of Regents, during which time he established the Philip and Mary Shannon Foundation, providing multiple student scholarships and presenting the Philip and Mary Shannon Speaker Series in partnership with Seton Hall's School of Diplomacy and International Relations. From 2001 to 2004, the speaker series featured New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman; presidential historians Michael Beschloss, Robert Caro, Doris Kearns Goodwin, and David McCollough, and former president of the Soviet Union and Nobel Prize winner Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Shannon's favorite pastime was boating with family and friends, most recently in the Florida Keys. A resident of Summerland Key, he was a member of the advisory board of Mote Marine Laboratory and founder of the grassroots, activist planning group, Citizens Not Serfs. This most recent campaign, on which he was working at the time of his death, advocates for the environmental preservation of the Florida Keys. Mr. Shannon was an active parishioner of The Church of Good Shepherd, Cumming, Georgia, and St. Peter, Big Pine Key, Florida. Loving survivors include his wife of 46 years, Mary Jean McMahon, Cumming, Georgia. In addition, he is survived by his son David, daughter-in-law Julie, granddaughters Audrey and Lily, Milton, Georgia; son Liam, daughter-in-law Laura, granddaughters Abigail, Olivia, and Fiona, Atlanta, Georgia; son Eamon, daughter-in-law Jennifer, grandson Finn, Honolulu, Hawaii; and daughter Brettany, Los Angeles, California. He is also survived by sister Rita, North Arlington, New Jersey. Family will receive friends 6:00 to 8:00pm Tuesday at the McDonald & Son Funeral Home & Crematory in Cumming. Please refer to mcdonaldandson.com and stpeterchanel.org for directions. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Catholic Relief Services at crs.org.

Damon Winter had finished his photo session with Fabienne Jean, a young dancer in Haiti whose lower right leg was amputated in the aftermath of the 2010 earthquake. The Brooklyn duo Blondes makes shimmering electronic music, but the members Zach Steinman and Sam Haar used to be more interested in guitars than synths. "In college we were into Gang of Four and Television," Steinman said, "but our tastes evolved through '70s disco and Kraut, and eventually '80s electronic." It's a trajectory that is evident in the sparse vocal samples and economical beats on their well received debut EP, "Touched." The pair's creative adventurousness also spilled over into a recent photo shoot for The Moment, for which Steinman and Haar were fittingly dressed in clothes by White Mountaineering, a Japanese label that mixes up American and avant-garde references with the same abandon as Blondes' experimenting on their synths. (Yosuke Aizawa, the White Mountaineering designer, honed his chops assisting Junya Watanabe, one of the iconoclasts of Japanese fashion.) "I've definitely never worn a kilt before," Haar said of his outfit. Luckily, in music as in life, Haar and his partner in crime are not afraid of change.

Traveling in winter comes with a particular packing challenge: namely, what to do with the coat? MaxMara's solution is the Cube, a reversible, convertible, collapsible Siberian goose-down puffer. Should the destination require no more than a bathing suit, the jacket folds up into its own little zippered tote. Or for cold-climate options, the Cube can be restyled with interchangeable hood trims and cuffs (in fabrics like linen and suede) or shortened with the help of hidden buttons. While the winter collection stuck to city-friendly black, the spring line, in stores now, comes in four styles and eight slope-worthy colors, from pink to orange. Prices range from $750 for a vest to $4,350 for a fur-lined coat; extra cuffs and trimmings are $175 to $475. At MaxMara, 813 Madison Avenue; (212) 879-6100.

The daily patrons of 0fr (pronounced "oh-eff-eehrrr"), a family-run intello-chic bookshop in the Marais area of Paris, are a mixed bunch. "Our customers always vary," the owner Alexandre Thumerelle says. "We usually have locals - students from the fine arts Grande École across the street, designers, models and artists who live in the area. We have tourists, but the ones who come here are pas mal." Thumerelle, 39, opened his internationally eclectic store in 1995 with his younger sister, Marie. Since then, 0fr has become an indie destination spot for its assortment of vintage and newly released art books and cult fashion magazines. Small but busy, it doubles as a exhibition space for emerging artists (past artist inhabitants have included Will McBride and Mark Borthwick) as well as a publisher for Paris-centric publications (including "GuideParis," a yearly manual filled with local favorites). "People think Parisians are snobs, but 'GuideParis' and 0fr prove that we're not so bad. We don't mind newcomers ... most of the time." To celebrate its 15 years in existence, 0fr will be releasing a retrospective book in May. Showcasing all 160 of its publications, the book will include collaborations with other Parisian insiders, such as Purple magazine's Olivier Zahm and the designer Agnès B.

The Rum House was a shabby little piano bar off the lobby of the Edison Hotel on 47th Street west of Seventh Avenue, marvelous in its way as a place to stop in before a show for a whiskey sour. Irene Gandy, the legendary Broadway press agent, often held court in one corner. Tyros with musical-comedy in their blood sketched out bits in another. Always, tourists mooned. The bar was a tie to the Rialto of old - an adult-beverage version of the Polish Tea Room next door, where producers gathered to dream and scheme over tuna fish on rye, a scene out of Runyon, a simple place for a drink. And then, in the summer of 2010, after 37 years, it closed.

The Bagger reached her recently at her home in the Scottish countryside, in the midst of a snowstorm and dinner preparations (fish pie was on the menu), to talk about moviemaking, the director she loves but can't imagine working with (Martin Scorsese), her distance from Hollywood (asked if she was a member of the Academy, Ms. Swinton confessed she didn't know), and winning that Oscar. A cultural space that opened this fall was named for its seedy legacy. Back in the roaring '20s, Le Bal was a cabaret, dance club and "hôtel d'amour" (read: brothel). After World War II, the venue was converted into the largest PMU ("Pari mutuel urbain," a bar for betting on horses) in France. Vacated and abandoned by 1992, it was re-purchased by the city in 2006 and selected as the spot for a multipurpose art space that includes galleries, a bookstore and a cafe.

LAWRENCE--Samuel B.,a noted Central Florida businessman, avid art collector, renowned dog owner, and longtime supporter of Rollins College, Lake Highland Preparatory School, Florida Hospital and Holderness School, died at home on Sunday, January 2, 2011. Born in Russia on May 10, 1921, he and his late mother, Eunice Haiman Lichtenstein Haas, entered the United States in 1925. Raised in Connecticut, Washington State, New York and Philadelphia, Mr. Lawrence was introduced to Orlando in the late 1930s by his mother, who wintered there. Educated at George Washington High School and having served with distinction as a member of the United States Marine Corps. in World War II, Mr. Lawrence became a grower of shade tobacco in the Connecticut River Valley and served as a two-term representative in the Connecticut State Legislature. The novel "Parrish", written by his cousin Mildred Savage, was inspired by his life and was the basis for the movie of the same name, for which he served as technical advisor. In 1959, he and his former wife, the late Lois Becker Lawrence Odence, moved to Orlando with their two daughters. Mr. Lawrence invested at that time in the fledging Budget Rent A Car Company. Eventually, a major portion of Budget's corporate structure was moved to Orlando, and Mr. Lawrence, as executive vice president, oversaw its rapid growth into a worldwide corporation. When Budget was sold to Transamerica Corporation, he became an investor and executive with Major Realty, a prominent real estate development concern in Central Florida. A highly proficient hunter and an award-winning trapshooter, Mr. Lawrence was also a superb fly fisherman who owned a home in the Bitterroot Valley of Montana for many years. He was also a familiar figure around the marinas of Singer Island and Chubb Key, where he fished for sailfish with great success. Since 1968, Mr. Lawrence had been certified as an AKC multi-breed judge. He and his wife Marion, whom he married in 1970, were owners of numerous championship dogs, among them most notably the wire-haired fox terrier Lacey, winner of the 1992 Best in Show award at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Their Pembroke corgi Kevin was awarded first in the herding group at Westminster in 2006. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence assembled, during their marriage, an outstanding collection of American art. Many of their paintings and sculptures have been shown at Cornell Art Museum at Rollins and at the Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg. The Lawrences have made numerous gifts of art to the Cornell Museum. Other gifts to Rollins include the Samuel B. Lawrence Center and the Ruth duPont Terrace. Mr. Lawrence was named a CHIEF (Champion of Higher Education in Florida) by the presidents of the independent colleges and universities of Florida in 1993 and received an honorary doctor of letters degree from Rollins in 1995. He leaves his beloved wife of forty-one years, Marion Walters Lawrence; his two daughters, Barbara Alfond and her husband Theodore, and Ruth duPont and her husband Thomas; his step-daughters Kathleen Schumann, Debra Deluca and Diane Deluca; seven grandchildren and sixteen great-grandchildren. he, and his family, are very grateful to his loving and devoted caregivers Dorrie (Tiny) Dockrey, and Vitra (Cindy) Ferguson. A memorial service will be held at the Knowles Memorial Chapel at Rollins at 11:30 on Wednesday, January 5th. In lieu of flowers, Contributions in Mr. Lawrence's honor may be made to the Samuel B. Lawrence Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o President Lewis Duncan, Rollins College, Winter Park, FL 32789.

NATIONAL An article on Friday about political tensions over the regulation of greenhouse gas emissions by the federal Environmental Protection Agency misstated the amount of carbon dioxide emitted by the nation's energy sector in 2008 and 2009. It was about 5.8 billion metric tons in 2008, not 5,800 metric tons, and it was about 5.4 billion metric tons in 2009, not 5,400 metric tons. The article also misidentified the state in which a federal court declined last week to issue a restraining order blocking the enforcement of new federal emission rules in Texas. The court is in Louisiana, not Texas. And a picture caption misidentified the state in which the Allen S. King power plant is located. It is in Minnesota, in Oak Park Heights -- not in Wisconsin.

DOLGER--Jonathan. First a great editor, then a talented literary agent, an incomparable friend of almost 50 years, he was loyal, smart, observant, with a great sense of irony, funny and deeply kind. What adventures we shared when publishing was still a cottage industry and we were lucky enough to be young and a part of it. Thank you, Jane, for giving my treasured friend all those years of happiness. You have my love and my deepest sympathy. Helen Brann

His wit, warmth and brilliance will be missed. Funeral Services Tuesday at 10:00 at Plaza Funeral Home, 91st and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, we would appreciate a contribution to StoryCorps.org, his favorite charity.

O'CONNOR--Capt. Charles G. (Bud, Doc, Charley), age 93, passed away on December 30, 2010. Born in Brooklyn, NY he most recently resided in Hoboken. He went to sea to support his family in his teens and worked his way up from deck hand to captain. He saw convoy service in the darkest hours of WWII. Charles spent 12 years in Calcutta, India as Director General of South Asia and Persian Gulf operations for American Export Isbrandtsen Lines. Since retiring from the sea he has lived in Hoboken, NJ since 1975 where he indulged his lifelong passions for military and Irish history. Charles was a devoted brother and uncle and friend to hundreds of people around the globe. We will sorely miss his generosity, intelligence, wit and kindness. He is survived by his sisters Josephine Chopin and Sheila Coleman and many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Funeral Services were private. To send online condolences please visit: IntrocasoAngeloFH.com

CAIRO -- Egyptian authorities increased security around churches on Monday as sectarian tensions mounted after a bombing in the coastal city of Alexandria that killed 21 and wounded nearly 100 leaving a New Year's Mass. Egyptian news reports said the authorities want to forestall further unrest as the Coptic Christmas approaches on Friday. Police officers have been instructed to arrest people they regard as suspicious and to prevent crowds from gathering outside churches.

LOS ANGELES - ''I am now an attorney of record in the case.'' So said Martin Garbus, in a brief phone conversation after a closed-door hearing Monday in the child custody dispute between Mel Gibson and his former girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva. Mr. Gibson's lawyers had opposed a request by Mr. Garbus, who is from New York, to be allowed to represent Ms. Grigorieva in the Los Angeles County Superior Court case. They cited, among other things, his public remarks about the dispute during a November interview on one of Larry King's final televised interview shows for CNN. On the program, Ms. Grigorieva described how she had recorded Mr. Gibson's obscene rants to her because she feared he might kill her. Mr. Garbus, who appeared with her on the program, had said that Mr. Gibson did not want to pay any support for his daughter with Ms. Grigorieva. Before arguments began on Monday, Judge Marjorie S. Steinberg closed the courtroom to all but the parties and their lawyers. After saying that he was now officially an attorney in the case, Mr. Garbus declined further comment. Blair Berk, a lawyer for Mr. Gibson, also declined to comment. Ms. Grigorieva attended the Monday court session. Mr. Gibson, however, was not present during the brief public session before the closed proceedings.

O'HARE--Edward John, passed away at home on January 1, 2011. He was born in NYC in 1937 and moved to Atlanta in 1987. He married Katharine Cavanagh in 1961 and they have four children and four grandchildren. After attending Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, NY, Ed served in the US Army and achieved the rank of staff sergeant. Upon his return from Korea, he graduated from Saint John's University and worked in advertising at Foote, Cone & Belding and then Ogilvy & Mather. He spent many years at American Express in NYC before joining American Security Group/Assurant, where he retired as CEO in 2000. Ed loved to play golf and was a member of the Cherokee Town & Country Club. He also enjoyed birdwatching, cooking, hockey, puzzles, Scrabble and family vacations at the ocean. He was an active supporter of the Holy Spirit Preparatory School in Atlanta. He is missed by his family: his wife Katharine; children: Cartha, Jennifer, Edward Marcus (Liza) and Matthew; and grandchildren Kate, Edward Patrick, Andrew and Dylan. His large extended family includes siblings Edward Heiner (Joan), Eleanor Carr (Frank), John O'Hare (Linda) and Lorraine Moran (Dennis). He was pre-deceased by sister Rosemary Heiner. The family will welcome friends at Patterson's Funeral Home (Arlington location at 173 Allen Road, Sandy Springs; 404-851-9900) on Wednesday, January 5th from 5pm-8pm. The funeral mass will be at the Holy Spirit Catholic Church at 4465 Northside Drive, Atlanta on Thursday January 6th at 10:30am. Donations may be sent to Holy Spirit Preparatory School.
