BAER--Fernand B. Jr. October 10, 1935-December 28, 2010. We have lost an irreplaceable friend. Our hearts are shattered. Our cherished Tony was a gentleman, scholar, and the most devoted friend anyone could have. He gave without hesitation in ways that cannot be measured. No matter what, he was ever curious, vibrant, full of humor and eager to embrace life at its fullest. No matter what, he was compassionate, generous, and a lifesaver and buoy to any friend in need. No matter what, he never complained. Instead, he strode forth, with a smile on his face, ready to do good and bring joy. For Tony, every day was an opportunity to learn something new to add to his already impressive and vast store of knowledge. His was the gift of truly listening and selfless caring for others. A virtual one-man Google, one's inbox never stayed empty if he knew you needed to know whatever it was. How lucky were we to have him in our family. How painfully silent it is now that he is gone. We pray that he is at peace. He will forever be missed. All our Love, Catherine, Fred, Christopher and Freddie

LANGAN--Michael William (Bill) Age 55, died peacefully on December 31 at the Dana-Farber/Brigham & Women's Cancer Center after a courageous battle with leukemia. Just two months ago, Bill was honored with the prestigious Leadership Award by the International Superyacht Society (ISS), recognized by his peers for his outstanding contributions to the standards, prestige and character of the luxury yachting industry. Although he was unable to travel to accept the award in person, he was deeply moved by this tribute. Born in Greenwich, CT on June 9, 1955 to Dr. Michael Joseph and Kathleen Holman Langan, Bill competed in most of the major ocean sailing races around the world. Starting in the sport on Long Island Sound at age 10, he was proud to have participated in 20 consecutive Newport Bermuda Races, his first at age 15, and to eventually serve as the race's Technical Director. Bill graduated from Greenwich High School and Webb Institute with a BS in Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering. Following a student internship at Sparkman & Stephens, the New York-based yacht design and brokerage firm, he joined the design department there in 1978 as Chief Draftsman. Two years later, Olin Stephens named him Chief Designer, the position Olin himself held for 50 years. Bill's early work with S&S included project management of the 12-meter yacht Freedom that won the America's Cup race of 1980. In preparation for the 1987 America's Cup challenge, Bill was chosen as designer for the America II campaign sponsored by the New York Yacht Club. 1987 marked the last time 12-meter yachts would compete in the America's Cup, and with that change Bill decided to concentrate the firm's business on luxury sailing yachts over 75 feet. Over the course of 20 years with S&S, Bill was responsible for over 300 individual designs. In 1994, Bill participated in the expedition, headed by former United States Secretary of the Treasury William Simon, that navigated the icy conditions of the Northwest Passage from Alaska to Greenland. Bill redesigned, refitted and strengthened Simon's yacht, the 175-foot Itasca, to make Simon's dream journey a reality. In 1998, Bill fulfilled his own dream to found Langan Design Associates, Inc. of Newport, Rhode Island, and settled his family in Jamestown. With Bill at the helm, his firm completed over 40 designs, each unique, but all of them timeless in style, with attention to craftsmanship, advanced technology, and seaworthiness. His design vision was well received starting with his first design, the 130-foot ketch Victoria of Strathearn, that won design awards from both ShowBoats International and the ISS. Later designs include Eos, a 305-foot 3-masted schooner, the largest private sailing yacht in the world to date. Bill encouraged his wife to start her own firm, Candace Langan Interior Decoration, specializing in yacht interiors. Their most recent collaboration, Calliope, a 42-meter motor yacht, is featured in the December issue of Yacht International. Bill was a member of Conanicut Yacht Club in Jamestown, New York Yacht Club, and the Storm Trysail Club. He served as Chairman of the Cruising Club of America Technical Committee for over 12 years. Bill was devoted to his family. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Candace Register Langan, and two children, Tom and Annie of James- town, RI, his parents of Greenwich, CT, six siblings and their spouses: Meg Moore (John) of Reston, VA, Ellen Langan (Steve Krafchick) of Seattle, WA, Katie Langan Santee (Kevin) of Mamaroneck, NY, Betsy Dell (Roger) of Roseville, CA, Bob Langan (Margot) of Portland, OR, and Stephen Langan (Kathy) of Bedford, NH; his mother-in-law Anne Mickle Register of Chestertown, MD, brothers-in-law Croft Register (Pam) and Fred Register (Connie), and sixteen nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 8 at 2pm St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jamestown, where Bill and his family are members. Following the church service, there will be a reception at the Conanicut Yacht Club. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial gifts be given in Bill's name to The Jimmy Fund, the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, 10 Brookline Place West, Brookline, MA 02445-7226, or to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, Donor Services, P.O. Box 4072, Pittsfield, MA 01202.

BONILLA--Dr. Frank. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Dr. Frank Bonilla, Thomas Hunter Professor Emeritus, Hunter College. Dr. Bonilla taught in the Sociology and Political Science departments at The CUNY Graduate Center from 1973 to 1993. He was the founding Director of Hunter College's Center for Puerto Rican Studies, a position he held for twenty-one years. Dr. Bonilla was an accomplished scholar who published several books. He was a passionate community activist focused on the pursuit of social justice, racial equality and human rights. A dedicated educator, he generously shared his time, knowledge and wisdom with his students. We extend our deepest sympathy to the extended Bonilla family and friends. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

REINAUER--B. Franklin, age 79, died peacefully on Sunday, January 2, 2011 at Morristown Memorial Hospital, NJ. Born at home in Hawthorne, NJ to Bert and Lucy Reinauer he was raised in the Wortendyke section of Midland Park NJ. Franklin completed his B.S. in Business Administration at Lehigh University, Bethlehem, PA, class of 1953 where he was a member of Delta Tau Delta Fraternity. Upon graduation from college Franklin joined his brother Harold in the family business, established by his father in 1923: Reinauer Transportation Companies, based in Newark, NJ and Staten Island, NY. The family business comprised a fleet of tugboats and barges operating on the eastern seaboard of the United States. He remained an active principal in the company today, known as Reinauer Maritime Group based in New York and Boston, MA. Under his tenure Reinauer has grown from a fleet of 16 tugboats and barges to a multi-faceted marine service company comprised of 72 tugboats and barges, marine construction in New York and Boston Harbors and ship building operations-SENESCO in North Kingstown, RI. Franklin was an avid golfer and participant member at Ridgewood Country Club, Navisink Country Club, New York Athletic Club and Mid-Ocean Club, Bermuda. He raised his family in Wyckoff, NJ and, in later years, enjoyed his homes at the Jersey shore and Tampa, FL. Franklin is survived by his beloved Cissi McEneaney, his three children; Dean Allison Reinauer-Murray and husband Thomas of Sparta, NJ Christian Franklin of Sparta, NJ and Curtis Darrell of Quincy, MA and three grandchildren. Franklin was predeceased by his parents, his brother Harold in 1994 and the mother of his children. Visitation, Wednesday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm and Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm at Vander Plaat Funeral Home (www.vpfh.com), 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ. For further information, please visit the funeral home web site. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Lehigh University for Scholarships, Development Gifts Processing, 622 Broadhead Avenue, Bethlehem, PA 18015 (www.lehigh.edu) or Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, P.O. Box 1956 Morristown, NJ 07862-1956 (www.atlantichealth.org).

By defeating the St. Louis Rams Sunday night, the Seattle Seahawks qualified for the N.F.L. playoffs in spite of having lost nine games and won only seven. They are not, technically speaking, the first N.F.L. team to have reached the playoffs with a losing record: in its strike-shortened 1982 season, the league temporarily expanded its post-season to include 16 teams, and the Detroit Lions and Cleveland Browns each advanced with 4-5 records.

Ever the provocateur, Lady Gaga posted a picture of herself on her Web site, dancing with her blonde hair flying in the wind and wearing nothing but a ''Born This Way'' jacket. The image follows her first Twitter posting of 2011 in which she announced that her new single, ''Born This Way,'' will be available in stores on Feb. 13 and that the album of the same name will be for sale on May 23. The announcement should come as no surprise to Lady Gaga followers; she had already posted on Twitter a few samplings of the lyrics from the song: ''Don't hide yourself in regret, just love yourself and you're set. I'm on the right track baby, I was born this way.''

CAREY--James Raymond. James Raymond "Ray" Carey of Rutherford and Normandy Beach, NJ, died on Tuesday, December 28, 2010, at home in Cape May, NJ. He had just celebrated his 75th birthday on December 19th. He was the beloved husband of 52 years of Margot Nelson Carey, his "first wife", and the treasured father of Nelson Lorin Carey and his wife Grace of Cape May. Ray was born in Taylor, Pennsylvania, the son of the late James and Pearl Carey. He was the elder brother to Christine (Lou) Zigray, Joseph (Mary Ann) Carey and Jule (George) Steffen, and uncle to cherished nieces and nephews. Ray was an ardent supporter of his alma mater, Lafayette College '57 (Go Leopards!), and was a member of Delta Tau Delta fraternity. After graduation, he served his country in the United States Army and was honorably discharged at the rank of Captain. Ray worked for the Union Carbide Corp. for 36 years, retiring in 1993 as Director of Audits. He held many civic roles in Rutherford, his home for the last 52 years (when he wasn't reading at Normandy Beach, NJ) serving as a member of the Rutherford Borough Council, a board member of Parish Nursing, the first President of the Kipp Center and a dedicated supporter of the YMCA. For over 30 years, he was a board member of the Boiling Springs Savings Bank, retiring as Chairman this year. Ray was a loyal friend and neighbor and was honored to have been chosen as the 2007 recipient of the Lincoln Award by the Republican Club of Rutherford. He was a member of the Boiling Spring Lodge 152 F&AM, Royal Arch Masons, Fortnightly Club and the Upper Montclair Country Club. Ray's leadership of the Everyman's Bible Class and his membership as a parishioner and Elder of the First Presbyterian Church of Rutherford allowed him to express his devotion to God. Despite all of his many achievements, none meant more to Ray than his strong faith and loving family. If he had any disappointments in this life, Ray did not burden others with them, but instead kept striving to persevere and thereby demonstrate his confidence in God's love and protection. Ray's bravery in illness was a life lesson to all and his family will never forget the kindness, compassion and excellence of all of his medical care givers, our "A" Team. Donations to Leonia Summer Stage: www.leoniasummerstage.org c/o Dr. Frank D.Livelli, or the First Presbyterian Church of Rutherford Music Fund are appreciated, but a kindness done for one in need would also honor Ray's life. A memorial service is planned for a future date.

Believing that women are underrepresented on the walls of most art museums, Linda Lee Alter, a Philadelphia collector and artist, donated some 400 works by artists including Louise Bourgeois, Kiki Smith, Alice Neel, Nancy Spero and Louise Nevelson to the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. Ms. Alter, who started collecting in the 1980s, bought works dating from 1910 to the present in all media. There are paintings and sculptures, ceramics and photography as well as works on paper. ''My hope was to find a museum emphasizing inclusion and diversity, one working toward greater representation of art by women and artists of color in its permanent collection and where my collection would be enthusiastically welcomed because it embodied the institution's vision,'' she said in a statement released by the Academy.

The New York theater company Naked Angels, which develops new plays and had its first production on Broadway last year with the drama ''Next Fall,'' announced on Monday that Andy Donald would succeed Geoffrey Nauffts as artistic director in July. Mr. Donald, a theater director and producer, has been associate artistic director of Naked Angels since April 2009. Mr. Nauffts, an actor, director, and long-time company member of Naked Angels, became artistic director in September 2007 but soon found himself celebrated as a writer for ''Next Fall,'' his first play. The Naked Angels production of ''Next Fall'' had a critically acclaimed run Off Broadway in 2009, then transferred to Broadway the next year. While receiving strong reviews there as well as Tony Award nominations, including for best play, the production was not a commercial success and ran for about five months. Mr. Nauffts said in a statement that he planned to continue to write and direct for Naked Angels, and advise on artistic matters as a board member. Mr. Donald, the founding artistic director of the Charlie B. Theater Company in Los Angeles, said in the statement that he looked forward to bringing new writers and others into the company. Among the company's offerings this season is the world premiere of the play ''A Long and Happy Life,'' by Bekah Brunstetter, and another world premiere, ''Outside People,'' by Zayd Dohrn. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The crisp white two-piece suit that John Lennon wore on the cover of the 1969 Beatles record album ''Abbey Road'' sold at a Connecticut auction on New Year's Day for $46,000. The suit, which was made for Lennon by the French designer Ted Lapidus, was purchased by an anonymous bidder, according to Billboard.com. The sale took place at Braswell Galleries in Connecticut and it wasn't the only item of Lennon memorabilia on the block. Hank Gioiella of Darien, Conn. paid $5,500 for a rusted 1972 green Chrysler station wagon.

MOSCOW -- A couple of months ago one of Russia's elder statesmen set out on a paradoxical mission: to rehabilitate one of the most beloved figures in Russian history, Tolstoy. This would have seemed unnecessary in 2010, a century after the author's death. But last year Russians wrestled over Tolstoy much as they did when he was alive. Intellectuals accused the Russian Orthodox Church of blacklisting a national hero. The church accused Tolstoy of helping speed the rise of the Bolsheviks. The melodrama of his last days, when he fled his family estate to take up the life of an ascetic, was revived in all its pulpy detail, like some kind of early-stage reality television.

That 62-page cabbies' manual could soon be seeing a few more changes. The Taxi and Limousine Commission has already earned international interest in its plan to modify the once-little-known cabby dress code, ending a specific ban on '80s fashion staples like tube tops and cutoff shorts and adding language that requires drivers to ''present a professional appearance.''

HANSEN--Edward A.,a resident of Palm Beach, Florida, died December 31st, 15 days before his 80th birthday. He was a graduate of Northwestern University and the University of Michigan Law School. After two years of Army service, which included a tour of duty in Korea, he joined the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel. He was a leading corporate partner who helped the firm define and distinguish its corporate and securities practice. Among the many matters on which he led were the establishment of two prominent insurance companies, ACE Limited in 1985 and XL Group plc in 1986, for clients Marsh & McLennan and J.P. Morgan. He retired in 1991. Mr. Hansen, while living in New York, was a Trustee of the Village of Tuxedo Park, and on the Board and an officer of the Metropolitan Opera Club. For many years Mr. Hansen also served on the Board of Overseers for the Hood Museum at Dartmouth College. He was a former resident of Aspen, CO, where he served on the boards of Aspen Public Radio, Aspen Santa Fe Ballet, and National Council of the Aspen Music Festival. Mr. Hansen moved to Palm Beach in 2007. In addition to his wife, Julia, he is survived by a daughter, Victoria, a son Christopher, grandsons Nicholas and Christopher, and a brother, Donald. A memorial service will take place at 4pm Wednesday, January 5th at St. Bartholomew's Church in NYC. A celebration will take place in Palm Beach in February and in Aspen this summer. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Aspen Theater Masters, PO Box 899, Aspen, CO 81612 or the Hansen Exhibitions/Acquisitions Fund at the Hood Museum at Dartmouth College, Hanover NH 03755.

WILLIAMSON--Marshall. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Marshall Williamson, a member of the vocal arts, collaborative piano, and graduate faculties of the School since 1978. An artist of extraordinary taste and sensitivity, Marshall worked with some of the great singers of the twentieth century. As a teacher, he was deeply respected by students and colleagues alike for his gentle approach to teaching and his great depth of knowledge in all areas of the vocal arts. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean

The most significant development in mergers and acquisitions in 2010 may be not what actually happened but what deal makers think happened - a return of confidence. That sometimes fickle state of mind encouraged the first annual gain in deal-making worldwide since the financial crisis. Global dollar volume in announced mergers and acquisitions rose 23.1 percent in 2010, to $2.4 trillion, according to Thomson Reuters data. In the United States, merger volume rose 14.2 percent, to $822 billion.

KATZEN--Philip, on January 1, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Lila, loving father of Denize Katzen and Hal (Anita) Katzen, brother of Lillian Fish, cherished grandfather of Donna and Matthew Katzen, dear companion of Kathleen Culver. Services Tuesday 2pm at Trinity Cemetery, 770 Riverside Dr., NYC.

Broadway did smashing business during the week of the New Year's holiday in spite of inconveniences related to the blizzard cleanup, with 16 musicals and one play (''The Merchant of Venice'') each drawing more than $1 million and contributing to a total take of $35 million, according to the Broadway League, the theater trade group that publishes weekly grosses every Monday. That $35 million represents a sizable increase over the $28.1 million for the comparable week in 2009. The musical ''Wicked'' set a record for the highest-grossing show in Broadway history, collecting $2,228,235 for the standard eight performances, helped in large part by premium ticket prices topping out at $300. ''The Lion King'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera'' also set box-office records at their theaters; ''The Lion King'' nearly passed $2 million for the first time on Broadway as well, collecting $1,993,370. The new musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' which is still in previews, also had an exceptional week at the box office, grossing $1.88 million - a close third to ''The Lion King.'' (Both shows have the same director, Julie Taymor.)

8:30 P.M. (Showtime) CAIRO TIME (2009) In this film by Ruba Nadda, Patricia Clarkson plays Juliette, a magazine writer on her first trip to Egypt, and Alexander Siddig, above with Ms. Clarkson, is Tareq, a local resident who offers to show her the views she has promised to save for her husband, a United Nations official delayed in Gaza. ''What gives this delicate, decorous movie its distinctive throb of melancholy sensuality is less the humdrum possibility of adultery than the intimation of a three-way entanglement involving the man, the woman and Cairo,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The film itself is perhaps a bit too cautious, preferring diffidence and indirection to overt emotion,'' he added. Still, ''the time does pass agreeably enough, and if 'Cairo Time' does not amount to much, it does evoke a wistful state of feeling and a complicated city with enough skill and sensitivity that you wish it had dared more.'' In ''Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work'' (2010), at 10, Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg ''tagged along with their subject, racking up miles and yowzah moments in her relentless pursuit of fame, money, attention, love, kicks, masochistic thrills or whatever it is that makes Ms. Rivers, née Joan Alexandra Molinsky, run,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times. They begin by moving in close to Ms. Rivers's 77-year-old, cosmetically altered face -- without makeup. ''To their credit, the filmmakers don't try to make her look good, and while they omit some of her uglier routines, they don't (perhaps can't) ask you to love her,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''That's a wise move. Ms. Rivers may be a comic genius, but she's easier to admire from the distance of a movie seat and perhaps across the passage of time.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER This Season 11 premiere pits Bob Harper and Jillian Michaels against two mystery trainers as each of the 11 two-member teams is given the choice to go with the unknown and receive four weeks of immunity -- or take the tried and true (that would be Mr. Harper and Ms. Michaels, who has announced that this round will be her last) and risk going home after a week. The contestants include Rulon Gardner, an Olympic gold medal wrestler; Don and Dan Evans, identical twin police officers who started gaining weight when they joined the force; Sarah Nitta, who has lost pregnancies because of her weight; and Arthur Wornum, this installment's heaviest contestant, weighing in at 507 pounds.

BLAU--Frances Suchman of New York and Florda, age 97, died January 2, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Blau. Last survivor of her five dear siblings. Remembered with love by her son, Lawrence, daughter-in-law Judith Blau, grandmother of Laura and Jonathan Paul, Richard and Arleen Blau, great-grandmother of Joseph Blau, Ethan and Cassie Paul. Private family funeral. Contributions to American Heart Association.
SPATZ--Natalie, January 4, 1908 - June 6, 2000. Beloved, cherished, adored and treasured mother. Happy Birthday Mama. One lifetime with you was not enough. Allen, Kenneth and Diane

BAER--Fernand Ben Jr. ("Tony"). Born October 10, 1935, Tony Baer died at his home in New York City on Tuesday December 28, 2010. Raised in St. Paul Minnesota, he served in the U.S. Army and was national President of the Young Republicans under Dwight Eisenhower. After attending the University of Minnesota, he boarded a bus with eighteen dollars in his pocket and went to New York City where he would spend the rest of his life. His career in the investment industry spanned 50 years in association with firms such as Andresen & Co., Hambrecht and Quist, Unterberg & Towbin, and Allen & Company. He was one of the original venture capitalist investors in Cray Research and Data General and founded his own investment firms Baer & Co. in 1983 and the Wellesley Capital Group in 1998. Tony was an avid collector of the French artist SEM and was a member of many clubs around the world. He was also a sponsor of the opera, the ballet, and the theater of New York City. He is survived by his son Brandon, his sister Barbara, and his two grandchildren Natalie and Dylan. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday January 25th 5:30 to 7:30pm, at the University Club, One West 54th Street.

SIMON--Leonard. The Community Preservation Corporation (CPC) mourns the passing of our friend and former Board Chair, Leonard Simon. Len served as Chairman of CPC's Board of Directors in 2005 and 2006 and was on our Board from 1998-2009. Len's dedication to provide quality affordable housing will always be deeply appreciated and his guidance to our company and loyal friendship will forever carry a remarkable legacy. We send our deepest condolences to his family. Michael Lappin, President & CEO, The Community Preservation Corporation

Looking for value among a crop of players coming off injury, the Mets signed the left-hander Chris Capuano and the right-hander Taylor Buchholz to one-year contracts Monday. Igarashi is owed $1.75 million in 2011, so he may be able to clear waivers and return to the Mets as a nonroster player in spring training.

LOWRY--John G.,on January 1, 2011. Beloved friend of Nancy Teufel, Roger Jorgensen and Adela Lowe. Brother of Edward Lowry. Uncle of Richard Lowry. Died peacefully after 79 years. Funeral Private. M.J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 718-788-2255.

Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanistat Southern Methodist University,is studying fossils of ancient plantand animal life in the Mush Valleyof Ethiopia. She is posting atnytimes.com/scientistatwork.Mush Valley is only about 160 ki-lometers northeast of the moderncapital city, Addis Ababa, but itfeels as though it could be a thou-sand miles away.What reallytakes me away from it all are therocks and fossils exposed by andalongside the Mush River. Theyprovide us an exciting opportuni-ty to document life, climate, land-scape and atmosphere 22 millionyears ago. As we excavate blocksof fine-grained sediment -- pri-marily shale -- looking for cluesto the past, the pivotal roleplayed by that ancient time peri-od is always on our mind.The Mush Valley preservesplants and animals from a timesoon after a land connection wasestablished between Afro-Arabiaand Eurasia -- a land connectionthat marked the end of Africa'sisland status and that was usedby animals to migrate between the two previously separated land masses. By looking at thefossil record from that period oftime -- before the Red Sea wasformed -- we can gain a clearerview of which species survivedthis great migration and whichdid not.Circumstantial evidence ispointing toward the influx of in-vaders as deadly competitors re-sponsible for the demise of theancient African mammalian fam-ilies, including Arsinoitheres (anextinct rhinoceroslike mammal), some elephant families and somerelatives of living hyraxes.We have already found somemammal bones at Mush -- as yetunidentifiable -- in addition toamazing fossil frogs with softbody parts preserved. We hope tofind more! And we wonder: Willany of the extinct forms beamong them, or will the faunahave a modern aspect?

RAND--Mary Frances, 80, of New York and Southampton, died at home on December 31, 2010 following a long illness. Born and raised in St. Louis, Missouri. Mary Frances was the daughter of Edgar Eugene Rand and Sarah Frances Moore Rand Ewald, sister of Jeanette Hale Rand Mitchell and Helen Octavia Rand and aunt of Harley Rand Mitchell, all of whom predeceased her. She is survived by her niece, Leslie Mitchell McKinney, of St. Louis. Educated at Mary Institute, Finch College and The Art Students League, Mary Frances was a gifted amateur painter, an avid tennis player, a bridge aficionado and long-time member of the Colony Club, the Meadow Club and the Colonial Dames. A loyal companion of many dogs and one great cat, she was rich in friends. Funeral service on Thursday, January 6, 2011, 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Humane Society of New York or to a charity of your choosing.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Wednesday 5-7pm. Burial private.

TAYLOR--Billy. The arts world lost a great friend in Billy Taylor, a brilliant jazz pianist, educator, policy advisor and ardent spokesman for the arts. He was a vital part of Americans for the Arts for many years, delivering the Nancy Hanks Lecture on Arts and Public Policy in 1998, participating on our Artists Committee since its inception, volunteering generously as an arts advocacy spokesperson and serving as the honorary chair of the Arts and Business Council for more than three decades. The nation has lost a true arts advocate, and the board and staff of Americans for the Arts deeply mourn his loss.

President James Buchanan's critics rightly condemned him during the secession crisis of 1860-'61 - but they did so for exactly the wrong reason. The naysayers blasted the president for passiveness in the face of disunion, for failing promptly to reinforce endangered federal forts in the South. True, the president retreated from sending reinforcements - except for a few critical days around the New Year. At that moment, a sudden burst of irresponsible activism shrunk his record of passivity to comparative unimportance.

Because of certain commitments, it used to be difficult for my wife, Jackie, and me to travel much during the autumn, so we rarely got out of the country at the height of the game season. The record industry's traditional post-holiday doldrums were reflected in this week's Billboard album chart as sales of Christmas-related CDs dropped sharply and even nonholiday fare experienced a decline. Taylor Swift's "Speak Now" continued as No. 1, for the third week in a row, but its sales fell 72 percent, to 77,000, from the previous week. Sales of the records that had been holding down the No. 2 and 3 slots leading into Christmas, "The Gift" by Susan Boyle and the "Glee" cast's "Christmas Album," plunged more than 90 percent, dropping both of those CDs out of the Top 10.

O'HARE--Edward John, passed away at home on January 1, 2011. He was born in NYC in 1937 and moved to Atlanta in 1987. He married Katharine Cavanagh in 1961 and they have four children and four grandchildren. After attending Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, NY, Ed served in the US Army and achieved the rank of staff sergeant. Upon his return from Korea, he graduated from Saint John's University and worked in advertising at Foote, Cone & Belding and then Ogilvy & Mather. He spent many years at American Express in NYC before joining American Security Group/Assurant, where he retired as CEO in 2000. Ed loved to play golf and was a member of the Cherokee Town & Country Club. He also enjoyed birdwatching, cooking, hockey, puzzles, Scrabble and family vacations at the ocean. He was an active supporter of the Holy Spirit Preparatory School in Atlanta. He is missed by his family: his wife Katharine; children: Cartha, Jennifer, Edward Marcus (Liza) and Matthew; and grandchildren Kate, Edward Patrick, Andrew and Dylan. His large extended family includes siblings Edward Heiner (Joan), Eleanor Carr (Frank), John O'Hare (Linda) and Lorraine Moran (Dennis). He was pre-deceased by sister Rosemary Heiner. The family will welcome friends at Patterson's Funeral Home (Arlington location at 173 Allen Road, Sandy Springs; 404-851-9900) on Wednesday, January 5th from 5pm-8pm. The funeral mass will be at the Holy Spirit Catholic Church at 4465 Northside Drive, Atlanta on Thursday January 6th at 10:30am. Donations may be sent to Holy Spirit Preparatory School.

AMESTOYGabrielle, 108, died December 28, 2010 in New York. Born February 13, 1902, in the small Basque village of Macaye, France, Gabrielle grew up on the ancestral family farm. In May 1918, after the death of her father, her mother took the family to America on a military transport. They settled in Milltown, New Jersey, where Gabrielle worked in the Michelin factory, married, and had her daughter, Irene. Later, living in New York, she worked into her 80s as a nanny and then as a cook for private families, returning to the Basque Country almost every year into her 90s. Always full of life and fun, Gabrielle had close friends on both sides of the Atlantic. She is survived by her grandchildren, Bruce Williams, Linda Marlatt, Barry Williams, and Dennis Williams, all of the Allentown, Pennsylvania area, ten great-grandchildren, five great-great-grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews in the United States and France, including grandnieces Paulette Strauss and Suzanne Noguere in New York. She is predeceased by her daughter, Irene Williams, son-in-law Leonard Williams, and grandson Peter Williams. Funeral services will be in Macaye, where Gabrielle will be buried with her beloved brother Felix, who died in the Battle of the Ardennes.

THE ARTS An article last Wednesday about problems with the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' misstated the circumstances of an accident in rehearsals last fall in which a dancer suffered broken wrists during a flying stunt. He landed correctly, not incorrectly; others did not execute the stunt properly. The error also appeared on Dec. 4 in an article about problems with the production.

Steven Cohen is the new secretary to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, among his most powerful aides. So please don't confuse him with Steve Cohen, the Memphis congressman, or Steven A. Cohen the billionaire hedge fund manager. Or the two Steve Cohens who are experts on Israel often quoted in The New York Times and other newspapers - Steven M. Cohen at Hebrew Union College in New York and Stephen P. Cohen at the Institute for Middle East Peace and Development, also in New York. And though they have the same middle initial, the latter should not be mistaken for the Stephen P. Cohen who is an expert on South Asian politics at the Brookings Institution. And he should not be confused with Columbia University's Steven A. Cohen, who is director of its environmentally focused Earth Institute. Or New York University's Stephen F. Cohen, who is a professor of Russian studies and history.

BERLISS--Arthur D.,Jr. died peacefully on December 31, 2010 at age 96. He is survived by his wife, Suzanne; his son, Henry; his grandsons, Jeremy and Jeffrey, and his sister, Marian. His love for and devotion to Suzanne were extraordinary. Arthur graduated from The Fieldston School in 1932 and from Yale in 1936. When he was accepted by Harvard Law School but not by Yale Law School, he decided not to become a lawyer. He served in the US Navy with distinction in World War II. He earned a Silver Star in 1943 at age 29 due to his bravery at the time of the invasion of Sicily. He was in command of a ship close to the shore the night before the invasion that had been ordered to signal the location of the landing beach to the invading forces. He had a successful business career in the printing business that resulted in the sale by him and his partner of the Allen Hollander Company to Litton Industries when Arthur was in his mid-50's. In conjunction with Admiral Gene La Roque and other patriotic people, Arthur helped start and enlist substantial support for the Center for Defense Information in Washington, DC. Arthur loved golf and he served as a Board Member and President of Quaker Ridge Golf Club. He traveled extensively throughout his life. In 1975 he and all his family mourned the death of his daughter, Elizabeth. His grandsons, Jeremy and Jeffrey, born in 1976 and 1980 respectively, were always a great source of joy for Arthur and Suzanne. Arthur was buried on January 2, 2011 between his mother, Marie, and his daughter, Elizabeth. A memorial service will be scheduled. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to Doctors Without Borders, or such other charity that people who knew and loved Arthur choose.

Lindsay Pollock, a reporter for Bloomberg and the author of ''The Girl with the Gallery,'' about Edith Gregor Halpert, has been named editor in chief of Art in America. This 98-year-old magazine, which combines reporting and criticism, is owned by Brant Publications, whose chairman is the prominent art collector and former Andy Warhol buddy Peter Brant. (Brant Publications also owns Interview, the magazine that Warhol founded.) Ms. Pollock has frequently written about Mr. Brant, and he has apparently been impressed.

KANTOWITZ--Solomon, died peacefully on January 4, 2011 at the age of 97. A devoted husband for 59 years to his beloved Ruth (deceased). Loving father to Joyce (and Marvin) Hartstein, Barbara (and Michael) Kalvert. Adoring grandfather to Elise (and Rob) Kipness, Seth (and Rachel) Kalvert and Peter (and Lori Ruth) Kalvert. Loving great-grandfather to Justin, Ryan, Sasha and Owen. Beloved brother of Goldie Weinstein. Loved by his many nieces and nephews. We will all miss the family patriarch. Sol earned his B.S. and M.S. from CCNY. He was a pioneering educator in the New York City school system and was principal of East New York Vocational - Technical High School. His 40 year career began as a history teacher at Brooklyn Tech High School He later became the Academic Chairman at Maxwell Vocational High School and served with the Board of Examiners and as an adjunct professor at Pace University. "King Solomon" was truly a gentleman and a scholar. Funeral services Thursday 12noon Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd. at 76 Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

BROOKS--Charlotte Park, an abstract expressionist who painted under the name Charlotte Park, died peacefully on December 26, 2010 at the age of ninety-two at her home in East Hampton, New York. Ms. Park was born August 13, 1918 in Concord, MA. Her father was George Coolidge Park, Sr, who died in 1918 of pneumonia, and her mother was Maybel (nee Hawkes) Park. Her sole sibling was George Park, who predeceased her. In 1939, Ms. Park graduated from the Yale School of Fine Art in New Haven, Connecticut. During World War II, she volunteered at the Department of Federal Public Housing in Washington, DC and then worked for the Office of Strategic Services (OSS), which produced intelligence, analysis, and planning in support of overseas Allied military operations. She met the artist James Brooks through the OSS, and they moved to New York City in 1945 and later married in 1947. After moving to New York, the excitement of the abstract expressionist art scene captivated Ms. Park and Mr. Brooks, and they soon joined the ranks of its leading avant-garde members, while developing close friendships with the movement's pioneers like Jackson Pollock and Lee Krasner. Through their close friendship, Ms. Park and Mr. Brooks rented the front space of Mr. Pollock's old studio at 46 East 8th Street. In 1949, Mr. Brooks and Ms. Park joined the Pollocks and many other artists on Long Island, first in Montauk and then in The Springs, East Hampton. Ms. Park and Mr. Brooks physically moved their house on a barge from Montauk to its present location in The Springs. During the 1950s and early 1960s, Ms. Park took a unique approach to abstract expressionism, painting blocky, curving, or linear shapes with vibrant colors and dynamic brushstrokes. Ms. Park exhibited regularly during the 1950s at the Stable Gallery and Tanager Gallery in New York and was included in the Painting Annual of 1953 at Whitney Museum of American Art. Like many female abstract expressionists, however, curators, critics, and galleries often overlooked her work in favor of male artists, including her husband. The widespread belief that this was primarily a masculine artistic movement perpetuated this disregard. Although Ms. Park believed in Mr. Brooks' work and was happy to take a backseat in order to help his career, a series of recent gallery and museum exhibitions and critical praise is correcting this oversight. Museums such as Guild Hall in East Hampton and Parrish Museum in Southampton consistently include her paintings in group shows, which feature leading abstract expressionists or important Long Island artists. Spanierman Modern, Ms. Park's gallery in New York City, gave her a second solo exhibition in October 2010, and nearly all oils in the show have sold. Reviewing the Spanierman exhibition, Roberta Smith, an art critic of the New York Times, commented that "she is as good as several of the artists both men and women in the Museum of Modern Art's current tribute to the movement." James Brooks died on March 9, 1992. Ms. Park and Mr. Brooks did not have any children. A graveside ceremony is to be held at the Green River Cemetery, Accabonac Road, East Hampton, New York, on January 10, 2011 at 1pm.

The Critics' Choice column on Tuesday, about new CDs, including ''Basic Instinct'' by Ciara, misspelled another singer's name in some copies while comparing Ciara to her and other performers. She is Rihanna, not Rhianna.

BAER--Fernand B. Jr. October 10, 1935-December 28, 2010. We have lost an irreplaceable friend. Our hearts are shattered. Our cherished Tony was a gentleman, scholar, and the most devoted friend anyone could have. He gave without hesitation in ways that cannot be measured. No matter what, he was ever curious, vibrant, full of humor and eager to embrace life at its fullest. No matter what, he was compassionate, generous, and a lifesaver and buoy to any friend in need. No matter what, he never complained. Instead, he strode forth, with a smile on his face, ready to do good and bring joy. For Tony, every day was an opportunity to learn something new to add to his already impressive and vast store of knowledge. His was the gift of truly listening and selfless caring for others. A virtual one-man Google, one's inbox never stayed empty if he knew you needed to know whatever it was. How lucky were we to have him in our family. How painfully silent it is now that he is gone. We pray that he is at peace. He will forever be missed. All our Love, Catherine, Fred, Christopher and Freddie

Borders began holding talks with publishers on Tuesday, seeking to convert delayed payments into interest-bearing debt as part of a plan to refinance its debt, according to people briefed on the matter. Borders has been in talks with lenders, including GE Capital and Jefferies, to refinance its existing bank loans from a group led by Bank of America, these people said. Bank of America and GE Capital were two of the lenders that provided the company with as much as $970.5 million in financing through a revolving credit deal last year.

RUBIN--Joseph. It is with deep sadness that the partners and staff of Berdon LLP mourn the passing of our friend and former colleague Joseph Rubin on January 2nd. In his 35 years with the firm, Joe was respected for his insights and professionalism, and highly regarded by those of us who worked with him and learned from his example. Our fondest thoughts go out to Joe's wife Edith, his children Jonathan and Larry, and to all who loved him.

Milliseme A smart French establishment from the talented chef Laurent Manrique, spread out over the back of the second floor of the Carlton Hotel on Madison Avenue and 29th Street. It isn't easy to get to, precisely. There are staircases involved, an elevator if you like. But, holy cats, is there a beautiful, exciting brasserie up there, a restaurant devoted to the pleasures of the sea that manages to be both luxurious and humble, ambitious and rustic, all at once. The atmosphere is festive and urban, pleasant in the extreme. Waiters bustle this way and that in long aprons and black vests as Samy Kebbab, the restaurant's effusive and seemingly omnipresent maitre d'hôtel, rushes that way and this, managing the room as if it were a party -- a master of the hotel, in the truest sense. Eat, eat! SAM SIFTON

12:12 p.m. | Updated The deal-making failures of 2010 were awarded F's last week. With the turn of the year, it is a time for optimism. So I would like to award the A's, the top grades for deal makers who excelled in the past year. Government The Treasury Department's restructuring team, led by Jim Millstein, earns an A for its work on the American International Group. The team negotiated the largest corporate work-out in history involving repayment of a $60 billion Federal Reserve loan, $30 billion initial public offering of A.I.G.'s subsidiary AIA and the sale of Alico, another A.I.G. subsidiary, for $15.5 billion. The Treasury Department will end up owning more than 90 percent of A.I.G., a position to be sold in the coming years, and the government now stands the chance of breaking even on its investment. The Treasury Department executed best in class deal-making, all at a government salary.

Discovery Communications expects Oprah Winfrey's cable channel to achieve profitability in its first year. Discovery and Ms. Winfrey flipped the switch on OWN, short for the Oprah Winfrey Network, on New Year's Day. The new channel enjoyed heavy sampling among viewers over the weekend, though executives have cautioned that they expect a bumpy ratings ride in the beginning.

Roger Ebert announced Tuesday that he had chosen a young and relatively unknown Russian-born movie critic, Ignatiy Vishnevetsky, to serve as a host of his new movie-review program, ''Ebert Presents At the Movies,'' which will have its premiere Jan. 21 on public television stations around the country. Mr. Vishnevetsky, 24, is a contributor to The Chicago Reader and a critic and essayist for MUBI.com, a new Web site that operates as a kind of screening room and social networking forum for movie lovers. He will host the show with Christy Lemire, the film critic for The Associated Press.

9 P.M. (13) DON PASQUALE A new season of ''Great Performances at the Met'' begins with Otto Schenk's production of Donizetti's comic opera about an aging Don (John Del Carlo) who, frustrated that his nephew Ernesto (Matthew Polenzani) insists on marrying his beloved, the penniless Norina (Anna Netrebko, above), instead of taking a suitable wife, decides to cut off his inheritance by getting married himself. Mariusz Kwiecien plays the duplicitous Dr. Malatesta; James Levine conducts. Reviewing the production in The New York Times in November, Vivien Schweitzer wrote, ''Ms. Netrebko offered a vivid portrait of Norina, her fluid voice lustrous as she navigated the bel canto hurdles in a performance that was both physically energetic and vocally rich.'' Her transition to the vixen ''Sofronia,'' the Don's new wife, Ms. Schweitzer added, ''was complete as she flounced down the stairs in hot-pink tights, tiara and velvet gown, flustering the hapless Don by her sudden metamorphosis from timid to tyrannical.'' 1:30 P.M. (13) NEW YORK NOW SPECIAL EDITION: 2011 STATE OF THE STATE ADDRESS Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will detail his plans for the year, including spending cuts and modifications to government agencies.

KORN--Seymour, born September 3, 1920, died at home on December 31, 2010. Devoted husband of Shirley (died March 9, 2004). Adored son of Morris and Harriet Korn. Loving father of Rita and Bill Korn. Foodie, traveler, aesthete, enthusiast. Receiving at 180 East End Ave., 3H, January 8, 4-6pm.

Two weeks ago, the ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' performer Christopher Tierney was on morphine at Bellevue Hospital Center and wondering, in moments of clarity, whether it would take months or years to recover after falling more than 20 feet at the Dec. 20 performance. Only one week ago Mr. Tierney left intensive care for Manhattan's Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine. But on Tuesday, the long-locked, muscular performer was bounding around the set of ABC's ''Good Morning, America'' and smiling for photos by onlookers - the only visible evidence of his serious injuries being a torso brace covered with stencil images of Spider-Man. Mr. Tierney, 31, is happily working with the producers of ''Spider-Man'' in what politicians refer to as changing the narrative: Finding a way to turn a bad-news story to their advantage, or at least finding a dramatic way to change the subject. In this case, the storyline has shifted from safety concerns at ''Spider-Man'' - how many stagehands does it take to put Peter Parker in a harness? - to the high spiritedness of Mr. Tierney, his refreshing refusal to consider any sort of legal action, and his dream of returning as one of several actors and dancers who play the masked Spider-Man during stunt sequences.

Mary Frances was the daughter of Edgar Eugene Rand and Sarah Frances Moore Rand Ewald, sister of Jeanette Hale Rand Mitchell and Helen Octavia Rand and aunt of Harley Rand Mitchell, all of whom predeceased her. A loyal companion of many dogs and one great cat, she was rich in friends. Funeral service on Thursday, January 6, 2011, 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Humane Society of New York or to a charity of your choosing.

BUSINESS DAY The Your Money column on Saturday, about health incentives in the workplace, referred imprecisely to a provision of the new federal health law. The law allows employers to offer rewards to employees of up to 30 percent of the total cost of health insurance (or up to 50 percent in some circumstances); 30 percent is not the minimum amount of rewards allowed.

She was 86. The cause was lung cancer, a spokesman said.

ODEN--Lowell Patrick Died on December 30, 2010, at the age of 68, in his home in Bronxville, NY. The cause of death was complications from pneumonia after a valiant struggle with a long-term illness. A Texas native, Pat moved to New York in 1970 and over a 35-year career became one of the nation's leaders in the development of the health care tax-exempt bond market, and a trusted advisor to the health care industry. His clients included a nationwide spectrum of health care providers. After receiving his MBA degree from Texas Tech University, Pat went to work at White, Weld & Company in public finance. As a Managing Director of Credit Suisse First Boston, he developed, recruited, and managed one of Wall Street's most successful health care finance groups, several members of whom went on to become prominent leaders in health care and higher education, which serves as one of his many legacies. Upon retirement, Pat became a consultant and was also an Adjunct Professor at the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia. He was active in his community, serving as chairman of the Village of Bronxville Finance Committee from 1994-2004, as a member of the Lawrence Hospital board finance committee, the Bronxville School Foundation finance committee, and the Bronxville School District's strategic planning committee. Pat is survived by his wife of 37 years, Madeline Eckett Oden; their much loved and cherished children, Melissa and Patrick; his brother, Michael Oden of Austin, TX and sister Nanci Kerlin, of Atlanta, GA. Memorial services will be held on Friday, January 7 at 10am at the Church of St. Joseph, 15 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY. To honor Pat's professional legacy, the family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations in his memory be given to the Lowell Patrick Oden Executive-in-Residence in Health Organization Management which is being established at The Rawls College of Business at Texas Tech University. Donations should be directed to the Texas Tech Foundation and sent to Texas Tech University, Rawls College of Business, Box 42101, Lubbock, TX 79409.

MICHELS--Herman D.,was born in Weehawken, New Jersey, on October 16, 1927, to Herman C. and Grace E. Michels. The family moved to Teaneck, New Jersey, and the Judge graduated from Teaneck High School in June of 1945 and joined the United States Navy. He completed basic training at Camp Perry in Williamsburg, Virginia, and was assigned to the Admiral's staff aboard the heavy cruiser U.S.S. Fall River based in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. The Judge was honorably discharged from the Navy in July of 1946 and graduated from Muhlenberg College (A.B.) in 1950 and from Rutgers Law School (LL.B.) in 1953. While attending Rutgers Law School, he was a member of the Rutgers Law Review and was awarded the Milton M. Unger Memorial Award and the Municipal Corporation Law Prize. On graduation from the law school, he served as law clerk to the Honorable G. Dixon Speakman, Essex County Assignment Judge, until December 31, 1953. From January 1, 1954, he practiced law as an associate, and then from January 1, 1963, as a partner in the law firm of Toner, Crowley, Wolper & Vanderbilt and later Toner, Vanderbilt, Michels & Light in Newark, New Jersey. Thereafter, he practiced as senior partner in the law firm of Michels & Schwartz in Newark, New Jersey. Judge Michels was admitted to the practice of law in New Jersey as an attorney in 1953 and as counselor-at-law in 1955. He is also admitted to practice before the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey (1953), the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit (1956), and the United States Supreme Court in 1956. He was appointed to the Superior Court of New Jersey on February 1, 1972, by Governor William G. Cahill and was assigned to the Law Division, Superior Court, in Newark, New Jersey. He was then assigned to the Appellate Division on April 11, 1974, and reappointed as a Superior Court Judge on February 1, 1979 by Governor Brendan T. Byrne. He was appointed as Presiding Judge of the Appellate Division on September 8, 1980, and then as the Presiding Judge for Administration of the Appellate Division on April 3, 1985. He attended and completed the Appellate Judges Seminar conducted by the Institute of Judicial Administration for New York University School of Law and the Management Seminar conducted by the Institute of the National Center for State Courts. He also served as Chairman and lecturer of the New Jersey Judicial College and lecturer for the Institute for Continuing Legal Education. Judge Michels was a member of the Essex County, New Jersey and American Bar Associations, the American Judicature Society, the Maritime Law Association of the United States, and was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was a former President and member of the Executive Committee of the Council of Chief Judges of State Courts of Appeal. He served as Chair of the Public Access Subcommittee of the New Jersey Judiciary Information Systems Policy Committee (1996), the New Jersey Ethics Commission (Michels Commission) (1993), the Supreme Court Committee on Court Reporting (1991) and the New Jersey Supreme Court Judiciary Drug Abuse Study Group (1987). Judge Michels was currently counsel to the Gibbons law firm in Newark, working with the Firm's Appellate and Alternative Dispute Resolution practice groups. He served as an arbitrator, mediator and special discovery master. He attended and completed the mediation for professionals course conducted by the Center for Dispute Settlement in Washington D.C. and the advanced arbitration course conducted by the American Arbitration Association in New York, New York. He is a panel member of the CPR Institute for Dispute Resolution's New Jersey Panel of Distinguished Neutrals, the American Arbitration Association, and the ICC International Court of Arbitration (North America). He was certified by the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey as an arbitrator and mediator. He had served as an arbitrator and/or mediator in over 400 cases in the past 13 years. These included construction, contract, commercial insurance, reinsurance, employment, legal and medical malpractice, personal injury, corporate and partnership dissolutions and environment damage cases. He also served as an arbitrator in an international construction matter administered by the Singapore International Arbitration Association and as a court-appointed special discovery master in major environmental insurance coverage, partnership, business and insurance fraud matters. Judge Michels was an avid hunter, tennis player and gardener. He was a member of the Coral Beach and Tennis Club in Paget, Bermuda, and the Amwell Valley Conservancy in Amwell, New Jersey. He was a Vestryman and Junior and Senior Warden at Christ Church, Short Hills. He was a member of the Short Hills Club, serving on the Board of Governors, and as Vice President and General Counsel. He is survived by his wife, Ann (nee Harrison), of 55 years, and five children: Sarah of New York City; Stephen and his wife, Tracy, of Kirkland, Washington; Martha and her husband, Dr. Michael Levy, of Las Vegas, Nevada; Linda and her husband, Richard Carchia, of Short Hills, New Jersey, Christian, of Voorhees, New Jersey and 10 grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother, David, of New Milford, New Jersey. He was predeceased by his father and mother and a brother, Warren. The funeral service will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, January 8, 2011 at Christ Church, 66 Highland Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey. Services under the direction of Bradley Smith & Smith Funeral Home, 415 Morris Ave, Springfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Overlook Hospital Foundation at 36 Upper Overlook Road, P.O. Box 220, Summit, New Jersey 07902, or Christ Church, 66 Highland Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey 07078. For further information or to send the family a message of condolence, please go to: bradleyfuneralhomes.com

ANELLA 222 Franklin Street (Green Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn; (718) 389-8100, anellabrooklyn.com. An intimate little art house of a restaurant (above), with a narrow bar and dining room decorated in that nice urban variation on farmhouse chic that is common to restaurants in north Brooklyn. The chef is a talented fellow named Joseph Ogrodnek, who offers bread fresh-baked in a flower pot to start, followed by a tightly focused menu of simple, seasonally appropriate food. Mr. Ogrodnek is a skilled practitioner of the vegetable arts. Like Midas, who turned everything he touched into gold, he elevates the simplest greens and tubers into realms more celestial than those generally experienced in restaurants in Brooklyn where the entrees average around $25. Can Goldman Sachs, the profit-seeking missile of high finance, really make money by investing $450 million in Facebook, at a vertigo-inducing price that values the social-networking company at $50 billion? On first blush, the answer would appear to be no. After all, in May 2009, the company was valued at $10 billion. Last August, Facebook was valued at $27 billion and now it's $50 billion - for a company with a reported $2 billion in revenue and negligible profits. If General Electric, with 2010 revenue of around $150 billion, traded at a similar multiple of revenue, it would be worth $3.75 trillion instead of $200 billion. Facebook is now considered to be worth more than Time Warner, DuPont and Goldman's rival Morgan Stanley.

SCHEAR--Catherine Klaus, 69, passed away at her home in Berkeley, California, with her family by her side. Her death was due to a brain tumor. Catherine will be remembered as a fiercely devoted mother and grandmother, an accomplished woman of letters, a talented and humane psychotherapist, a dear friend to many. Catherine is survived by her husband, Richard Newman, her daughter and son-in-law, Stephanie and Eric Tilenius, her son and daughter-in-law, Joseph K. Schear and Antje Linck, and her two cherished grandsons, Niles and Liam Tilenius. Born in Toledo, Ohio on December 17, 1941, to Mark and Helen Klaus, Catherine earned four Master's degrees (speech therapy, Columbia; art history, UC Berkeley; art history, CUNY; psychotherapy, Wright Institute). She taught art history at several Bay Area colleges and universities and served on the board of the San Francisco Art Institute and the Society for Asian Art; she published articles on Ernst Kirchner, RB Kitaj, Peter Voulkos, among others. Catherine was extremely intelligent, a dynamic presence-gorgeous and stylish, graceful and brave, to the end.

Bloomsbury Auctions, the London company that bills itself as the world's leading auctioneer of rare books and manuscripts, opened a New York branch with great fanfare three years ago, but it appears to be struggling in an economy that has not been kind to book dealers. Several specialists in the New York office, which fills two floors on West 48th Street, have left for other companies, including Sotheby's, Bonhams and Doyle, and no Bloomsbury sales for 2011 are scheduled in New York. Rupert Powell, the company's deputy chairman, said in an interview that the branch was not closing. ''We're just having a strategic review about what we decide to do,'' he said, adding, ''I can't really give you any more clues.''

During the Tim Duncan era, the San Antonio Spurs have come to define the precious N.B.A. commodities of stability, continuity and internal comity. Most of their core players were drafted by the organization and, with the exception of Duncan and David Robinson (who played on the first two title teams), not with high picks. In a league dominated by a small number of franchises, most from the larger markets, the Spurs of South Texas have been conspicuous in their ability to contend over an extended period without glitz or hype.

Gitlin, a sociologist at Thomas Jefferson University. Dr. Gitlin has been appointed director of a new center on aging at Johns Hopkins University; she is not the newly appointed director of the Center on Aging and Health at Johns Hopkins, a separate entity.

PRAGUE -- It could be the plot of a Cold War thriller: a Russian spy working undercover as a prison psychologist seduces an attractive female army major, dubbed the Czech Mata Hari, who passes on state secrets from three senior generals. The spy flees the country. The generals resign in disgrace. But in what some here have called the worst espionage scandal in the Czech Republic since 1989, the Rakhardzho affair -- named for Robert Rakhardzho, a wily Russian spy -- appears to contain elements of both fact and fiction. Distinguishing the two is difficult, but the tale includes a subplot involving one of the largest nuclear power deals in Czech history, an intricate web of deceit and a cast of characters that has reached the highest levels of the army and government.

For all of the shows closing this month, several at a loss to their investors, Broadway had a financially robust 2010. Brand-name musicals like ''Wicked,'' ''The Lion King,'' ''Jersey Boys'' and ''The Addams Family'' sold enough premium-price tickets (on the order of $250 to $350) for 2010 to help set an overall record for Broadway's 40 theaters. Shows grossed a total of $1.037 billion in the 2010 calendar year compared with $1.004 billion in 2009, according to statistics compiled by the Broadway League, the trade group of theater owners and producers. Roughly 12.11 million people saw a Broadway show in 2010, while 11.95 million went in 2009.

BUTLER--Marian, died December 26, 2010, she was 94. Born in Binghamton, NY, Marian was the daughter of Charles and Ethel (nee) White Blakeslee. She graduated Vassar College with a Bachelor of Arts Degree and was a member of the Vassar Golf Team. During WWII, in Washington D.C., she volunteered as an ambulance driver for the Red Cross. Her husband, Arthur Leon Butler was on active duty in the European Theater and married Marian after the war. She inherited the Cambridge Business School, Inc. from her husband after his death in 1967. She later added the ESL (English as a second Language) Division. PAHLAVI--HIH Prince Ali Reza. Armao and Company mourns the sudden loss of our esteemed Vice Chairman and Counselor, His Imperial Highness Prince Ali Reza Pahlavi of Iran. Born in Tehran in 1966, He obtained a B.A. from Princeton University in 1984, a Masters Degree from Columbia in 1992 and attended Harvard University in pursuit of a Ph.D. in Ancient Iranian studies. Prince Ali Reza was an intelligent, sensitive, loyal, fearless and dedicated to His Family and friends. His counsel, wisdom and sense of humor will be profoundly missed and always cherished. Although He left Iran at the time of the Islamic uprising in 1979, His heart and soul were forever with His country and countrymen.

Ben Affleck and ''The Town'' grabbed one of 10 best-picture slots from the Producers Guild of America, which announced its nominees on Tuesday morning, possibly advancing the Boston drama's chances to make the big list at the Oscars. The remainder of the nominees were the expected names: ''The Social Network,''''Inception,''''Black Swan,''''True Grit,'' ''The Kids Are All Right,'' ''The Fighter,'' ''The King's Speech'' and ''Toy Story 3.'' Left off the feature list were indie wild cards like ''Winter's Bone'' and ''Blue Valentine,'' both of which have drawn praise for their performances. (The producers' guild does not nominate actors; its awards go only to the producers of each film.) ''Toy Story 3'' was also nominated as best animated film, alongside ''How to Train Your Dragon'' and ''Despicable Me.'' That there were only three films selected -- as opposed to five last year -- may be a sign; there is already fierce speculation about which animated films will draw favor with the academy, which can nominate up to five in that category but does not always do so. The documentary nominees, announced last month, are: ''Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer,'' ''Inside Job,'' ''The Tillman Story,'' ''Waiting for 'Superman,''' ''Earth Made of Glass'' and ''Smash His Camera.''

Antidepressants like Prozac and Paxil are widely used to treat depression, but a much less costly alternative called bright light therapy, in which a patient sits under an artificial light for a set period of time each day, is not. Light therapy is typically recommended for seasonal affective disorder, the "winter blues" brought on by shorter days and limited sun. Some psychiatrists prescribe it for this condition, often as a last resort when patients fail to respond to drugs.

Bloomberg will address the city live from the Blue Room at City Hall at 3 p.m. Thursday concerning a storm that could bury the city in up to five inches of snow on Friday. The mayor's briefing will be broadcast live on nyc.gov, NYC TV Channel 74 and NY1 News. One measure already taken is the suspension of alternate-side parking through Saturday, which will run the current streak to 16 days.

Another one of Oprah Winfrey's friends is joining her new cable channel. OWN, the channel that started up last weekend, said Thursday that Suze Orman (pictured) would create a show called "Money Class," featuring advice for people in financial straits.

Back in July I wrote about how to make better videos of your active vacations. I used a ContourHD camera to film rides along a twisty road on a motorcycle. The camera, which is the size of a compact LED flashlight, can stick just about anywhere to get some eye-grabbing high-definition shots. Just one problem. It has no viewfinder, so after reviewing my footage I often had to adjust the camera position and shoot all over again.
Bad memories, perhaps?

ERBIL, Iraq - On a recent trip to the Kurdistan region in the north of Iraq, duty required us to drive to a place here in its capital that we didn't know. My colleagues and I, all Iraqis, stopped by the first police officers we spotted, naturally enough, to ask for directions. We asked in Arabic, then I tried in English.

General Motors is free to explore a patented car-battery technology developed by Argonne National Laboratory, it was announced Thursday. But even with its freshly inked worldwide licensing agreement, don't expect G.M. to push aside LG Chem, the Korean battery manufacturer responsible for the battery cells installed in the Chevrolet Volt -- LG Chem already uses the Argonne technology.

An exhibition of the work of the photographer Ezra Stoller opens today at Yossi Milo Gallery. Stoller, who died in 2004 at age 89, was the foremost chronicler of Modernist architecture, using his large-format camera to record seminal 20th-century works like Mies van der Rohe's Seagram Building, Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater and Guggenheim Museum, and Eero Saarinen's TWA Terminal at Idlewild Airport (now Kennedy). The exhibition of gelatin silver prints includes not just images of these buildings but also of lesser-known midcentury works like the Starkey house in Duluth, Minn., by Marcel Breuer, and the International Style, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill-designed First National City Bank (now Citibank) branch, also at Kennedy - which still stands, albeit in a less pristine landscape than when Stoller trained his deep-focus lens on it. So influential was Stoller's approach, which captured a building's lines in sometimes abstract, often monumental compositions, that a project wasn't considered complete until it had been "Stollerized." The exhibition continues through Feb. 12.

This past weekend, Facebook deleted the page for The Leaky B@@b, a breast-feeding support group where thousands of women come to ask questions and trade answers. It was the latest in an ongoing series of skirmishes between Facebook and nursing mothers -- specifically those who have posted photos of their children breast-feeding.

Setting the tone for the 112th Congress - in which every House bill must cite the constitutional source of its authority - members of the House of Representatives began to read the United States Constitution aloud from the chamber's floor on  Thursday morning.
